SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 4; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
At Home With a Zebra Table And a Skeleton Chair

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
William McCartyCooper used two kinds of period furnishings in the interiors he designed -- conservative (for his clients) and eccentric (for himself). Among the exotic objects in his Los Angeles home were chairs carved in the shape of an elephant and a human skeleton, plus a table with stuffed zebra legs.
On Saturday, these witty, some might say weird, items will be auctioned, along with 300 other furnishings from the McCarty-Cooper estate, at Christie's in New York in a sale estimated to bring as much as $3 million. 
 During the 1960's, the Miami-born designer became one of the most prominent decorators in London. He was adopted in 1972 by his companion, Douglas Cooper, the art historian of the Cubist period whose widely exhibited art collection was inherited by McCarty-Cooper in 1984. In the late 1980's, McCarty-Cooper moved to Los Angeles, where he died last May at the age of 53.
The most-discussed item in Christie's sale is the Russian-made skeleton chair. "It's bizarre but amusing, a caricature of a human skeleton that must be uncomfortable to sit on," said James Parker, curator of European sculpture and decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Mr. Parker said he remembered the chair from a 1980 auction at Christie's in London, where McCarty-Cooper bought it for $36,300, because he had never seen another like it. The chair is now estimated to bring only between $10,000 and $15,000.
Many of the sale's estimates are much lower than the prices paid by McCarty-Cooper. "The chair is an oddity not everyone would want to buy," explained William J. Iselin, who heads New York sales of European furniture at the auction house. "Under the circumstances and in the current economic climate, I would much rather have a conservative estimate."
Peter Schaffer, one of the owners of A La Vieille Russie, Russian art dealers in New York, said he had seen only one other such skeleton chair, at the Hermitage's Ethnographic Museum in St. Petersburg.
According to Brett Vinovich, the former West Coast correspondent for Connoisseur magazine who was a friend of McCarty-Cooper, "Billy hung a cowboy hat on the skeleton chair and used it as a valet in the corner of his bedroom. He loved telling the story of why it was made. It seems that a titled Russian aristocrat had it carved as a wedding gift for his former lover when she married another man."
Actually, all that is known about the chair's history is contained in a three-line dedication, from one man to another, handwritten in Cyrillic on the webbing under the seat. It reads: "From Nikanor Ivanovich Cheshchev to Nickolay Ivanovich Kolemin, 1838."
Almost as curious are the four elephant chairs, among the heftiest bergeres Christie's has auctioned in many years. Each weighs more than 150 pounds and was carved from a single block of wood. When the decorator bought them in 1985 from Herve Aaron, who heads the New York galleries of Didier Aaron, the Paris-based French furniture dealers, he was told they were 19th-century chairs. Now the dealer thinks they may be from the 20th century.
Mr. Aaron said that McCarty-Cooper, who created French 18th-century interiors for Didier Aaron briefly in the late 1970's, had an eye for both the simplest and most elegant objects. One, a Jacques-Emile Ruhlmann bed with a sunburstlike headboard, is expected to fetch as much as $90,000. "The use of the tiger print on that bed against the striped headboard makes you think you are in the middle of a jungle," Mr. Aaron said.
The Ruhlmann headboard, which came from Didier Aaron, and most of the score of pieces McCarty-Cooper bought from Anthony De Lorenzo, a Madison Avenue dealer in Art Deco furniture, were of Makassar ebony, a striped red and black wood.
"If it wasn't Makassar," Mr. De Lorenzo said, "McCarty-Cooper had a problem with it."
After looking at the zebra-legged table in Christie's catalogue, Bruce M. Newman, a dealer in exotic furniture who owns the Newel Art Galleries in New York, said, "Welcome back to El Morocco," referring to the zebra-skin-decorated Manhattan nightclub that was popular in the 1930's and 1940's. "That table isn't 19th century, as Christie's catalogue says -- it's pure 1930's."
Christie's was unable to identify the maker of the table, Howland Ward Ltd., whose name was inscribed on a label on the table. But Mr. Newman recognized the name as that of a London taxidermist, in business from about 1905 or 1910 to the 1960's.
Mr. Iselin of Christie's said it is difficult to date one-of-a-kind objects. "The specific date of the zebra table and whether it be 1890, 1910 or 1930 is not that important," he said. "The value of the table lies not in its antiquity, but in its unusual design."
Although he had resisted buying the skeleton chair twice in the past, Mr. Newman said he might succumb this time. "It's an extraordinary object," he said, "and there are plenty of decadent people who may want it -- including me."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Minority Developers;
Enlarging the Ranks of Home Builders

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN the plumbing business, Leslie Levi Jr. made his mark long ago. His company has been in business in Brooklyn for 41 years.
For 27 years, Raleigh W. Hall has been in the home-improvement business in Jamaica, Queens. And for 19 years Andrew Velez has been plying the general contractor's trade from an office in downtown Manhattan. 
 Too long, these minority construction men felt, to be working only on other people's jobs. They would like to do their own new-construction projects as owner-developers -- conceiving the plan, getting the financing and approvals, hiring the architect, managing the construction, handling the sales, taking the risks, earning the profit. But they lacked the size and experience as developers to qualify for the financing needed to make this possible.
"We have always been able to get the $200,000-to-$300,000 job," said Mr. Levi, the 63-year-old founder of Livel Mechanical & Equipment Corporation, which is at 1110 President Street in Brooklyn. "But the number of jobs we've had over $1 million you could count on the fingers of one hand, and still have a few fingers left over."
An attempt to correct that situation for small minority-run contracting companies is being made by the New York City Housing Partnership, the business-led nonprofit development organization that has been an intermediary between New York City and private builders in the construction of moderate- to middle-income for-sale housing since 1983. It established a Neighborhood Builders Program in 1988 to work with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development to "bring minority contractors into the mainstream of the home-building industry," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the Housing Partnership.
Three years later, 10 percent of the Housing Partnership's newly built affordable units are being done through the Neighborhood Building Program. About 200 two-family houses have been completed or are nearing completion in the hands of five minority builders in the program's first "cycle." A second cycle with six builders is getting under way. Construction financing has come from major banks -- Chase, Dime Savings of New York, National Westminster and Chemical.
ONE dividend of the program is that in this time of recession it has provided work for companies that might otherwise have been forced out of business.
"It's terrible out there now," said Mr. Velez, describing the competition that has developed for construction work. He and other small contractors tell of having to bid against major companies for work that the large companies would have ignored a few years ago.
Mr. Velez built 34 two-family houses at 169th Street and Prospect Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx under the Partnership's program. "It came along at the right time," he said.
Another characteristic of these houses is that they tend to require a somewhat higher level of public subsidy to provide greater security for the lender. That leads to lower prices for the buyer and home-buying opportunities for a slightly lower income level of buyer. At one site in southeast Queens, the average income of two-family home buyers is expected to be about $25,000, said Ms. Wylde.
Results of the program are on view on Tompkins Avenue between Kosciusko and Pulaski Streets in Bedford-Stuyvesant, across the street from Mount Pisgah Baptist Church. There Mr. Levi has produced 19 two-family houses that sold for $139,000 to $142,500. Each buyers gets a renter in the upstairs apartment. Market rents range between $500 and $600 a month.
Since the actual cost of construction is about $220,000 a house, the public subsidy amounts to $80,000 a house (or $40,000 per unit). This is about $15,000 a unit greater than is usual in New York City's affordable-housing programs.
With his own crew, Mr. Levi built the foundations for full basements, the sidewalks and sewer and water-main connections, and the interior and underground plumbing and carpentry finishing. For the house itself he turned to the manufactured product of DeLuxe Homes of Pa., based in Berwick.
MANY of the other minority contractors are choosing a "stick-built" house rather than one built in a factory. But both products have found sales success. Construction financing for Mr. Levi's $4 million Tompkins Avenue project came from the Community Preservation Corporation; permanent loans to buyers came from Chase Manhattan Bank.
In the Jamaica section of Queens, Mr. Hall has sold 13 of the 14 two-family houses he built on two Linden Boulevard sites. His wife is the secretary-treasurer of the 27-year-old contracting firm. As in some other cases, the State of New York Mortgage Agency guaranteed a major fraction of his construction loan.
"If it hadn't been for this job I don't know whether we could have maintained our business this year," said Mr. Hall.
In the Bronx, Gerson Nieves, the 43-year-old president of Nidus Realty Corporation, completed 26 two-family houses under the Neighborhood Builders Program on East 155th Street between Melrose and Elton Avenues. He has been in the real-estate business for 17 years as a broker, appraiser, property manager, syndicator and rehabilitator of existing buildings.
In some cases the initial construction loan was made possible because a large creditworthy builder was ready to guarantee it. That role fell on more than one occasion to Fred Wilpon, co-owner of the New York Mets, chairman of Sterling Equities, one of the city's largest owner-builders, and chairman of the nonprofit development corporation that was set up to run the Neighborhood Builder Program.
Other veteran home builders have stood over the shoulders of minority companies as they did their first development project, ready to step in if matters went awry in construction or sales. Among these were W. Randy Lee, the Staten Island developer; the Hudson Companies of Brooklyn; Procida Construction of the Bronx and the Bluestone Organization of Queens.
THE ultimate beneficiaries are the home buyers themselves, who are purchasing a house for the first time. One of Mr. Levi's buyers was June Daniels, a school teacher who said she raised three children in "the projects" in Bedford-Stuyvesant and got tired of "living on the 16th floor."
"I was paying $600 a month in rent and it was going up," she said. She has been living in the new house with a relative as her renter since Christmas, she said. "It feels like home, really," she said. Her monthly costs are about the same as when she rented.
Sellers of new affordable homes are emphasizing the comparison with rental costs. The Hudson Companies, a major nonminority builder of affordable housing, is telling house shoppers at Sojourner Truth Homes, on DeKalb Avenue six blocks east of Mr. Levi's project, that they can get a two-family house for $160,000 and hold after-tax housing costs below $500 a month.
The actual figure is $487 a month, assuming the tenant pays $550 a month in rent, Hudson says. The buyer needs $14,800 for the purchase -- $8,000 as down payment and $6,800 in closing costs.
This is possible because 30-year mortgages can be obtained at 8.5 percent interest in the current market. The same house two years ago, when rates were 10.5 percent, would have cost $628 a month to carry. The drop of two percentage points in interest rates cuts $200 a month off debt payments.
The drop means that many more people can qualify for mortgages. The minimum income required for home buying has dropped by about $10,000 -- to $30,600 from $40,100 on the $160,000 house, for example -- said Alan R. Bell, a Hudson Companies partner. "We're selling briskly," Mr. Bell said.
As for the minority builders, they hope that one development will lead to others. Mr. Levi is in the predevelopment phase with 40 more houses in Brooklyn. The Tompkins Avenue houses, he said, "put us on the map."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leslie Levi Jr. outside the two-family houses he built in Brooklyn. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Talking: Taxes;
New Rules To Figure Deductions

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AS homeowners begin to prepare their 1991 tax returns they should take special note of new rules and forms if they have a home office, if they have an annual income of more than $100,000 or if they refinanced a mortgage last year.
Those who operate a home-based business or profession, for instance, will have to disclose far more when calculating allowable office expenses on a new form being tied to Schedule C. 
 The homeowner with an adjusted gross income in excess of $100,000 will face a change limiting the value of the time-honored deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes. And anyone who refinanced a home in 1991 to take advantage of bargain-level interest rates will discover that restrictions apply concerning the tax deductibility of costs associated with the refinancing.
Henry B. Holmes, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said the new form for home office deductions, No. 8829, is being introduced "because a lot of mistakes were being made."
But Paul Edwards of Santa Monica, Calif., co-author of "Working From Home," a book series on home offices, said the change was made because the number of taxpayers filing for home-office deductions rose from 6 million in 1980 to 22 million in 1990, making these deductions a more signficant source of lost revenues if inflated figures were being used.
Despite the added paperwork, Mr. Edwards said, it is more important than ever to take the deductions, since they are now less likely to trigger an audit. In the past, certain accountants had been reluctant to recommend claiming home-office deductions, suggesting they became "red flags" for an audit. "But with so many more people doing so, it's no longer a problem," Mr. Edwards said.
Moreover, he says the new form will make it even less profitable for the I.R.S. to single out these returns because there will be less opportunity for inflated estimates. Even renters working at home, he said, should find some advantages in filling out the new form.
Form 8829 requires homeowners to gather information they may never have needed before. But Julian Block, a tax attorney in Larchmont, N.Y., and author of "The Homeowner's Tax Guide" (Runzheimer, 1991), reminded taxpayers that this does not mean pre-existing rules have changed. To take any deductions, he said, the area or room must still have been used exclusively for business.
The only exceptions are areas used for storing inventory or if the business is home-based day care. In those instances, normal household activities like watching TV and dining can also take place in the rooms.
The new form will ask the taxpayer for precise calculations of the square footage used for business in relation to the square footage of the home, rather than simply the percentage used for business, as in the past. Day-care providers will have to allocate the percentage of time when the rooms are being used for business, in addition to the area.
The best way to calculate total square footage, say the experts, is to measure each room and add the figures. Total square footage may also be on file at the local tax assessor's office.
Robert D. Grossman Jr., a tax lawyer in Washington and former I.R.S. trial attorney, said that in an audit the I.R.S. might try to include unfinished areas like a basement or garage in the total square footage, since this would lower the relative percentage used for business. But since no definitive definitions exist, accountants recommend using the total area of the finished space.
Form 8829 will also require detailed reporting of the full amount being spent on mortgage interest, real estate taxes, insurance, repairs and utilities and may not permit certain deductions to be taken simply as a percentage of the whole, as in the past. Mr. Block said "you will have to figure it all out more carefully."
The form also asks for the calculations used in reaching the figure given for depreciation. This will require more precisely separating the value attributable to land from the dwelling, since land can never be depreciated. Mr. Grossman recommends getting a written estimate of land value from a local real estate agent. Another method is to allocate the same ratio as the one on the property tax bill -- say 1/3 or 1/4 of the total.
HAVING such documentation in your tax records, said Mr. Grossman, would provide confirmation, in an audit, of a rationale for the figure and "will look so much better than a wild guess."
Finally, Form 8829 requires calculations that will make it more difficult to avoid the limit on home office deductions that apply if certain minimum income levels have not been attained. But Mr. Block noted that any disqualified deductions can be added onto next year's expenses.
Homeowners with an adjusted gross income above $100,000 may find their deductions for mortgage interest and property reduced. Mr. Block provides as an example a tax return showing an adjusted gross income of $150,000. Adjusted gross income is the net figure after such things as contributions to a retirement account, alimony payments and qualified portions of the Social Security tax and health insurance premiums of the self-employed.
The example further assumes the taxpayer is itemizing the remaining deductions from adjusted gross income (which normally include mortgage interest, property and state or local income taxes) for an itemized total of $20,000. This amount must then be reduced by a sum equal to 3 percent of $50,000 (the amount over $100,00), which is $1,500, for a net itemized total of $18,500 ($20,000 less $1,500). This bites most deeply into mortgage interest and property taxes in that these items tend to dominate itemized deductions. A handful of deductions such as medical expenses are exempt from the reduction.
Anyone who refinanced a home during 1991 will find that points charges associated with refinancing will not be deductible right away. Rather, the deduction must be spread over the life of the loan. An exception is any points charges specifically associated with money being borrowed for renovations.
Lary S. Wolf, a tax attorney in Manhattan specializing in real estate, gave as an example a homeowner with an existing $80,000 loan who borrows $100,000 when refinancing to generate $20,000 extra for an updated kitchen. Only the points charges allocated to the $20,000 portion of the loan could be deducted immediately. No other expenses qualify. Payment of the points, he added, would also have had to be made from sources other than the money being borrowed.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Concert Opera Company Makes Debut

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
THIS doesn't seem like the most propitious time to launch a new opera company, given the state of the economy, but Connecticut Concert Opera is about to do precisely that, introducing a four-event premiere season at the Centennial Theater in Simsbury. "The economy is certainly a concern," said the president of the ensemble, John Wadhams, "but our fund-raising results to date have been most encouraging, and I believe we'll achieve our objective after the first performances.
"Connecticut knows a lot about opera, thanks to major companies in Hartford and Stamford, and visits to eastern Connecticut by Sarah Caldwell's company from Boston. What Connecticut Concert Opera will do is to present some of the favorites originally written for smaller casts and smaller houses. The 400-seat Centennial Theater is just such a magnificent small opera house, so the experience our audiences will have there is one of intimacy and involvement with the performers, along with a chance to hear some of the best singing in Connecticut." 
 The new company, which is affiliated with Hartford Camerata Conservatory, is under the artistic direction of Toby Hall. The 1992 season, eventually including works of Mozart, Puccini, Menotti and a "Sondheim and Hammerstein Spectacular," will open at 8:15 P.M. on Friday (and next Sunday afternoon at 2:15) with Rossini's sparkling comedy "Italiana in Algeria."
The principals, including Mary Fox, Wayne Rivera and Yu Ping, are all seasoned professionals and, as the company title suggests, the performances will be given concert style, accompanied by Mr. Hall at the piano and sung in the original language, with supertitles offering abstracts (rather than full translations) of the arias and ensembles.
For more information about the company or Rossini reservations, call 561-2670.
Fully staged productions with orchestra scheduled by the Shubert Opera Company in New Haven include next weekend's "Elisir d'Amore" by Donizetti. The Metropolitan Opera soprano Betsy Norden and the tenor James Caputo (a native of Guilford) share top billing, with performances scheduled at 8 P.M. on Friday and at 2 P.M. the following Sunday at the Palace Theater.
The Shubert Performing Arts Center is including a Wednesday 7 P.M. dress rehearsal of the opera in its student series, one of the most comprehensive cycles in the state especially designed for young audiences. There is no admission charge, but entrance is subject to seating availability. Call 624-1825 for more details, or reservations for the weekend performances.
"Notes in Mid-Winter" is the title of a free series of recitals being presented this month at the New Canaan Library. This afternoon at 2 the Trio Fervore plays Shostakovich, Beethoven and Smetana, while next Sunday the baritone Richard Lalli, joined by the pianist William Braun, sings compositions ranging from Schubert to William Bolcom, with some Irish folksongs and American parlor ballads as well (966-8133).
Another vocal enticement is part of the "Musical Masterworks" series at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, the noted artists being the mezzo-soprano Brenda Boozer and the pianist Charles Wadsworth. The program at 5 P.M. on Saturday includes the Habanera from Bizet's "Carmen" and Ravel's "Scheherazade" song cycle (434-7862).
On the symphonic scene, Saturday is the big night, with no less than six orchestras in performance, but the New Haven Symphony has Tuesday evening to itself: at 8 P.M. in Woolsey Hall its music director, Michael Palmer, will conduct Mozart's Symphony No. 29, the "Variaciones Concertantes" of Alberto Ginastera and, with the guest soloist Robert Roux, Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 (776-1444).
At 8 P.M. on Saturday the Eastern Connecticut Symphony will be at the Garde Arts Center in New London, where its music director, Paul Phillips, will be introducing Carolyn Kalhorn, winner of the orchestra's 32d annual young artist competition, in Brahms's Violin Concerto. Also on the program are favorite works of Beethoven, Tchaikovsky and Richard Strauss (443-2876).
At that same hour in First Church of Christ Congregational, the Farmingdale Valley Symphony under John Eells tackles some novelties -- including an assortment of early pieces for brass and Spohr's Nocturne for Winds, Brass and Percussion -- before arriving at the more familiar pleasures of Schubert's Symphony No. 5 (677-9570).
At the Greater Bridgeport Symphony concert, at 8:30 P.M. on Saturday in Klein Memorial Auditorium, the group's music director, Gustav Meier, will yield the center of musical attention to Ralph Votapek. The American pianist, who sprang to international attention 30 years ago as the gold medalist of the first Van Cliburn Competition, takes on the marathon challenge of performing three Concertos in a single evening: the first of Brahms and Prokofiev, plus Gershwin's Second Rhapsody (576-0263).
The New Haven Symphony will return to Woolsey Hall at 8 P.M. on Saturday for the centerpiece concert in its Mozart Festival. The occasion is actually quite festive: the Bicentennial marked Mozart's death, while Saturday's program anticipates the anniversary of his birth, Jan. 27, with the Overture to "Don Giovanni," the Symphony No. 39 and the Violin Concerto No. 5, the last featuring Sergiu Luca as guest soloist (776-1444).
For Orchestra New England under James Sinclair, a Concerto Fest will begin at 8 P.M. on Saturday at Battell Chapel in New Haven, with the group's concertmaster, Raphael Ryger, stepping forward to take the lead in Vivaldi's "Four Seasons," while the ensemble's principal cellist, Steven Thomas, is featured in the G-major Concerto of Luigi Boccherini (934-8863).
Finally, Skitch Henderson will be the guest conductor of the Waterbury Symphony in an 8:15 P.M. pops program at Kennedy Auditorium, spotlighting music of John Williams and other master contributors to "The Sound of Hollywood" (574-4283).

HEADLINE: In a Courthouse, Co-ops on the Block

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
ON most Fridays, usually around noon, a small knot of people gathers around a scuffed, steel-gray office table in the rotunda of the New York State Supreme Court Building on Foley Square for what has become a fast-booming sideshow to the region's depressed real estate market: co-op foreclosure auctions.
The auctions should not be confused with foreclosures on troubled co-op sponsors, those developers who have converted apartment buildings into co-ops and are now, because of the weakness of the market, drowning in debt. 
 Rather, these are auctions of single co-op apartments whose owners, for a variety of reasons, but often because of layoffs or a problem with personal finances, have fallen hopelessly behind in their mortgage payments.
"I am hearing stories that are just terrible," said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "There are individuals, sometimes parents with children, who are losing everything."
"It seems to be a hard time for sponsors and a hard time for individuals," added Harold A. Lubell, a Manhattan lawyer who is an adjunct professor of real estate at Fordham Law School.
There are about 550,000 co-op apartments in New York City, about 80,000 condominium units and 669,000 one-family houses, according to the city's Department of Finance. The national foreclosure rate on one-family homes and condominiums, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, based in Washington, is 0.98 percent, and has been steadily increasing since the beginning of 1990.
But no one knows how many co-op units have been foreclosed since the recession began putting middle-class New Yorkers out of work and cutting their incomes.
Foreclosures on co-ops, as opposed to those on condominiums or houses, are business transactions made under the Federal Uniform Commercial Code rather than a court proceeding and, as such, are not tallied by court clerks or bar associations.
A foreclosure on a co-op apartment does not involve real property or even a title exchange. Rather, it involves shares in the co-op corporation that owns the building where the defaulting apartment buyer lives. With the shares goes a proprietary lease on the buyer's apartment, which the buyer loses when he surrenders his shares to the lender. Loans on co-ops are known as "share loans" or "end loans," although they are generically referred to as mortgages.
"They don't get registered like a deed," Ms. Rothman explained.
While lenders and others familiar with the co-op scene differ on the number of foreclosures, all agree that the rate is high and that it is likely to grow as New York sinks deeper into recession.
Frank L. Truglio, a former senior advertising executive who in the mid-80's earned more than $100,000 a year, is one of the many New Yorkers whose co-op has been foreclosed on in recent years. Foreclosure was scheduled for last Friday on his one-bedroom co-op apartment, 8-F, at the Brevard, a 14-year-old tower at 245 East 54th Street on the corner of Second Avenue.
"I'm a product of the recession," Mr. Truglio said, explaining that his company eliminated his job in November 1990 and that he has been unable to make his monthly loan payments to Citibank since then. "I've been trying to get back into the business, but I am told that I am overqualified."
Seven years ago, Mr. Truglio, who is 48 years old, borrowed $100,000 and put down $57,500 of his own money for the co-op unit. Until November 1990, he had kept up his loan payments to the lender and monthly maintenance payments to the co-op. He still owes the bank $75,000, plus $10,126 in back maintenance payments and assessments. The monthly charges on the apartment are $900.
"The people in the building don't know what is going on, but the maintenance people do," he said. "It is very obvious to them what my condition is. When they come in to do some work, they see that I had to sell off my furniture, and now all I have left is a folding chair and a table."
Mr. Truglio, who is divorced, said he thinks often about whether he will become homeless. "It is very scary, very emotional," he said. "I'm all wound up; I've been in the hospital over the whole thing. Never having been fired or let go, you don't react as fast as you should."
He added that he has tried to sell his apartment, dropping the price to as low as $140,000. "It doesn't matter what the price," he said. "I wasn't getting any traffic."
"If the bank does auction it off," he added, "I'm not sure I know what I'm going to do."
FORECLOSURES can be initiated against co-op apartment shareholders for falling behind on either their loan or maintenance payments, which the bank must pay when the unit's owner falls into arrears. This responsibility for making past-due maintenance payments gives banks an added incentive to foreclose quickly.
Steven L. Einig, a lawyer who has handled thousands of co-op foreclosures in the last six years on behalf of several New York lenders, said that banks usually foreclose when an owner is behind 60 to 90 days on loan or maintenance payments. "An auction might take place four to eight weeks later," he said.
A petition of bankruptcy by an apartment owner, however, can forestall the process, as it did for Mr. Truglio. Depending on the bankruptcy code section under which the owner files for protection from creditors, the delay can be as short as a few weeks or for a longer period while a new payment plan is arranged with the bank.
The auction for Mr. Truglio's apartment was scheduled to be held in the rotunda of the Supreme Court Building on Centre Street, where -- by tradition, not because it is part of any judicial proceedings -- all Manhattan co-op auctions are held. (In Queens, tradition dictates that the auctions be held, rain or shine, on the outdoor steps of the Supreme Court building.)
"I have never seen as many co-op auctions as I see now," said Norman Goodman, the Clerk of the Supreme Court in Manhattan "On Fridays, there is always a crowd around the auctioneer out there."
The auctions, which are advertised in the newspapers, have little in common with the better-known auctions of one-family houses and condominiums. Indeed, those who arrive at co-op auctions generally are baffled by the process and tend to ask questions more than make bids.
"Aren't there supposed to be paddles?" asked Jonathan M. Silver, who stopped by the courthouse to watch a Friday auction this month and half-expected to find a Sotheby's or Christie's atmosphere.
BUT there are no paddles here. Or chairs, either. In fact, co-op unit auctions in New York City are about as casual as sidewalk three-card monte games.
"Fifty-one thousand, nine hundred and eighty and sixteen cents!" barked the auctioneer, William Mannion.
"Do we hear another bid?"
A small crowd stared blankly.
"Going once! Twice! Third and final call . . ."
"Sold to the Dime!" Mr. Mannion said, slamming his hand down on his briefcase. "Congratulations."
The Dime, of course, is the Dime Savings Bank.
Mr. Einig said that about 80 percent of all properties that are put up for auction attract only the initial bid of the bank.
"What is happening is that people are looking for the deal of the century and when they don't find it they walk out," he said.
Douglas Bourie and Charles Hansen, however, found what they feel is a bargain co-op at auction. For $1 over the opening bid of $57,750, they bought a five-room apartment at Hudson View Gardens, a co-op at 116 Pinehurst Avenue in Washington Heights.
"I think I've gotten a very good price," Mr. Bourie said.
"Exceedingly reasonable," said the first vice president of the building's co-op corporation, Dr. Edgar C. Hanks.
 Mr. Mannion said he almost didn't accept the bid because it was only $1 over the opening bid. "You could be here all day upping $1 bids," he said. "But in this case there didn't appear to be any other bidders. Usually, I go up in $100 increments."
Mr. Bourie's purchase was the only one by a bidder in the rotunda on Jan. 10. Three other units didn't sell and went back to the bank. The sale of a fourth, at 11 Riverside Drive, which had attracted considerable interest, was canceled at the last minute when the owner showed up with a bankruptcy petition. The opening bid would have been $195,000.
"I talk to the real estate officers every day, and they tell me that every day they get keys in the mail," Mr. Mannion said, referring to owners who give up on paying their loans and move out of their apartments. . "I do not think it is going to slow down at all. All my clients tell me their files are growing, and I don't see any letup."
ALSO surrrendering apartments to lenders are investors who bought occupied rent-regulated units in converted buildings in the hope that they could sell them at big profits after their tenants left. With prices weaker and the spread between regulated rents and maintenance widening, many investors are giving up.
The only statistical information available about share-loan foreclosures comes from a survey of legal notices of The New York Times from October 1989 to November 1990 by Gateway Community Restoration, a nonprofit developer in Sunnyside, Queens. That survey showed 3,728 foreclosures in the five boroughs, but there are no earlier or later data available for comparisons.
Antonia Dosik, executive director of Gateway, said that most co-op shareholders are defaulting because they cannot afford both the loans on their shares and the monthly maintenance charges, which cover their portion of the cost of the building's own mortgage as well as taxes, services and utilities. Because of the dearth of data about co-op loans, it is impossible to say whether they are falling into foreclosure at a faster rate or in a greater proportion than mortgages on condominiums and one-family homes.
Ken R. Enos, an assistant director of owned real estate with the Dime Savings Bank in Manhattan, which has been a major writer of share loans, said that the percentage that has fallen into foreclosure is no greater than the percentage of defaulted condominium and house mortgages.
Mr. Enos also said that the number of foreclosed share loans at the Dime appears to have peaked. "Ours have stabilized some," he said.
Other real estate professionals who watch foreclosures, however, believe co-ops may be taking a greater battering than banks are letting on.
"They are definitely up," said Dorit Breger, the publisher of Foreclosure Update, a newsletter in New York that collects foreclosure figures from the legal advertisments in eight New York City publications.

Einig, Dime Savings Bank lawyer; Charles Hansen and Douglas E. Bourie, successful bidders on apartment in Washington Heights. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Help for Home Buyers
 
Question: I am trying to buy a house in the city. I understand that there are programs to help first-time home buyers with mortgages. Is there a source for information on this kind of assistance? . . . Gurunath Pasumarty, Rego Park, Queens 

Answer: Yes. You might start with the State Mortgage Agency of New York. The agency, known as Sonny Mae, helps qualified low- and moderate-income families and individuals throughout the state to obtain low-cost mortgages.
The agency's regular mortgage program applies to one- to four-family homes and co-ops and condominiums. Currently, the down payments required range from 5 and 10 percent depending on the type of home being purchased. The current interest rate on 30-year mortgages is 8 percent. Sonny Mae mortgages are only for buyers who will occupy their homes.
A new Sonny Mae program is for first-time buyers of newly constructed homes. Among the requirements is that participants have household incomes of no more than 80 percent of the median income for their areas. There is also a ceiling on the purchase prices on homes but the required down payment can be as low as 2 percent in certain areas and the mortgage program will also provide $2,500 in closing costs.
You might also check with individual lenders, some of which provide assistance to first-time buyers.
More information on the loan programs can be obtained by calling the agency toll free at (800)382-HOME.
 
Right to a Lease
 
Question: I have shared a rent-stabilized apartment with a companion for almost 11 years. During this time I have occasionally asked that my named be added to the lease, but my requests have been denied. About five years ago, the building we live in was converted to a noneviction co-op. We stayed as renters.
In light of the Braschi decision, which granted domestic partners succession rights on leases, do I have any legal right to be added to the lease now? . . . Jack Rowen, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the rent-stabilization code that gives spouses the right to be added to leases does not extend to live-in companions as defined by the Braschi decision.
"The regulations were amended to accommodate Braschi, which pertains to succession rights," said Mr. D'Agosta, "but not the rules on adding spouses to leases."
Depending on the circumstances of your situation, Mr. D'Agosta said that you could be entitled to a renewal lease if your companion, the named tenant, leaves the apartment or dies.
The division's rent administration office is at Gertz Plaza, 93-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, N.Y. 11433
 
Replacing an Appliance
 
Question: I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment for many years. The kitchen appliances are worn out and the landlord is willing to replace them. I would like the replacements to be the best on the market. Must I accept the ones he buys or can I buy my own appliances? . . . Harold Freed, Manhattan
 
Answer: You can buy your own only with the landlord's permission. The laws that cover rent-regulated tenants give them the right to working kitchen appliances. But landlords can repair appliances or replace them with used ones. If your landlord buys new appliances he is under no obligation to buy the ones you would select. If the appliance he puts in is new, he can add 1/40 of the cost to the rent. Most landlords prefer to replace appliances themselves because of the financial advantage. The rent increase is permanent and becomes part of the base in determining future rent increases.
If your landlord allows you to buy your own appliances and you move out of your apartment, you would either have to leave them behind or arrange to have them replaced with appliances that are acceptable to him.

HEADLINE: Englewood Considers A Longer School Year

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
WHILE most discussion about a longer school day and year remains in the abstract, Englewood schools are on their way to making the concept a reality. This month the district convened a committee of community and school representatives to investigate whether to extend the school year to a minimum of 200 days.
As in most school districts in New Jersey, Englewood's public schools are currently in session 180 days. The proposal would also lengthen the school day to at least seven hours from six and a quarter hours. 
 "I think it's fairly likely that we will go to a longer school year," said Dr. Michael Passow, president of the Parent-Teacher Organization at Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood and a former school board member. "Englewood's board and now more and more of its faculty are seeing that we have the possibility to be an educational leader in this country with the restructuring of how we're teaching."
For some time, Englewood school administrators have advocated the idea of a year-round educational program. But unlike most school districts around the country that remain open all year, the district is not motivated by the desire to relieve overcrowding.
"The driving force behind all of this is achievement," said William Trepicchio, Englewood's assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction. "We feel that for what it is the students ought to know before they leave high school, the quality that has to be behind that requires them to have more time in school."
The notion of a longer school year for New Jersey public schools received renewed attention with the release of the Quality Education Commission report this month. The commission, appointed by Gov. Jim Florio a year ago to identify educational requirements for the state in the year 2000 and beyond, called for extending the school year to 220 days and lengthening the school day itself. Such a move is estimated to cost up to $2 billion a year.
Supporters of the recommendation point out that the United States has one of the shortest school years in the industrialized world, and they argue that there must be a connection between American students' poor performance on international educational assessment tests and the amount of time they spend in school. The school year in Japan, for example, is more than 240 days long.
Americans seem to be increasingly in agreement. A Gallup poll last fall indicated that, for the first time, a majority of those sampled favored a longer school year.
 
Cost of Air-Conditioning Is a Factor
Englewood school officials say that it is too early to estimate the cost of their proposal, but that the principal expense would involve teacher salaries and air-conditioning. No time lines have been set, but given the need for contract renegotiations and building alterations, the earliest that Englewood schools could possibly run on a year-round calendar is thought to be the 1993-94 academic year.
The biggest stumbling block to instituting a longer school year is usually taxpayer unwillingness to pay for it. Englewood may have a slight advantage over most New Jersey school districts in this respect since it is one of the few districts in the state with appointed school boards and budgets approved by boards of school estimate instead of the voters.
One impetus for extending the school year is to have greater continuity in learning. By eliminating long summer vacations, educators hope to avoid weeks of review in September for students who seem to have forgotten everything they have learned.
But the curtailment of summer vacation, an ingrained American tradition, poses many additional questions. The committee will have to decide whether more time in school is worth sacrificing such mainstay middle-class activities as summer camp and summer family vacations, and the opportunity for students to work in the summer to help pay for college.
Proponents of a longer school year contend that the benefits of summer vacations are inconsequential if they lead to a long-term demise of the United States as an economic power. They also say that the vision of camping days and vacation trips is outmoded and that most American children now spend their summers on the streets or in front of television sets, waiting for their parents to return home from work.
 
More Immediate Problems Cited
 There has been no official reaction to the proposal from the Englewood Education Association, but the union's president, Kathleen Rimmer, said there were more immediate problems to address. Among the concerns she cited were poor heating and ventilation systems in school buildings and increasing class sizes.
"Teachers' initial reaction is we'd like to get things right for 10 months first before we think about making the school year 12 months," she said.
The move to a longer school year is also receiving support from Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood. A bill he introduced at the end of the last legislative session would establish a $30 million, three-year competitive grants program for schools that are interested in expanding the length of the school day and year.
"It just got to the stage that he thought people were talking about this one too much and not doing anything about it," said Larry McDonnell, Mr. Torricelli's press secretary.
The bill would require schools to be in session a minimum of seven hours a day, 200 days a year. Districts, except for poor ones, would have to raise 20 percent of the additional cost themselves, and the United States Department of Education would monitor the results.
 
Curbs on Holidays Urged
 "We hope that after three years we would have the evidence to say, see, it does cost more money but it works," Mr. McDonnell said.
Mr. Torricelli held a news conference at Dwight Morrow High School in December to unveil his bill. The news conference was attended by a number of students selected by the school administration, who praised it. Several told the Congressman they thought school should be longer and more rigorous, and one suggested eliminating some holidays as a start.
That viewpoint may not be universal.
"Many of us aren't too thrilled," said Kate Passow, an eighth grader, who is the daughter of the president of Dwight Morrow's parent-teacher group and who attended the news conference. "The good part is that we'd get a better education, but the down side is that we'd have to spend more time in school."
On one point she was adamant. "We're really not getting much out of school as it is now," she said. "The school has to be improved before we even extend the school year."
Englewood is trying to improve the quality of time currently spent in school. The high school is midway through a $600,000 three-year grant from the RJR Nabisco Foundation to reorganize what happens in the classroom so that students take a more active role in learning and teachers become more like coaches.
 
Debate Turns 'Nasty'
 Northern Highlands Regional High School in Allendale knows firsthand how hard it is to make even the slightest adjustment to the school day. After years of discussion, the district's Board of Education voted last week to switch from a seven-period day to an eight-period one, an action that will probably add about a half-hour to the school day.
James Ryan Jr., president of the board, said the move would enable students to take more electives.
But the teachers are threatening a lawsuit if they have to teach an extra class, and more than half of Northern Highlands' 694 students staged an all-day sit-in in the school auditorium to protest the possibility of having to take more courses.
"Things have gotten so nasty around the building in the last week or two with job actions and pressure on the students," said Dr. David Garrahan, the district's Superintendent of Schools. "But no one can really argue with what the board is doing. We have constantly heard from every major commission and panel that has studied American education in the last 10 years, and we're continually being compared unfavorably with graduates from European and Japanese high schools."

HEADLINE: Biotechnology Companies Find a Home In the State

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE biotechnology industry has found New Jersey. From bags of bugs to designer drugs, from cloned chrysanthemums to a substitute for human blood, an increasing number of New Jersey companies are creating and developing innovative products, using the sophisticated technology born of the biotechnology revolution.
State officials and industry experts say that after a somewhat slow start, New Jersey is now emerging as a major site for biotechnology businesses -- a multibillion-dollar industry that holds out the promise of solving some of mankind's most pressing environmental and medical problems. In addition, they say, the state's enhanced presence in the biotechnology market will aid the state's economy by creating new industry and jobs.
"We feel that New Jersey is becoming a leader in the biotech industry," said Brooke Hern, a spokesman for the State Department of Commerce and Economic Development. Mr. Hern said an informal survey of listings of biotechnology companies nationwide by the department had shown New Jersey to have 193 biotechnology companies -- second only to California with 365, and just ahead of Massachusetts with 183. 
 "Up until a few years ago, there wasn't even an industry code for biotechnology," Mr. Hern said, referring to the way officials classify specific industries for statistical purposes.
For purposes of the survey, Mr. Hern said, the biotechnology industry was broadly defined to include all companies involved in industrial microbiology, biology, chemistry or engineering that used genetic engineering, live microorganisms or cell cultures from other organisms to produce new products.
Industry experts are not quite as enthusiastic as state officials are about the state's relative ranking; most believe that Massachusetts still ranks ahead of New Jersey and that New Jersey is something of a late bloomer. Nevertheless, they say, in recent years New Jersey has established itself as a major source of management expertise, scientific talent and venture capital -- the three ingredients necessary for any budding biotechnology venture.
"New Jersey provides a nice opportunity for new bioscience firms because they can find quality people right outside their door," said Jack E. Stover, partner in charge of New Jersey high-technology practice in the Princeton office of Coopers & Lybrand, the consulting and accounting firm.
"It's a lot easier to steal someone from a Johnson & Johnson and bring them on board than it is to go to Boston or San Jose and then have to relocate them," he said.
In addition, he said, the pharmaceutical companies provide a "role model" for the smaller bioscience companies and often provide necessary capital through joint venture arrangements. And when that money runs out, Mr. Stover said, there is a vast amount of public and private money available in the area.
"We've got dozens of companies in New Jersey that have raised capital to continue their research and development efforts," he said.
The growing appeal of the state as a center for high technology, Mr. Stover said, "provides a huge opportunity for the future of New Jersey, especially as it relates to spawning and developing new technologies and new applications for those technologies."
J. Steven Burrill, international director for high technology in the San Francisco office of Ernst & Young, the consulting and accounting firm, said the biotechnology industry began in the San Francisco Bay area in the late 1960's and early 70's. Spawned by advances in biology that gave scientists the ability to manipulate an organism's genetic code, the industry has grown steadily over 20 years.
"My estimate is that you're talking about a $50 billion industry before the end of the decade," Mr. Burrill said. "Only a handful" of biotechnology companies, he added, have gone bankrupt over the last 15 years.
"Almost every company has developed enough technology that there is always a way that they can get value out or merge with somebody," Mr. Burrill said.
Over the next several years, Mr. Burrill said, between 120 and 150 major products are expected to be approved by various regulatory agencies. To date, he said, only a few products have successfully navigated the arduous, expensive and time-consuming approval process and are actually being marketed.
One such product has been developed by Enzon Inc., a South Plainfield company that was founded by two Rutgers University professors in 1983. The product, called Adagen, is a drug that is used to treat victims of severe combined immunodeficiency disease, commonly referred to as "bubble boy" disease.
Victims of the disease are children whose bodies do not produce a necessary enzyme, said Glenn Kazo, vice president of corporate development for the company. Without the enzyme, Mr. Kazo said, the children's immune systems fail to develop, leaving them susceptible to infection and often forced to live in plastic "bubbles," isolated from others and the environment.
Though the ability to manufacture the enzyme has existed for some time, he said, it must be administered to patients in frequent doses because the body quickly flushes it out of the bloodstream. Frequent use of the enzyme, however, would cause severe side effects. In fact, Mr. Kazo said, the raw enzyme was so toxic that it was never developed for use.
 
'Like a Stealth Protein'
 Enzon's founders solved that problem in the late 1970's while still at Rutgers by attaching an inert substance -- polyethylene glycol -- to the enzyme molecule.
"It works by disguising the surface of the molecule," said Dr. Abraham Abuchowski, president and co-founder of the company, along with Dr. Frank F. Davis. "It's actually like a stealth protein," he said.
The resulting Adagen compound was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in March 1990 and is now being supplied to 14 children who have the disease. Though the company makes no profit on the sale of the drug, the technology it has developed can be used to make other designer drugs, as they are commonly called in the industry.
In fact, the company recently entered into an agreement with the California-based Genlabs Technologies Inc. to develop a modified form of a Genlabs drug called GLQ223 for the treatment of AIDS.
Another potential use for the technology, Dr. Abuchowski said, is the production of hemoglobin -- the protein present in blood that is responsible for carrying oxygen.
 
Quest Has Taken Years
 "This is probably one of the most unique pharmaceutical products ever created," Dr. Abuchowski said. "People have been trying to make artificial blood for years."
The raw hemoglobin, which is obtained from cow blood and then "disguised" by attaching polyethylene glycol, could be used as a replacement for blood lost in an accident, during an operation or even by a soldier on a battlefield.
The semi-synthetic hemoglobin, Dr. Abuchowski said, is now being tested on animals and should be ready for testing on humans by the end of the year.
Another New Jersey company that has produced marketable products is the DNA Plant Technology Corporation in Cinnaminson, one of the largest biotechnology companies in the United States.
David Gilbert, DNA's manager of corporate communications, said the company had focused its research on five basic areas.
Using gene splicing techniques, Mr. Gilbert said, the company has been able to create new vegetables, including a snacking pepper that tastes like a sweet red bell pepper but is the size of a small jalapeno chili pepper.
The company has also developed a low-fat frying oil, a test kit to detect fungal diseases in grass, another test kit to detect petroleum contamination in soil and a biological additive that helps create "a higher quality artificial snow."
 
Long-Lived Chrysanthemum
 Mr. Gilbert said the company was also involved in a joint venture with a Dutch company to breed and market flowers with novel colors and patterns. One flower that the company has already created through genetic engineering is a white chrysanthemum with a long vase life.
The new flower should sell well, Mr. Gilbert said. "This particular chrysanthemum is known as 'Moneymaker' in the profession because of its very desirable agronomic characteristics," he said.
Indeed, experts say, the robust health of the biotechnology industry itself, particularly in the area of drug research, is based upon the same principle that motivates the creation of a white chrysanthemum.
"When you win, the win is enormous," said Bernard Tenenbaum, director of the George Rothman Institute of Entrepreneurial Studies at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison. "The biotech business is a waiting game. But the problems they're trying to solve are so big and so fundamental to society that the nurturing of the bioscience industry represents future investment returns on a tremendous scale."
 
A Magnet for Capital
The biotechnology industry, Mr. Tenenbaum said, has been a magnet for huge infusions of venture capital despite investor caution inspired by the current recession.
"There are lots of venture people who love this business," he said. "They might put a million or two million in for 30 percent of a company that could be worth hundreds of millions of dollars."
The increasing number of new biotechnology companies in New Jersey, Mr. Tenenbaum said, while partly a result of investor interest, is also a result of the high concentration of pharmaceutical companies in the state. Occasionally, he said, the "research" portion of a drug company's "research and development" suddenly becomes a new biotechnology company.
One example, he said, is Celgene, a Warren-based biotechnology company that was created by the Celanese Corporation in 1986.
"Celgene makes bags of bugs," Mr. Tenenbaum said. "They make microbes that scrub pollutants."
 
Converting Hazardous Waste
 Dr. Thomas B. Lewis, vice president of the company, said that while Celgene did not produce bugs in the conventional sense, the company had developed a system that used live microorganisms to convert hazardous industrial waste into harmless byproducts.
"We have demonstrated a biological reactor system that converts methylene chloride, a suspected carcinogen, into carbon dioxide, water and salt," Dr. Lewis said, referring to a demonstration of the system conducted in cooperation with General Electric. About 400 million pounds of methylene chloride is produced and used by industry each year, D.r. Lewis said.
The microorganisms in Celgene's biological reactor system, he said, are naturally occurring ones that have been selected to degrade the man-made chemical efficiently.
The water produced by the system is so clean, Dr. Lewis said, that it could meet Federal drinking water standards.
 
Another Approach on Waste
 Another company that is using genetic engineering to treat hazardous waste is Envirogen in Lawrenceville. Unlike Celgene's biological reactor system, which treats hazardous waste before it leaves the factory, Envirogen's technology focuses on biologically degrading hazardous materials like chlorinated solvents and PCB's that have already entered the waste stream.
Roger J. Colley, president of the two-year-old company, said Envirogen, in addition to working with natural organisms that will be introduced for commercial application this year, was using the common bacteria E. coli as a living factory to create genetically modified microorganisms. Those microorganisms, he said, are specifically designed to biodegrade certain toxic chemicals that have been introduced into the environment.
The company, Mr. Colley said, like other young biotech companies in New Jersey and elsewhere, will spend a great deal of time, money and effort before it actually has a product it can sell.
"It's a slow, cautious process before we get to the use of these organisms in the field," he said. "We don't know whether it's two years or 10 years down the road."

HEADLINE: Communities Told to Improve Water Purity

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
NEW Federal and state standards for water quality are forcing local officials in Westchester to step up plans for expensive filtration plants or to search for alternative supplies. The mandates are also increasing demands for a regional approach to water management.
Westchester relies on the vast New York City reservoir system for 85 percent of its drinking water. Earlier this month, 11 municipalities in the county learned from state health authorities that their current treatment programs are inadequate and that new proposals to meet strict new standards of water purity must be submitted by March 31. 
 Communities have until June 1993 to put their plans into effect, seven years after amendments to the Safe Water Drinking Act were passed by Congress in 1986. The Federal law prompted the state to enact even tougher standards, later modified, which originally called for all surface water supplies to be filtered.
Some of the affected Westchester commmunities, like Irvington and Briarcliff, rely exclusively on the Croton Reservoir system, where water quality has steadily deteriorated. Although the Croton supply still meets Federal standards for safe drinking, state authorities are now requiring that every gallon of water be filtered.
Although New York City is building a $600 million water-filtration plant for the Croton Reservoir in the Bronx, that new system will handle only the part of the supply serving New York City residents.
Other Westchester communities, including Harrison and the town and village of Mamaroneck, draw their water from the Rye Lake section of the Kensico Reservoir, which state authorities ordered filtered.
Five other Westchester communities connect to the Catskill Reservoir above the Kensico Reservoir in northern Westchester, where the water, especially in springtime, is unusually muddy.
 
Date With Destiny Delayed
 Parts of Yorktown, Montrose, Cortlandt, Pleasantville and New Castle have learned that the increased turbidity in their supply will require them to develop alternatives to meet new water-purity standards or seek another supply.
Other Westchester communities, although escaping their neighbors' fate under the state guidelines released this month, realize that their date with a costly destiny has only been delayed. These communities, which draw their water from the Delaware and Catskill sections of the New York City Water Supply System, are waiting for the outcome of the city's current negotiations with upstate communities to set strict new rules for watershed protection.
The regulations, if enacted, would severely limit residential and commercial development in the 11-county watershed region, but the proposals have encountered bitter local opposition. If political considerations force these proposed regulations to be diluted, state officials have warned that their new regulations governing water purity will take effect.
New York City would then be required to filter the Delaware and Catskill Reservoirs, the largest part of its system, at an estimated construction cost of $6 billion and a yearly maintenance cost estimated at $600 million. The implications are dire, city officials agree. "We get 90 percent of our water from Delaware-Catskill, and protecting the watershed around that system is a crucial economic issue for New York City and the region," said Sanford Evans, deputy commissioner for public affairs with the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. "This is no tree-hugger's fear."
James R. Covey, the associate director of the Bureau of Public Water Supply in the State Health Department, said his department hoped that the city would be better able to protect its remaining watershed area. "The Croton Reservoir is in a highly developed area," Mr. Covey said. "With major interstates and with large development complexes smack dab in the middle of the water supply, you must filter."
New York City still has a chance to avoid the same thing happening in the Delaware-Catskill watershed, Mr. Covey said. "We have required a long-term plan from them showing they have the resources available to meet our requirements. If the city can establish and enforce its criteria for watershed protection, it won't have to filter water from the Delaware-Catskill."
 
New Guidelines Under Consideration
 Environmental groups and some state and city officials are concerned that continued development in the Croton watershed will cause the raw water quality of the Croton to deteriorate rapidly, conditions they say are also occurring in other watershed areas. The Hudson Valley region in which the watershed is situated is one of the fastest-growing areas in the state, with planners predicting that by 2015 its population will have grown 20 percent from the 1988 level.
State law allows the discharge of treated sewage into the reservoir system, but the process for obtaining permits allows for many violations, environmental groups charge. Officials who monitor permits for the State Department of Environmental Conservation said the department is considering new guidelines to limit discharges.
"We don't make the laws; we are given the rules to work with," said Cesare J. Manfredi, environmental regional water engineer for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "The law doesn't preclude the discharge of treated sewage."
While he acknowledged that permitted amounts are exceeded, Mr. Manfredi insisted that his department is able to track all major offenders.
A more worrisome danger, Mr. Manfredi said, is the growing presence of phosphorus in the reservoir system, a nutrient that he said contributes to excessive algae and weed growth, thus reducing the effectiveness of chlorine as a disinfectant. New regulations are being put into effect that require sewage treatment plants to limit phosphorus discharges, Mr. Manfredi said.
 
Rates Nearly Double
 Westchester officials said all these signs were hopeful but they are not optimistic. "We are concerned long-term with the apparent inevitability of expensive filtration plants," said Village Manager Steve McCabe of Irvington, who is overseeing the building of a new $4 million connection to the Delaware-Catskill reservoir system. "Who knows how long the Delaware and Catskill will last?" he asked.
A regional solution would have been less expensive for village residents, who are now paying water rates nearly double what they were two years ago, Mr. McCabe said. "Why didn't everybody get together?" he asked. "We did it with solid waste, but here, all we have is another Federal and state mandate with no money."
Town Supervisor Caroline Silverstone of Mamaroneck agreed. "A filtration plant will be incredibly expensive," she said, adding that a solution that could increase local water rates 50 percent was probably inevitable. Coliform bacteria have appeared in some area water samples, she said, referring to the bacteria resulting from untreated sewage. The discovery of the bacteria is a development that cannot be ignored, she said.
While the piecemeal approach being adopted by Westchester communities to protect their water supplies in response to state and Federal requirements is inefficient, Mrs. Silverstone said, appeals for county help have been ignored. "We have complained to Mr. O'Rourke," she said, "but we have only had a pro forma response."
 
'The Process Moves Very Slowly'
 Last week, Salvatore A. Celona, Director of the Westchester County Water Agency, defended his agency in coordinating water policy. "The municipalities are frustrated, and so are we," Mr. Celona said. "We have been cooperating, but the whole process moves very slowly."
Mr. Celona and members of his agency were expected to meet late last week with representatives from Yorktown, Somers and Cortlandt to discuss county cooperation in building a regional filtration plant for the three communities.
The county allocated $35,000 last week to hire Guastella Associates of Boston to review New York City's proposal to raise water rates for upstate consumers by an average 70 percent. The rate hike, the first proposed in 20 years, was submitted to the State Department of Environmental Conservation last fall. That department is to hold public hearings on the proposal, but no dates have been set.
Officials in many Westchester communities said last week that they had heard little opposition from residents about current and proposed water-rate hikes. In New Castle, the only community expected to have a new filtration plant on line before the state deadline in June next year, the $20 million plant will cost residents an additional $200 a year.
"It is very important that all municipalities drink filtered water if that's how you prevent disease," said Gerard Moershell, Commissioner of Public Works for New Castle. "Let's face it. People pay four or five times the cost of water to rent cable television each month. Let's get a proper perspective."
 
 
 
WATER RIGHTS AND THE LAW
 "Development Rights and Water-Body Protection, Legal Solutions," a conference sponsored by the Pace University School of Law and the Real Estate Law Society, will be held on Wednesday in the Moot Court Room at the law school.
The half-day conference will consider such issues as developers' rights and the Constitution, water-protection strategies under Federal and state law, Federal Clean Water Act mandates and their impact on state and local law, comprehensive planning and regulations at the county and local level and balancing interests through regional and statewide planning statutes.
The seminar, which begins at 8:30 A.M., costs $75 for each registrant. Checks payable to the Pace University School of Law should be sent to Mary Liscio, events coordinator at the Law School at 78 North Broadway, White Plains, N.Y. 10603. For more information, call 422-4262.
