HEADLINE: Getting Blacks and Whites Together Under One Cultural Roof

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE yearly spotlight on the achievements of black Americans will shine in the county tomorrow, the official observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, and will beam throughout what the county has designated as African-American History Month next month. As in past years, the county's cultural calendar is filled with lectures, films and exhibitions planned by public and private organizations to pay tribute to the two national celebrations.
But who in the county will attend these events? Will black and white people share equally in their American heritage or will audiences be mostly black, as they have been in the past? 
 The question resonates with a larger issue as many of the county's white-run arts and cultural institutions increase their efforts to attract black and other minority visitors to their events. The relatively recent commitment by these institutions to broaden their audiences stems from a variety of economic and humanitarian concerns and has met with some success, notably by the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York in Purchase and by the Hartsdale-based New Orchestra of Westchester.
But more often, community and cultural leaders say, bringing together blacks and whites with common interests is like moving mountains, even when the purpose is enjoyment and celebration.
 
Advertising Is Not Enough
 While some say more advertising is needed to attract more diverse audiences, others say advertising is not enough and that only personal contact can break racial barriers.
Janet Langsam, executive director of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, said the council had begun "a much greater outreach," distributing its monthly newsletter, Artsnews, through newspapers and conducting two monthly cable television shows. The arts in particular "suffer from a wrongful image of elitism and exclusivity," Ms. Langsam said.
Advertising alone does not draw whites to events sponsored by blacks, even when the program honors a universally admired figure like Dr. King. Hal Fitzpatrick, chairman of the fourth yearly all-day King celebration being held at the County Center here tomorrow, said that neither newspaper ads, fliers to schools nor his remarks in interviews that everyone was welcome had brought more than a few "very bright and enlightened white people to the event in the past."
Mr. Fitzpatrick, vice president of the African-American Men of Westchester, which sponsors the event, said tomorrow's celebration would be "filled with activities on stage and off," including performances by Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes, the Westchester Choral Society and others. Tickets for the event, scheduled from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., are $4; $2 for children and the elderly. For more information, call 949-9463.
 
Few Whites, but Few Blacks Either
 The county's official kickoff ceremonies for African-American History Month, held at the County Courthouse here each year, have also been well publicized, but few whites have attended. Judy Matson, the county's Director of Cultural Affairs, said that last year even the turnout by blacks was small.
Dr. Julius C. Ford, chairman of the Westchester County African-American Month Steering Committee, said there had been no special effort to attract support in either the black or white communities beyond publishing the month's calendar of events in the newspaper. He added, however, that black history "is everyone's business" and said he hoped that whites as well as blacks would attend this year's kickoff on Feb. 1 at 1 P.M. at the courthouse.
This year's keynote speaker, Dr. James Washington of the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan, will speak on "African Roots Explore New Worlds: Pre-Columbus to the Space Age," and local youth groups will perform. For more information, call 285-2934.
Ms. Matson, a member of the steering committee, said it was frustrating that a more racially mixed group did not attend such other county-sponsored events as the free summer concerts at the Kensico Dam Plaza or last June's all-day Mozart Marathon at the County Center. "You wonder how you can do things in a different way to bring the entire community to programs," Ms. Matson said.
 
Economic Incentives Begin
 Of the many who have asked that question, some have found the answer in multiculturalism. Now that the concept is "politically correct," more organizations feel entitled, if not expected, to provide programs that will appeal to a wider audience.
In order to qualify for a challenge grant from the Council for the Arts in Westchester several years ago, local arts groups had to show how they would work to diversify their staffs and boards of directors and also to serve minority groups better with their programming.
Twelve organizations received the grant, including the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.
"It's a difficult line to walk," said Philip Verre, the museum's director. Mr. Verre said that while the museum was committed to addressing "the needs of the audience that is traditionally disenfranchised," including the black and Hispanic people in the museum's own neighborhood, he also said that democracy and quality must coincide.
"We must make what we have here more accessible, more comfortable and enjoyable," Mr. Verre said.
In order to "build bridges over the gaps" and to make newcomers to the museum feel at ease, Mr. Verre said, he invites community groups to hold events at the museum. The local chapters of Delta Sigma Theta sorority, a black group, and the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs have held recent meetings at the museum. Also, Mr. Verre said, the museum sponsors drop-in art workshops on Saturdays for neighborhood children.
 
Black Women in Music Series
 The Performing Arts Center at SUNY Purchase, under the leadership of its director, Christopher Beach, has expanded its programming this season to include a series on black women in music as well as black dance and theater groups. Mr. Beach said his interest in attracting minority-group children, in particular, to the programs was "a response to a dramatically changing mix in the next generation."
In order to publicize the new programs, and to extend a welcoming hand beyond the traditional audience, the center gave a party last June. Virginia C. Reines, community relations director of the center, said 400 people, black and white, were invited to a performance by the dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones, a supper and a tour of the center's four-theater complex. The new relationships forged at the party and in the many phone calls that followed led to a small but promising number of group sales for the season's opening concert by Queen Ida and Her Bon Temps Zydeco Band, Mrs. Reines said.
In addition, the Performing Arts Center made some important new friends who have taken their own friends and families to programs. Salina Wilson, the director of public affairs for Con Edison, said she had not known of the Performing Arts Center before the party, even while working in a previous job in Purchase. "Once I knew it was there -- boom! -- I became a subscriber, and I took my son there," Ms. Wilson said.
She also said the local chapter of the Coalition of 100 Black Women, a national group of which she is a member, had sponsored its own theater party at a September performance of Les Ballets Africains at the center.
 
Inspired by Leonard Bernstein
 Robert A. Carpenter, a member of African-American Men of Westchester, was also at the party last June, where he said he had had "a personal vision that I could make an impact on the minority youth." He had been inspired in his own youth by watching Leonard Bernstein's Concerts for Young People on television, he said, and now saw a chance "to expose kids to the length and breadth of the performing arts."
Working with Kathryn K. Wolfe, group sales director for the center, he arranged for 85 children and chaperons to attend a performance by the mime and magician Avner the Eccentric in November, after which the performer met with the group. Mr. Carpenter said he hoped to take the youngsters to see the dancer Kevin Wynn at the center next month and Sweet Honey in the Rock, an all-woman gospel group, in March.
Perhaps the most ambitious effort to unite the county's blacks and whites in an arts event is "Music America," the New Orchestra of Westchester's benefit concert for a consortium of 20 local community organizations, at the Performing Arts Center on Friday at 8 P.M. On the program is "Cry the Beloved Country," a concert theater piece derived from "Lost in the Stars," Kurt Weill's musical about apartheid in South Africa based on Alan Paton's novel "Cry the Beloved Country."
The Morgan State University Choir, based in Maryland, will perform the work with the orchestra and soloists under the baton of Paul Lustig Dunkel, the New Orchestra's music director. Also on the program will be Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue," with Terrence Wilson, a 16-year-old pianist from the Bronx, as soloist. (For more information about "Music America," call 682-3707.)
Originally, these works were to be performed only in the orchestra's regular Saturday night and Sunday afternoon subscription series, until Mary Luehrsen-Young, the orchestra's executive director, and officials at Pepsico, which is sponsoring the program, sat down to talk.
 
'We Are Mutually Cooperating'
 Ronald E. Harrison, vice president of community affairs at Pepsico, said he saw an opportunity for the company to observe King's birthday in a meaningful way and help community groups at the same time. Representatives of the 20 groups, selected for their efforts to promote "ethnic, racial and religious harmony and respect," Mr. Harrison said, have met many times to make plans, stuff envelopes and contribute what Ms. Luehrsen-Young called "sweat equity."
Many members of the racially mixed consortium said that aside from the money they hope to make at the event -- more than half the proceeds of the higher-priced tickets for the concert and a reception will go to the benefiting groups -- the project has been valuable in bringing together the organizations.
"Instead of being competitive, we are mutually cooperating and accomplishing our own goals as well," said Henry Hobbs, executive director of Human Development Services of Port Chester, a member of the consortium.
Many of those at Friday's concert will be attending a live performance of a symphony orchestra for the first time. Ms. Luehrsen-Young said this would be a good introduction for them, since the program "breaks down the mystique that symphony orchestras only play Mozart and Beethoven."
On the other hand, Ms. Luehrsen-Young added: "I don't want to do programming just because it attracts a certain audience. That's a short-term viewpoint and rather self-centered. American music and the American symphony orchestra represent so many diverse ethnic influences, and we need to keep our sights on that goal.
"Maybe we'll build an audience slower that way," she said, "but it will be for the right reasons."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Hertz to New York: Pay More

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
When he founded the first rent-a-car company in 1927, John Hertz thought he could control the business from top to bottom by building the cars himself, and came up with a model called the "Drive-Ur-Self," complete with running boards and a windshield that opened for ventilation. But he eventually decided that buying the standard models built by other manufacturers was more practical.
Now, 65 years later, the current chairman of the Hertz Corporation, Frank A. Olson, is also trying to keep control, in his case over the company's losses in New York City. Mr. Olson's solution -- imposing charges that would shoo away Hertz's riskiest customers -- may last longer than the Drive-Ur-Self, but it is already taking him down a rough road. 
 On Friday, New York Attorney General Robert Abrams sued Hertz over its policy, initiated Jan. 2, of imposing surcharges on rentals by residents of four New York boroughs, including $56 a day for Bronx residents. (As it happens, Mr. Abrams is a former Bronx Borough President.)
Hertz said it had instituted the policy because of extensive third-party losses. New York's "vicarious liability" law allows people injured by rental cars to sue the company that owns them, and Hertz said it had paid out $45 million over three years.
"We buy an asset, a $15,000 car, and rent it to a customer," Mr. Olson said. "Then we are responsible for whatever he does with it. If he hits a school bus, we can pay out $30 million." Mr. Olson said Hertz could justify the new surcharges by showing state officials the figures on liability losses, but he said that no matter what, the company was free to set its own prices.
Prices are particularly important these days. Last year was a rough one for the rental car industry, with business travel way down because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war. "In the first quarter, people were afraid to go to the bathroom, let alone get on an airplane," Mr. Olson said. Hertz controls about 31 percent of the airport rental market, he said, but that was 31 percent of a rather small number.
Mr. Olson, who is 59 years old, has been Hertz's chairman since June 1980 and a director since 1974. From June until December 1987, he was chairman, president and chief executive of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines and the parent at that time of Hertz. When Hertz was spun off at the very end of 1987 he went with it, and is one of the group of top executives that owns 20 percent of the company, which is based in Park Ridge, N.J.
While Hertz is not publicly traded -- Ford Motor owns 49 percent, Volvo of North America owns 26 percent and a German bank, Commerzbank, holds the other 5 percent -- Mr. Olson said with obvious pride that his company was the only one in the field with its own credit rating. His competitors rely on their corporate parents (generally auto makers) or, like Avis, have no public debt.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Cross-Atlantic Rate Play

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
This is an unusual time for the United States bond market. Short-term interest rates are near 20-year lows, while rates abroad are much higher. That's an environment in which nimble risk takers might make a profit on the spread. But it's also an environment that many corporte treasurers, who want to preserve capital while putting idle money to work, are not used to.
Given these circumstances, Robert N. Gordon, president of the Twenty-First Securities Corporation in New York, is seeking an opportunity for his American corporate customers with millions of dollars in cash on hand. Paribas Asset Management, the investment subsidary of the French bank, is looking for entree to more American customers. And both want to act quickly because the interest rate opportunity they see is not going to last long. 
 So they have joined forces. Twenty-First Securities is providing the introduction to customers and Paribas the investing expertise with a special bonus: It will guarantee the nervous corporate treasurer that there will be no loss on the original investment. The principal will be secure.
Sounds great. But selling this product is not as easy as it sounds, even though some corporate treasurers like the sound of the new scheme. For one thing, corporations can often be slow in opening up to new investment ideas. For example, it has taken years for many global companies to begin thinking artfully about hedging their foreign-exchange exposure abroad. Also, budget goals set internally often discourage any adventuresome investing of corporate funds.
"Most corporate treasury departments are risk adverse almost to a fault," said Ken Drucker, treasurer of the Sequa Corporation, a New York-based manufacturer of aerospace products.
The sentiment of some treasurers seemed to be summed up by Paul Willey of Dresser Industries in Dallas, the energy production and service company: "Even some of the best have gotten hammered in the past on sure-shot deals." Dresser does not plan to put any money into the plan.
The product being offered is investment in medium-term bonds, focusing on Europe, with all investments hedged back into dollars to avoid currency risk. There are good arguments for shifting funds in that direction.
Interest rates in Europe are twice or more what they are in America. Also, there is a strong likelihood that rates in Europe will begin to fall this year when the German Bundesbank eases credit, which would create capital gains to add to the interest rate return. In the United States, on the other hand, short-term interest rates are inching up from their recent lows. Those increases will steadily nibble away at principal.
To make this shift to Europe more palatable to corporate types, Paribas decided to offer the no-loss-of-principle guarantee. It is in effect as long as the money -- with a minimum investment of $15 million -- is left with Paribas for at least a year.
Such a guarantee does catch the eye. "Our clients," Mr. Gordon said, with a nod to Will Rogers, "are more concerned with the return of their money than the return on their money.".
But the guarantee is really nothing more than a sales lure. Neither Paribas nor Twenty-First Securities think it will have to be drawn on. A look at the European bond market -- and its prospects for the next year -- support that idea. Mr. Gordon calculated that interest rates on German bonds with a four-year maturity would have to rise about 1.85 percentage points before the loss on the purchase price of the bond would wipe out the interest earned.
"There would have to be an extraordinary mistake" for a loss of principal to occur, said Peter Reinemann, a vice president at Paribas. "We are running the fund in an extremely conservative way and it is extremely unlikely that you would have anything like that." Paribas is travelling the States looking for customers. So far, no one has bitten. Among the companies they have talked to, in additon to Dresser, are CSX, Bristol-Meyers, Walt Disney and Litton Industries.
"The product is good and the guarantee enhances it," Mr. Wiley of Dresser said. "It is hard to get into Europeann securities and this strategey is important if Americans are ready to do that," he said, agreeing that the investing environment for corporate treasurers in the United States is difficult at the moment with interest rates so low. "Treasurers became fairly numb earning a comfortable rate."
But despite all that, he wouldn't put money in the fund. "You are making a rate bet against the principal," he said, scarey territory for many corporate treasurers, even with a guarantee.
For Mr. Wiley, it's all moot anyway. Dresser corporate policy wouldn't allow it, since the company prefers buying its own bonds. "We like to make the call," he said.
But Mr. Drucker of Sequa sees it the other way. With the guarantee, the downside is not getting the 4 percent a company can earn in the United States with current Treasury or certificate of deposit yields. The upside is getting foreign denominated bond yields that are much higher. "From an intellectual point of view it seemed rather intriguing to me," he said.
Still, he won't invest either. He doesn't have the cash available just now.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life CENTRAL CITY, Colo.;
Charming His Way To a Second Gold Rush

BYLINE: By Mary Billard

 BODY:
Less than an hour's drive from the big city of Denver, this picturesque Victorian hamlet is so folksy that the nearest coffee shop -- a good 10 miles down the interstate -- keeps the mugs of its regulars conveniently hanging on one wall. You'll find no shopping malls here. You can't even buy milk or bread. But you might pick up some nice Gold Rush memorabilia at the Lost Gold Mine, where tourists can root around the hollows of a closed-down shaft.
This is not exactly the kind of boom town where a flashy Hawaiian developer might be prone to plant his next project. Yet it is here that Christopher Hemmeter expects to extract his next million -- mustering all his country-boy charms to convince the 336 year-round residents that his dreams of glittery casinos are their dreams, too. "I'm not an interloper," he says. 
 For two decades, Mr. Hemmeter dominated the Hawaii hotel scene, building mind-boggling mega-resorts that were compared to India's Taj Mahal long before gambling became part of Donald Trump's vernacular. His 1,600-room Westin Kauai has a 2.1 acre reflecting pool, a fountain with eight life-sized marble horses and 10 miles of waterways, explorable by gondola. One of its 14 elevators is inside a 100-foot cliff. And it wasn't even his biggest hotel.
But the Central City power brokers were not about to allow Mr. Hemmeter to run wild, even if they thought he could snap some life into the limp local economy and usher in a second Gold Rush.
Central City's zoning, designed to preserve the historic town, allows a building to be 53 feet tall, but not if it's also that wide. Mr. Hemmeter's first proposal was "too tall," said Alan Granruth, the historic preservation administrator for Central City and jazz festival director. Asked to elaborate, Mr. Granruth obliged: "It was just too tall."
After the rejection, Mr. Hemmeter, 52, showing true Western grit, settled in last winter to take time to appreciate the locals, or, as he puts it, "to learn their dreams."
His Colorado roots helped his understanding. Mr. Hemmeter attended the University of Colorado for a year and fondly remembers performing in Central City's Mine Shaft bar in his salad days as part of a singing group. Until a few years ago, he had a house on Aspen Mountain -- with its own elevator in a cliff. (He sold it in the late 80's for a reported $17 million to Ted Field, movie producer and heir of Marshall Field department store, who now has it on the market for $25 million.)
In Hawaii, Mr. Hemmeter had been Mr. Glitz. But he sold his Hawaiian hotel properties for a handsome profit in the late 80's -- pocketing $188 million here, $320 million there. He had been splitting his time between his Bel Air mansion and his Hawaiian retreat at Diamond Head (onetime asking price: $60 million). But his interest in Hawaii faded in early 1991, after losing a bid to develop a major portion of Honolulu's waterfront.
Meanwhile, voters in Colorado had approved limited gambling in Central City and two other towns. Seeing gambling as the one growth area in the hotel business, Los Angeles-based Hemmeter Partners soon bought a 10,000-square-foot parking lot in Central City for an unheard of $5 million and leased property from the gas station in neighboring Black Hawk. The plan was to build two $12 million casino-and-restaurant complexes.
Mr. Hemmeter arrived here last January selling his project and his personality. Known for his common, folksy touch, he is universally called Chris, even by his construction crews. "Chris? Great family. Good people," said Jerry Brown, one of the gas station owners. "It sounds real syrupy, but we're just real comfortable with him and the deal. Real comfortable."
The area needed Mr. Hemmeter as much as he needed them. Bruce Schmaltz, the former unpaid mayor of Central City, said the once grand town was "falling down around our ears." A change in gold mining economics around World War I had turned Central City from "the richest square mile on earth" in 1859 into a virtual ghost town, according to Dick Allen, City Councilman and owner of the Lost Gold Mine.
Gambling was seen as the salvation -- a way to preserve the town's Victorian heritage, while modernizing its antique water system and roads. The $1,000 licensing fees the city is collecting per gambling device or table annually is expected to push its budget from $230,000 in 1991 to $2.5 million this year, with an $800,000 surplus. Suffice it to say, the new water system has been built. And several 19th-century buildings like the Teller House hotel and the Toll Gate Saloon have been restored by private interests.
Mr. Schmaltz has stepped down as mayor to run businesses. His holdings? "A gift-and-rock shop, a T-shirt shop and the Dostal [Alley] Saloon & Gambling Emporium," laughs Mr. Schmaltz. "We are comfortable, very comfortable."
After months of meetings with the historic commission, Chris Hemmeter seems to have romanced the town. While one-fourth the size of the Westin's reflecting pool, his 30,000-square-foot casino here, for which ground-breaking began last week, will be four times larger than the biggest casino approved to date. "He came in with a 35-foot building," Mr. Granruth said. "We are very pleased."
The casinos, which are to open by June 1, will be named the Bullwhackers after the pioneers who drove across the Great Plains. "Bullwhackers. Bullwhackers," repeats Mr. Hemmetter, relishing the sound. He certainly seems to have the Western thing down.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 12-17

BYLINE: By Frederik Eliason

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
The Irrepressible Bull Market Keeps Roaring Along 

The air waves are filled with New Hampshire residents talking about how low their state's economy has sunk, but many other people seem to be betting that a recovery is not far away. Despite a shortage of good economic news, the stock market has defied gravity day after day. After soaring 60 points on Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12 more on Wednesday and, after a one-day breather, jumped to 3,264.98 on Friday, closing at its 10th record high in 15 sessions. If the explanations for the rises seemed flimsy, trading volume was solid. At least 200 million shares have been traded daily on the Big Board in every session since Dec. 27. Commentators had some difficulty in deciding why people are suddenly so bullish. But Peter G. Grennan of Shearson Lehman Brothers found a down-to-earth explanation for the sudden flow of cash to Wall Street: "The real nut came when depositors at the banks had to start accepting less than 4 percent."
 
 
Those Retailers Were Right
 
Retailers who were complaining last month about the weak holiday shopping season were not kidding. Retail sales, covering receipts at car dealers, gasoline stations, restaurants and appliance stores as well as Christmas shopping at the malls, fell four-tenths of 1 percent in December. And both of the two previous months were revised downward. For the year, retail sales rose only seven-tenths of 1 percent. It was the poorest annual performance since 1961. The overall picture is of consumers even more restrained than had previously been thought.
 
 
Salomon Was Not Alone
 
Salomon Brothers is in deep trouble for making illegal bids at Treasury auctions. But apparently almost everyone inflated customer orders when bidding for the debt of Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and Sallie Mae and two other Government-sponsored agencies. So the Securities and Exchange Commission imposed fines ranging up to $100,000 on 98 banks and securities firms. The penalties totaled about $5 million and saved both the S.E.C. and the companies the cost of lawsuits. The S.E.C. investigation found institutions with elaborate sets of phony records that would allow them to seek more than their share of debt securities so they could be assured of filling all orders. But lawyers for the companies asserted that, unlike the case involving Salomon, nobody was harmed by the inflated bids.
 
 
The End of an Oil Era?
 
Oil production in the United States fell sharply at the end of last year. Output was the lowest in 30 years in the fourth quarter and outside of Alaska it was the lowest since 1950. The director of finance for the American Petroleum Institute, Edward H. Murphy, said, "It's quite possible that the age of major domestic production is coming to an end." The decline was attributed in part to a drop in demand, related both to the recession and to the better gasoline mileage of recent-vintage vehicles. It also reflects increased use of natural gas. But the trend does not go far beyond the borders of the United States. Worldwide, demand for oil is growing, and exploration and production are increasing as well.
 
 
At Least Prices Aren't Soaring
 
The recession has had at least one positive side effect. Consumer prices rose just 3.1 percent last year, the smallest rise since 1986 and barely half the rate of increase in 1990. The Labor Department said the inflation picture in December was about the same as it had been for months. Consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent after a gain of four-tenths of a percent in November.
 
 
Trucks, but Not Cars
 
All those shoppers who were thrifty in December did not rush to auto showrooms as the new year opened. Vehicle sales in the first 10 days of January slumped to an annual rate of 5.3 million, a dismal pace that was slower even than December's and than the beginning of last year, when war loomed in the Mideast. But there was one positive detail: Truck sales rose 6.7 percent in the latest period.
 
 
State of the Economy
 
Back from his foreign travels, President Bush ventured into New Hampshire to start his re-election campaign and to confront his domestic economic problems. "I probably have made mistakes in assessing the fact that the economy would recover," Mr. Bush said. He is aware of the economic decline, he asserted, while adding, "Maybe I haven't conveyed it as I should have." He indicated that he will outline his plans to address economic problems in his State of the Union address at the end of the month.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Citicorp, Think Rebound
 
Last year, it took more than mere mediocrity or even a stroke or two of bad luck for a company's stock to drop. Citicorp managed it, however, with huge loan losses, big employee cutbacks and rumors about management missteps. Bank stocks as a whole rose 67.3 percent in 1991; Citicorp fell 17.8 percent. But this week, Citicorp started to catch up with the rest of the pack. What news changed investors' minds about the nation's biggest banking company? Citicorp said it would lose as much as $150 million in the fourth quarter and $475 million for the full year. This announcement was no better than many analysts had predicted, but investors seemed elated that the news was not worse. And they apparently were cheered by predictions of profits in 1992. For the week, Citicorp's stock was up about 40 percent.
 
 
Some Sit Out the Super Bowl
 
The annual head shaking has begun about the stunning price of Super Bowl ads this year: $850,000 for 30 seconds. Certain prominent television advertisers, including Coca-Cola, have decided to sit this one out. Although CBS is offering package deals that combine the football game with spots in other game-day programs or in the Olympics, the network says it is confident that, as usual, all of the advertising time will eventually be sold -- and at the full price.
 
Air Space Subdivision
 
The Federal Communications Commission took the first steps toward clearing the air for new generations of wireless telephones. The move may ultimately allow a caller to find individuals anywhere in the world, no matter how far they wander off the beaten track. The F.C.C. proposed allowing the new technology to use some frequencies now reserved for police dispatching and utility companies. It also suggested that new customers could buy out existing frequency owners and underwrite their costs of moving to new frequencies.
 
 
Big Blue's Revenue Drops
 
I.B.M. reported a loss of $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter because of a $3.4 billion accounting charge to pay for corporate cost-cutting. For the full year, the giant computer company lost $2.8 billion, in part because of an additional big write-off to pay for retirees' health-care benefits. But perhaps the most striking feature of the report was the company's decline in revenues: 6.1 percent, to $64.8 billion, for 1991. It was I.B.M.'s first year-to-year drop in revenue since 1946. Analysts said this provided stark evidence that the computer industry is no longer a rapidly growing business. In light of this reality, I.B.M. has been cutting its costs. The company said 29,000 jobs were eliminated last year, considerably higher than the goal of 20,000, but it still plans to cut an additional 20,000 jobs in 1992. Still, investors found enough to like in I.B.M.'s report on Friday that the company' stock rose 87.5 cents a share, to $96.375.
 
 
Macy's Stalls on Payments
 
Off and on for months there have been rumors that R. H. Macy & Company was not paying its suppliers. Now it is documented. In the wake of disappointing Christmas sales, the company said it would postpone payments until Jan. 25. Macy's said agreements with several banks required it to reduce its borrowing and thus it was short on cash. Some suppliers worried that a bankruptcy filing might be next, but the company insisted that it had no such intention.
 
 
Bad Outlook for B-Schoolers
 
The job outlook for men and women who will receive master's degrees in business administration this spring is not good. According to Northwestern University's annual survey of corporate recruiting plans, employers expect to hire 8 percent fewer people with M.B.A.'s this spring. Even in financial firms, where business has been great lately, many of the jobs will go to people laid off elsewhere rather than to newly minted M.B.A.'s. But the news apparently has not reached prospective students. Duke University's business school says applications have increased 83 percent this year compared with the comparable date a year earlier. This could make for a good case study on the market forces working on prospective M.B.A.'s.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Bright Spot in Trade
 
The United States trade deficit was only $3.57 billion in November, the lowest monthly deficit in nearly nine years. Export sales climbed to $37.46 billion in the month, exceeding the record that had been set only a month earlier. The improvement in the deficit was attributable in part to the sluggish American economy, which caused retailers and others to cut back on overseas orders. Imports dropped 5.5 percent in November, to $41.03 billion. In light of the unexpectedly low deficit in November, the trade imbalance for the entire year will almost certainly drop below $100 billion for the first time since 1983.
 
 
The 'Names' Duck at Lloyd's
 
After 300 years, Lloyd's of London has proposed putting a ceiling on members' exposure to losses. Before this, its investors, known as "names," faced unlimited liability. Lloyd's, which is famous for providing insurance for almost any request, experienced huge losses in the late 80's, and some names were said to have been ruined. Under the new plan, a levy of one-quarter of 1 percent will be imposed on all members' participation to create a fund to cover names' extraordinary losses.
 
 
Another Nibble at A.T.&T.
 
The "telegraph" is no more, and now the "American" in A.T.&T.'s full name is less absolute than it used to be. Under a deal reached last week, the company will take a 39 percent stake in a venture to build and operate a modern long-distance telephone system in Ukraine. It is the first significant stake for A.T.&T. in a long-distance network in a foreign nation, and it is one of the first big agreements involving a leading American company and a former republic since the Soviet Union was disbanded last month.

HEADLINE: USAir Discovers There Is Life After a Messy Merger

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
Since taking over USAir last year, Seth E. Schofield has won high marks for making the best of a bad hand. But it is still far from clear that the troubled carrier, the country's fourth-largest airline, will wind up a winner.
When Mr. Schofield was promoted to chief executive, replacing Edwin I. Colodny, USAir was hemorrhaging. A pair of ambitious mergers in the late 80's, with Pacific Southwest Airlines and Piedmont Aviation, produced a raft of problems. The carrier had also been battered, along with the rest of the industry, by the effects of the recession and the Persian Gulf war. 
 USAir continues to bleed, but at a much slower rate. Costs have been cut, through a mix of layoffs, deferred orders of new planes and the closing of overlapping facilities. Many of the money-losing routes in PSA's highly competitive West Coast market have been dropped.
And some of the roughest edges of the messy Piedmont merger have been smoothed out. No longer -- or, at least, not nearly so often -- is the carrier referred to as Useless Air because of problems with flight delays, lost luggage and surly employees.
Losses could drop this year to as little as $145 million, said Paul P. Karos, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. That is less than a third of 1991's estimated loss of $457 million. Moreover, the company, based here, is cushioned by a $1.5 billion cash reserve.
"They have been very prudent," said Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley. "They have been husbanding their financial resources through very difficult times."
Things are even stable enough these days for Mr. Schofield to embark on a new program of domestic growth and consolidation. Earlier this month, USAir got final approval to buy a slew of takeoff and landing slots at New York's La Guardia Airport from Continental Airlines. And it recently agreed to operate the Trump Shuttle in the coveted Boston-Washington corridor.
But what Mr. Schofield and his staff say they cannot afford to do is expand just as aggressively abroad, where the biggest growth in traffic is expected over the next decade.
"Quite frankly," said Randall Malin, executive vice president of marketing, "we were not in the position to compete with the carriers with deep pockets."
As the airline industry contracts, however, the biggest carriers are getting even bigger by developing abroad. American, United and Delta have all been busy buying up foreign routes. The problem now facing Mr. Schofield is that USAir is in danger of becoming just a domestic feeder line for these global giants.
To be sure, USAir has a few toeholds abroad, with some service to Europe and the Caribbean. It just spent $50 million to acquire a London-to-Philadelphia route from Trans World Airlines. Eventually, USAir can make up some of its disadvantages by forming alliances with such major overseas carriers as British Airways or Lufthansa -- a course that it is already pursuing.
Nonetheless, for better or worse, USAir is sticking largely to its domestic knitting, continuing, in particular, to repair the damage from its merger with Piedmont.
"They ended up with too many hubs," said Dan Kasper, a consultant on international aviation at Harbridge House, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass. "They have to get that together."
USAir started out modestly as Allegheny Airlines, which built up a route system in the East. In 1972, the carrier made a big jump in size by acquiring Mohawk Airlines. When deregulation was introduced in 1978, the airline established a major hub in Pittsburgh and its fleet blanketed many Eastern markets. In 1979, it changed its name to USAir to reflect its wider reach, and in the late 80's, it made its biggest leap by acquiring PSA and Piedmont. The carrier now has 429 planes operating out of five hubs -- Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Charlotte, N.C., and Indianapolis.
USAir had no choice about expanding, analysts say, given the consolidation that was dramatically changing the nature of the industry. But the major breakdowns in service that grew out of the Piedmont merger could have been avoided, they say.
USAir was aware of the huge problems that Northwest Airlines encountered when it quickly took over Republic Airlines in 1987. Confusion about that merger and resentment between the two employee groups led to months of turmoil and years of ill-feeling at Northwest.
USAir was determined to avoid such an upheaval. Among other things, it raised the wages and benefits of Piedmont employees to the higher union levels of USAir.
But in an effort to minimize confusion and duplication, it decided that Piedmont employees would have to adopt the work methods and operations of the parent. Many from Piedmont balked, however, at the more rigid and bureaucratic ways of the larger carrier, which formally took over Piedmont in August 1989.
The result was often chaos. Large numbers of canceled flights played havoc with USAir's schedule and passenger complaints soared over missed connections, misplaced baggage and hostile or nonexistent service.
In hindsight, said Mike Schwab, senior vice president of operations, there was a basic contradiction in USAir's approach to the merger. The idea to use a "mirror image" strategy, recasting Piedmont in USAir's mold, was at odds with the goal of bringing together the best of both companies.
But while some union leaders and employees are still upset at the way the merger was carried out, most have put aside their bitterness, Mr. Schwab said. Passenger complaints have dropped so sharply that the carrier had the lowest rate in the industry in October.
"The problems of the merger are behind us," Mr. Schwab said.
Meanwhile, the airline has also moved to cut down its overhead, laying off 3,800 employees and sharply cutting back its flights out of Dayton, Ohio, a Piedmont hub.
It also phased out many of the smaller cities it served on the West Coast since it took over PSA in 1988.
The retrenchment, said the 52-year-old Mr. Schofield, "got us down to the point where we felt comfortable that we had matched capacity with demand."
As for going global, Mr. Schofield says he is not worried that USAir has fallen behind.
"We want to go international," he said. "It's important to go, but only out of those cities and hubs that make sense for us. We don't believe going everywhere in Europe is the end all."
Meanwhile he proudly described the dominant position that the airline is building in the New York area.
Now that the agreement to buy 62 jet slots at La Guardia has been approved by the Federal bankruptcy court overseeing Continental's Chapter 11 reorganization, USAir departures there will rise to 30 percent of the airport total, from 21 percent. Added service will include 12 daily flights to Florida, five nonstops to Atlanta and five nonstops to Chicago's Midway airport.
USAir is also gearing up to revamp the Trump Shuttle, which it will begin to manage after a final agreement is signed. The carrier plans to buy the shuttle at the end of five years, when it has the right of first refusal.
USAir is expanding operations in Pittsburgh as well. A new terminal there will open in October, expanding its gates to 52, from 36.
"We still see a lot of growth in the U.S.," Mr. Malin said. "The question for the industry is whether it will grow at 2, 4 or 8 percent a year. We don't know the answer to that."
The recession, higher fares and general belt-tightening by companies have reduced the frequency of business trips but the long-term impact will not be known until the economy recovers, he said.
Because of USAir's strong cash position and growing ability to stem its losses, most analysts believe that the carrier is in fairly good shape.
"There is no near-term cash flow problem whatsoever," said Mr. Karos, the industry analyst for First Boston, who recently did a liquidity analysis of the airline.
He warned, however, that a crunch could come later this year. "If there has been no turn in the economy, if there is no turn in the industry, then Chapter 11 may have to be invoked," he said.
But even if USAir went into Chapter 11, Mr. Karos said, it would have the strength to reorganize and not be forced to liquidate, as Pan American and Eastern were.
Mr. Karos added that if the airline were able to limit its losses this year to under $250 million there would be little danger of having to seek bankruptcy protection. One hurdle the carrier has to overcome, he said, is to win concessions from its major unions.
Further cost-cutting will not be easy, however. USAir flights are shorter than most, averaging 457 miles compared with about 800 miles for other major carriers. "We land and take off often," Mr. Schofield said, a schedule that adds to fuel and labor expenses and makes USAir one of the highest-cost airlines in the business.
Given all these constraints, USAir must still find a way to grow fast enough to remain one of the industry's major players.
"We recognize that we cannot shrink our way into prosperity," Mr. Schofield said.
 
COMPETING WITH ITSELF
 When USAir announced a year ago that it would drop Dayton International Airport as a hub, some of the painful costs of the carrier's 1989 merger with Piedmont Aviation were made clear.
USAir said that it had lost $45 million in Dayton, long one of Piedmont's most successful hubs, in the 18 months before it sharply curtailed operations there. But what the carrier did not say was that the Piedmont takeover had left it with too many hubs and that, in this case, it wound up cannibalizing one of its own.
Roy Williams, now the director of aviation at Dayton, worked for USAir as head of airport relations at the time of the merger. He recalled that the carrier ran flights to both its Pittsburgh and Dayton hubs that were convenient for business travelers from such points as Toledo and Detroit. Since Pittsburgh, long a USAir hub, had more connections, traffic to Dayton eventually began to decline.
"They were competing with themselves," he said.
While the cutback was justified -- other carriers had established themselves in such nearby hubs as Cincinnati (Delta), Cleveland (Continental) and Detroit (Northwest) -- it greatly fed the anger of Piedmont employees who were absorbed in the merger, Mr. Williams said.
Dayton International has not been able to fill the gap left by USAir's dwindling presence even though such carriers as American and Northwest have added flights.
"We have our hopes," Mr. Williams said. Meanwhile, the airport plans to break even this year through an increase in landing fees.

HEADLINE: All About/Packaging;
Learning to Wrap Products in Less -- or Nothing at All

 BODY:
Packaging, that ubiquitous staple of modern life, is big business, adding as much as $70 billion a year to the nation's economy. It protects goods from being tampered with and from being battered during the journey from factory to store. It preserves food and helps sell the products within.
It also represents a new way for financially strapped local governments, which bear the cost of disposing of garbage, to cut their costs. A variety of state legislative initiatives would force manufacturers to be accountable for a package after it was sold and thereby cut down on what is the fastest-growing component of the garbage crisis, accounting for more than 30 percent of the nation's municipal solid waste. 
 "While states like New York can't afford teachers, police, shelters for the homeless and full-time subways, packaging manufacturers unthinkingly foist millions of dollars of expenses onto us all every day," said Allen Hershkowitz, a scientist at the National Resources Defense Council.
Redundant packaging, environmentalists argue, includes boxes, for perfume bottles say, that are in turn covered in plastic wrapping; single-serving foods that produce far more waste packaging per ounce of edibles than larger-sized servings, and compact disks sold in packages 10 times the volume of the disk itself.
 
'Date and Rate' Laws
How Much Can Be Recycled, and When
 One of the most watched of the state actions was a bill introduced in Massachusetts last yearproposing to ban by the mid-1990's any packaging that does not meet certain reuse or recycling standards. Although it died at the end of the year, environmentalists are now trying to revive it.
The bill, referred to in the industry as a "dates and rates" measure, was expected by many environmentalists to serve as a prototype in other states.
Specifically, it would have banned packaging by July 1, 1996, that could not be reused at least five times, 25 percent of whose raw materials are not recyclables or 25 percent of whose contents are not being recycled. The recycling requirement would increase to 35 percent by 1999 and 50 percent by 2000. The bill was passed by the House and had the support of Gov. William Weld, but it died in the Senate.
The bill was vigorously opposed by manufacturers and retailers of packaged goods, who argue that recycling mandates are impractical in places where recycling facilities do not exist or are very limited. Only one type of plastic, the material found in large soda bottles, is being commercially recycled now, so under the law, most plastic packaging would in effect be banned.
"Dates and rates will ban the safest and most effective food packaging," said Jeffrey Nedelman, vice president of the Grocery Manufacturers Association, one of the leading opponents of such measures. For example, he said, no good replacement exists for the plastic foam and clear wrap used to package meat. "Safeway tried going back to the cardboard that was used 20 years ago as an experiment in Oregon and it failed," Mr. Nedelman said. "The cardboard absorbs blood and sticks to the meat after it's been in the freezer."
Even so, supporters of the measure, led by the Massachusetts Public Interest Research Group, intend to try again in the legislature and plan to take the initiative to voters on the fall ballot if they fail. "We have the signatures, so if we don't have a legislative agreement by the end of May, we will go ahead," said Amy Perry, an official of Masspirg, as the group is known.
Meanwhile, similar bills are being filed in other states and at the Federal level. "We are looking at six states with serious dates and rates legislation this year," said Mr. Nedelman. He said it was unclear what would happen in Congress, but noted that Representative Al Swift, a Washington Democrat and the chairman of a key subcommittee of the Committee on Energy and Commerce, had introduced a bill patterned on the Massachusetts proposal.
Another proposal making the rounds would establish a ratio between product and packaging. It would mandate that no more than a certain percentage of the total volume of an item -- N.R.D.C. favors 10 percent -- is package rather than the product itself.
 
Stores Can Help
Displaying Products In the Raw
 There is a precedent for making manufacturers and retailers responsible for disposal of packaging. In Germany, manufacturers are now required to collect and recycle the cartons used to ship products to stores. As time goes on, German retailers will have to allow customers to remove purchases from packages and leave the packages at the store.
Sensing similar trends in the United States, some manufacturers and retailers are already changing their packaging. McDonald's 1990 initiative to abandon foam polystyrene hamburger boxes in favor of a less bulky wrap of paper and flexible plastic is the most celebrated example.
Sears, Roebuck and Company is working with its suppliers to reduce packaging by 25 percent by the end of 1994. The company estimates the program will eliminate 1.5 million tons of packaging a year by the end of 1994 and save it $5 million a year.
In some stores, Sears is displaying its Craftsman brand hand tools like pliers and screwdrivers on racks without any packaging. Once the no-package program is expanded to 500 stores, the company said, it will eliminate 78 tons of plastic a year.
Wal-Mart Stores and the K-Mart Corporation had previous begun similar, though less extensive, packaging reduction programs.
 
A Design Problem
New Ways to Catch the Consumer's Eye
 At least initially, the trend could be a boon to package design firms.
"Most of our clients are now listing environmental friendliness as a design objective," said Richard Gerstman, managing partner of Gerstman and Meyers, a package design firm in New York. "A few years ago it did not even come up."
For example, he said, hardware that formerly had been sold in cardboard and plastic "blister packs" may now be displayed in boxes. A blister pack is typically split open to get at the material inside and then discarded. But a box might be used to store unused components and not go immediately into the trash.
Some consumer goods marketers are reluctant to simplify or reduce packaging because that is what does the final selling job on the store shelf. But Mr. Gerstman said they can get the product identification without a large billboard. In the past, he said, many bottled products also had cardboard outer containers. When the outer container was eliminated, he said, designers simply made the label on the bottle larger and more noticeable to attract the eye of shoppers.
 
 
COMPETING WITH ITSELF
 Recessions are bad for recycling programs. Last year, the demand for reclaimed materials dropped because manufacturers were making fewer products and because the price of the virgin raw materials slipped.
While materials made of recycled products are less expensive, manufacturers often prefer the virgin materials because, among other things, they are easier to source.
With mandatory recycling programs in place in many areas of the country, materials brokers said, glass, aluminum and plastic containers continue to pour into collection centers, regardless of demand. With excess supply chasing inadequate demand, prices took a beating.
According to Recycling Times, a publication of the National Solid Waste Management Association, prices for glass containers, aluminum beverage cans and plastic bottles fell to near record lows in 1991. By year-end green glass, which comes into the country carrying imported wines and beer, had no value at all, according to the newspaper's price survey.
The price paid by brokers for aluminum cans fell from almost 30 cents a pound at the beginning of the year to barely more than 20 cents by the end, according to the survey. The value of clear polyethylene terepthalate, which is used in large soda bottles, fell from almost 7 cents a pound to 1.2 cents.
Prices may firm up this year, brokers say, with the expected startup of new plants to process reclaimed materials.

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
For some people, coin collecting is a love, and for others it is a legacy. Often, a coin collection cherished by the original owner is passed on to heirs who have neither the interest nor the expertise to know what to do with all those old nickels and quarters.
The first thing to do is to figure out which of three different types of collections you've inherited. There's the true collection, one for which the collector spent hours poring through catalogues and browsing in coin shops, carefully selecting the best pieces he could afford. Such a collection can take years to build and is usually handsomely packaged and meticulously catalogued. It probably includes sales records for coins bought and sold and a list of each coin in the collection. 
 The second type is the collection built from the coins of everyday life. Usually all United States currency, the coins may have come from change in the grocery or delicatessen and probably show some wear and tear. But often some fine specimens show up in such a collection.
One collector, the owner of a coin laundry, built quite a good collection from the change boxes in his washers and dryers. Over the years, his careful attention to lint-covered coins paid off.
The third type of collection is the one most people are familiar with: a jar, sometimes huge, containing loose pocket change. Possibly a large part of the national debt is cloistered this way and perhaps a small part of the international balance of payments, as most leftover pesos and francs and marks from trips abroad go into this collection, too.
No matter which of the three types of collection is bequeathed, the same rule applies: Know what you have. For the last two types, it is best to go to a local coin dealer and buy "A Guidebook of United States Coins" by R. S. Yoeman, published annually by the Western Publishing Company. It is available by mail from Donovan Music and Toy Distributors, where it is listed as item No. 9051-92. The cost is $8.95, plus $3 shipping and handling, from the company at 732 Clinton Street, Waukesha, Wis. 53186; (800) 236-7123.
The guidebook is also referred to as the Red Book, and it shows the best price paid for each type of United States coin in the preceding year. This gives some indication of the value of each coin. In the front of the book is a chapter on grading coins. Although no one will become an expert simply by reading that chapter, one can become familiar with the grading system.
With the book in hand, go through the collection, assessing each coin's condition and then checking its approximate value. Take notes on each coin that seems valuable. Put the ones that are not valuable into a separate pile: no matter how common and battered a quarter may be, it's still worth 25 cents.
If you want to sell the coins that seem to have some additional value, take them to the coin dealer from whom you bought the Red Book. Ask what the dealer will offer, then take the coins to several other dealers. Take the best offer.
If the offers seem low compared with the Red Book values, don't feel that you are being cheated. The book price is the highest price paid for a particular coin. It does not mean that the same coin will sell for the same price again.
Also, the coin market is a little slow these days because of the recession and because coin collecting is not as popular as it was years ago. A dealer might have to hold your coins for some time before he can resell them. And a dealer may make no offer at all because he already has plenty of what you are selling. You can hold on to the coins until prices go up.
Finally, if your inheritance is a true collection, try getting in touch with the company that dealt with the collector. Usually the original collector will be well known in the small community of serious collectors.
Established dealers are usually listed in the Yellow Pages. Complaints about dealers may be on record at the Better Business Bureau. Also, the American Numismatic Association (818 North Cascade Avenue, Colorado Springs 80903; 719-632-2646) can tell you about any complaints it has received about specific dealers. But it will not recommend one dealer over another.
Established dealers may offer appraisal services. They may offer to buy the collection or sell it at auction, or they will suggest someone who might. The cost of an appraisal varies with the size of the collection and the location. In New York, a dealer's written appraisal of a small collection of fewer than 100 coins will probably cost $50 to $100.
Of course, after all this work with coins, you may find that you have been bitten by the collecting bug yourself.

HEADLINE: Guess We Just Don't Figure in U.S. Car Makers' Marketing Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While experts decide who to blame for the American auto industry's problems, I'd like to tell my story of trying to buy an American car. 
 I am a self-employed woman who likes to drive a five-speed, manual-transmission car. In December I went shopping to replace an eight-year-old Honda Accord (my second). Even though I have been happy with my Hondas, I was concerned about our national economy. So I decided to make a concerted effort to find an American equivalent. Surely, I reasoned, American marketing savvy would produce an American version of such a popular, top-selling five-speed car. Here's what happened:
My first stop was Ford, where the stick-shift options were a lower priced Escort or top-of-the-line Taurus, which had more "bells and whistles" than I wanted and cost $11,000 more than I wanted to spend. Ford's other moderate-priced cars didn't come with manual transmission.
Next stop, Pontiac. I liked the Grand Am and the price was right. It seemed like a good alternative to the Accord. But the salesman had no five-speed cars for me to road test. He offered to order one if I left a $300 deposit. "If you don't like it, all you'll lose is your $300," he explained.
Because the Grand Am really looked like a possibility, I pursued it further and went to another town where a Pontiac dealer had a car for me to test drive. The clutch was nice and smooth and the car handled well. However, General Motors redesigned the 1992 Grand Am and added a center console with a covered catch-all between the front seats. Every time I shifted gears my elbow hit the hard plastic cover that serves as an armrest. Nothing could be done about it.
The salesman noted that his wife, who is my height (5 foot 3), drives the 1991 Grand Am and would have the same problem with the '92 model I did. I suggested he inform G.M.'s powers-that-be that they redesigned themselves out of a customer, that they should be more sensitive to people like me. He said he wouldn't because they would only accuse him of not being able to make the sale.
Fourth stop Buick, because my son-in-law suggested I look at the Skylark. There I was told that Buick makes no cars at all with a stickshift.
Last stop Honda -- and my third five-speed Honda Accord. Now I drive it without feeling guilty. I really tried, but American car makers have not factored me into their marketing plans.
 
PHYLLIS SINRICH
Stamford, Conn., Jan. 9, 1992

HEADLINE: No Cinderella Story for Russian Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a member of the three-author panel on Key Issues of Soviet Economic Reform at last week's American Economics Association meetings, I was taken aback by your news article "Russians Urged to Act Fast" (Business Day, Jan. 6) reporting agreement on questions concerning privatization and stabilization, and the type and amounts of aid required: full speed on the former, and a maximally open spigot on the latter. There was no such agreement. 
 Wanting rapid privatization is like opting for fraternity and liberty. The issue is how fast it can really proceed and if it cannot be fast, what this implies for economic policymaking.
Experience everywhere, including that of Margaret Thatcher, whose firm intentions are beyond doubt, and of Poland, demonstrates the many roadblocks, economic and political, privatization faces. Just imagine: how rapidly will buyers be found for most of the obsolete industrial dinosaurs in the former Soviet Union?
At the meetings I discussed the difficulties of land privatization in the former Soviet republics, a minor issue in Poland where collectivization had not occurred significantly.
For instance, there are few land records and assessments of quality variations without which farms cannot be subdivided equitably among families. Again, the massive size of the farms means that the heavy tractors designed for them will be unsuitable for the small farms resulting from the division of the cropland among the farm households. Cooperative use of the tractors, and eventual redesigning of new tractors, will be necessary: both will take careful planning, institution building and therefore time. Slogans will not suffice.
Equally, stabilization is now the crying need. The Russian budget deficit, fueling inflation, is 15 to 20 percent of its national income. But bringing it down to zero in three months, as early reports of advice to President Boris N. Yeltsin indicated, is surely not feasible. And if seriously attempted, it would create massive dislocation and unemployment: it would be like slamming the brakes in a car speeding at 100 miles per hour. Is this good advice?
The aid conference scheduled toward the end of the month in Washington will need to keep away from such follies. It will also need to focus on two salient political and economic realities:
* The infancy, at best, of the political culture of democracy and of the economic institutions of capitalism makes the former Soviet republics worthy recipients of technical assistance and unworthy candidates for large-scale financial aid. Megabuck plans, fashionable last year, are both costly and unsuitable to the task.
* A combination of the fear of lapse into anarchy and the presence of a multitude of missiles drives us toward assisting these countries. Why not tie, with delicacy but firmness, our aid into the destruction of these missiles? "Nukes for dollars," like debt relief for environment, is an idea whose time has come. It should unite both Democrats and Republicans behind an effort that otherwise lacks political appeal.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, Jan. 9, 1992
 
The writer, a professor of economics at Columbia University, is the author of "Perestroika in Perspective."

HEADLINE: Whose Welfare?;
The Poor, They Are Different, and in '92, Ever More Invisible

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H.

 BODY:
THE Democratic candidates for President, anxious to woo back the disaffected middle class, have all but abandoned their traditional role as champions of the disenfranchised.
It is almost an oversight, this eerie silence on the campaign trail about issues that affect the poor. But it is a telling omission for the party that had traditionally spoken for the disadvantaged, especially during a battle over whether states should cut entitlement programs to balance strained budgets. 
 In New Jersey, California, Michigan, Tennessee, Illinois, Massachusetts and Wisconsin, welfare programs have emerged as a popular cash cow for strapped treasuries. In some cases -- as in New Jersey -- the budget cuts have come attached to proposals designed to limit family size. In others, the reductions in general aid have slashed across the board.
But if these remarkable changes of direction have been the subject of heated debate in state capitals -- Jesse Jackson marched in Lansing, Mich., last week -- they have been largely ignored on the campaign trail.
Instead, wooing the middle class has become all the rage. They are angry and they vote. What Presidential candidate could resist?
None, apparently. The major candidates for President are campaigning during a protracted recession that pitched President Bush onto the political defensive as he made his first appearance in New Hampshire last week and has let the Democrats make their case.
But the candidates have built their campaigns around middle-class tax cuts, capital-gains tax cuts and universal health care programs designed to appeal to middle-class workers. Their consultants have searched out the code phrases that might turn off middle-class voters by suggesting that they favor welfare.
When Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas commiserates with New Hampshire voters about how the unemployment rolls there have been swollen by middle-class people, he gets approving nods and applause. When the Democratic contender is asked about the New Jersey welfare-cut proposal awaiting the signature of the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, he equivocates, saying that he lacks specifics on the New Jersey plan.
 
'Compassion Fatigue'
 Even Senator Tom Harkin, the most outspoken defender of traditional Democratic values in the field, has only addressed poverty as a campaign issue in what one of his advisers described as "a thematic sense." Like the other candidates, he talks about child care and child-support enforcement, said Lorraine Voles, a Harkin campaign spokeswoman. But such questions are discussed far more often in the context of what Ms. Voles called the "middle-class squeeze."
In their messages for 1992, the candidates seem to have scrubbed poverty from their agendas. If they talk about the poor at all, it is to promote ideas like earned income-tax credits. Dependency is not in vogue.
"Polls are showing these guys that people are feeling a compassion fatigue," said Robert Borosage, an analyst for the Institute for Policy Studies in Washington who advised Mr. Jackson in 1988. "They're tired of the homeless, tired of poor people. In some sense, it's a great retreat to the conservative agenda."
Take the word "needy." It sometimes seems to have been effectively redefined to mean those who are considered to be otherwise capable of earning $50,000 or more a year.
 
Losing a Voice
 "Nobody's speaking for poor people," said Kevin Gray, an adviser to Senator Harkin in South Carolina.
And the candidates' staffs as much as admit it.
Paul Tsongas' "definition of liberalism is expanding the pie," said Peggy Connolly of Mr. Tsongas' staff.
"It doesn't come up a lot," said Steve Jarding, a spokesman for Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. "It is a campaign geared to a middle class pinched very hard in the 1980's. The haves got more and the have-nots got less, but the tax burden fell on the middle class."
It's a message that falls on receptive ears at campaign rallies, events that poor people may not have the motivation or the bus fare to attend. But, if anything, their plight is more desperate than it has been in years.
Last fall, the Census Bureau reported that the poverty rate rose sharply in 1990 and that declining incomes forced 2 million more people below the Federal poverty line -- $10,419 for a family of three. By the end of the year, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington policy research organization that specializes in poverty issues, reported that 40 states cut or froze benefits to families with children.
The five major Democratic contenders will have two opportunities to address such issues in Washington this week before the United States Conference of Mayors and Mr. Jackson's Rainbow Coalition.
It is an interesting dilemma for the Democrats, who are working assiduously to shed any Republican effort to tag them as tax-and-spend liberals. Michael S. Dukakis was never able to fully escape such a characterization.
The other problem is that, for ill or good, the problems of the poor have become inextricably bound up in the thorny question of race. David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard, garnered the majority of the white vote in the Louisiana governor's race by alluding frequently to undeserving welfare recipients.
During the last two Presidential elections, the Democrats were able to conveniently sidestep the whole matter by ceding the issue of the disadvantaged and the disenfranchised to Jesse Jackson.
"The unmentionable in all of this is race," said Mr. Borosage. "What this represents for Democrats is a kind of assumption that people think of poor people as African-American and Hispanic."
But, in a politically twisted way, there could be good news in the offing for the disenfranchised. Absent Mr. Jackson's overwhelmingly popular presence, white candidates will probably be more likely to lobby for black votes. And they will remain ever mindful that many blacks, too, are middle class.
And in the final analysis, candidates seem to realize that even many of the poor don't like to call themselves poor. "We all want to think we're middle class, even if we're not," said Andres Gonzalez, a former executive director of the Texas Mexican-American Democrats, which recently endorsed Governor Clinton.
It is not as if the candidates never come in contact with the needy. Last weekend, Bill Clinton toured a soup kitchen in Keene, N.H., while last Friday, Mr. Tsongas toured a Boston homeless shelter. But these often have the air of side trips.
Some advocates hope that poverty will return as a campaign issue when the campaigns leave the largely rural early primary states and travel to industrial ones.
"Frankly, it has more to do with the fact that the poor are not a powerful constituency," said Jennifer Vasiloff, the executive director of the Coalition on Human Needs, an antipoverty group based in Washington.
The candidates deny this. Helping the economy will help all income groups, they say. And the poor will reap their share of the benefit.
Mr. Borosage noted that organized labor and some other advocacy groups have already accepted this approach as pragmatic and the best way to win the general election. "A lot of the organized activists are prepared in fact to make that deal," he said. "But poor people aren't prepared to make that deal."

HEADLINE: Salvador Warily Prepares for War's Aftermath

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AS though the civil war in El Salvador were dying a human death, faces from the whole course of the conflict seemed to flash before Government and rebel leaders as they made their ceremonious peace here last week. A Catholic Church human rights advocate sat at the treaty signing not far from a conservative businessman whose family was reputed to have financed paramilitary death squads. A few feet away, a retired Army colonel who has become one of the country's more garrulous right-wing politicians could look over at one of the guerrilla commanders whom he had once fought.
Across the ideological spectrum, no one save a few bewildered young guerrillas and a few more military officers acted as though there might have been anything they had lost. Dr. Charles Clements, an American physician who spent a year tending to rebel wounded on a strategic Salvadoran volcano, had a pleasant chat with one Salvadoran Army general; Jennifer Jean Casolo, an American religious worker who was once jailed by the Salvadoran security forces on charges of stockpiling weapons for the guerrillas, shook hands with another. The United States Ambassador to El Salvador, William G. Walker, wrapped an arm around Joaquin Villalobos, the guerrilla commander whom American officials had most despised, and talked about having lunch back in San Salvador one day soon. 
 Yet if the breadth of the celebration was startling after so many months of bitter, forced compromise, it also seemed to give way easily to sober considerations of what lay ahead. All of the conciliatory words between the rebel leadership and President Alfredo Cristiani suggested a gathering tolerance on both sides; they did not change any minds about what further reforms El Salvador should undertake or how. Even as the bloodletting was brought to a formal halt after 75,000 deaths, there was a sense among people who had participated or merely suffered in it that a far less violent struggle for political control would not necessarily be much less intense.
Along with the recognition that the war could not be won and had become a severe political liability to whomever was seen to perpetuate it, a confluence of changes helped stop the fighting. As the Bush Administration quietly abandoned the Reagan quest to vanquish a perceived Marxist threat, Congressional Democrats reduced American military aid. With the evaporation of Cuba's allies in Eastern Europe, the Salvadoran rebels began to distance themselves from Cuba's Government. And even before their election defeat in early 1990, Nicaragua's Sandinistas could no longer afford the Salvadorans uncompromising support. But while those shifts helped moderate Salvadoran politics, they did less to alter the economic inequalities and democratic failings that have always been the war's essential fuel.
There is little question that if fully implemented the treaty would bring many changes. Mr. Cristiani has long blamed the outbreak of war primarily on the repression -- much of it sponsored or carried out by his more radical allies -- that virtually shut off the possibility of legal politics to the democratic left. And as he has quietly allowed wider margins of press freedom and political activity, he has agreed to measures that should lift the remaining political restraints and halve the military's size to about 31,000 troops.
Nonetheless, some critics of the Government argued that the treaty would not end extremist violence, particularly from the right, the impunity of the military officer corps, or the corruption that has fed on more than $4 billion in United States aid over the last decade. Nor, as Mr. Villalobos hinted after the treaty was signed, would it necessarily keep the 6,000 or so armed rebels from responding in kind to any violence that might take place between the start of the formal cease-fire on Feb. 1 and the destruction of the insurgents' arms in late October.
The treaty promises land to peasants in rebel-held zones and the possibility of partial ownership for some workers in state enterprises that are to be privatized. It is also certain to give a new thrust to the economy, which has managed surprising growth over the last two years despite the war's enormous strain. By itself, however, the settlement does little to resolve a disparity of incomes that the war has left only more skewed, or to raise real wages that have fallen almost every year since 1980. Though many of El Salvador's rich have grown richer, only 46 of them paid taxes on income of more than $2,500, according to Christian Democratic Party figures.
How effectively or democratically the political party that emerges from the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front will pursue economic and social change can only be guessed. Several rebel officials said their party may not run a presidential candidate in the 1994 elections. Instead, they would back a coalition of leftist and centrist parties they hope will stretch as far as the liberal faction of the divided Christian Democrats.
Some analysts believe that the former guerrillas could become the country's most disciplined and organized political force almost instantly and still not far surpass the low levels of support they have received in opinion surveys.
 
Fragile Changes
 The rebels have always dismissed such polls as distorted by the fears that the war has so ingrained in Salvadorans. But it would not be at all surprising if they found that their most effective tactics were the sort of street demonstrations and civil disobedience that the military and rightists attacked violently a decade ago.
It may be the clearest measure of the fragility of change that both sides seized on the presence of foreign dignitaries at their peace-making to plead for help in verifying the agreements and rebuilding the country. Already, the United Nations is sending more than 1,000 military and police observers to monitor the treaty's implementation. The many pledges of help, however, seemed to add up to far less than the $1.8 billion that Mr. Cristiani said reconstruction would cost.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was among the guests in Mexico City unwilling to commit to any specific levels of aid, and there seemed to be an unusual degree of bipartisanship to his circumspection. "This is not an environment in which anyone in the Administration or Congress is thinking about making money available, because it is needed elsewhere," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs and supports reconstruction aid. "It has unfortunately become something of a national tradition that we are willing to spend billions to win a military conflict but withhold millions that would insure that peace is sustained."
