HEADLINE: The World;
What Kind of Economy Would a Palestine Have?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

DATELINE: BEIT SAHUR, Israeli-Occupied West Bank

 BODY:
ISSA ABUAITAH and his 200 employees at the Jordan Plastics Company make mattresses, housewares and industrial containers in this village, a 10-minute drive from Jerusalem. The factory, wedged between stone houses, is no high-tech wonder: machines mixing polyurethane foam and quilting mattress covers get a lot of help from human hands. But Jordan Plastics competes successfully in Israeli markets because its products are well made and its labor costs are low. And just such enterprises, analysts have begun to say, represent the main chance for prosperity in an autonomous or independent Palestine.
The current negotiations over the future of the West Bank and Gaza Strip are still at only the earliest stage. Last week, announcements that two right-wing parties would leave Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's coalition in outrage that the Israeli leader would even consider autonomy, underscored how tentative the talks are. But if autonomy ever appeared likely, economic factors would soar in importance. Already, experts are looking at the possibilities, and many agree on one principle: The viability of an autonomous Palestinian economy would depend on keeping it open to the world in general, and to Israel in particular. 
 From 1948 to 1967, when Israeli occupation began, the West Bank was a poverty-ridden region of Jordan; Gaza, ruled by Egypt, was a patch of desert crowded with refugees. It is no wonder, says Howard Rosen of the International Institute of Economics in Washington, that two-thirds of the natural increase in population from 1952 to 1967 was offset by emigration.
Since 1967, Israel has spent little to develop the economic potential of Arabs in the territories. But just opening the borders allowed large numbers of Palestinians to commute to jobs in Israel, starting an economic boom that doubled average incomes by 1980. On the eve of the Arab uprising in 1987, one out of three wage earners was a commuter and their earnings constituted one-quarter of West Bank and Gaza income.
Whoever leads any future Palestinian entity will have strong political reasons to back away from the Israeli connection. But Palestinian economists may well have different advice. George Abed, an exile who heads the Welfare Association, a Palestinian development group in Geneva, says the number of workers "would eventually have to decline." But he acknowledges that many commuters' jobs could not soon be replaced. Nor do Palestinian economists think integration with Jordan would work. The West Bank and Jordanian economies are too similar to gain much from trade, says Hishan Awartani, an economist at Al Najah University in Nablus. "Heading east," he says, "is a myth."
However, if some Palestinian economists are reconciled to retaining links with Israel, they are determined to change the terms. The occupation, argues Osama Hamed, who teaches at Temple University in Philadelphia, has generated a "one-sided customs union" in which Israel buys selectively from Palestinians while requiring them to pay full tariffs on imports. In an analysis for the Institute for Social and Economic Policy in the Middle East at Harvard, he estimates that Israel skims one-fifth of West Bank income.
Israeli economists scoff at this figure. But Ezra Sadan, who heads a Government commission on the economic future of the territories, is scathing in his criticism of the way the territories are regulated. His recommendation to Israeli occupation forces would be not to lift a finger "to protect the Israeli market."
 
'Unbelievably Neglected'
 Plans for developing a Palestinian economy that have been drawn up privately by Arabs and Israelis turn out to be remarkably similar. Ephraim Ahiran, a Hebrew University economist, thinks the starting point should be a huge investment in roads, communications, housing and medical care. "The infrastructure," he says, "is unbelievably neglected." He agrees with Mr. Abed that $10 billion to $15 billion over a decade would be appropriate. Professor Ahiran says the money, presumably from gulf Arabs and the West, would create an "aid-led development boom" in which Palestinians could accumulate skills and capital.
Could an autonomous Palestinian economy succeed? The West Bank has little arable land and no natural resources, save the stone quarried to build houses in Israel. Gaza is isolated and overpopulated. And there is always an impulse to try short cuts. "All new states make the same three mistakes," quips Ephraim Kleiman, an economist at Hebrew University. "They inflate, they protect markets, they create bureaucracies. Israel is a prime example."
But the territories' intangible assets include an educated labor force and a natural base for tourism. Perhaps most important, many Palestinians who emigrated to the gulf and North America have proved their mettle in business. Even some in the West Bank are doing well. Dozens of shoe factories undercut Israeli prices. Haddad Ltd., a farm implement maker in Jenin, has used Italian designs to put rival Israeli plow manufacturers out of business. Mr. Abuaitah of Jordan Plastics seethes with impatience for a chance to invest in new product lines and compete in world markets. "The West Bank will be easy to develop," he says. "I'm not afraid."
In addition, Israel might well see a self-interest in making a Palestinian economy work. "For our own security," says Professor Sadan, "we have to keep them well fed." Professor Awartani, a cautious optimist on development, doubts that Israel will have to do much feeding. Some day soon, he says only half-jokingly, "Palestinians and Israelis will be jetting around on the same planes, selling to the same sheiks."

HEADLINE: Balancing Nature's Claims and International Free Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS a filling for sandwiches, tuna long ago gained a hallowed spot among the nation's favorite lunchtime staples.
But as the focus of a dispute between the United States and 30 other nations, the simple tuna sandwich is proving to be a far more complex emblem of an enormously risky change in the world's commerce, the linking of ecological concerns to international trade. 
 Earlier this month, efforts by American environmentalists to protect natural resources through trade restrictions were advanced considerably when a Federal District judge in San Francisco ruled that the Government must ban more than half the imports of yellowfin tuna to protect dolphins. Business leaders, though, called the decision a dangerous precedent that could prompt Mexico and the 29 other nations affected to counter with restrictions on American exports, or increase tensions in efforts by Mexico and the Bush Administration to reach a free trade agreement.
At a time when exports of American products are, arguably, the strongest sector of the United States economy, business leaders are concerned about either potential outcome. The Commerce Department reported last week that exports in November totaled $37.5 billion, a record, and the monthly trade deficit was $3.57 billion, the lowest in nine years.
"The dolphin issue has really brought things to a boil," said Abraham Katz, president of the United States Council for International Business, an affiliate of the International Chamber of Commerce that is based in New York. "American environmentalists are not only attacking Mexico, but the whole system of world trade to support their concept of sustainable economic development. It could easily prompt a backlash."
 
Trade vs. Commerce
 Before the fight over tuna, the world had used separate forums in its attempts to solve environmental and trade disputes. Businessmen turned to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 44-year-old treaty administered by an international agency in Geneva that has served to regulate world trade. Environmentalists established a tradition of acting on ecological problems with national laws and international treaties. The dispute over tuna illustrates what can happen when trade rules under GATT collide with ecological protections.
Because dolphins swim over schools of yellowfin tuna in the Pacific, thousands drown yearly in fishermen's nets. The Marine Mammal Protection Act was passed by Congress in 1972 to limit the slaughter in the American fleet to 20,500 dolphins a year and in 1988 a new amendment directed the Department of Commerce to ban imports of tuna from foreign fleets, including from Mexico, that had higher levels of dolphin kills.
In 1990, when the Department of Commerce finally barred imports from Mexico and four other countries, Mexico filed its own complaint with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In October, a three-member GATT panel decided in Mexico's favor because, it said, dolphins were killed in foreign and international waters and the United States had no authority to extend its environmental laws to a sovereign nation.
On Jan. 9, Thelton E. Henderson, chief judge of the Federal District Court in San Francisco, ignored the GATT panel ruling and raised the prospect of greater tension when he decided that the Government must bar roughly half of the 266,000 metric tons of tuna imported in the United States. Judge Henderson determined that Mexico, Venezuela and Vanuatu, a group of islands in the southwest Pacific, were shipping outlawed tuna to the United States through 27 other countries in violation of United States law.
Such clashes are certain to increase as conservation groups become more aggressive and declining economic conditions in many regions of the world compel nations to step up their use of natural resources. In fact, economic desperation is beginning to erode some of the historic international environmental agreements.
Last month, Iceland announced it was withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission in June, a move clearly intended to enable Iceland's fishermen to resume commercial whaling. South Africa and several other southern African nations are pressing to change provisions in the 1973 treaty to protect endangered species in order to begin killing the region's last African elephants for ivory.
Alarmed that more nations may be prepared to roll back hard-fought gains on the environment, conservation groups now are looking to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade as a means for reducing ecological damage by rewriting its provisions. The United States and other governments agree that the GATT needs to examine the relationship between trade and environmental protection. But they also insist that the issue be excluded from negotiations on international trade, currently at a difficult stage.
Both sides are clearly aware that the idea of joining ecological ideals with trade is fraught with hazards. Economists have found that rising prosperity tends to reduce pollution by providing the means for paying for controls. Others worry that the cost of complying with the environmental standards of industrialized countries could lead to greater impoverishment and pollution in underdeveloped nations like Mexico.
"The one way out of this dilemma between free trade and the environment is to set uniformly high standards," said Hilary French, a senior researcher at the Worldwatch Institute, an environmental group in Washington.
The 12 nations of the European Community are considering levying a tax on carbon dioxide and other byproducts of burning coal and oil to control gases believed by some scientists to cause global warming. But such a measure could make some European industries uncompetitive unless other nations followed. "In the world of trade, we're no longer the biggest player," said Mr. Katz of the United States Council for International Business. "It goes both ways now. Any of the environmental goals we press on other countries, there are some out there that can do the same thing to us."

(Camerapix/Gamma-Liaison, Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Region;
Learning to Be Vicious Can Begin at Home

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
AFTER 10 days of almost daily reports of racially motivated attacks on children throughout the city by other young people, Mayor David N. Dinkins had nearly exhausted his supply of adjectives to describe the disgust and anger he felt.
Finally on Wednesday, on the occasion of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, the Mayor asked an audience at the Waldorf-Astoria, "Who taught our children to hate so thoroughly and so mercilessly?" 
 It is a question many New Yorkers are asking as the incidents continue. These almost surreal acts of violence and humiliation are a reminder of what child-education experts, civil libertarians and the clergy have been saying for years: that society has been failing in its duty to teach children not to hate.
Mr. Dinkins told the N.A.A.C.P. at the Waldorf Astoria that he found the crimes reprehensible. "But I cannot find it in my heart to blame children alone for these deeds," he said, adding that he was issuing a "loud wake-up call to the adults of our city."
"The problem of violence is best addressed not in the Mayor's office but in your office," he said. "Not in the Blue Room but in your children's room. Not in City Hall but in city schools and city streets."
The call comes none too soon, said Michael Meyers, who directs the New York Civil Rights Coalition. "It's becoming fashionable to hate," he said. "And since you're not going to be punished for being violent, it's become pedestrian, and commonplace and acceptable."
The current series of incidents began Jan. 6 when two black children, a 14-year-old boy and his sister, 12, were set upon by four whites as they walked to school. They robbed them, cut off some of the girl's hair and then smeared them with sneaker polish.
While the two children were not badly hurt physically, the ugly episode tore at their psyches. The boy said he felt he could no longer trust white people. His mother, Nellie Wilson, her heart breaking as her own anger welled up, tried to talk him out of rash judgments.
"If they hadn't put paint on them, I could have taken it. I would have been angry, but not like this," Mrs. Wilson said. "But the painting, the cutting the girl's hair and the racial slurs, that's the part that bothers me.
"This world is so vast, so big, big, big," she said, close to tears herself. "Why can't we get along?"
Several experts say the incidents also reflect a recession-fed tension in the increasingly multicultural society in overcrowded cities.
Most hate crimes, said Jack McDevitt, a sociologist at Northeastern University in Boston, are about turf. In an analysis of 452 bias crimes in the Boston area in the 1980's, he found that most involved someone walking, driving through or working in a neighborhood, or a family moving in. Almost a third of the perpetrators were white men under 30 years old.
"Sometimes these are people who are going through difficulties of their own," he said. "They might see violence in their own homes. If their father hits their mother, they have to think, well, my father loves my mother. So it becomes easier to beat up on someone who is black that they don't care for at all.
"In some ways, some of them may be looking for tacit approval at home," he continued. "They hear their parents say, 'The blacks are getting this, the blacks are taking this away from us,' so in some strange way they think they're doing what their parents want."
 
'Your Victim Is Down'
 Dr. Alvin F. Poussaint, a psychiatrist at Harvard University Medical School who writes about racial conflict, agreed that economic hard times worsen things.
"Sometimes they're just looking for ways to let out their feelings of frustration and anger," he said. "Their momentary feelings of power they feel at the time when they attack each other. It's frequently a power trip -- your victim is down, at least at those moments."
Almost everyone agrees that children learn to hate from those around them. Stereotypes can be reinforced every day, whether by television programs that show minority characters in a negative light or by a teacher who regularly chooses not to call on certain children.
David Addams, who directs the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys and teaches a high school course called Civil Rights and Race Relations, said school integration has brought children of different races together so they can at least begin understanding each other. But he said that housing and jobs continue to separate them.
"When you go home at the end of the school day to a segregated community," he said, "and your parents have spent all day in a job market that may not be totally integrated -- like Wall Street, which is still mostly white, or a construction site which might be all people of color -- you may get messages that defeat all that you learned in school."
Abbie Cuellar was disillusioned at the end of her first year of teaching the civil rights and racial relations class at Park East High School in Manhattan. Most of her students were black and Puerto Rican, and many seldom met white people, except at stores or when job-hunting.
"They had an 'us against them' feeling," she said. "At first I thought, 'We're not doing anything here.' But at the end of the year, three kids gave speeches about how they learned through the class that they have to look at people as individuals."
The recent incidents have been hateful and poignant in their ability to hurt. But there is also some hope. More schools are adding courses on racism. And children themselves can demonstrate that once they understand the pain of someone's suffering, they will reach out to the wounded child.
At the Bowman School in Lexington, Mass., an entire class of fifth graders studying the Bill of Rights wrote letters to Nellie Wilson's children.
One of them, in round, neatly pencilled letters, read:
"Before I tell you how I feel I want to tell you that I wanted to write this letter and that no-one made me.
"I was shocked when I heard what happened to you. I don't see why anyone would or should hurt anyone just because of a different skin color. Even though I am white I am still mad. Why would anyone do this?
"Please don't lose faith! Casey Cross."

HEADLINE: SAUDIS PRESS U.S. FOR HELP IN OUSTER OF IRQA'S LEADER

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia is pressing the Bush Administration to organize a large covert action campaign in Iraq aimed at dividing Iraq's army and toppling Saddam Hussein, United States and allied officials say.
The Saudi initiative seeks an allied effort to supply arms and intelligence to Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq, Shiite Muslim fighters in the south and Sunni Muslim opposition forces in central Iraq. The aim is to draw out and divide Mr. Hussein's last Republican Guard divisions protecting his strongholds around Baghdad and subject them to allied air assaults. 
 Saudi advocacy for a new and more aggressive campaign comes as the Bush Administration is considering new steps to support Iraqi rebel forces with allied military power and to exploit growing tensions in the Iraqi leadership in a manner that would hasten Mr. Hussein's downfall while leaving the formation of a successor government clearly in Iraqi hands.
 
Political Issue for Bush
 The White House remains deeply concerned that the Iraqi leader is still in power at the outset of a Presidential election year in which his survival has become a political issue. The ouster of Mr. Hussein before November's election would remove the shadow that the Iraqi leader casts over Mr. Bush's campaign and eliminate the possibility that Mr. Hussein could do harm to Mr. Bush's re-election effort through provocative statements emanating from Baghdad.
American and allied officials discussed those plans with a reporter because some believe that the disclosure will by itself instill confidence in Iraqi opposition forces, while others, who oppose some of the proposals, hoped that public knowledge would provoke a cautionary public or congressional response.
 
Fomenting a Coup
 Substantial military forces from the United States, Britain, France and Saudi Arabia remain in the Persian Gulf area. American military leaders, including Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have cautioned that any effort to dislodge Mr. Hussein from Baghdad would require a major new deployment, including ground combat forces, to the region, a prospect that would increase the political risks for President Bush in an election year.
It could not be learned whether Britain and France have been consulted about the new planning. But senior American and Saudi officials have discussed military and covert action options over the last 10 days.
The American planning effort focusing on taking more active measures to foment a coup represents a realization within the Bush Administration that stronger measures might be possible in coming months to take advantage of what Administration officials perceive as a weakening of support for Mr. Hussein brought about in part by sanctions that are strangling the Iraqi economy.
In the initial postwar period, the Administration relied principally on sanctions to weaken the Iraqi leader. But by last fall, Mr. Hussein's grip on power seemed to be strengthening and he appeared to be exploiting the humanitarian crisis in Iraq to break the international coalition against him.
Then, when intelligence reporting indicated a fracturing of unity in Mr. Hussein's inner circle, the White House began preparing for more aggressive steps to seize opportunities that might arise to topple Mr. Hussein, like a coup plot by military commanders.
In addition to the Saudi option of secretly arming guerrilla forces, a senior Bush Administration official said in an interview this week that the Administration has considered coordinating its efforts with Kurdish and Shiite forces inside Iraq to foment a coup for which Iraqi military commanders would seek allied support.
That Saudi-backed option would require a major allied air campaign over Iraq and possibly the reintroduction of American ground troops in the region. military officials said.
With Mr. Hussein's air force grounded since the end of the war, the use of air power to destroy Mr. Hussein's remaining tank divisions and helicopter fleet would be the key to his final defeat in the view of a number of military officials.
 
So Far, No Decision
 United States and allied officials interviewed over the last several weeks indicated that no decisions had been made and that no final package of options had been presented to President Bush. The anti-Saddam Hussein planning still is being coordinated by the so-called Deputies Committee, which includes senior officials from the Pentagon, the State Department, the C.I.A. and the National Security Council.
The senior official who discussed the possibility of aiding a coup attempt said that Kurdish guerrillas in the north and Shiite Muslim resistance forces in the south "can be a dimension of an approach" to attack Mr. Hussein's power base.
But he said the key to a successful overthrow of the Iraqi leader remained the defeat or neutralization of the five of seven Republican Guard divisions that are stationed in the greater Baghdad area to protect the Iraqi leader.
The official said that there must be a broad-based, national character to a successful opposition to Mr. Hussein, including participation by Kurds, Shiites and the minority Sunni Muslims of central Iraq who have long been the leadership class in the country.
 
Arms-Supply Network
 "Sooner or later, I am convinced that the people Saddam depends on will turn on him as a dead end," the official said.
President Bush, in his statement Thursday on the anniversary of the beginning of the war that reversed Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, praised "the efforts of thousands of brave Iraqis who are resisting Saddam's rule."
The senior official said the statement was part of a concerted American campaign to nurture and develop an Iraqi resistance that could figure into plans for the final demise of Mr. Hussein.
Among the covert action options that Saudi Arabia is promoting is the formation of arms-supply and guerrilla-warfare networks organized by allied intelligence services that could challenge poorly trained Iraqi Army units garrisoned in most of the rural areas of northern and southern Iraq.
 
Allied Air Power
 Saudi officials and Iraqi opposition leaders say that many Iraqi regulars would desert or defect in large numbers once they were challenged.
If guerrilla forces seized Iraqi territories, Mr. Hussein would be forced to either cede control of those areas to the resistance or send his best Republican Guard units out from Baghdad to crush the rebellion.
At that point, the rebels would be protected by allied air power, in the view of Saudi officials and some Iraqi opposition leaders.
The key to supporting such guerrilla operations would be to prevent Mr. Hussein's Republican Guard units from employing their attack helicopters and their three heavily armored divisions against a dedicated assault from allied-backed resistance groups.
"There has to be a combination of a major covert operation and a major air operation and then leave the rest to the Iraqi people," said a senior allied official who has been discussing strategy with Bush Administration aides involved in the planning.
 
Saudi Equipment Pledged
 Kurdish guerrillas already control much of northern Iraq. But the Kurdish leadership is divided over whether to launch a direct challenge to Mr. Hussein. Shiite resistance in the south is much less organized and not well understood by allied officials, but Shiite opposition leaders say they can step up their guerrilla activities if they have arms and support from Saudi Arabia and the United States.
Saudi Arabia is willing to equip Iraqi resistance forces with missiles that would be able to shoot down Iraqi helicopters and destroy armored vehicles, a senior allied official said.
In November, the Deputies Committee asked the Joint Chiefs of Staff to develop military plans for an American response to any request for assistance from Iraqi military commanders plotting against Mr. Hussein.The White House request to the Joint Chiefs coincided with a letter Mr. Bush sent to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd pledging Mr. Bush's determination to achieve the overthrow of Saddam Hussein and to continue providing adequate military forces in the region to do that.
The letter, carried to the Saudi king by Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, also was intended to smooth American-Saudi relations after a long summer of haggling over whether the Saudis would accept the storage of a large stockpile of American military equipment and ammunition as part of a new security arrangement in the Persian Gulf region. The storage issue has yet to be resolved.
The new round of American planning also was motivated by intelligence reports indicating growing disaffection with Mr. Hussein among Iraq's traditional ruling families and clans. At least one bloody rivalry had surfaced between Mr. Hussein's son-in-law, Hussein Kamal Hassan, and another close relative, Ali Hassan Majid, who presided over occupied Kuwait as Mr. Hussein's personal representative. Both relatives have held a series of key posts in Mr. Hussein's Government over the last decade.
In November, the Iraqi leader replaced Mr. Hassan as Defense Minister with Mr. Majid, setting off a gun battle between the security forces of the rival relatives, according to what was described by one official as a reliable "human intelligence" report received by the Central Intelligence Agency.
A Deputies Committee meeting on Dec. 12 examined the limitations in using United States military forces in supporting an indigenous challenge to Mr. Hussein's authority, and that review focused in part on the strong cautionary recommendation from General Powell that the success of any new United States military intervention in Iraq could not be assured without a large and combined effort by United States air and ground combat forces.
 
Powell's Diminished Role
 One official, describing the White House reaction to General Powell's report, said it was deemed the "wrong answer" because of its insistance that major ground combat forces would have to be committed. As a consequence, a subcommittee of the deputies has been meeting under National Security Council supervision since mid-December to consider and refine military and covert action options for Iraq, officials said.
General Powell's contribution to the continued policy discussion appears to have been diminished since the planning meetings have been pulled into the White House. But a one-star general from the Joint Chiefs of Staff attends each meeting, an Administration official said.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, has argued that the use of American air power to support rebel Iraqi military units could have the decisive effect of breaking the back of Mr. Hussein's core security force in Baghdad, an allied official said.
Saudi officials are said to have argued that ground combat forces are not needed to bring down Mr. Hussein if an effective guerrilla force can be armed and supported with allied air strikes against Iraq's top military units.
 
Chemical-Arms Training
 To some officials in the Administration, the risks of such a major operation outweigh the benefits. If United States military forces got bogged down in an Iraqi civil war, it would seriously tarnish the image the military achieved in the Persian Gulf war.
There are other unknowns. A senior American analyst said last week that Mr. Hussein's military forces continue to train on equipment that is associated with chemical warfare, indicating that a final showdown with Mr. Hussein might include the use of chemical weapons.
Yet some officials say Mr. Hussein is near the end of his tether and that his rule could shatter under greater pressure.
The Central Intelligence Agency, which had predicted that Mr. Hussein would not complete 1991 in office, today declines to estimate how long he can survive.
 
Effects of U.N. Sanctions
 There are several reasons for presuming he cannot survive indefinitely.
Iraq has been denied virtally all of its national income by United Nations sanctions for more than 18 months and continues to refuse to sell limited quantities of crude under United Nations supervision.
Iraqi Government expenditures indicate that its reserves are no longer adequate to supply more than essentials, like food and medicine, to military forces and key leadership groups. The rest of the country gets subsistance rations.
Though the Sunni Muslim core of the Iraqi leadership rallied to Mr. Hussein in March when minority Kurds and southern Shiites launched twin uprisings, that support is now fraying, senior American analysts say, as Mr. Hussein has reneged on pledges to undertake democratic reforms, purged possible rivals from his Cabinet and shown indifference to the human suffering of millions of Iraqis.

HEADLINE: HOSPITALS MAY GET ADDITIONAL BURDEN ON MEDICARE BILLS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In an effort to discourage unnecessary health services and control costs, the Bush Administration plans to require hospitals to play a central role in arranging and billing for Medicare services, even when the services are performed outside a hospital.
A confidential memorandum summarizing new rules to be issued soon by the Government has been circulated at the Department of Health and Human Services. It says the rules will require hospitals to "assume financial responsibility" for many of the medical goods and services that elderly people receive as outpatients after leaving the hospital. The new requirement applies to laboratory work, X-rays, CAT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, scores of tests and the rental and purchase of medical equipment like wheelchairs. 
 Federal health officials say that changes requiring hospitals to "bundle" medical services into one bill will result in better-coordinated care for the elderly at lower cost. But for the 34 million Medicare beneficiaries, the new rules could mean less freedom in choosing where to go for outpatient services as hospitals direct them to particular clinics.
 
Alarm at Hospitals
 Hospital executives express alarm at the change, viewing it as a costly new administrative burden imposed by the Government.
The new rules reflect the policy of the Administration, supported by Congress, to bundle Medicare services together and pay for them as a package whenever possible. Medicare officials say that will help control health costs because hospitals will negotiate discounts in return for agreeing to send their patients to particular suppliers and clinics. Hospital officials say they are worried that such arrangements could be deemed anti-competitive or seen as kickbacks.
Federal health officials say the policy change can be made by regulation without any new laws. They have already revised the Medicare manual for hospitals to reflect the new policy.
In a speech this week to the American Nurses Association, Gail R. Wilensky, head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, explained her philosophy this way: "I want to bundle services and move away from a la carte fee-for-service medicine." She said the current system, which pays doctors and clinics separately for each additional service, gave them economic incentives to provide unneeded care.
In an interview, Dr. Wilensky said the final rules, to be issued this spring, could help beneficiaries by reducing the amounts they pay for outpatient services. The rules say beneficiaries "will not be billed as often for charges in excess" of the amounts recognized as reasonable by Medicare.
Outside suppliers that now bill patients or the Medicare program would bill the hospital. Under the rules, if a supplier improperly bills Medicare or if a hospital employee refers patients to a clinic that has no arrangement with the hospital, the Government may impose a fine of as much as $2,000 on the supplier or the hospital.
The new rules were prepared by Dr. Wilensky and Richard P. Kusserow, inspector general at the Department of Health and Human Services. The inspector general would impose the penalties.
In a memorandum summarizing the rules, Dr. Wilensky and Mr. Kusserow said, "Hospitals would be required to assume financial liability for all items and services furnished by an outside entity to their outpatients, and the practice of 'unbundling' these services would be prohibited."
In theory, patients would retain the freedom to choose clinics and suppliers of outpatient services, but in practice hospitals would direct them to certain clinics with which the hospitals have made arrangements.
 
Worries About Antitrust Laws
 Hospital officials say that if they comply with the new rules, they will run the risk of violating antitrust laws because they will have to channel patients to certain suppliers. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, ruled in December 1990 that a hospital committed illegal "anticompetitive acts" by referring patients to an equipment supplier in which the hospital had invested.
Hospital executives and doctors also fear they may be accused of violating Medicare's antikickback statute. Under the Medicare law, it is a crime to solicit or accept remuneration in return for referring Medicare patients to a health-care provider or ordering products from a particular company.
Almost every hospital refers some patients elsewhere for specialized services. If, for example, an elderly person falls, bruises his head and then has blurred vision, he may go to the emergency room of a local hospital. After examining the patient, the emergency room doctor may send him to aradiologist to have a CAT scan to see whether there is any accumulation of blood or other fluid under the skull.
At present, the radiologist typically bills Medicare for the procedure. Under the new rules, the radiologist would send his bill to the hospital, and the hospital would file the claim with Medicare for payment under a fee schedule. If the Medicare reimbursement was significantly lower than the bill, the hospital could be forced to absorb the difference.
 
Acknowledging Losses
 In a preamble to the new rules, the Government acknowledges that "hospitals may not be able to fully recoup increased costs they incur as a result of bundling outpatient services." But for most hospitals, it says, the increase in costs should not be significant.
Joanne M. Judge, president of the Community Hospital of Lancaster, Pa., voiced the concern of many hospital officials and doctors. "I don't think Medicare will save any money at all," she said. "There will simply be a new layer of billing added to the process."
Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, which represents millions of Medicare beneficiaries, said the new rules could help patients by reducing the confusion of multiple billing. But he also expressed concern that if a hospital consistently steered patients to a few suppliers, it could reduce competition in the health-care market and result in higher prices.
Trade associations representing nearly all of the nation's 5,500 hospitals object to the new rules. Among the groups objecting are The American Hospital Association, the Catholic Health Association, the National Association of Public Hospitals and the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 hospitals owned by investors.
In a letter to Dr. Wilensky, they said the new rules "would make hospitals financially liable for services they do not provide and for costs they cannot control." The decision about where to send patients is made by doctors, not by hospital administrators, and hospitals have no control over where patients go after they are discharged, the letter said.
The Government rejects that argument. It says that hospitals have "the degree of control needed" because they can insist that doctors wanting hospital privileges comply with policies on the referral of patients.

HEADLINE: Mexicans Come to Work, but Find Dead Ends

SERIES: Without a Ladder: The Mexican Immigrants/First of two articles.

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Bordered by factories and docks, the Magnolia Park neighborhood has long been a beacon for generations of Mexican immigrants seeking sturdy homes and steady wages. Over time, most found jobs, assimilated and moved on to a better life.
But that is much less the case nowadays. The neighborhood is as much a place to stay poor as it is to start poor. Upward mobility among the 14 million people of Mexican descent in the United States -- the nation's fastest-growing major ethnic group -- is faltering, and on Magnolia Park's shady streets the signs of trouble are everywhere: high-school dropouts, teen-age mothers, families doubled and tripled up in bungalows, and day-laborers who gather at street corners hoping to sell their services. 
 Raul Jimenez, a 62-year-old machinist, remembers better days in Magnolia, as the neighborhood is commonly known. "I arrived on Saturday, rested on Sunday and found a machinist's job on Monday," he said. "That was 1956, and Magnolia was a place where people could work hard for good money."
 
A Bleaker Job Market
 The neighborhood's troubles started with the oil bust of the early 1980's and continued as the nation's labor market underwent vast changes, shifting more and more from a blue-collar, manufacturing base to high-technology and service industries. With the loss of those jobs went the traditional steppingstones that Mexican immigrants had long used to get ahead. Now, the immigrant networks that once helped new arrivals like Mr. Jimenez find factory work mostly lead nowhere.
Immigrants still receive lots of help from relatives and friends in finding work, but they usually end up in dead-end, low-paying service jobs -- cleaning offices, mowing lawns, baby-sitting or sewing. Because wages in Mexico are even worse, rapid growth in this sector of the economy keeps drawing people across the Rio Grande, both legally and illegally. And the ready availability of such jobs is enticing teen-agers to drop out of school, often to help support their families.
Hugo del Moral came to Magnolia five years ago. He had several years more education than Mr. Jimenez and substantially more work experience as a machinist. But working mostly at odd jobs, the closest he has come to a factory floor is the one he has swept as a janitor.
"It's been hard to keep our dignity sometimes, but we still have our hopes," said his wife, Maria.
 
Economy Down, Population Up
 The story is much the same in other big cities where people of Mexican descent are concentrated, in neighborhoods like East Los Angeles and the Pilsen area of Chicago. While the upheaval in the labor market hurt urban working-class neighborhoods of all ethnic or racial groups in the 1980's, because it occurred just as the Mexican-American population was exploding, the neighborhoods where they live suffered particularly.
During the 1980's the number of people of Mexican origin in this country grew at five times the rate of the national average. Nationwide, this group accounts for about two-thirds of the entire Hispanic population.
The surge in growth was mainly fueled by two factors. The first was a wave of immigration from Mexico that numbered at least 4 million in the decade when estimates of illegal aliens are included -- the largest such influx by any national group in American history and about 45 percent of the total of 9 million people who immigrated to the United States in the 1980's.
The second factor was a high birth rate. In Mexican neighborhoods like Magnolia, at least one out of every three residents is under the age of 16.
These numbers alone insure that the nation will have to be increasingly concerned with the future of people in places like Magnolia. At issue is whether America can still assimilate poor and unskilled immigrants and make them a source of economic vitality.
 
Neighborhood Declines
Immigrants Find Downward Mobility
 Most Mexican communities have so far avoided the tailspin that carried many black and Puerto Rican neighborhoods into a seemingly permanent state of economic despair. But locked in their own peculiar dynamic, the Mexican neighborhoods, too, have begun to fall.
If current trends continue, at the turn of the century young people of Mexican descent will be second only to young whites as the largest source of new entrants into the labor force. But some experts are pessimistic about the prospects for these young Mexican-Americans, fearing that many will be high school dropouts and young unwed mothers at a time when the country will need highly skilled workers to compete globally.
It was a different world when Mr. Jimenez, the machinist, came to Magnolia in the 1950's. Post-war industry was booming and factory jobs required little education. "I always found work," Mr. Jimenez said, his large gnarled fingers stained black by lubricating oil. "If I changed jobs, it was because I went for something better."
Although Mr. Jimenez and his wife have learned only a little English, their four children finished high school and three went to college. Such generational advances have not been unusual among Mexican immigrant families that arrived before 1982. Historically, the first-generation immigrant has begun the process of becoming an American and the second has completed it, making notable economic gains.
But leaders in many Mexican-American communities now worry that this pattern has been broken.
 
'Eyes No Longer Sparkle'
 "I can tell by looking in their eyes how long they've been here," said the Rev. Virgil Elizondo, rector of San Fernando Cathedral in San Antonio. "They come sparkling with hope, and the first generation finds that hope rewarded." But he added: "Their children's eyes no longer sparkle. They have learned only to want jobs and money they can't have, and thus to be frustrated."
In many ways Magnolia, Houston's oldest Mexican neighborhood, is a profile in miniature of America's large and scattered population of Mexican descent.
Starting in 1916, refugees from the Mexican Revolution settled in Magnolia, a swampy area named for its big-blossomed trees, and helped build the Houston Ship Channel that borders it. Except during the Depression, it offered a stable home for those content with their industrial jobs and served as a stepping stone for immigrants with higher aspirations.
"Magnolia was the heart of all the colonias," said Mr. Jimenez, speaking in Spanish and using an old term for Mexican immigrant neighborhoods.
Magnolia still acts as a springboard for some. Austin High School, which serves the neighborhood, has an enrollment that is 94 percent Hispanic, and last year 68 percent of the graduating seniors went on to college. But only 400 seniors made it to graduation out of a class that began with 1,500 freshmen.
Across the country, dropout rates of 60 percent or more are common in schools with large numbers of Hispanic students. Many of the dropouts are teen-age parents. Every year in Magnolia out of a population of about 20,000, nearly 90 percent of whom are of Mexican descent there are about 400 new teen-age mothers.
 
The Signs Are Everywhere
 Signs of economic decay and diminished opportunities are everywhere. In the middle of a residential area sits an equipment yard for a once-thriving manufacturing plant. But now it is nothing more than rusting piles of metal and chest-high weeds. Nearby, the huge doors of a warehouse are open, revealing an abandoned interior.
Yet a certain degree of economic vitality is also visible. On the commercial streets are a new Taco Bell and several other fast-food restaurants as well as a new shopping center serving the low end of the retail market. They now coexist with dozens of old cantinas, small dark places where men drink beer with salt and have been known to draw pistols, and yerberias, crowded shops that sell herbal teas, statues of saints and sticks from ebony and mesquite trees -- accoutrements favored by spiritualist cults.
"There has been a two-part restructuring of the work force in Magnolia," said, Nestor P. Rodriguez, a sociologist at the University of Houston. "The old, industrial jobs disappeared, which caused many people to change work or retire or move cities. And at the same time low-wage service sector jobs boomed. The net effect is that you still have a lot of economic activity, but it is at the bottom of the ladder."
Despite the prohibition on hiring illegal aliens in the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, several recent studies have shown that people continue to enter the country surreptitiously and readily find service-sector jobs by using false documents. Many of the low-wage jobs are also filled by former illegal alines who are among the 1.9 million Mexicans granted amnesty under the 1986 law.
"They may not earn much individually, but there are enough immigrants with two or three jobs to a household that they are keeping the neighborhood alive," said Mr. Rodriguez
 
Economy Changes
Different Workers In a Different World
 Magnolia's troubles can be traced to the Texas oil bust of 1982 to 1987, when plunging oil prices set in motion an economic collapse in Houston, the center of the industry, that some economists have compared in severity to the Great Depression. The empty office buildings and abandoned, half-built housing subdivisions appeared all the more jolting because the oil bust followed boom years that had made Houston among the most properous and fastest-growing cities in the country.
The changes in the local labor market brought on by the bust and the city's subsequent recovery are a stark version of what is happening more gradually nationwide. The number of jobs in manufacturing in Houston dropped from 163,200 in 1981 to a low of 74,000 in 1987. Since then the number of manufacturing jobs has risen to 176,400, but many are now in high-technology fields requiring skills that few immigrants have. Across the country the number of manufacturing jobs dropped by nearly 6 percent during the 1980's while the number of jobs in the service sector grew by more than 27 percent.
Roger Waldinger, a professor of sociology at the University of California-Los Angeles, found in a study that nearly 36 percent of the native born Hispanic workforce was employed in construction or manufacturing in Houston in 1980 but that by 1987 the number had dropped to 14 percent. Meanwhile, the proportion of Hispanic residents working in the service sector climbed to about 50 percent.
This tidal shift in employment helped bring a sudden end to a long period of upward mobility.
Gregory DeFreitas, an economist at Hofstra University on Long Island, said income for workers of Mexican origin across the nation rose from the 1950's through the 1970's. They were concentrated in areas experiencing robust growth, especially Texas, the Southwest and California. Meanwhile, blacks and Puerto Ricans increasingly suffered from the decline of manufacturing in the Midwest and the Northeast. In the 1970's family income for people of Mexican origin rose by 7 percent, compared with about 3 percent for whites and blacks.
But in the 1980's a national recession, the restructuring of the labor market and competition from new immigrants all took their toll. Mr. DeFreitas found that real family income for people of Mexican origin fell by more than 13 percent between 1979 and 1987. During that time, the earnings of whites remained comparably flat and those of blacks fell by almost 7 percent.
To make matters worse, having never recovered from the last recession, neighborhoods like Magnolia are now enduring another one, and some of the economic losses look permanent.
 
Numbers Rise
Old Job Networks Lead to Nowhere
 The oil bust also dealt a potentially long-lasting setback to the network built up over decades in Houston's Mexican neighborhoods that had helped thousands of people find work.
Such a network is typical of all immigrant communities, and access to it can determine an immigrant's success. But with manufacturing jobs scarce, the network in Magnolia is now leading mainly to dead ends.
"We came because my sister was here and we had friends here who told us that they would help us find work in the port, in the factories, with the oil companies," said Maria del Moral. Indeed, she and her husband, Hugo, a janitor, received plenty of help, but they were led to menial jobs.
Even when networks still connect to good jobs, they cannot serve their purpose if the job seekers are unqualified. The Flores Motors Company, for example, an auto-repair shop in Magnolia, has long been a stepping stone for a number of employees who went on to open busineses of their own. But these days the company's president, Roy Flores, is frustrated.
"I still have good jobs that'll feed a family," he said, "but I'm going to have to open my own school soon if I want to fill them. The Mexican people coming up these days just know old-fashioned technology, and the kids coming out of school here don't know any. Men will come in here who have been working in a body shop in Mexico and they won't have any idea what we're doing."
Although the good jobs that once propelled the upward mobility of Houston's Mexican-Americans are ever harder to find, the city continues to draw large numbers of immigrants in search of work, many of them crossing the border illegally and many now coming from Central America. Census figures show a 72 percent increase in the Hispanic population of the Houston area during the 1980's.
Driven by political turmoil or the kind of economic crisis that saw real per capita income in Mexico drop by more than half since 1982, the new arrivals readily accept low-paying service jobs that do not offer the wages, benefits, security or chances for advancement of the old manufacturing jobs.
Ana H., who spoke only on the condition that her full name not be used because she lives here illegally, said she had been able to get started in Magnolia because so many minimum-wage jobs were available.
For a time she lived in a small two-bedroom apartment that was home for as many as six adults, all working cleaning offices, washing dishes and doing other menial jobs. Now Ana has a job as a maid, has married a gardener and, she said, has no regrets about her move to America. "I didn't expect it to be easy here," she said. "But it is better than what I had."

HEADLINE: 1992 Campaign: Political Memo;
Using Ads to Cast Star of White House Series

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 18

 BODY:
Thanks to the Presidential advertising campaigns that began this week, television viewers here have been learning day and night about some tough yet compassionate men who can swim the butterfly, shake hands with construction workers, defend a hockey net and still find time to personally provide health care and a job to everyone in America, including the middle class.
Faced with such frequent messages from such caring individuals, many citizens here have done their best to forget the entire experience. It is still easy to find serious television viewers who cannot recall the name of a single Democratic candidate. Some people even claim they have not seen any of the advertisements. 
 But some of the state's voters are trying to sort out the advertisements. They realize that all the promises sound the same, and they do not expect the promises to be kept anyway, but they still hope the commercials will guide them in making a crucial decision for the Presidential primary on Feb. 18: Which of these guys would be the least painful to watch on television for four years?
"You might as well get someone who can give decent lip service on the tube," explained 24-year-old Brooks Fraser, an especially experienced viewer due to his job selling televisions at the Cookin' electronics store in Manchester.
This week's advertising has already inclined Mr. Fraser toward one candidate. Recently unemployed for six months, Mr. Fraser is as worried as anyone about the economy, but his choice is not based on economic policies. He could not immediately name the details of his candidate's economic program. In fact, he could not immediately name the candidate.
"He's the one with gray hair, says he has a comprehensive program -- what's his name?" Mr. Fraser said. "There's a phone number -- and he sits on a desk, maybe?" Mr. Fraser thought about it for a minute, gave up, and let another salesman at the store match the spot with the name: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
"Yeah, he's the one, Clinton," Mr. Fraser said. "He looked like he'd be comfortable giving you what you want to hear."
That may not be the sort of deliberation that the Founding Fathers had in mind for choosing the President, but there are worse criteria. With candidates so well-trained to avoid the specific or the unpopular, voters can't be sure what Presidential policies they will have to suffer through, but they know they'll have to endure the President's talking head every night on television.
Mr. Clinton is doing well in the air war, partly because his advertisements have been on so often, but also because he seems more calmly authoritative than most television news announcers, both in his advertisements that run during newscasts and in his appearances on the programs.
On the Friday evening newscast here he was not even ruffled by newspaper reports on accusations that he had had extramarital affairs, accusations made by an Arkansas employee who was dismissed in 1988. The videotape showed the Governor hounded by reporters but serene as ever, smiling and patiently explaining that these were old and long-since discredited accusations.
Then he appeared live on the WMUR-TV newscast and was asked a question that many politicians would consider unfair: "Have you ever had an extramarital affair, Governor?" Mr. Clinton showed no indignation or unease. "Well," he replied with a Reaganesque chuckle, "if I had, I wouldn't tell you."
Mr. Clinton's advertisements flash newspaper headlines and show him with construction workers, but they mostly consist of him in an office talking directly to the camera. He makes general promises about the middle class and urges viewers to call for a copy of his plan.
The other candidates' advertisements seem more elaborately produced, which is always a risk. It invites comparisons with other commercials, and politicians can rarely match those happy actors selling beer and detergent.
The advertisements for Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska show him on a hockey rink, where he talks about trade. "Others guard their goal to keep our products out while we leave our net open," he says, and promises that the Japanese will "find out this President can play a little defense, too." His gaze might be a little too intense, and television viewers may have special reason to wonder what this Presidential goalie plans to keep out. Does a victory by the American team mean no more Sony Trinitrons?
The advertising for Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa shows him in shirtsleeves trying to rouse a crowd by shouting, "Let's have resource-based economics!" He has the exuberance of a good stump speaker, but when he waxes enthusiastic about new programs -- "I want to be known as the President that rebuilt America!" -- his passion can be disconcerting on the small screen, particularly to viewers who do not want to be known as the ones who paid for the renovation.
 
Beyond the Pretty Pictures
 The most noteworthy aspect of the spots for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts is what's missing: his voice. The reason seems obvious to anyone who has watched Mr. Tsongas be interviewed. Although he seems quite thoughtful, his message tends to get lost in his mushy diction. His advertising avoids this by relying on a narrator and a collage of scenes: mountains, assembly-line workers, Mr. Tsongas swimming laps. But the advertisements can leave even distracted viewers like Doreen Fontaine unsatisfied.
"Yes, Tsongas, I saw him swimming, but he didn't say too much from what I gathered," said Ms. Fontaine, a 50-year-old nurse from Londonderry. She said she hadn't really had time to pay attention to the advertisements or the candidates' interviews on television, but she was beginning to make up her mind.
"There was one that impressed me," she said. "I can't remember exactly what it was he wanted. I think it was for the working man and the economy, and something about health insurance. He seemed like he had confidence in what he was saying. He had a plan, I think. What was his name? Clinton. Is that one of the Democrats?"

PUB-DATE: January 19, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 24; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1170 words

HEADLINE: 1992 Campaign: Republicans;
Bush Campaign Scrambles to Put Forth a More Caring Candidate

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Racing to overcome a late start and an unexpected primary challenge, the Bush re-election forces have sent the President forth in a burst of appearances intended to show that he cares about the home front and understands the suffering of the recession.
The strategy seems intended to reap maximum political advantage from the State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, when the President will lay out his program for easing the problems he now so openly acknowledges. Indeed, some Republicans are already worrying that the White House has raised expectations for the State of the Union that it will be unable to meet. 
 In general, the Bush campaign still has a decidedly catch-up feel about it, reflecting a President whose poll ratings dropped with remarkable speed and whose plans presumed a far more leisurely stroll to re-election.
"It's a good team, but they're scrambling now," said Edward Rollins, who was campaign manager for President Ronald Reagan's re-election in 1984. "They've got a primary in five weeks that they didn't expect."
 
The Buchanan Challenge
 Bush strategists are essentially trying to retool the President, at a time when a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted Jan. 6-8 showed that two-thirds of the American people say he spends too much time on foreign affairs, 80 percent say the economy is in bad shape, and fewer than a fifth say Mr. Bush cares "a great deal" about the problems of people like them. The White House hopes to show that the leadership qualities the President demonstrated during the war in the Persian Gulf, when his popularity soared to historic levels, can be brought to bear on domestic problems.
The immediate audience for "Message: I care," as Mr. Bush put it this week, are the voters of New Hampshire. The state's Feb. 18 primary carries a huge risk of embarrassment for the White House because of the aggressive challenge from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator. In recent weeks, Mr. Bush and his surrogates on the campaign trail, like Vice President Dan Quayle, have tried to defuse the potential for a protest vote in New Hampshire by persuading its residents that their concerns have already been heard.
"The message for New Hampshire is not necessarily a universal one," said one Republican strategist, "but it is generally applicable: that he cares and understands, that he's going to do something about it, that he does have an economic growth plan and that part of the problem is Congress."
 
Making Up for Lost Time
 Last week was an example of the concerned, domestic George Bush. He told farmers in Kansas City that he would "fight for American jobs, everywhere." He told New Hampshire residents that he understood the economy was "in a free fall," although, "maybe I haven't conveyed it as well as I should have." He spoke of his concern with race relations and urban ills in Atlanta.
Even as they recast the Presidential message for an election year, Mr. Bush's campaign advisers are struggling to assemble an organization and make up for months of lost time. Even without a primary challenge, Mr. Bush waited a very long time before beginning to organize for his re-election, many Republicans said. "We were about six months ahead of them in '84," said Mr. Rollins.
Mary Matalin, the campaign political director, said: "The organizational side is clicking right along. We know where to go and what to do." Referring to her Democratic counterparts, she added, "These other guys are still updating their Rolodexes."
 
Teeter-Skinner Team
 At the heart of the Bush re-election effort are Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman and principal strategist, and Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, both of whom have strong roots in Illinois politics and have known each other for years. In contrast to 1984, when James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, was widely seen as the dominant figure in the Reagan re-election drive, several Republicans close to the Bush campaign predicted that Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter would have a much more equal relationship.
Frederick V. Malek, with the title of campaign manager, will be the chief operating officer of the campaign, and Robert A. Mosbacher. holds the title of general campaign chairman. Mr. Mosbacher, who is leaving his position as Secretary of Commerce, is an old friend of Mr. Bush's and will function in a time-honored role in a Presidential campaign: "The guy who knows exactly how the President thinks, knows the President's friends, knows how the President will react in a situation -- the real peer," said one Republican strategist close to the campaign.
 
'Lacks a Common Touch'
 Some Republicans continue to worry about the top command of the Bush campaign for two reasons: as many of them put it, there is no Jim Baker and there is no Lee Atwater. Mr. Baker, now the Secretary of State, was the clear and acknowledged decision-maker in the 1988 campaign, these Republicans say. Mr. Atwater, who died of a malignant brain tumor last year, was the master strategist with a feel for the South, for popular culture in general and for no-holds-barred political combat.
"I think the campaign lacks a common touch," said Craig Shirley, a conservative consultant.
In recent weeks, the campaign has taken on the first of what is expected to be an expanding team of media consultants: Don Sipple, who handled Governor Pete Wilson's 1990 campaign and has a special expertise on California; Mike Murphy, who was the consultant for Gov. John Engler's upset victory in Michigan, and Alex Castellanos, who has handled several races in the South, including Senator Jesse Helms's 1984 and 1990 re-election campaigns in North Carolina.
Mr. Helms's 1990 campaign produced one of the more talked about commercials in recent years, featuring a pair of white hands crumpling a rejection letter while the announcer intoned, "You needed that job and you were the best qualified, but it had to go to a minority because of a racial quota." The commercial proceeded to denounce the civil rights bill then pending in Congress.
 
Veterans of '88 Campaign
 The Bush campaign also features such veterans of the 1988 campaign as Ms. Matalin, the political director; Rich Bond, a senior adviser; Charles Black, also a senior adviser, and James P. Pinkerton, whose title is counselor but who is expected to work closely on message. Mr. Pinkerton did much of the research on Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, which was used to such devastating effect in the 1988 campaign.
Noting the Presidential experience of most of the top operatives, Mr. Bond said: "We understand a couple of basic things about Presidential politics. First and foremost, we understand it's an elevator operation, and as quickly as you go up, you can just as quickly go down.
"A Democratic nominee is about to burst on the scene and be everything to everybody, and what our operation does is insure a proper picture of this nominee is conveyed to the American people."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert A. Mosbacher Sr.; Frederic V. Malek; Robert M. Teeter; Mary Matalin; James P. Pinkerton; Charles Black; Richard N. Bond.
 
Chart: "Bush's Presidential Campaign Staff"
 
STAFF
 Robert A. Mosbacher Sr. -- General campaign chairman...Charged with coordinating political, fund-raising and operations arms of the campaign...Finance chairman for Mr. Bush's 1988 Presidential campaign...Former Secretary of Commerce.
 Frederic V. Malek -- Campaign manager...Chief operating officer, overseeing administrative nuts and bolts of the campaign...Masterminded the 1988 Republican National Convention...Was deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.
 Robert M. Teeter -- Campaign chairman and chief political strategist...Responsible for overall tone and direction of the re-election effort...For 20 years he has honed his reputation as a poll taker...At various times has worked for Presidents Nixon, Ford, Reagan and Bush.

HEADLINE: ULSTER'S WARFARE TAKES VARIED TOLL

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Down the block from Bedford Street, where 800 pounds of explosives blew a three-foot crater in the middle of the downtown area this month, a white-tie dinner and dance was held this week beneath the copper-covered dome of City Hall.
The Queen and the Princess of Romania were invited, along with the Lord Mayor of Belfast and a number of American businessmen. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration and now publisher of Forbes magazine, was the guest of honor. And after a dinner of poached Irish salmon and roast beef, Eddie Haughey, a businessman who organized the affair, rose to say he had gathered them all together to "foster the good name of Northern Ireland." 
 There were too many misconceptions and misperceptions about Northern Ireland, Mr. Haughey declared. It was time, he said, "to show the world how we really are an industrious, educated, cultured, forward-thinking society, worthy of world attention as a center for investment."
But while most businessmen and government officials here agreed with the spirit of Mr. Haughey's message, and appreciated his convening such a festive evening, a lot of ordinary people on the streets of Belfast do not feel much like dancing these days.
 
Six Bombings in Six Weeks
 Over the last six weeks, the Irish Republican Army has set off six bombs in the city center as part of a continuing campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. In addition to injuries, the attacks have cost millions of dollars in damage and have left people with jangled nerves.
[Early Saturday, the I.R.A. claimed responsibility for a roadside bombing in rural County Tyrone that killed seven workers and wounded seven others in a commuter van on Friday evening. The British Government said later that it would send 500 more troops to Northern Ireland to bolster security.]
The bombings have also snarled traffic into Belfast, with police officers in flak jackets and troops in battle gear stationed at checkpoints along roads leading into the city in an attempt to deter further bombings.
Politicians opposed to the I.R.A. are calling for even tougher security measures that include imposing curfews, issuing compulsory identity cards and sealing the border with the republic of Ireland, to the south.
"If they really wanted to show these visitors what is really happening in this city all they would have to do is take them for a walk to view the bomb damage around it," said Sammy Wilson, one of three members of the City Council who boycotted the dinner and dance at City Hall.
Along with fellow members of the Democratic Unionist Party, a mostly Protestant political organization, Mr. Wilson wants to see a much harder line taken with Irish republican militants.
Beyond the shadowy warfare between the rival paramilitary groups, which resulted in 94 deaths last year, the highest toll in nearly a decade, another battle is being waged in Belfast: a public relations campaign of images and impressions.
On the one side are the British, business owners and Northern Ireland officials who argue in brochures and press releases that life and commerce are becoming more and more normal in spite of "the troubles," as the 22-year-old conflict over Irish nationalism is euphemistically called both here in the north and in the south.
On the other side are the I.R.A. and some small, more militant supporting groups, whose bombs and bomb threats are intended to wreak havoc on the ordinary rhythms of life in the capital by interrupting commerce and making Belfast seem a city besieged.
 
Compensation Is Paid
 The economic damage toll has grown, too, something underlined by compensation payments made to bombed-out shopkeepers by the British Government. In the last nine months, the British have paid the equivalent of $41 million to businesses in Northern Ireland, a sum equal to what they spent for such payments for all of 1990.
Chris Thompson, whose sporting goods store in central Belfast was damaged by a bomb in November, says the recent attacks have taken the wind out of the weary capital. But like other businessmen, Mr. Thompson says he intends to carry on.
Three blocks away, Richard Traynor, who owns a photocopy shop, says that although he has been bombed three times in the last eight years, he has no plans to leave.
"What can you say?" Mr. Traynor said with a shrug. "This is Belfast." Then he added, "Besides, I've got a lease for another two years."

HEADLINE: Texas Governor Proves Adept in Her First Year

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 17

 BODY:
The day after Ann W. Richards was elected Governor of Texas in November 1990, she described politics in Texas as "a contact sport" and "not for the weak or the lily-livered."
While no one would accuse her of being docile in her year in office, Governor Richards has behaved more like a chess player than a linebacker. 
 She has made deals and compromises with other powerful politicians, and when she has resorted to head-on tackles, she has picked easy targets like the insurance industry or the operators of troubled nursing homes. Having campaigned as a no-nonsense reformer impatient with the good-old-boy system of Texas governance, in office she has shrewdly practiced the art of the possible.
And, as she begins her second year, Governor Richards seems very mindful of the limitations she faces.
In a news conference Thursday to mark her anniversary, she bemoaned court orders on legislative redistricting and school finance as well as the difficulties of taming the state bureaucracy and, most of all, the uncertainties of a souring economy.
"Texas is now very much vulnerable to the vagaries of the national economy," said Governor Richards, a Democrat. "We no longer have the insulation of cotton or cattle or oil. We are going to feel this recession very much."
When she entered office, Governor Richards said she counted on a rising economy to help Texas avoid tax increases. Asked Thursday how the recession would affect the state's fiscal prospects, she was unusually gloomy and uncertain, saying, "Well, I really don't know."
Just six months ago she faced the prospect of a $4.5 billion deficit in the 1992-93 biennial budget, and for the first time the idea of imposing a state income tax was receiving serious attention. She was saved that pain when John Sharp, the state Comptroller, came up with proposals for $4 billion in spending cuts, many of which were enacted.
The air of crisis helped her persuade the Democratic-controlled Legislature to narrowly approve a lottery, one of her chief campaign proposals, but even so the state adopted a $2.7 billion tax increase that included a revision of the state's major tax on businesses. Although the levy is not strictly an income tax, businesses that used to pay taxes only on their capital assets now pay either on assets or income, whichever is greater.
In a statement marking the Governor's first year in office, Fred Meyer, chairman of the Texas Republican Party, said she "campaigned against an income tax, promised in July there would not be an income tax, then signed Texas' first income tax into law in August."
 
Avoiding Political Disaster
 But so far Governor Richards has escaped the political disasters visited on other governors who have increased levies: The tax increase here affected businesses rather than individuals and Governor Richards has avoided being perceived as its author.
"Everyone knew there was going to have to be a tax increase when she came into office, just as everyone knew George Bush was going to have to go back on his 'no new taxes' pledge," said David Prindle, a professor of government at the University of Texas at Austin. "But she certainly put forth a consistent public face of being forced to accept something unwillingly, and she did it much more successfully than the President did with his tax increase."
Mr. Meyer said that the state is heading for "disaster of titanic proportions," and while such a claim may be partisan, a number of the Governor's fellow Democrats acknowledge that the fiscal crisis was merely postponed last summer and that another reckoning is due when the Legislature draws up the next two-year budget in 1993.
Looming over the state and its Governor is the unresolved question of how to equalize financing among school districts that vary widely in their ability to raise money from property taxes. Having already rejected two previous school finance plans, the Texas Supreme Court is considering challenges to a law enacted last year that boosts state spending and redistributes locally raised money among rich and poor school districts.
This law is expected to increase state spending by as much as $5 billion over the next four years, and there is still the possibility that the court will demand more.
Governor Richards displayed some of her trademark verbal ferocity Thursday when she accused the court of "inappropriate and capricious" behavior in continuing to ponder the case even as school districts are set to collect taxes under the new plan at the end of this month. "We are all mystified at this point," she said.
 
A 'New Texas'?
 Ann Richards, 58 years old, came to the Governor's office after eight years as State Treasurer by defeating a rancher and oilman, Clayton Williams, who strutted his nostalgia for Texas's myths. Last January, Governor Richards proclaimed her inauguration "the first day of the new Texas."
But, unlike other governors who have taken office determined to remake their states and who have immediately begun battles against the established powers -- the recently defeated Buddy Roemer of Louisiana being an example -- Governor Richards has operated within the constraints of political reality.
While she has not been able to enact all of the ambitious agenda she set out in her early days, she can point to some notable accomplishments. A package of measures to stabilize insurance rates and combat fraud is perhaps her clearest victory. She also has far more minority and female appointees than her predecessors had. But on the environment and on ethics in government she has bargained rather than battered and has accepted compromises.
Sometimes her methods have seemed more akin to the old Texas than the new one she proclaimed.
Republicans and news organizations accused her of violating the Texas Open Meetings Act when she plotted strategy with members of the powerful Legislative Budget Board at a private retreat on a virtually inaccessible coastal island last June, and at other key moments she has been caught operating behind closed doors.
Mary Beth Rogers, the Governor's chief of staff, said, "The Governor is certainly an outsider in terms of the industries that have traditionally tried to dominate this state government, but in terms of understanding how you make things happen in this very cumbersome legislative process, she's no outsider."
She added: "You don't always have to hit people over the head with a baseball bat to get things done. When you have the power of this office there are other ways you can effect change."
