HEADLINE: Bush to Propose $500 Million Rise In Budget for Head Start Program

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
President Bush will propose an increase of more than 23 percent in Federal spending for preschool children in the Head Start program, and he will expand it to combat illiteracy and unemployment among parents of children enrolled in the program, Administration officials said today.
In his new budget request, to be submitted to Congress in 10 days, Mr. Bush will seek an increase of more than $500 million for the popular program, which now serves 621,000 children at a cost of $2.2 billion this year, the officials said. 
 The increase would be the largest since the creation of Head Start in 1965. But it is less than what supporters of the program, including many Democrats in Congress, say is needed to guarantee access to Head Start for all children eligible on the basis of family income. The Democrats and other advocates of the program would increase the Head Start budget by $1 billion a year, to reach a total of nearly $8 billion by the end of 1997.
 
Seeking to Expand Enrollment
 Wade F. Horn, the Federal Commissioner for Children, Youth and Families, said today that the extra money sought by Mr. Bush would permit more children from low-income families to enroll in Head Start. At present, he said, 60 percent of the eligible children enter school having had at least one year of Head Start.
In contrast to the estimates by Federal officials, Sarah M. Greene, executive director of the National Head Start Association, which represents parents and teachers of children in the program, said "1.4 million children eligible for Head Start are not being served" because the program reaches only 28 percent of the 2 million children eligible under Federal laws and regulations.
Mr. Bush is expected to announce some of his plans on Tuesday, when he visits a Head Start center in Catonsville, Md., outside Baltimore.
Nine out of 10 children in Head Start come from families with income below the official poverty level, which was $13,359 for a family of four in 1990. Children in Head Start receive instruction intended to foster their intellectual and emotional development. They also receive health-care services and well-balanced meals. Research has shown that children in Head Start perform better on preschool achievement tests than comparable children not enrolled in the program, and in later years they do better in school.
Mr. Horn said the Administration was shifting the emphasis of Head Start to make it "a two-generation program" that serves parents as well as children in low-income families. Thus, he said, the Government wants to have an adult literacy program in every Head Start center in the country by the end of this year. In addition, he said, Head Start centers offer job training and placement services for parents of Head Start children.
In his 1988 Presidential campaign, Mr. Bush said he would expand Head Start to reach all eligible 4-year-olds. He has not accomplished that goal, though the Head Start budget has increased 78 percent since he took office.
Enrollment in Head Start has increased by 171,000 children, or 38 percent, in the last three years.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Killer Seized Outside a New Jersey Mall

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 18

 BODY:
The strange prison-escape saga of the stockbroker murderer who frightened Connecticut and New York residents and set off a massive manhunt ended this afternoon in New Jersey, when the police captured the escaped convict, Frank Vandever, at a mall in Paramus.
After searching for him in Rockland County just north of the New Jersey border, Mr. Vandever, a transvestite who was convicted of murdering a client, was arrested as he walked toward a car that was stolen this morning from the very motel here where he had slipped away from F.B.I. agents two days earlier. 
 Mr. Vandever was arrested at 5:15 P.M. as he walked toward the car in the sprawling parking lot of the Garden State Plaza, roughly 10 miles from this Rockland County community where a report of his appearance at an Econolodge motel frightened residents and touched off the intensive search, the police said.
He stole the car at 7:30 this morning from a woman who lived at the Econolodge and who maintained a morning ritual of starting her car and then dashing inside while it warmed up, said Paul Kunar, an investigator for the New York State police. The police said they believed Mr. Vandever knew the woman's habit because he had been staying at the Econolodge.
A Paramus police officer, Kenneth Ehrenberg, spotted the car in the mall's parking lot at 4:10 P.M. When Mr. Vandever returned to the car, officers were waiting, and he surrendered without a struggle, Mr. Kunar said.
 
$70 Money Order
 The police had been combing the mall parking lot after Mr. Vandever was identified by clerks at a convenience store in Bergenfield, N.J.
Earlier today Mr. Vandever had appeared at a 7-Eleven store wearing a red flannel lumberjack's jacket and looking unkempt. He bought a $70 money order and left, said John J. Kindergan, the store's owner.
Minutes after he left, a police detective came into the store to warn them that Mr. Vandever might be in the area.
"He appeared very scruffy, not someone who had taken a shower in the morning," said Daniel King, the store's weekend clerk. He said the clerks who were on duty then recognized Mr. Vandever from the photographs that have been widely publicized in recent days and notified law enforcement officials.
The manhunt gained unusual notoriety after Mr. Vandever and the other escapee, Ronald Rutan, slipped through the bars and the high-technology fence of a maximum-security prison in Somers, Conn., on Dec. 31. They then terrorized a couple, stole their car and vanished for more than two weeks until F.B.I. agents caught up with them on Thursday in Rockland County, just north of New York City, only to lose Mr. Vandever again when he vaulted over a fence and disappeared once more.
Responding to a telephoned tip, agents had caught up with Mr. Vandever and the other escapee, Ronald Rutan, at the Econolodge. Mr. Rutan was arrested immediately. But when Mr. Vandever slipped away, local, state and Federal law-enforcement authorities set up a search involving bloodhounds, helicopters, roadblocks on the area's major highways and house-to-house searches.
The escape of Mr. Vandever and Mr. Rutan set off a political furor in Connecticut because of allegations that it would not have been possible before budget cuts left the prison staff reduced and dependent on a new technology in prison fences. Last year, under the administration of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., officials decided to reduce staffing of guard towers at the prison as part of his administration's budget-cutting moves.
The two men escaped by relying on two techniques, one as old as James Cagney movies and another so new that it caught prison officials off guard.
Mr. Rutan, who worked in the prison kitchen, slowly cut his way through the bars there, officials believe, in preparation for the escape. Then, between 7 and 10 P.M., when the security staff was reduced because of the holiday and the state's austerity budget, the two men slipped through the bars and worked on two 12-foot-high fences equipped with electronic motion detectors.
Officials have since said that they believe the fence was sensitive to any type of jarring, for example, if someone brushed against it or jumped onto it, but not to the approach used by the two men.
The police said they believe that one of the men held the fence tightly so as to reduce any motion, while the other snipped very carefully at the wires to avoid setting off any alarms.
After the escape, the two men first frightened people in the area of northern Connecticut near the prison in Somers, holding a couple hostage at knifepoint before tying them up and stealing their truck.
Then they preoccupied the people of Rockland County, N.Y., where they were discovered in midafternoon on Thursday after a tip to the F.B.I. from an unnamed Connecticut woman who said she had seen a segment about the pair on a syndicated television program, "Hard Copy."
After the tip, F.B.I. agents went to an Econolodge motel on Route 59 in Spring Valley, where the woman reported that she had seen the two escapees. According to an F.B.I. agent in charge of the search, Don Clark, the agents had not yet set up their stakeout when the two men returned to the Econolodge in the stolen truck. The F.B.I. agents identified themselves while the two men walked toward the room they had occupied for about 10 days. The two men began running in different directions.
Mr. Rutan was quickly captured. But Mr. Vandever vaulted over a fence behind the motel and disappeared.

HEADLINE: U.S. Human Rights Office Grows in Influence

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Patricia M. Derian, the first Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, has vivid memories of her early days in office. She recalls that she was often resented, ridiculed or ignored, and certainly not taken very seriously.
"After I had been there awhile, I invited all the other assistant secretaries to a meeting so that I could tell them what it was that I was there to do," she recalls. "It was one of those times when you're talking and people look away, extremely embarrassed at this naive display. They thought, this is going to be some little creampuff here." 
 That was in 1977. A decade and a half later, human rights has moved to the center of foreign policy debate in Washington, spurred by pressures from Congress and a voiciferous lobby of rights and relief organizations. The subject figures in all Congressional debates on foreign aid. Worldwide, few nations are finding that they can defy human rights scrutiny without diplomatic consequences.
Since 1981, Republican administrations have often been the target of criticism by human rights groups, which charge that Washington has been uneven or inconsistent in raising rights issues because of other policy considerations. Nonetheless, these administrations have drawn the major groups -- Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights -- into their consultations.
"We see assistant secretaries and desk officers all the time," said John G. Healey, head of Amnesty International in the United States. "Even if we don't get what we want, we're in the mix now. The relationships are warm. They seek, we give. They call, we help."
As Americans grow more critical of spending money on foreign aid in hard economic times and the ferment of the post-cold war world presents many new claims for attention, the human rights lobby can enhance its influence.
"I think one of the best examples of the influence of human rights groups in recent years is China," said Sidney Jones, executive director of Asia Watch. "By criticizing United States policy on China, the human rights organizations have been able to exert some pressure on China itself."
Over the last two years, Ms. Jones added, every time China seemed in danger of losing its preferred tariff status with the United States, it would respond to key debates in Congress by releasing some prisoners.
One of the most sustained campaigns in the waning years of the cold war was on behalf of Soviet Jews and other citizens whose rights were restricted in the former Soviet Union.
Robert Pastor, professor of political science at Emory University and former Latin American specialist at the National Security Council, says the emergence of democracies in the Western Hemisphere is a tribute to the success of rights campaigns.
"In human rights, we are really dealing with an international movement of great consequence," he said. "It would be hard to find a country in this hemisphere in which raised consciousness of human rights has not had any effect. Even in the most extreme case of Cuba, Fidel Castro has had to deal with the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and he has had to respond to questions posed not by the United States or the Cuban-American community but by Latin Americans."
Not all areas have high human-rights profiles. Many Africans see great needs on a continent where lately, most of the attention has been focused on South Africa. The world has not reacted to hundreds of thousands of Somalis facing starvation and death in factional warfare, said Rakiya Omaar, executive director of Africa Watch. Sudanese struggle to get a hearing for charges that their Islamic Government is brutally suppressing a rebellion in the Christian and animist south. country.
"In 30 years, human rights has been put on the agenda of the world by the pain of suffering people," Mr. Healey said. "Every group has the right to claim some kind of victory. There has been a change in the river of consciousness."

HEADLINE: A Family Gets Back on Track With Help From the Neediest

 BODY:
Time was, the Rosas had enough -- not a lot, but enough. Maria Rosa, 26 years old, remembers when she and her family could afford fresh vegetables and meat. That was more than a year ago. "My son is anemic. He is used to fresh food and we eat out of cans now." she said, glancing sadly at her husband.
Until early last year, her husband, Richard, worked regularly for various delivery companies, providing him with enough income to support his family. But he was laid off last February and was unable to find another job. Even though both had gone to night school and were certified building superintendents, they still had trouble finding steady work. 
 "We have gone from the stage of having little to nothing," Mr. Rosa said. "The recession has really hit us hard."
Mr. Rosa, 28, found a job as a truck driver just before Jan. 1, but the road to financial and emotional recovery will not be easy. He brings home about $270 a week. Their modest, one-bedroom apartment in Flushing, Queens, costs $730 a month, and there is barely any space for 4-year-old Richard Anthony to play.
 
Hope for the Future
 "We can't afford to send him to a day-care center," she said. "He stays home with me, we do everything together."
The situation has taken a toll on Mrs. Rosa's health and has put a strain on her marriage, bringing on bouts of depression and worries about her son. "We have no social life, we can't do anything," she said. "But the worst part is having to say no when he asks for a new toy or food. It's heartbreaking."
With the help of the Catholic Charities Diocese of Brooklyn and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the Rosas now have hope for the future. "I don't know where we would be without them," Mr. Rosa said. "I don't even want to think about it."
The Rosas were referred to the Catholic Charities Family Center by their priest at St. Michael's Cathedral in Flushing. Now they are able give their son "real food" to help keep him healthy, Mrs. Rosa said.
The Neediest Cases Fund gave them $731 in cash for their rent and some money to buy a turkey for Christmas. It also supplied them with emergency food packages and money for transportation, as well as counseling sessions once a week.
 
Starting Fresh
 The Neediest Cases helps thousands of New Yorkers get their lives back on track. The campaign's overhead is covered by the newspaper so that all contributions are distributed to seven charities that feed the hungry, clothe the poor and help families like the Rosas overcome long-term problems.
Now their main concern is to start fresh and begin a new life. "I want to go to college and become a psychologist," Mrs. Rosa said. "I want to help people."
Her husband also has higher expectations. "I'm just taking this job to pay the bills," he said. "But I'm going for my tractor-trailer license to put Maria through college."
The Rosas don't have much, but manage to find the time for other people. Recently they helped feed the homeless at St. Michael's Cathedral. "It was wonderful to be able to touch so many people with so little," Mrs. Rosa said. "Helping people as a family is special."

HEADLINE: The Minibus From Loneliness

 BODY:
"What would I do in Florida?" The answer Julia has in mind is plain: nothing. Since her parents emigrated from Poland in 1910, she has lived in Brooklyn. It is where she went to school, got her first job sewing ($3 a week), where she married, raised a family and bought her daughter a home. Julia, 90 years old and widowed, is mentally sharp and too vigorous to sit home all day, but she can no longer go out walking in the winter or at night. Julia hates to ask her grandchildren on Long Island for favors, and her daughter is now 70 and blind.
So every weekday, a minibus operated by the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged provides her with round-trip transportation to the Williamsburg Senior Center, where she enjoys a hot lunch, planned activities and the company of friends. The minibus, which serves senior citizens of all races and creeds, is just one of many programs for the elderly supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 Eighty-year-old Minnie knows how easily isolation can overtake those growing old. The onset of arthritis and a heart condition forced Minnie to become homebound, sadly alone with her memories. Now, with access to the minibus, an Irving Berlin song or a life story is readily shared with peers. "We tell each other what's on our hearts," Minnie explains. "Our children moved away. Both parents work today, so they have no time for us. They have a better life," Minnie adds, her voice brimming with pride. "We paved the way for them. But now we're very, very lonesome people."
For retirees who years ago decided to remain in the city, and who now have outlived spouses and friends, living alone in decayed neighborhoods has brought unanticipated sorrows and fears. The recession squeezes New York's oldest residents particularly hard, as purchasing power shrinks on fixed incomes and the interest on life savings declines.
Throughout this year, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will rescue tens of thousands of the city's elderly from hunger and loneliness. Even a small donation can provide a wealth of comfort and care for the isolated and infirm. The holiday season is past but the 80th appeal continues. All who can are asked to help.
Tax-deductible contributions should be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Post Office Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: A Worthy War

BYLINE: By Stephen J. SolarzBy WASHINGTON; Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of New York, is a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

 BODY:
The historical revisionists are already at work. Last year's triumph in the war against Iraq, they claim, has turned to ashes. We won the war only to lose the peace. But the naysayers who make this argument too cavalierly dismiss the strategic and diplomatic benefits produced by Operation Desert Storm.
To be sure, the fact that Saddam Hussein remains in power is deeply disturbing. But this hardly constitutes an argument against the war, particularly since he would still be comfortably ensconced in Iraq and Kuwait if we had not moved against him. 
 Perhaps the war's most significant achievement has been the extent to which we have substantially set back Iraq's efforts to obtain nuclear weapons. We now know that Iraq was far closer to developing them than was believed a year ago. Had we not been willing to use force, Saddam Hussein would undoubtedly have obtained a nuclear arsenal, with grave consequences for the region and the world.
But there were other benefits as well. By liberating Kuwait from the clutches of a Mesopotamian megalomaniac, we prevented Saddam Hussein from getting his hands on the economic jugular of the world. We demonstrated that powerful countries will no longer be permitted to take over weaker ones. And we opened the way for a Middle East peace process that has made it possible, for the first time in over 40 years, for Israel to negotiate directly with its Arab neighbors.
It is worth considering what the consequences would have been had we not been willing to use military power against Iraq. Based on Mr. Hussein's willingness to use other weapons of mass destruction, there is every reason to believe that, once he acquired nuclear weapons, he would have used them as well.
Moreover, after absorbing Kuwait, Mr. Hussein would have been in a position to dominate the entire Persian Gulf. At best, to prevent the other gulf dominoes from falling, we would have been obliged to maintain tens of thousands of American troops indefinitely in the culturally and climatically inhospitable Arabian Peninsula.
Furthermore, there would have been no peace process between Israel and the Arabs. The stability of the Arab countries willing to join us in opposing Iraq would have been badly shaken. And the stage would have been set for additional campaigns of conquest, in which the number of casualties inflicted by a nuclear-armed Iraq would have been infinitely greater than the number of those killed last year.
While reasonable people disagreed about whether sanctions would be sufficient to force Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait, it seems clear in retrospect that economic pressure alone would not have done the job. Even now, after we have destroyed much of his military machine and economic infrastructure, and with sanctions still in place, Mr. Hussein remains unregenerate and unrepentant. His refusal to comply with the cease-fire agreement is clear evidence that the continued application of sanctions would have been a formula for failure, rather than a strategy for success.
The opponents of war also told us we would get hopelessly bogged down in a desert war with massive American casualties. Yet we won the war in six weeks, with fewer than 150 American fatalities.
We were cautioned that the Arab masses would overthrow Arab governments courageous enough to oppose Iraq. Yet every one of our Arab partners is more stable today than if Mr. Hussein had gotten away with the annexation of Kuwait.
We were warned that a war would divert tens of billions of dollars from pressing problems at home. Yet virtually the entire cost of the war was paid by our coalition partners and other friendly countries.
We may not have accomplished everything we hoped to, but there can be little doubt that the gulf and the world are far more congenial to American interests and values than they would have been had we acquiesced in Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression against Kuwait.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Bush's Crucial Decision

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Nothing else President Bush does this year is likely to matter as much, in human terms, as how he answers Israel's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees. He will be deciding on the chance for peace in the Middle East.
The critical question is whether the President ties any guarantees to an end of Israel's massive current settlement drive in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. If he does not, Palestinians will see his decision as a signal that Israel can and will go on taking what they consider to be their land. 
 At that point it would be politically difficult, perhaps impossible, for the Palestinian negotiators to remain in the talks on autonomy in the occupied territories. The hope of peace, present since the two sides began talking to each other in Madrid, would be over.
Failure of the negotiations would in turn have grim consequences for Soviet immigrants here, whose support is the stated purpose of the loan guarantees. Ephraim Sneh, a retired Brigadier General who was the military governor of the West Bank and is now one of the rising younger figures in the Labor Party, explained why.
"To absorb the Soviet Jews properly we have to develop industry," Mr. Sneh said. "That requires foreign investment. But it will not come while we are in the quagmire of the conflict with the Palestinians -- while we are the only Western democracy that occupies another people.
"The key to social and economic progress is peace with the Palestinians. And nothing is more against the hope of peace than the settlements."
The head of the Jewish Agency, Simcha Dinitz, agreed that Israel should focus on absorbing Soviet immigrants rather than settling among Palestinians. But he said it would be wrong for the President to condition loan guarantees.
"If you want to punish us for the settlements," Mr. Dinitz said, "do it some other way. Don't punish the immigrants."
That will not be an easy argument for Mr. Bush to resist in an election year. But if he really cares about peace and about the Soviet immigrants, as he does, he will resist it. For there is no question of punishment. The question is how to clear the path for peace by stopping settlements, and the only way at hand is to condition the loan guarantees.
How Mr. Bush does it is important. If he were to say flatly that there will be no guarantees unless and until there is a freeze on settlements, Prime Minister Shamir might well reject the guarantees, denounce American "colonialism" and redouble settlements -- however terrible the cost to Israel.
The better course is the one reportedly being discussed. That is to approve $2 billion for one year, with any amount spent by Israel on settlements to be deducted from future guarantees. Thus if Israel spent $600 million in 1992, it would get a guarantee of $1.4 billion in 1993.
But that will work only if the United States rigorously monitors what Israel spends on housing, roads and other infrastructure in the territories. Israel has promised in the past not to use U.S. aid money in the territories -- and then simply use the aid to free up Israeli funds for settlements.
If American policy is sensitively explained, I think most Israelis would understand and accept it. After all, the United States is not obligated to grant Israeli requests against what it deems to be its own interest. Mr. Sneh said:
"I don't need America to tell me settlements are wrong. But since money is fungible, I can understand if Mr. Bush declines to be the treasurer of Gush Emunim." Gush Emunim are the zealous vanguard of the settler movement.
Moreover, many Israelis are beginning to resent what the settlement policy costs them. Projects to relieve major highway bottlenecks in Israel proper have just been cut so that West Bank roads for settlers -- who are 3 percent of Israelis -- can be improved. In new settlements there is a teacher for five or six children, in Jerusalem 1 for 40 children.
President Bush should tell Israel: We are sympathetic with the great humanitarian enterprise of making a place for immigrants. We will help. But we do not want our help to be used in a way that destroys the chance for peace: the chance to build a better, safer, more prosperous Israel.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
After 10 Years, an All-New Montero

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
ACCORDING to conventional wisdom, the Japanese like to copy things American, but that is not always so. They take good ideas where they find them, and this time the nice notion comes from England.
The vehicle in question is Mitsubishi's Montero, a fancy sport-utility wagon that looks like nothing so much as the British Range Rover and that carries the upscale effort to nearly the same extreme. 
 Mitsubishi has been sending the Montero to America for a decade, but the model that made its debut in showrooms this month is the first complete redesign in all that time, and it reflects the evolution of what was once considered a simple workhorse, a vehicle that could climb mountains and cut through forests. A vehicle, in short, that could go anywhere but the country club.
Sport-utility models now account for about 6.5 percent of the automobile and light-truck market, and the number of entries has continued to climb as more buyers have been lured by their off-road abilities and cargo capacity. In 1983, there were seven such offerings. Today, there are 20.
All the same, most people never take these things off the highway. Image is, in part, what Montero and the other contenders are all about, and that is easy to understand. You really don't want to plunk down $30,000 or so, and then rush off to the brambles.
For '92, Montero comes in four flavors, plain, RS, LS and SR, and prices range from a base of about $18,000 to the $27,885 sticker of the top-of-the-line tester, an SR done up in dark green metallic paint and tan leather.
The body has been rounded a bit, although aerodynamics are not the Montero's long suit, and silver vinyl has been added as lower-body cladding to protect against dings and scrapes. Aluminum wheels carry huge and aggressive tires, and there is a mix of blackout trim and brightwork, including chrome bumpers.
All Monteros come with four doors, and the new model is longer, wider and taller than its predecessor. But the body is not all that has been redesigned. A new V6, similar to those in the 3000GT and in Mitsubishi's recently introduced Diamante sedan, powers a new four-wheel-drive system, and the antilock brakes have been made compatible with all modes, no matter how many wheels are driving the vehicle.
The 3-liter engine, mounted longitudinally, puts out 151 horsepower, and the LS and SR models accommodate it with standard four-speed automatic transmissions, while lesser Monteros have standard five-speed sticks. A separate lever allows the driver to shift into four-wheel drive at any speed up to 62 m.p.h.
Inside, the Montero lives up to its billing as a luxury cruiser. The SR's tilt wheel was wrapped in leather, and both front buckets were of the "suspension" type for extra cushioning. There was full power equipment, including a one-touch down feature for the driver's window and buttons for the truck-style sideview mirrors.
The dash includes full instrumentation, and a center pod lets you know inside and outside temperatures as well as altitude and compass direction. It also incorporates an inclinometer to show the position of the vehicle relative to the ground. A lighted diagram in the instrument panel takes the guesswork out of four-wheel drive, indicating which wheels are doing the work.
A large, electrically operated sunroof is mounted midships over the rear seat, a bench that folds forward to increase cargo room. With the seat in its upright position, the Montero can carry 44.8 cubic feet of luggage, camping gear or what have you. Folded, the space increases to 96.6 cubic feet.
One reason there is so much room is the location of the full-sized spare, which hangs outside the rear hatch. But that location also creates one of the Montero's few problems, covering a goodly chunk of the back window. Combined with the blockage posed by the rear seat's headrests and the rear window's wiper, it means the driver can see very little out the back.
Another problem, and one that seems endemic to sports-utility vehicles, stems from the Montero's height and huge tires. On the highway, it wanders annoyingly and requires constant correction.
Still, this is a friendly vehicle, one that cruises easily at more than the legal limit, and it is put together well and comfortable. Electronically controlled shock absorbers offer three settings of firmness, and there is more travel in the suspension than there used to be. On the road, that translates into a quiet and solid ride. And there is no question that you have a lot of machinery under you; this thing weighs more than two tons.
Given that, the fuel economy ratings are understandable. City mileage averages 15 per gallon, and the highway figure is only three better. The tank is relatively large, however, holding a bit more than 24 gallons, so you can travel a good long way in the wild.
It goes without saying that gas is no problem when you're headed for the country club.

HEADLINE: SAUDIS PRESS U.S. FOR HELP IN OUSTER OF IRAQ'S LEADER

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia is pressing the Bush Administration to organize a large covert action campaign in Iraq aimed at dividing Iraq's army and toppling Saddam Hussein, United States and allied officials say.
 The Saudi initiative seeks an allied effort to supply arms and intelligence to Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq, Shiite Muslim fighters in the south and Sunni Muslim opposition forces in central Iraq. The aim is to draw out and divide Mr. Hussein's last Republican Guard divisions protecting his strongholds around Baghdad and subject them to allied air assaults. 
Saudi advocacy for a new and more aggressive campaign comes as the Bush Administration is considering new steps to support Iraqi rebel forces with allied military power and to exploit growing tensions in the Iraqi leadership in a manner that would hasten Mr. Hussein's downfall while leaving the formation of a successor government clearly in Iraqi hands.
 
Political Issue for Bush
 The White House remains deeply concerned that the Iraqi leader is still in power at the outset of a Presidential election year in which his survival has become a political issue. The ouster of Mr. Hussein before November's election would remove the shadow that the Iraqi leader casts over Mr. Bush's campaign and eliminate the possibility that Mr. Hussein could do harm to Mr. Bush's re-election effort through provocative statements emanating from Baghdad.
 American and allied officials discussed those plans with a reporter because some believe that the disclosure will by itself instill confidence in Iraqi opposition forces, while others, who oppose some of the proposals, hoped that public knowledge would provoke a cautionary public or congressional response.
 
Fomenting a Coup
 Substantial military forces from the United States, Britain, France and Saudi Arabia remain in the Persian Gulf area. American military leaders, including Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have cautioned that any effort to dislodge Mr. Hussein from Baghdad would require a major new deployment, including ground combat forces, to the region, a prospect that would increase the political risks for President Bush in an election year.
 It could not be learned whether Britain and France have been consulted about the new planning. But senior American and Saudi officials have discussed military and covert action options over the last 10 days.
 The American planning effort focusing on taking more active measures to foment a coup represents a realization within the Bush Administration that stronger measures might be possible in coming months to take advantage of what Administration officials perceive as a weakening of support for Mr. Hussein brought about in part by sanctions that are strangling the Iraqi economy.
 In the initial postwar period, the Administration relied principally on sanctions to weaken the Iraqi leader. But by last fall, Mr. Hussein's grip on power seemed to be strengthening and he appeared to be exploiting the humanitarian crisis in Iraq to break the international coalition against him.
 Then, when intelligence reporting indicated a fracturing of unity in Mr. Hussein's inner circle, the White House began preparing for more aggressive steps to seize opportunities that might arise to topple Mr. Hussein, like a coup plot by military commanders.
 In addition to the Saudi option of secretly arming guerrilla forces, a senior Bush Administration official said in an interview this week that the Administration has considered coordinating its efforts with Kurdish and Shiite forces inside Iraq to foment a coup for which Iraqi military commanders would seek allied support.
That Saudi-backed option would require a major allied air campaign over Iraq and possibly the reintroduction of American ground troops in the region. military officials said.
 With Mr. Hussein's air force grounded since the end of the war, the use of air power to destroy Mr. Hussein's remaining tank divisions and helicopter fleet would be the key to his final defeat in the view of a number of military officials.
 
So Far, No Decision
 United States and allied officials interviewed over the last several weeks indicated that no decisions had been made and that no final package of options had been presented to President Bush. The anti-Saddam Hussein planning still is being coordinated by the so-called Deputies Committee, which includes senior officials from the Pentagon, the State Department, the C.I.A. and the National Security Council.
 The senior official who discussed the possibility of aiding a coup attempt said that Kurdish guerrillas in the north and Shiite Muslim resistance forces in the south "can be a dimension of an approach" to attack Mr. Hussein's power base.
 But he said the key to a successful overthrow of the Iraqi leader remained the defeat or neutralization of the five of seven Republican Guard divisions that are stationed in the greater Baghdad area to protect the Iraqi leader.
 The official said that there must be a broad-based, national character to a successful opposition to Mr. Hussein, including participation by Kurds, Shiites and the minority Sunni Muslims of central Iraq who have long been the leadership class in the country.
 
Arms-Supply Network
 "Sooner or later, I am convinced that the people Saddam depends on will turn on him as a dead end," the official said.
 President Bush, in his statement Thursday on the anniversary of the beginning of the war that reversed Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, praised "the efforts of thousands of brave Iraqis who are resisting Saddam's rule."
 The senior official said the statement was part of a concerted American campaign to nurture and develop an Iraqi resistance that could figure into plans for the final demise of Mr. Hussein.
 Among the covert action options that Saudi Arabia is promoting is the formation of arms-supply and guerrilla-warfare networks organized by allied intelligence services that could challenge poorly trained Iraqi Army units garrisoned in most of the rural areas of northern and southern Iraq.
 
Allied Air Power
 Saudi officials and Iraqi opposition leaders say that many Iraqi regulars would desert or defect in large numbers once they were challenged.
 If guerrilla forces seized Iraqi territories, Mr. Hussein would be forced to either cede control of those areas to the resistance or send his best Republican Guard units out from Baghdad to crush the rebellion.
 At that point, the rebels would be protected by allied air power, in the view of Saudi officials and some Iraqi opposition leaders.
 The key to supporting such guerrilla operations would be to prevent Mr. Hussein's Republican Guard units from employing their attack helicopters and their three heavily armored divisions against a dedicated assault from allied-backed resistance groups.
 "There has to be a combination of a major covert operation and a major air operation and then leave the rest to the Iraqi people," said a senior allied official who has been discussing strategy with Bush Administration aides involved in the planning.
 
Saudi Equipment Pledged
 Kurdish guerrillas already control much of northern Iraq. But the Kurdish leadership is divided over whether to launch a direct challenge to Mr. Hussein. Shiite resistance in the south is much less organized and not well understood by allied officials, but Shiite opposition leaders say they can step up their guerrilla activities if they have arms and support from Saudi Arabia and the United States.
 Saudi Arabia is willing to equip Iraqi resistance forces with missiles that would be able to shoot down Iraqi helicopters and destroy armored vehicles, a senior allied official said.
 In November, the Deputies Committee asked the Joint Chiefs of Staff to develop military plans for an American response to any request for assistance from Iraqi military commanders plotting against Mr. Hussein.The White House request to the Joint Chiefs coincided with a letter Mr. Bush sent to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd pledging Mr. Bush's determination to achieve the overthrow of Saddam Hussein and to continue providing adequate military forces in the region to do that.
 The letter, carried to the Saudi king by Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, also was intended to smooth American-Saudi relations after a long summer of haggling over whether the Saudis would accept the storage of a large stockpile of American military equipment and ammunition as part of a new security arrangement in the Persian Gulf region. The storage issue has yet to be resolved.
 The new round of American planning also was motivated by intelligence reports indicating growing disaffection with Mr. Hussein among Iraq's traditional ruling families and clans. At least one bloody rivalry had surfaced between Mr. Hussein's son-in-law, Hussein Kamal Hassan, and another close relative, Ali Hassan Majid, who presided over occupied Kuwait as Mr. Hussein's personal representative. Both relatives have held a series of key posts in Mr. Hussein's Government over the last decade.
 In November, the Iraqi leader replaced Mr. Hassan as Defense Minister with Mr. Majid, setting off a gun battle between the security forces of the rival relatives, according to what was described by one official as a reliable "human intelligence" report received by the Central Intelligence Agency.
 A Deputies Committee meeting on Dec. 12 examined the limitations in using United States military forces in supporting an indigenous challenge to Mr. Hussein's authority, and that review focused in part on the strong cautionary recommendation from General Powell that the success of any new United States military intervention in Iraq could not be assured without a large and combined effort by United States air and ground combat forces.
 
Powell's Diminished Role
 One official, describing the White House reaction to General Powell's report, said it was deemed the "wrong answer" because of its insistance that major ground combat forces would have to be committed. As a consequence, a subcommittee of the deputies has been meeting under National Security Council supervision since mid-December to consider and refine military and covert action options for Iraq, officials said.
 General Powell's contribution to the continued policy discussion appears to have been diminished since the planning meetings have been pulled into the White House. But a one-star general from the Joint Chiefs of Staff attends each meeting, an Administration official said.
 Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, has argued that the use of American air power to support rebel Iraqi military units could have the decisive effect of breaking the back of Mr. Hussein's core security force in Baghdad, an allied official said.
 Saudi officials are said to have argued that ground combat forces are not needed to bring down Mr. Hussein if an effective guerrilla force can be armed and supported with allied air strikes against Iraq's top military units.
 
Chemical-Arms Training
 To some officials in the Administration, the risks of such a major operation outweigh the benefits. If United States military forces got bogged down in an Iraqi civil war, it would seriously tarnish the image the military achieved in the Persian Gulf war.
 There are other unknowns. A senior American analyst said last week that Mr. Hussein's military forces continue to train on equipment that is associated with chemical warfare, indicating that a final showdown with Mr. Hussein might include the use of chemical weapons.
 Yet some officials say Mr. Hussein is near the end of his tether and that his rule could shatter under greater pressure.
 The Central Intelligence Agency, which had predicted that Mr. Hussein would not complete 1991 in office, today declines to estimate how long he can survive.
 
Effects of U.N. Sanctions
 There are several reasons for presuming he cannot survive indefinitely.
 Iraq has been denied virtally all of its national income by United Nations sanctions for more than 18 months and continues to refuse to sell limited quantities of crude under United Nations supervision.
 Iraqi Government expenditures indicate that its reserves are no longer adequate to supply more than essentials, like food and medicine, to military forces and key leadership groups. The rest of the country gets subsistance rations.
 Though the Sunni Muslim core of the Iraqi leadership rallied to Mr. Hussein in March when minority Kurds and southern Shiites launched twin uprisings, that support is now fraying, senior American analysts say, as Mr. Hussein has reneged on pledges to undertake democratic reforms, purged possible rivals from his Cabinet and shown indifference to the human suffering of millions of Iraqis.

HEADLINE: A Worthy War

BYLINE: By Stephen J. Solarz; Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of New
York, is a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The historical revisionists are already at work. Last year's triumph in the war against Iraq, they claim, has turned to ashes. We won the war only to lose the peace. But the naysayers who make this argument too cavalierly dismiss the strategic and diplomatic benefits produced by Operation Desert Storm.
 To be sure, the fact that Saddam Hussein remains in power is deeply disturbing. But this hardly constitutes an argument against the war, particularly since he would still be comfortably ensconced in Iraq and Kuwait if we had not moved against him. 
Perhaps the war's most significant achievement has been the extent to which we have substantially set back Iraq's efforts to obtain nuclear weapons. We now know that Iraq was far closer to developing them than was believed a year ago. Had we not been willing to use force, Saddam Hussein would undoubtedly have obtained a nuclear arsenal, with grave consequences for the region and the world.
 But there were other benefits as well. By liberating Kuwait from the clutches of a Mesopotamian megalomaniac, we prevented Saddam Hussein from getting his hands on the economic jugular of the world. We demonstrated that powerful countries will no longer be permitted to take over weaker ones. And we opened the way for a Middle East peace process that has made it possible, for the first time in over 40 years, for Israel to negotiate directly with its Arab neighbors.
 It is worth considering what the consequences would have been had we not been willing to use military power against Iraq. Based on Mr. Hussein's willingness to use other weapons of mass destruction, there is every reason to believe that, once he acquired nuclear weapons, he would have used them as well.
 Moreover, after absorbing Kuwait, Mr. Hussein would have been in a position to dominate the entire Persian Gulf. At best, to prevent the other gulf dominoes from falling, we would have been obliged to maintain tens of thousands of American troops indefinitely in the culturally and climatically inhospitable Arabian Peninsula.
 Furthermore, there would have been no peace process between Israel and the Arabs. The stability of the Arab countries willing to join us in opposing Iraq would have been badly shaken. And the stage would have been set for additional campaigns of conquest, in which the number of casualties inflicted by a nuclear-armed Iraq would have been infinitely greater than the number of those killed last year.
 While reasonable people disagreed about whether sanctions would be sufficient to force Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait, it seems clear in retrospect that economic pressure alone would not have done the job. Even now, after we have destroyed much of his military machine and economic infrastructure, and with sanctions still in place, Mr. Hussein remains unregenerate and unrepentant. His refusal to comply with the cease-fire agreement is clear evidence that the continued application of sanctions would have been a formula for failure, rather than a strategy for success.
 The opponents of war also told us we would get hopelessly bogged down in a desert war with massive American casualties. Yet we won the war in six weeks, with fewer than 150 American fatalities.
 We were cautioned that the Arab masses would overthrow Arab governments courageous enough to oppose Iraq. Yet every one of our Arab partners is more stable today than if Mr. Hussein had gotten away with the annexation of Kuwait.
 We were warned that a war would divert tens of billions of dollars from pressing problems at home. Yet virtually the entire cost of the war was paid by our coalition partners and other friendly countries.
 We may not have accomplished everything we hoped to, but there can be little doubt that the gulf and the world are far more congenial to American interests and values than they would have been had we acquiesced in Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression against Kuwait.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Little Relief Seen for Connecticut Hotels

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE new year is not expected to bring much relief to Connecticut's beleaguered hotels. Since 1989, the industry has been battered by the loss or contraction of corporations within the state, by a general cutback in business travel, a decline in tourism and the brute force of the recession in New England.
"In most cases Connecticut hotels are doing as poorly as last year or worse," said Ronald Balmer, director of the Connecticut Hotel-Motel Association in Hartford. "They are hunkering down and cutting back. General managers are doing middle level-tasks. Some properties are closing entire floors and some are in the hands of lenders." 
 The Bank of New England had at least 10 troubled Connecticut hotels in its portfolio when it was taken over by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group last July. Concerned that publicity would further devalue the hotels, Fleet/Norstar declined to identify them.
From the consumer's point of view, nothing has changed except that hotel rates are lower and hotel personnel more attentive. "The banks continue to operate them through management companies," Mr. Balmer said.
At the end of the third quarter of 1991 the average occupancy rate statewide was 59.2 percent, and the average daily room rent was $67.39. The Hartford region was worst, with an average occupancy of 48 percent. Fairfield County did best, with 67 percent. The break-even point is around 72 percent.
The number of hotel rooms in Connecticut has shrunk from 30,000 in 1989, when the figure included projections for new construction, to around 25,000. Mr. Balmer noted that construction was canceled, and Hartford lost 700 rooms when the Parkview Hilton was demolished in 1990 and the Summit Hotel closed in 1991.
Overbuilding in the 1980's produced an indigestible glut, and in a small state easily bypassed by travelers on the way to Massachusetts, Rhode Island or New York, competition for customers has become intense.
Spending money to make money is the catch phrase. The Hartford Sheraton and the Stamford Marriott are pouring more than $5 million each into renovating lobbies, meeting rooms, ballrooms, guest rooms and restaurants and are upgrading services to attract business. "Either you keep improving or you lose market share," said Carl Candels, director of the Hartford Hotel Association.
Brian Connelly, manager of the 400-room Sheraton, Hartford's largest hotel, predicts that the city will continue to lose hotel contracts until a site for a Hartford Convention Center is selected and a proposed 700-room hotel is built.
"We don't have enough rooms to handle regional meetings," he said. "The business has moved to Springfield, Boston and New York." The Providence Convention Center, opening in 1993, will add to the competition.
Occupancy at the Sheraton was 54 percent in 1991, and the average room rate dropped from $150 to $100. In recent weeks it has managed to lure the Hartford Graduate Center account away from the Holiday Inn, and a Pratt & Whitney group from the Radisson, both in nearby Cromwell. The 500-room Sheraton in Stamford, according to Hans Jaspers, its manager, "had a rough year." He would not disclose occupancy figures.
"One of our biggest losses was U.P.S.," he said, referring to United Parcel Service. "They took 40,000 room nights out of the city when they moved to Atlanta.".
"Stamford is a secondary market for New York," said Barbara Seiter, director of the Stamford Visitors and Convention Bureau. "Associations and companies look to us for a better price with proximity to Manhattan. Our average room rate is $70, compared to $150 and up in New York."
Stamford's largest hotel is the Marriott, with 510 rooms and seven suites. Opened in 1977 and expanded in 1986, it has fared better than the Sheraton, the Radisson Tara and the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, the city's other major hotels. Adly Kitmitto, the manager, estimates the weekday occupancy rate at around 75 percent, but weekends are slow.
Marriott's holdings in the state include full-service hotels in Trumbull, Rocky Hill and Farmington; Courtyard Inns in Windsor, Norwalk and Wallingford; Residence Inns in Shelton, Hartford, Meriden and New Haven; and a Fairfield Inn, the company's budget hotel, in Windsor Locks.
Paul Cerullo, regional director of marketing, says that the Residence and Courtyard Inns, priced below the average of $100 for the full-service hotels, are the company's fastest-growing divisions.
WHEN a hotel fails, it usually takes about 20 months for a new management company to turn it around. Early in 1991 the Ramada Inn in New Britain was taken over by the Northeast Savings Bank of Hartford. The bank hired Lodging Unlimited of Westchester, Pa., a 20-year-old management company specializing in distressed hotels, to operate the 119-room inn.
"The Ramada is in a marginal location with little hotel activity, and the recession aggravated its problems," said Michael Nocula, who was installed as manager. "We are in the final stages of a $500,000 refurbishing inside and out, and we have initiated a marketing blitz in an area covering Hartford, Waterbury, New Haven and Stamford."
Room rents were lowered from $60 to $40, but occupancy remains just above 40 percent.
The bank took over the Ramada from Donald Wallace, who bought it from his former partner, Simon Konover, chairman of Konover Associates, a West Hartford development firm. The Konover Hotel Corporation, a subsidiary, owns in various partnerships the Sheraton at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, the Mystic Hilton, the Sheraton in Norwich, the Ramadas in Hartford and Wethersfield, and The Inn (formerly Holiday Inn) in Plainville.
"We are not doing well, but we will hold on to what we have," Mr. Konover said. "There is no market for selling."
Next month a new gambling casino operated by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians will open in Ledyard, creating what may be a shortage of hotel rooms there. The Pequots expect daily attendance of 5,000 to 7,000 people, and Vivian Stanley of the Southeastern Connecticut Tourism District notes that "there are just 3,200 rooms in the area."
Acknowledged to be the state's premier tourist destination, the district contains Mystic Seaport, the Marinelife Aquarium, the Groton submarine base, the Coast Guard Academy, historic New London, Thames River recreational boating and now the casino. A Mystic Coast Coalition has been formed by business and civic leaders and the Pequot Indians to develop a unified marketing strategy.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:

Walsh, a Pratt & Whitney spokesman, said his company tried to spread its business among as many hotels as possible; it has not moved its account from one to another.

HEADLINE: Odyssey Ends for 'Raft of the Medusa'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
IN the summers of 1988 and 1989 Peggy Hill Rosenkranz halted her career in entertainment law and dabbled in producing theater in Southampton.
By 1990, theatergoers wondered what Mrs. Rosenkranz would come up with next. She had already put on a Pulitzer Prize-winning play near a pond in Agawam Park and a musical tryout at the Southampton Cultural Center. 
 What Mrs. Rosenkranz came up with was a tough play involving a support group for people with AIDS. It represented a cross-section of New York City, with white, black, Hispanic, gay, straight, bisexual, married, single, blue-collar and professional members.
 
Cast of Encounter Session
 The play was "Raft of the Medusa" by Joe Pintauro, a well-known playwright from the East End. The title is taken from the painting by Theodore Gericault that hangs in the Louvre. Its vision of shipwreck survivors provides a multilevel metaphor for the play's concerns.
A teen-age girl, a well-known actor and a hearing- and speech-impaired homeless woman on drugs are among those in an encounter session. Other characters include the ghost of an AIDS casualty who was a rabbinical student and a therapist who is modeled after John Haigney, head of the Long Island Association for AIDS Care.
"As soon as I read the script," Mrs. Rosenkranz recalled, "I was so moved and affected that I felt it was important that it have an effect on people. I realized this would be my third production."
But there was a hitch. "This was not a play for a summer weekend in Southampton," she said. "It had to be produced in New York."
But a play that was presumed unlikely by its producer and playwright for a summer weekend in the Hamptons and that garnered respectable reviews and wide press comment failed to adapt to the winter season in New York and closed last Sunday.
At a closing-night gathering in Mrs. Rosenkranz's apartment on Park Avenue, the guests, among them the playwright, his agent, cast members, the casting director, the press agent and the ushers, were, as Mr. Pintauro put it, "trying to figure it all out."
 
Sorting Out Reactions
 "Theories are floating around, and I don't know which I subscribe to," Mrs. Rosenkranz said. In conversations, the producer and writer repeatedly heard acknowledgments like, "Thank you for the opportunity," and, "I'm very proud to have worked on this play.' "
The guests' reactions to the closing included "sort of surprising" and "incomprehensible, shocking and traumatic." Theories for the closing encompassed resistance to the subject and bad timing. January is an off month in the theater.
There also were unanswerable questions, including, "Did the Magic Johnson publicity go against us?" and, "Are people feeling too vulnerable, too threatened?"
Some guests commented on the failure of gay organizations to respond to offers of discounts and free tickets. Mr. Pintauro said one inevitable reason was that "people were not buying tickets."
"It's all about money," he said.
"If the economics were such that we could have run 8 to 10 weeks without suffering devastating losses," Mrs. Rosenkranz said, "the play ultimately would have found an audience through word of mouth.
"But if you sink, you sink fast. You may expect to lose a lot the first week, but you hope to build up to break even, which would have been $40,000 a week, by the time the reserve was used up.
"But we never grew, and the losses were massive, over $30,000 a week. With a maximum gross of $88,000 a week, we started at $6,000 and never did more than $12,000."
To keep the show going, in its final week Mrs. Rosenkranz contributed an additional $10,000. "If we had just gotten in the ballpark of taking in $26,000 or $28,000," she said, "we could have tried to raise additional money. But we stayed at a low level."
"Raft" opened at the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village on Dec. 17. It closed after 9 previews and 30 performances.
Mr. Pintauro wrote "Raft" in his Victorian house on John Street in Sag Harbor. "It was as if it had touched an uncertain nerve and released a lot of the pent-up emotions that everybody has been sitting with," he said.
The play, he added, intends to confront "the monumentality of the catastrophe and the suffocating silence of helplessness, the experience of the horror of facing grief and anger, instead of cowering in fear, and then saying, 'Let's go on with honor.' "
Explaining her motivation to produce the play, Mrs. Rosenkranz said: "I had all the information and I had all the contacts. And I said, 'I'm the only one who can produce this and if I don't, it will never be produced.'
"I didn't know how to do it. So I learned how to do it, everything connected with producing commercially in New York City. But everyone told me, 'You have no idea how difficult it is to produce Off Broadway to begin with. You have no star. And this is a serious topic that's going to be a turnoff.'
"All theaters were putting us at the bottom of the list. Everything was difficult. Not a step along the way was easy. So I guess I had the passion and the tenacity."
Mrs. Rosenkranz spent most of the summer of 1990 in TriBeCa, where in mid-July she presented 15 showcase performances of "Raft" at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art. "By the third week," she said, "people were lined up in the streets, unable to get in."
Swept away by the play's theatrical power, social significance, turnaway crowds and what Mr. Pintauro called "explosive, immense" audience reactions, Mrs. Rosenkranz was determined to take "Raft" to Off Broadway.
She turned into a commercial producer for real, hiring other lawyers to draw up a limited partnership and negotiate options; interviewing managers, press agents, representatives of advertising agencies and casting directors; searching for a theater and luring investors, 12 in all, none of them friends from Southampton.
Finally, $400,000, the cost of the Off Broadway production, was raised, in contrast to the $7,000 cost of what Mrs. Rosenkranz called the "showcase on a shoestring."
For 20 years, Mrs. Rosenkranz has been spending summers in Southampton with her husband, Robert, an investment banker. They have a son, Nicholas, 21 years old, who was assistant director of Mr. Pintauro's play, and a daughter, Stephanie, 17. The family has owned a home on South Main Street for nine years.
Mrs. Rosenkranz earned a degree from the Columbia University Law School and studied acting at the Herbert Berghof studio in Manhattan. Although she has practiced corporate law and worked on criminal cases in the State Court of Appeals, it was through entertainment law that she balanced her practical and theatrical inclinations.
"You do a contract," she said, "and then you go to the opening night, which is much more interesting than negotiating for a shopping mall."
Although the reviews were mixed at best and Mr. Pintauro's writing was generally criticized as pat, overwrought and manipulative, enough strong adjectives, mostly "powerful," were extracted for advertising, even from negative notices. In The New York Times, Mel Gussow described the play as a "microcosmic crisis clinic, airing aspects of a tragedy and entreating the audience into an act of empathy."
Mr. Pintauro, a priest who turned to writing advertising copy and then poetry, novels and plays, bought a house in North Haven in 1960 for $9,000. Ten years later, after publishing several volumes of poetry, he purchased his current home, with a carriage house next to it, for "much more," he said.
Although many Off Broadway theaters have performed his plays, Mr. Pintauro is associated with the Circle Repertory as a company playwright, which means that his works are developed in a laboratory series. The theater presented his "Snow Orchid," with Peter Boyle and Olympia Dukakis, in 1982, and "Beside Herself," with William Hurt, in 1989.
"Wild Blue," eight one-acters by Mr. Pintauro that were seen in New York in 1987, opened in San Francisco the night before "Raft" closed. His unfinished "The Dead Boy" was recently read at the Royal Court In London. It is "just as startling and controversial" as "Raft," Mr. Pintauro said, adding that it was about a sex scandal involving a priest and a boy.
Referring to those who react to AIDS with apathy, as with people being locked in a refrigerator, Mr. Pintauro said "Raft" was "a cannon blast at that refrigerator door."
As to whether Mrs. Rosenkranz will again risk commercial producing, she said: "I think so. It's not possible to put this much effort into a project and just give up. People tell me it was not a failure. And now I have the skill."

LENGTH: 1389 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Los Angeles;
Despite the Doldrums, Downtown Bustles

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
WHILE construction of new office buildings approaches a standstill in this city's downtown, the center city remains abuzz with new public works and developer-government collaborations.
Among projects in contruction or planning are a subway system and stations, a concert hall, a convention center, museums and public amenities. Planning for most of them has been going on for years and their arrival seems unrelated to the current softness in the real estate market. 
 "Just because office space is overbuilt does not mean that nothing else needs to happen," said a developer, Michael Barker, co-managing partner of Barker Patrinely Group of Houston. "As the space that is now vacant fills up, more people are going to come downtown to work and live."
He plans to start construction next fall on two office buildings -- one of them for the municipal government -- totaling 858,000 square feet, a 426-room hotel, 326 residential units and a 100,000-square-foot Japanese American National Museum on land leased from the city in the Little Tokyo district.
Both the overbuilt office market and the publicly sponsored projects can be traced to the same source: a continuing effort by local government to turn a formerly drab area into what one official describes as "a world-class, 24-hour city." This has been a pet project of Mayor Tom Bradley, abetted by the powerful Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency, which oversees central city.
One of the most flamboyant efforts is the planned $110 million Walt Disney Concert Hall on a site owned by Los Angeles County, near the existing Los Angeles Music Center. Construction of the 2,450-seat concert hall, to be the future home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, was spearheaded by a $50 million contribution by Lillian Disney, widow of Walt Disney; promoters are soliciting private contributions to make up the rest.
The sculptural design by Frank O. Gehry, the Santa Monica architect, has won high praise from architectural critics. The project was recently approved by the Los Angeles City Council and construction is expected to start in the fall.
Another high-profile effort is the $14 million facelift of downtown's oldest park, Pershing Square. The 7.5-acre plaza is an eyesore of cracked concrete that has rankled the owners of surrounding office buildings.
The proposed redesign by the Mexican architect Ricardo Legoretta and the landscape architect Laurie Olin of Philadelphia promises a fountain with a 120-foot obelisk, a performance stage and ample planting for a park now occupied by transients and drug dealers. Work is to start next month.
In a novel arrangement, surrounding building owners will pay for $8 million of the costs through an elective tax district; the redevelopment agency is contributing the rest. The project won approval this month.
Another visible symbol of government-sponsored construction downtown is the million-square-foot expansion of the Los Angeles Convention Center. The drum-shaped building was designed by Pei Cobb Freed & Partners of New York.
The $300 million project, which has spurred the construction of 1,500 new hotel rooms, is currently under construction, with completion expected in 1993.
Most ambitious, however, is the intent to re-establish downtown as the linchpin in a regional rail system. The first leg of the Metro Rail subway system is due in June 1993. Three new commuter lines to the suburbs start operating in the fall.
"This is the renaissance of downtown as a transportation hub," said Elizabeth Harrison, vice president of Catellus Development Corporation. The company, formerly known as Santa Fe Pacific Realty, plans to renovate Union Station and to start construction later this year on a 500,000-square-foot building to be occupied entirely by the offices of the Regional Transportation District, a local transit authority.
DESPITE all these projects, downtown Los Angeles still appears unfinished to some urban planners, who have criticized the city for being "unfriendly" to pedestrians. The newer sections of the financial district are dominated by high-rise buildings, set back from the street and surrounded by empty plazas. One local architect has described the area scornfully as "a 1960's-style downtown built in the 1980's."
Downtown needs "connections" to link business, government, industrial and residential areas, said Rob Maguire 3d, co-managing partner of Maguire Thomas Partners, the most active office developer in the area. "You really need to get a pedestrian network of urban spaces," he said.
Maguire Thomas Partners recently contributed one such connection to the city: an outdoor stairway at the base of its 73-story First Interstate World Center. The steps offer a rare pedestrian link between Bunker Hill and the rest of downtown.
A few blocks away, city officials plan another such link: the reconstruction of a turn-of-the-century funicular railroad called Angel's Flight to carry passengers 70 vertical feet between Bunker Hill and lower-level streets. The officials would like to start the reconstruction by mid-year.
Pedestrian activity has also become a goal for the redevelopment agency, which did much in the 1960's and '70's to promote high-rise development in the area.
One attempt is to build wide sidewalks and plant trees on Hope Street, and remake it as a pedestrian corridor traversing the financial district and ending at the Los Angeles Central Library. The pyramidal building, designed by Bertram Goodhue in 1930, is undergoing a $154 million renovation and expansion.
Construction of the pedestrian corridor is to start next month and be paid for by the redevelopment agency.
Developers and leasing agents are sober but not sour about the office market. Vacancy rates were 25 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield of California. Much of that vacancy represents nearly 7 million square feet of space completed last year or expected in 1992, inundating a market of about 26 million square feet.
Despite poor publicity about commercial real estate, tenants surprised observers by absorbing 1.5 million square feet last year downtown, where absorption of 1 million square feet is considered successful.
Robert A. Ortiz, executive vice president of Cushman Realty Corporation, attributed the brisk leasing to an influx of law firms, international banks and Asian trading companies. Still, landlords have deeply discounted their rents to $24 to $27 in new buildings, almost as low as suburban rates, which run around $23 to $25. Downtown rents peaked in the early 1980's in the high-$30 range.
Although many of the current rents fall beneath the "pro formas" that developers and their lenders originally envisioned for this city's newest crop of buildings, "landlords must sign those deals anyway," Mr. Maguire, the developer, said.
Some naysayers appear ready to consign downtown to the same limbo of perpetual softness where Houston, Denver and Phoenix already dwell. But Mr. Maguire dismissed comparisons. "You don't have the problems of regional overbuilding, as do those cities," he said.
He observed that other office markets in Los Angeles County, including those in Santa Monica and Burbank, are restricted by lack of land, by no-growth zoning or by balky local governments. In the future, tenants requiring several floors may have to settle in downtown Los Angeles.
The "one positive note" about the current soft market, Mr. Maguire says, is that there is "absolutely" no financing available for speculative projects, and possibly none even for those with significant pre-leasing.
"EVERYBODY has been battered so hard that lenders are going back to prudent underwriting standards," and allow the tenants to catch up with the rising flood of space, Mr. Maguire said.
Notwithstanding the high vacancy rates, the recent spate of office construction has brought some new interest to a formerly undistinguished skyline.
Among the recent buildings are 777 Tower by Cesar Pelli of New Haven; First Interstate World Center by Pei Cobb Freed; Sanwa Bank Plaza by Albert C. Martin & Associates of Los Angeles; 550 South Hope by Kohn Pedersen Fox of New York, the 801 Tower by The Architects Collaborative of Cambridge, Mass., and the Gas Company Tower by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Pei Cobb Freed's design for the Los Angeles convention center. (Photograph by Roy J. Wright); Albert C. Martin's Sanwa Bank Plaza on Wilshire Boulevard. (Joe Aker)

 Speaking in flawless English that he refined during more than a decade of service in the United States, a former K.G.B. official has appeared on talk shows and before Congress to offer revelations about Soviet spying.  Fifty years after Nazi bureaucrats met at a villa to plan the destruction of European Jews, the building has been turned into Germany's first permanent memorial to six million Jews who were put to death. A1

 Tensions increased in Algeria as the national police headquarters was bombed and the new military Government reportedly rounded up more leaders of a Muslim fundamentalist party. A3
 
TUNISIA TIGHTENS REPRESSION
 In a move to cripple its Islamic fundamentalist movement, Tunisia has stepped up censorship and detentions, as well as harassment of women who wear veils. A3
 
CAMBODIANS POISED FOR SPRING
 About 370,000 Cambodian refugees are to begin returning to their war-ravaged homeland in March or April, a United Nations official said. The U.N. wants to have as many of the refugees as possible out of camps in Thailand and back home in time for the planting season. A2

 After a bitter period of losses and cost cutting in the United States, the largest American bank company hopes rapid growth abroad will rebuild its financial strength. A1
 
A THREAT TO ENLARGE ISRAEL
 Israeli's hawkish Housing Minister proposes to annex areas where Jewish settlers live in the West Bank if Israel agrees to Palestinian autonomy in the occupied territories. A6
 
IRAN PAID HOSTAGE TAKERS
 Iran paid the captors of Western hostages held in Lebanon about $1 million for each of the 10 hostages released since August, a senior Bush Administration official says. A6

 Over the objections of the Russian central bank and doubts of the Bush Administration, President Yeltsin's advisers are pushing to make the ruble convertible within a few weeks. A8

 Mining and timber companies, developers and other rural landowners are mounting the strongest challenge yet to the nation's principal environmental laws.  Critics of Halcion, the world's best-selling sleeping pill, said its manufacturer concealed data from the Food and Drug Administration showing it caused serious psychiatric side effects. The assertions prompted the agency to begin an investigation of the company. A1

TORN BETWEEN MEXICO AND U.S.
 Imelda H. grew up in Houston eating Mexican food, but when she turned 15 years old she moved out and ate plain white rice for the first time. Finally, she said, "I felt like an American." In predominantly Mexican neighborhoods across the country, such cultural turmoil is pulling families apart. A16
 
KEEPING SEATED IN ILLINOIS
 If Americans are angry enough with Congress to throw out local lawmakers, the March 17 primary in once insurgent-proof Illinois will be the first place it shows. A14
 
A HARDENING OF HEARTS
 Religious leaders say they fear that Americans are turning away from the outstretched hands of the homeless, numbed by the severity of the problem and confused about how to respond. A1

 The Mayor of Birmingham, facing a grand jury investigation of corruption charges, used the confrontation to expound his view that the Justice Department unfairly singles out black officials. A12

 Confirmations of more than two dozen Federal judges have been stalled because of new limits on Congressional access to background reports on Presidential nominees. A12
