HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT LAWS FACE A STIFF TEST FROM LANDOWNERS

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Angry about regulations that control the use of their land, mining and timber companies, developers, farmers and other rural landowners have organized a movement that represents the strongest challenge to date to the nation's principal environmental laws.
In the most successful tactic they have discovered so far, the movement's lawyers have been filing lawsuits for the last two years in a little-known Federal court in Washington, the United States Claims Court. Arguing that the rapid increase of environmental regulations in the last 20 years has restricted their right to use their own property, the landowners say such restrictions are tantamount to a "taking" of land. They argue that just like landowners whose property is seized for roads, bridges, parks or other public purposes, they are entitled to just compensation as provided by the Fifth Amendment.
 
Backing in Congress
 The Supreme Court is considering one such case from South Carolina, and a proposal to require the Government to compensate landowners affected by environmental regulations was approved by the Senate last summer and is pending in the House. That proposal has vigorous support in the White House, which has also proposed legislation to make Federal agencies pay judgments in such cases from their own budgets, making officials accountable for the effect of the regulations. 
 The nation's troubled economy and broad job losses across rural America in the timber industry, mining and agriculture are souring the mood for environmental restrictions and adding fuel to the movement behind the lawsuits.
"Congress never envisioned that the Endangered Species Act would be used by the preservationists to eliminate jobs and people's homes, and push people around the way it has," said Charles Cushman, the executive director of the National Inholders Association, a group based in Battle Ground, Wash., that represents owners of private property in Federal parks and preserves.
 
Raising Cost of Enforcement
 David Howard, a resident of Bleecker, N.Y., who is chairman of the Alliance for America, a national coalition of property owner groups in 44 states, agreed. "What you're seeing is people all over the country that are reaching the point of desperation," he said. "The Government issues more and more regulations, and we're losing local control over our land."
But environmental leaders say the lawsuits could cripple the Government's ability to enforce its basic environmental laws by making them too expensive to enforce. They say the real intention of the movement is to eliminate three decades of environmental protections that are broadly supported by the American public.
"For those of us who are deeply interested in preserving open spaces, this idea of compensation could be ruinous," said Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, who is the ranking Republican on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. "The courts appear to be whittling away at the existing structure of environmental protections, and there is a noticeable change in sentiment about environmental safeguards here in the Senate."
The idea of compensating property owners for losses caused by environmental restrictions was developed in 1985 by Richard A. Epstein, a law professor at the University of Chicago who wrote "Takings, Private Property and the Power of Eminent Domain" (Harvard University Press, 1985). In 1988 President Ronald Reagan signed an executive order based on the book that required agencies to review regulations for their effects on private property.
But environmental lawyers say such a legal strategy has been used before in efforts to thwart social changes. Southern slave owners in the 19th century, for example, argued that the Fifth Amendment protected them from demands to free their slaves, and similar arguments were made in the 1930's by industry groups seeking to set aside minimum wage laws, occupational health statutes and child labor laws.
"Historically, claims that the right to property existed in the Constitution have been used to try and prevent a whole panoply of social reforms and health laws," said Albert H. Meyerhoff, senior lawyer in San Francisco for the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the country's most influential environmental groups. "What's different now is there is an emergence of a new interpretation of property rights law. It presents an extremely serious threat to much of the environmental reform legislation that has been enacted over the last 30 years."
 
Movement Gains Influence
 Indeed, to an extent that has dismayed environmental advocates, the attack on government regulations is gaining influence in the White House, Congress and the courts.
Legislation to give the Attorney General new authority to review and veto Federal regulations for their effect on property rights passed the Senate last summer and is pending in the House.
Representative Jimmy Hayes, Democrat of Louisiana, gained 170 co-sponsors in the House for another proposal to allow all but the most ecologically valuable wetlands to be developed and require the Government to compensate owners prevented from using their land.
"What's driving it is the utter comtempt people now have for the arrogance the Government and the major environmental groups exhibit when it comes to protecting land," Mr. Hayes said. "If they don't believe this issue is red-hot everywhere, tell them to hold a meeting in any town in America."
 
'All the Elements in Place'
 Environmental lawyers who have monitored the movement said they agreed with Mr. Hayes that the movement was widespread. "What we have now are all the elements in place for a major change in how the Government applies its environmental laws," said Erik J. Meyers, general counsel of the Environmental Law Institute in Washington.
That is especially true in an array of legal cases making their way through the Federal courts, and the Supreme Court will consider several such cases this year. By far the most widely watched case will test South Carolina's authority to protect sensitive beaches on barrier islands from development against a property owner's right to seek compensation for two seaside lots he purchased for nearly $1 million but was not allowed to develop.
Legal experts, though, said the case might not produce a precedent because the property owner, David H. Lucas, had not yet exhausted all his legal remedies.
Far more important to the development of new interpretations of property rights law, say lawyers in the field, may be decisions this year from the Claims Court and the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.
 
Most Cases in Decade
 The Claims Court clerk said 52 cases involving allegations of the taking of property were filed last year, the most in at least a decade. The nearly 200 property-taking lawsuits pending in the Claims Court include cases in which property owners challenged the Government's authority to clean up toxic wastes, regulate grazing and water rights, buy land for national parks, restrict mining in wild areas and set aside private land to protect wetlands.
The Claims Court, which was set up specifically to consider such property cases not involving injury claims, and the appellate court are dominated by conservative judges appointed in the last 11 years. In recent months they have ruled that landowners affected by environmental regulations are entitled to compensation.
Late last year, in the largest judgment of its kind, the Government was directed by the two courts to pay a coal company in Wyoming more than $150 million because the Department of Interior barred mining in a protected area. The company, Whitney Benefits, argued in the Claims Court that its coal holdings had been rendered worthless by the restriction. The ruling, upheld by the appellate court, was the strongest legal challenge ever to the Interior Department's authority to regulate strip mining.
The Government appealed the ruling to the Supreme Court, but in a telling indication of the direction the newly conservative Court may take, the Court declined to take up the case, allowing the ruling to stand.
The Appeals Court for the Federal Circuit is also considering two decisions by Loren A. Smith, the Chief Judge of the Claims Court, who was appointed in 1985 by President Reagan. In 1990, Judge Smith ruled that a New Jersey developer and a Florida limestone company were owed millions of dollars by the Government because the Army Corps of Engineers refused them permits to destroy wetlands.
In the first case, Loveladies Harbor Inc., a development company in Long Beach, N.J., was barred in 1982 by the Corps of Engineers from building houses on 12.5 acres of wetland. The wetland was the last undeveloped portion of a 250-acre parcel the company bought in 1956 for $300,000. Judge Smith awarded the company $2.68 million plus interest from 1982 because he viewed the restrictions as a taking of private property.
In the second case, Florida Rock Industries was prevented from mining limestone on 98 of 1,560 acres west of Miami that it had purchased in 1972. In 1980, the Corps of Engineers ordered the company to stop mining because of concern that the activity would pollute ground water. Judge Smith said evidence presented by the company indicated that mining would not pollute water and awarded the company slightly more than $1 million plus interest for the 98 acres.
Both judgments were appealed by the Justice Department, which argued that neither company was eligible for compensation because the regulatory actions were legal and served a public purpose by safeguarding valuable natural resources. In an interview, Barry M. Hartman, the Acting Assistant Attorney General who heads the Environment and Natural Resources Division, criticized Judge Smith and other Claims Court judges for departing from Supreme Court precedents.
Mr. Hartman said that in the Loveladies Harbor and the Florida Rock cases, Judge Smith ruled that a taking of property had occurred even though the Government's action had only partly diminished the land's value. He said the Justice Department was concerned about the rulings because of the growing cost of claims and the potential for even larger judgments.
In an interview, Judge Smith defended his decisions and said he was not interested in establishing new law. "As trial judges, we try to follow the law as laid down by the Supreme Court and by the Federal Circuit," said Judge Smith, who was a member of President Reagan's transition team in 1981. "I call them as I see them. It may produce a result that some don't like, but I'm not a zealot."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Protecting the Wilderness"
 
Major environmental laws affecting landowners.
 
Endangered Species Act 1973
 Defines endangered and threatened species, directs the Government to draw up lists of these species and to acquire lands and waters for wildlife protection and management. The act can prohibit development of land inhabited by endangered species.
 
Clean Water Act 1972
 The Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 set a national goal of eliminating all pollutant discharges into waters by 1985 and making waters safe for fish, wildlife and people by 1983. Prohibits filling in wetlands on public or private land without a permit from the Government.
 
Wild & Scenic Rivers Act 1968
 Designates certain rivers or segments of rivers as part of a National Wild and Scenic Rivers System in which these waterways would be maintained in, or returned to, a pristine state. Sets rules for Government acquisition of land surrounding the rivers.
 
Wilderness Act 1964
 Creates a National Wilderness Preservation System permanently placing over 9 million acres of Federal lands in a protected state and providing for a 10-year review period in which other public lands might be added. Prohibits commercial activities, motorized vehicles and permanent roads in these areas. (pg. A15)

HEADLINE: Aristide Insists on Overhaul of the Haitian Army

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti, whose elected Government was overthrown in a coup on Sept. 30, insisted today that there could be no settlement of the Haitian political crisis without the removal of the army chief and a thorough reorganization of the military.
President Aristide, a populist priest who won Haiti's first genuinely democratic election 13 months ago with more than two-thirds of the vote, was also guarded in accepting the view of the Organization of American States that naming a new Prime Minister would constitute a political solution to the Haitian crisis. 
 Any immediate changes in the status of the army and its chief, Gen. Raoul Cedras, are not part of that political agreement. General Cedras, who said that the President was ousted because he had become a threat to democracy, apparently raised no objections to the O.A.S. political formula that would allow Father Aristide to return.
Today, President Aristide said in an interview that General Cedras had the choice of going to jail or leaving the country before democracy could be restored. But he said ordinary soldiers would be granted amnesty. He accused the military of narcotics trafficking and corruption and called the general and his associates killers responsible for 1,500 to 2,000 deaths and the forced exile of 10,000 political refugees.
"I repeat, political refugees," he said, emphasizing that he rejected the view of United States officials that many Haitians flee for economic reasons.
Diplomats close to the negotiations with President Aristide say that army leaders do not disagree fundamentally that the modernization of the armed forces is important. They would ultimately also accept the creation of a separate unpoliticized police force, which President Aristide is demanding, the diplomats say.
This would take considerable time, they said. Insistence on restructuring the military at the same time that the Aristide Government is restored could prevent a quick settlement.
On Jan. 8, the O.A.S. announced that all parties including President Aristide had accepted Rene Theodore as a new Prime Pinister. Like the President, Mr. Theodore, the leader of the Haitian Communist Party, spent years in exile during the regimes of Francois Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude. American diplomats regard Mr. Theodore as a moderate willing to embrace democracy and a free-market economy. His selection is subject to ratification by the Haitian Parliament.
Today, in an interview in Washington, where he is waiting to meet with Mr. Theodore and a parliamentary delegation, President Aristide said he was not in a position to accept Mr. Theodore as Prime Minister until the two could discuss a future government.
"I have met him only four times in my life, and spoken to him once on the telephone," said President Aristide, speaking in English.
While awaiting Mr. Theodore, who has delayed his trip to Washington for further discussions in Haiti, the exiled President has met with the O.A.S. Secretary General, Joao Clementa Baena Soares, and other officials.
President Aristide, who has been living in Caracas, Venezuela, since the Sept. 30 coup, sidestepped a question about which Americans he hoped to see on his visit here. Many of his supporters are critical of the United States, saying it could be more active in punishing the coup leaders, some of whom are reported to have American bank accounts and visas that allow them to visit this country frequently.
President Aristide would say only that many Haitians would like the United States to tighten its economic embargo on Haiti so that the military would feel the pinch more. But he praised President Bush and his Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, for supporting economic sanctions and his return from exile.
President Aristide said today that despite his misgivings about the military, he remained confident that in "only a few days" there could be a political agreement to clear the way for his return.

HEADLINE: Despite Polls, Mulroney Bid Seems Likely

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has turned setback into advantage before. In 1984, when he first sought to become Prime Minister of Canada, his Progressive Conservative Party was 14 percentage points behind the Liberals in opinion polls. In 1988, six months before his second-term victory, the Tories were 25 points behind.
Canada's next elections are not likely before the fall of 1993. Still, the Tories today are supported by only 16 percent of those surveyed, the lowest voter-approval rating for any governing party in this country. 
 Although Mr. Mulroney's public standing is in tatters, reflecting severe economic reverses and sharp divisions over a strategy for keeping Canada together, the longest-serving Conservative Prime Minister in this century seems determined to seek a third term. A recent shake-up of his Ottawa office, including the appointment of a new chief of staff, an ebullient former advertising man named Hugh Segal, who is well grounded in the party's grass roots, has reinforced this expectation.
Mr. Segal a bluff, witty man who calls himself a "Red Tory" -- roughly equivalent to a moderate Republican in the United States -- has a resume indicating electoral success: He helped a former Premier of Ontario, Bill Davis, win three straight election victories in that province. In a recent interview, Mr. Segal, who is 41 years old, spoke of helping the country get a "glimpse of the Prime Minister's soul and what he genuinely believes in" as the way to build support.
 
Naming New Advisers
 In trying to brush up his image, Mr. Mulroney has tapped other new sources of advice: younger Conservative loyalists, a former Foreign Service officer and a former top Montreal journalist. He is making these unorthodox moves when even the most ardent and optimistic Tories are hard put to find reasons for optimism.
A recent cartoon in The Globe & Mail of Toronto showed a monk at a miracle-monitoring center reading a headline saying "New Chief of Staff Hopes to Restore Mulroney's Popularity" and then urging a fellow monk to "Keep an eye on this one."
Hardly a day goes by without some news of layoffs as the country staggers through one of the deepest recessions in its history. More than 10 percent of the national work force remains unemployed. An economic recovery, which started the middle of 1991, has stalled, according to latest government statistics, largely reflecting conditions in the United States. About 80 percent of Canada's exports and 1.5 million Canadian jobs depend on the American market.
The Government has also had little success in reaching a national consensus on the constitutional changes needed to keep French-speaking Quebec from voting itself out of Canada.
 
Image of Disarray
 Last month an influential Quebec senator, Claude Castonguay, abruptly resigned as co-leader of a Parliament committee examining constitutional proposals. He gave ill health as the reason, but his departure reinforced a public impression of governmental disarray. Adding to this sense of floundering is widely reported in-fighting between the Constitutional Affairs Minister, Joe Clark, a former Canadian Prime Minister, and other top advisers to Mr. Mulroney.
Mr. Mulroney, who is 52, does have the advantage of time, at least 18 months, before he has to face the electorate. He is counting on the economy turning up well before then, presumably putting voters in a better frame of mind. His hopes could be well founded. Interest rates have sharply fallen, as in the United States, and inflation is running at an annual rate of less than 2 percent. Sensing better times ahead, the Toronto Stock Exchange has been enjoying a bull market, along with stocks in New York.
And there is some optimism among international experts. The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that Canada will lead the industrial world in growth this year and next and will achieve the second-lowest inflation rate, after Japan.
Mr. Mulroney is counting on credible progress in resolving the constitutional crisis. One of the points he makes is the linkage between the constitutional issues and the economy. Should the country break up, many economists believe, the economic consequences would be dire for all of Canada, and Quebec would end up the big loser.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
BABY'S DEATH RAISES QUESTIONS
A 5-month-old Harlem boy who had been badly burned more than a month ago died early Friday at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center. The case has become the focus of an investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney and the New York City Medical Examiner, who said that the child was abused and that they were also looking into the possibility that mistreatment at the hospital contributed to the child's death. A spokesman from the medical examiner's office said the autopsy showed that a feeding tube had been misplaced in the boy, puncturing his heart. B3. 

AIRLINES CHALLENGE LAW ON DETAINEES
Saying they are being forced to run what amounts to private jails in airport motels, an organization representing all the major overseas air carriers plans to file a lawsuit seeking to end a policy that requires them to house foreign detainees. As a result of the policy, established by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, hundreds of aliens have been held for months at a time at the expense of the airlines that brought them here. A MOST UNLIKELY FAMILY FILM
"Juice," the latest film to stir fears of teen-age violence at urban theaters, seems an unlikely fare for a Sunday family outing. But for many parents in the half-filled theater at 84th Street and Broadway, the controversial film about inner-city life offered a way to address the daily violence and peer pressure their children will probably confront, if they haven't already. Upper West Side Journal, B3.
 
WHAT OBSESSES NEW YORKERS ALWAYS HAS
For nearly four centuries, New Yorkers have been obsessed by race. Ethnic and racial violence continues to strike an even more visceral chord as the threshold of indignation rises with each horrific crime. The historic resonance of these conflicts may be comforting to some people because, after all, the city survived earlier episodes when tensions brought on by the integration of ethnic groups gave way to violence. HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Harkin Assails Competition In New Hampshire Debate

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa attacked several of his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination tonight in an attempt to give fresh impetus to his faltering campaign.
In a two-hour debate on WMUR, the state's only network affiliate, and on the cable network C-Span, Mr. Harkin accused Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas of imposing unfair taxes on "the little guy" and asserted that Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska had failed to protect American manufacturing jobs. New Hampshire's primary, the first in the nation, takes place Feb. 18, and all five of the principal Democratic candidates joined the debate. 
 Mr. Harkin is running fifth in the most recent poll, taken by The Boston Globe from Jan. 13 to 15 and published today. It represented more bad news for the Iowan, who has already suffered the defection of several major trade unions whose support he had sought for his liberal candidacy. Party strategists say that he must finish no worse than third to retain a realistic chance of nomination.
The Globe poll, which included 400 Democratic and independent voters who said they planned to vote in the Democratic primary, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points, the paper said.
Mr. Clinton finished first with 29 percent, with former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts second at 17 percent and Mr. Kerrey third at 16 percent. Although little known nationally, Mr. Tsongas has benefited from coming from a neighboring state. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had 7 percent and Mr. Harkin finished last with 3 percent.
The Democratic Presidential campaign is only now getting started in earnest, however, with the candidates beginning to draw sizable crowds, and many voters remain unfamiliar with the candidates. More than one voter in four surveyed by The Globe -- 26 percent -- described himself or herself as undecided, and if past New Hampshire races are any guide, many of those who say they have made up their minds will change them before the voting takes place.
Still, Mr. Harkin clearly felt the need to make an impact tonight.
He drew attention to a sales tax increase imposed in Arkansas during Mr. Clinton's term and asked, "If that's what he has done in Arkansas, what's he going to do as President -- stick it to the little guy again?" Mr. Clinton replied with a criticism of Mr. Harkin's vote for a Senatorial raise.
 
A Problem With Names
 A bit later, the Iowan clashed with Mr. Kerrey. He misidentified the Senator from Nebraska as "Senator Kennedy," to which Mr. Kerrey responded, "that's not the only thing you're confused about." Mr. Harkin said Mr. Kerrey should have voted against extending to President Bush special "fast track" authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
Drawing attention to Mr. Kerrey's new television commercials here, which show him as a hockey goalie defending American jobs in trade negotiations, Mr. Harkin said, "Last summer, you let the puck go by."
All the candidates blamed President Bush for the recession that has punished New Hampshire with particular severity, and all promised vigorous remedies, inluding tax cuts of various types. Mr. Brown, for example, said he would eliminate all Federal taxes except a flat-rate tax of 13 or 14 percent for everyone with minimal deductions.
The candidates' comments on crime, which with economics and education formed the subject matter of the debate, showed the scars of 1988, when Mr. Bush used what he contended was Michael S. Dukakis's softness on crime against him. Not all of the Democrats backed capital punishment, but several did, and all were careful to call for tougher law enforcement to make the streets safe.
 
Reply From Clinton
 The moderator of the debate, Cokie Roberts, a special correspondent for ABC News and a commentator for National Public Radio, raised with Mr. Clinton the possibility that if he were the nominee the Republicans would eventually find a woman who would lend credibility to repeated charges that he had been unfaithful to his wife, Hillary. He said he had run for office 17 times in 17 years, and insisted that any lurking scandals would have surfaced during those campaigns, adding, "I think the American people are sick and tired of that kind of negative politics."
"I'm the only real Democrat in the race," Mr. Harkin said in an aggressive closing statement. His television commercials in the state have only been running since Friday, and his aides are hopeful that they, plus his debate performance, will enable him to catch his rivals.
The candidates squabbled once again over a tax cut for the middle class, with Mr. Clinton asserting that it was essential to both long- and short-term economic growth. Mr. Harkin, who argues that such proposals would provide little help to most Americans, went on the attack at that point, focusing on Mr. Clinton's record on taxes in Arkansas.
Echoing his recent advertising campaign, Mr. Clinton argued that the Washington elites were out of touch with average Americans and "just don't get it."
 
Criticism for White House
 Mr. Tsongas also criticized the idea of a tax cut for the middle class, asserting that the idea was "coming from the media consultants and the polling people." The former Senator argued that a cut in the tax on capital gains, aimed at encouraging long-term investment, was a critical way of spurring long-term economic growth.
Mr. Brown seemed to be trying to broaden his message tonight. His notion of replacing the current income tax system with a flat tax was immediately criticized by Mr. Harkin. The Iowan criticized the concept as regressive and said it sounded "like something proposed by the Flat Earth Society."
In the midst of the intramural disputes, the candidates occasionally took some shots at the White House. Mr. Clinton asserted that the nation had "for 10 long years" suffered under an Administration that refused to deal with racial divisions. "We need a President who says, 'We've got to end the politics of race in this country,' " the Governor said.
Mr. Tsongas scoffed at Mr. Bush as a President who had "spent more time talking about crime than any President in history and done less about it."

HEADLINE: Charge Against Mayor Strikes Chord in Birmingham

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 18

 BODY:
As Mayor Richard Arrington was resisting a Federal grand jury's investigation of corruption charges here this week, and being cited for contempt in the process he used the confrontation to try once again to attract national attention to his view that the Justice Department unfairly singles out black officials.
Letters went out from the Mayor's office to a host of local and national organizations inviting them to participate in a hearing here next month into "the selective prosecution and harassment of black leadership." 
 Mayor Arrington, 50 years old, who became the city's first black mayor in 1979, said he hoped the meeting might provoke the interest of Congress in an investigation of its own.
But locally, his accusations have already struck responsive chords. Mr. Arrington's supporters accept them, and even some of his longtime political opponents lament the way the charges echo the days of Birmingham's racial divisions at the height of the civil rights struggles of the 1960's.
 
Hanging On to Logs
 Mayor Arrington's current battle involves his refusal to turn over appointment logs to investigators looking into charges of kickbacks on city contracts. But over the years, the Mayor has been investigated more than a dozen times, he says, and he has become a leading voice among those asserting that black officials are singled out.
His complaint was taken up by others in the 1980's, as investigations and indictments of black officials seemed to arise in disproportionate numbers. Frank Donaldson, the United States Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama, has denied a racial motivation in his investigations of the Mayor.
Many investigations of black officials here and elsewhere have faltered quietly or bombed loudly, but there have also been notable convictions. One was that of former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, on drug charges.
In the 1991 investigation of vote selling in the South Carolina Legislature, some of those convicted were black, but several others were white, a fact that some people, including Mr. Arrington, concede makes it more difficult for him to build support for his accusations.
"I don't think there is as much public receptivity to my charges in light of these events," said Mayor Arrington in an interview on Friday. "But that doesn't change the validity of the charges or the fact that there is a double standard when it comes to the investigations of black officials and white officials."
Milton Morris, a political scientist and vice president for research at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization focusing on issues affecting black people, said that so far there was little or no firm evidence that race has been a factor in Federal investigations of black elected officials. But he said there was ample evidence of the disproportionate effect that even the hint of wrongdoing has on them.
"The tragedy is that black elected officials are a relatively small but highly visible part of the population of elected officials," said Mr. Morris. "I have no evidence to support the claim that there is a deliberate and venal attempt to target them, but what happens is that any allegation simply stands out more prominently and with each allegation credibility is undermined that much more."
But some like Natalie Davis, a political scientist at Birmingham Southern College who operates a political polling firm, said Mr. Arrington's reputation generally for honesty would add credibility to his efforts.
 
15 Inquiries in Career
 Just four months ago Mr. Arrington won election to a fourth term with 63 percent of the vote in a city that is more than 65 percent black. As with most of his past re-election campaigns, he got more than 95 percent of the black vote, Ms. Davis said, and barely 15 percent of the white vote.
That kind of electoral one-sidedness has dogged Mr. Arrington's political career even as he has managed to maintain a reasonably strong economic base in the city. Throughout that time, he said, there have been no fewer than 15 investigations and attempts to snare him in inquiries directed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Through a 1989 Freedom of Information Act filing, Mr. Arrington has documented some of his assertions that Federal officials have shown an inordinate interest in him. On other occasions he has produced affidavits from other targets of Federal investigations who said they were asked by investigators to work under cover in implicating Mr. Arrington.
"They usually go after people who are vulnerable and facing other charges such as tax charges and they squeeze them," the Mayor said.
It is for that reason, he said, that he refused to release five years of his office appointment logs. With such a list, he said, investigators would have a wealth of names of people who could be intimidated.
According to Mr. Arrington, his lawyers and court papers in the current investigation, the Mayor is said to have entered into a kickback arrangement with an Atlanta architect, Tarlee Brown, who had done city contract work and who had been a business partner of Mr. Arrington's. Mr. Brown, who pleaded guilty to fraud charges and has been cooperating with investigators, first made the accusations last September in connection with a fraud case against a city consultant.
Mr. Donaldson, the United States Attorney, has refused to comment specifically on the investigation. But he and his aides have filed civil suits against Mr. Arrington charging slander over his accusations of racially motivated investigations.
Mr. Arrington and his aides concede that the investigation and the prospect that he may be jailed for contempt have hurt him in his dealings with the city's mostly white business community. Ms. Davis said the marginal support among this group is most affected by the investigation and the accusations of racism. They reason, she said, that where there is smoke there is fire.
David Vann, a lawyer and a former Birmingham mayor, said blacks in the city were almost uniformly behind Mr. Arrington while whites were split over the accusations. The result, Mr. Vann said, was a kind of "racial polarization."
Betty Bock, who is white and who is the president of the integrated Five Points South Neighborhood Association, said: "I am inclined to view this investigation of the Mayor as a fishing expedition. But I have real concern about hearing the word 'racism' bandied about. We have a history in terms of race relations, and we have worked very hard to overcome that image and made significant strides. This only serves to hurt our image."
Linda Coleman, a black member of the City Council, said support for the Mayor remained strong among blacks.
"He'll have all the support he needs to run the city from a jail cell if he has to," Mrs. Coleman said at a community meeting intended to bring out support for Mr. Arrington.

HEADLINE: From Pulpits, Talk to Calm Racial Tensions

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
From the majestic pulpit of Riverside Church, the Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr. scanned the diverse faces that showed his congregation to be one of the city's most racially mixed. He urged them to look at one another.
"We are not integrated because we are shoulder-to-shoulder," he declared to the hundreds of worshipers. "We are integrated because we are heart-to-heart." 
 It was a bittersweet point of pride, coming after a spate of racial attacks and retaliations that had spread across the city in the fortnight preceding the observance of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Yesterday, causes and cures for the racial tension were discussed in pulpits and pews, making many New Yorkers confront the uneasy realization that the dream of the civil rights leader remains elusive.
 
Appeals to Parents and Schools
 Dr. Forbes encouraged his congregation to attend social-issues discussions, including one on race relations, after the services.
Other clerics, like the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d of Abyssinian Baptist Church, encouraged parents to impart values of understanding and self-respect to their children and urged schools to develop a curriculum of inclusion that highlights the contributions of minority groups. And speaking at a ceremony commemorating the civil rights leader at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Mayor David N. Dinkins again exhorted parents to pay attention to their children.
At St. Patrick's Cathedral, John Cardinal O'Connor used the bias attacks as a jumping-off point for a denunciation of what he saw as a greater evil, abortion, postulating that Dr. King would have sided with abortion opponents.
Even as church leaders spent the day denouncing racial violence, however, the list of bias incidents grew. Hours before the congregations gathered, the police said, about a half-dozen black men surrounded a 29-year-old white Brooklyn resident in Williamsburg and asked, "White boy, what are you doing here?" before punching him in the chest and stealing his wallet.
And on Long Island, a suspect was charged yesterday in the Dec. 28 death of a man who police say was run off the road because his assailant believed he was gay.
The more recent attacks have led to retaliations, among them last week's reported rape of a 15-year-old white Brooklyn girl, an attack that the police have classified as a bias crime. At St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, residents of the teen-age girl's community were reminded by the pastor that the bias attacks echoed the biblical violence between Cain and Abel.
Speaking of more recent transgressions, the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, stood before the congregation and tempered his outrage against the girl's rape with exhortations that vigilantism would only heighten tensions. He urged people to "keep a lid on" their anger and set an example of tolerance to their children. "Remember, racism starts at the dinner table and in the living room," he said.
 
Fears of Retaliation
 Other fears of retaliation were voiced in the Bronx at a congregation of Albanian immigrants and their children. In the two Bronx attacks in which black and Hispanic youths had their faces smeared with white paint, the assailants claimed to be members of a neighborhood group of Albanian street toughs, prompting fear of retaliations and discrimination against the close knit immigrant community.
"In our codes of law and rules, we can discriminate against no religion, no race and no people," said the Rev. Rock Mirdita, pastor of Our Lady of Good Counsel Church in the Bronx. "We have to live in love and peace beyond the family circles." Befitting a church whose neighbors are mostly black and Hispanic, he drove home his point by urging the parishioners to follow the example set by Dr. King and Mother Teresa, who is Albanian, in their quests for peace.
The church's teen-age parishioners have been feeling a bit unsettled since the attacks, for fear of being attacked in retaliation of a crime they vigorously denounced.
"I feel like it's not right," said Debra Dediavanovic, 12 years old. "But I will not consider myself an Albanian because I'm not about to walk down the street and get beat up."
A mile or so to the west, the mother of one of the victims of racial violence led a group of about 100 black, Hispanic and some white residents of Williamsbridge in a march past the sites of attacks on the Bronx schoolchildren. Diane Figueroa stood with the group on the grassy strip of land where her son Bryan, 12, was attacked last week.
"I want to take back the community," she said. "This is not about black or white, because violence is violence and racism is racism."
Spurred by the attack on her son, Ms. Figueroa said she wanted to sponsor dialogues among teen-agers from different ethnic groups so that children could begin to understand each other better.
Discussions ran on after services at Riverside Church, where the congregation prides itself on its history of social activism.
"We got to tune in, one human being to another," said George Bynoe, who is black. He said he would like to invite David Duke, the former Nazi and Klansman who is running for president, to come speak at the church.
"Let's deal with it out in the open," he said. "He's just saying what a lot of people think."
 
Economic Justice
 Racial hatred, Mr. Butts said in an interview after services at the Harlem church, feeds on ignorance. He added that racial justice must be accompanied by economic justice in communities reeling from the recession that has heightened competition for jobs and government funds.
Mr. Dinkins, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said parents played an important role in that reconciliation. "Though it is easy to blame our culture of violence, what about the people who should be standing between that culture and our children, shielding them and teaching them right from wrong?" he asked. "It is sad to say but our children are dying for our attention."
Earlier in the day at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal O'Connor condemned the bias attacks but said they were dwarfed by the greater violence spawned by a lack of moral values.
Invoking Dr. King's writings, Cardinal O'Connor said Dr. King would have opposed abortion as the product of an unjust law imposed by the majority against a minority. "The minority," the Cardinal said, "being the unborn infants who are destroyed each year."

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: TV Critic's Notebook;
Sound Bites Are Tuned Out, And Clearer Images Emerge

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The producers of last night's two-hour get-together of contending Democrats on C-Span evidently learned something from NBC's 90-minute sound-bite festival last month. Instead of trying to squeeze a few words from all the suspects on every subject in the world, Cokie Roberts, presiding, focused on three big domestic matters: the economy, education and crime. She pressed the candidates politely if not always successfully for direct answers without trying to upstage them.
Although viewers may have been left with only a fuzzy notion of the specific proposals to which most laid claim, differences of message and of personality did come through. To be sure, the candidates were united in their put-downs of President Bush for getting the country into its present predicament, three of them spoke of their young daughters and all celebrated their superior compassion. But along the way they began to turn themselves into distinctive figures. 
 This time the cast is now reduced to five. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, the most obviously distinctive, is gone. Contrary to the conventions of the television mystery, the most obstreperous character was not the first to vanish. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who in the first debate got into a fight with his host, Tom Brokaw, over his insistence on soliciting contributions on camera, ended last night's program by reading from a fund-raising solicitation. Ms. Roberts complimented him on saving 29 cents per letter.
Mr. Brown, former Governor of California, has been much joked about, but he does not seem to mind being considered, as Ms. Roberts reported, "Governor Moonbeam." He returns to politics with the reputation of something of a flower child in a time warp and with a commercial that he delivers in response to just about every question: Political corruption, a kowtowing to big contributors, is at the heart of the nation's troubles, and his opponents are all part of it.
His main proposal last night, a flat 13 percent tax to replace the present income tax, had the same pure or simple quality. Whatever one's response to such an approach, there is no mixing up Mr. Brown with anybody else.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa seemed equally determined to set himself apart from "these fellows right here." Three of them, he accused, had in one way or another supported Reaganomics (omitting Mr. Brown, who has not been in office for almost a decade). Wagging a finger smack at the audience, he announced, "I'm the only real Democrat in this race." He also produced again a dollar bill, maybe the same one he displayed the first time around, to show how little the middle-class tax cut proposed by Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, whom Senator Harkin went after with particular bite, would mean to the little man.
Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, too, carried a prop. Three times he held up a pamphlet that bore his name, titled "A Call to Economic Arms." He pleaded guilty to not being a movie star ("Even my dog knows that," he cracked.), and his hangdog look conforms to his sober message. Like Mr. Brown, he has a single big truth: the need to halt America's economic decline. He makes a gloomy messiah. If you are in any doubt which one he is, look for the man with the worried expression.
Senator Kerrey did not mention Vietnam last night. Possibly in deference to criticisms of his dependence on his heroic war record, he made an effort to establish himself in some other way. Mr. Kerrey kept referring to his proposal for national health insurance, to which none of his competitors seemed to take exception. He also apparently has an industrial policy and a plan for restructuring the Federal Government. "I know how to do that!" he declared. That is more than any viewer can know; for television purposes, Senator Kerrey is mostly distinguished for energy of expression and remains a bit hard to place.
As the apparent front-runner, Governor Clinton is assuming the statesman's role. He does less picking on the others, rising only occasionally to the barbs of Senators Kerrey and Harkin, and last night he found a way to bring his accomplishments in Arkansas into almost every answer to Ms. Roberts's questions. The sure mark of the man who thinks he is ahead, he is already talking about bringing people together.

HEADLINE: Minority College Attendance Rose in Late 80's, Report Says

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The proportion of minority students of college age attending colleges and universities increased in the second half of the 1980's but remained below the proportion of whites attending such institutions, according to a report made public by the American Council on Education today.
The overall increase of minority participation in colleges was attributed to more aggressive recruitment by colleges and universities. 
 The study showed that of black high school graduates 18 to 24 years old, 33 percent were attending college in 1990, up from 26.1 percent in 1985. Though most of that increase was among black women, participation rates by black men increased 7.4 percent between 1988 and 1990, reversing a general decline over the previous eight years.
Of white high school graduates, 39.4 percent were attending college in 1990, up from 34.4 percent in 1985.
Hispanic participation rates rose slightly to 29 percent in 1990, from 26.1 percent in 1985.
 
Minority Gain Outpaced Whites
 Figures for Asian-American and American Indian students were unavailable because survey samples were too small.
The study, "The Tenth Annual Status Report on Minorities in Higher Education," examines the educational progress of black, Hispanic, Asian and American Indian students through high school graduation rates, college enrollment and degree attainment. The American Council on Education, which represents 1,800 two- and four-year colleges and universities, based the report on data from the Census Bureau.
"We're seeing an increase in the last two years of more aggressive efforts on the part of some colleges and universities to recruit minorities," said Deborah J. Carter, assistant director of the education council's Office of Minorities in Higher Education and an author of the report. "But we have not seen the gap in the participating between minority students and white students decline," she said.
Nonetheless, the report found that more minority students were enrolling in college between 1988 and 1990. Overall enrollment grew by 5.1 percent, to 13.7 million in 1990. In those two years enrollment rose 3.8 percent for white students, 8.2 percent for African-American, 11.5 percent for Hispanic, 11.7 percent for Asian-American and 10.8 percent for American Indian students.
But the study warned the minority gains could be reversed by the recession, along with rises in tuition costs, caps on college enrollment and declines in Federal education grants. "We would be wrong to look at the numbers, see progress, and conclude that recruitment and retention programs on behalf of underserved groups are no longer necessary," said Robert H. Atwell, president of the council.
Of particular concern is the declining number of Hispanic high school graduates. The high school graduation rates for Hispanic students dropped from 62.9 percent in 1985 to 54.5 percent in 1990.
In the same period, high school graduation rates for whites remained relatively constant, standing at 83.6 percent in 1985 and 82.5 percent in 1990. Rates for African-American students improved, going from 75.6 percent in 1985 to 77 percent in 1990.
Alfredo de los Santos Jr., vice chancellor of educational development at Maricopa Community Colleges in Tempe, Ariz., said the isolation of Hispanic students in poor urban schools would produce "deep social problems."
Copies of the report are available for $10.50 each, prepaid, from the Publications Department, American Council on Education, 1 Dupont Circle, Washington, D.C. 20036.

HEADLINE: California Leader Explains Speech Mix-Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson blamed himself and his press office today for the confusion surrounding the existence and identity of three men he referred to in his State of the State Message.
In a rare Sunday news conference, the Republican Governor introduced three men he said were the people he used in his Jan. 8 speech as examples of Californians who had been harmed by the recession. The introductions came days after published reports in which Wilson staff members said the three workers did not actually exist but were composites. 
 "They are not allegorical, they are quite real," Mr. Wilson said after introducing Shad Murphy, a carpenter, Concepcion Meza, a farm worker, and Wesley C. Seastrom, a businessman. "They are not composites. They are representative. There are thousands like them."
Mr. Wilson said the problem resulted from a misunderstanding between him and his spokesmen when The San Jose Mercury News asked about the carpenter. The Governor said all three men were representative of others who were having problems. From that, Mr. Wilson said, his staff wrongly told reporters the men he used in the speech were composites instead of real people.
The publicity, including national television reports, clearly embarrassed Mr. Wilson, who said, "There was a massive failure of communication internally."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Citicorp, now the stumbling giant of banking, is betting its salvation is overseas, where it is aggressively expanding even as other U.S. banks reduce foreign activities. [Page A1.] 
 Critics of Upjohn say the drug company concealed data for decades showing that the best-selling sleeping pill caused serious psychiatric side effects. [A1.]
Micron Technology is moving to compete in an arena where few U.S. companies dare tread: flat-panel display screens. [D2.]
United Technologies plans to announce sweeping changes aimed at cutting $1 billion in costs. [D2.]

Executive pay has become a national issue. The slumping economy, layoffs and President Bush's decision to take highly paid executives to Japan, where company chiefs are paid far less, have focused a harsh spotlight on corporate compensation. [A1.]
Mining and timber companies, developers and farmers have organized a movement that represents the strongest challenge to date to the nation's principal environmental laws. [A1.]
All around the country, manufacturers are scrambling to establish "partnerships" with important customers. [D1.]
 Despite risks that long-term rates could rise further, many portfolio managers and analysts say the sharp selloff represents an opportunity to buy. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D5.]

NBC has no interest in losing tens of millions of dollars on sporting events to remain the highest-rated network, Robert C. Wright, the network's president, told investment counselors. [D1.]
The process of beginning a new prime-time series with a highly produced, carefully polished pilot episode is doing a slow fade-out. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
Eileen Goudge and her publisher, Viking, have been romancing book reviewers, bookstore managers and readers to turn her into a commercial fiction writer with the sales of Danielle Steel. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Albany Faces Hard Choices In Cash Quest

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
As Gov. Mario M. Cuomo prepares to unveil his financial plan for the coming year, New York finds itself at the brink of fiscal chaos that has at its heart an intractable dispute over how to wring savings from the state's surging Medicaid and welfare budgets.
More than just an academic pursuit by sharp-penciled accountants, the conflict in Albany reflects a national debate over how states should control costs while the recession is simultaneously driving up welfare caseloads and constricting tax revenues. 
 The desperate search for cash has left all states with devil's choices as they struggle to brake the runaway growth of social-services programs.
 
Eligibility Standards
 Should they tighten eligibility standards and reduce benefits, as Republicans in the State Senate have proposed, thus relegating many welfare and Medicaid recipients to homeless shelters, hospital emergency rooms and prisons, at a greater eventual cost to the state? Or should they cut reimbursement rates for health-care providers, as the Assembly Democrats want, potentially sounding the death knell for struggling hospitals that still provide much of the primary care for the poor?
In his State of the State address two weeks ago, Mr. Cuomo, whose approach falls somewhere between those two polar opposites, challenged the Legislature to revise the state's Medicaid and welfare policies without abandoning its commitment to a tightly woven safety net.
But once the Governor translates that high-minded charge into a budget proposal, which he is to deliver to the Legislature on Tuesday, few expect the negotiations to go smoothly. "This is going to be an all-out war," Mr. Cuomo predicted last week.
 
Compromise Is Elusive
 For nearly three months, Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders have struggled in vain to fashion a compromise. Their failure doomed any chance of crafting an unusual multiyear financial plan, which would have closed both the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and the $4 billion gap projected for the fiscal year that begins on April 1. Mr. Cuomo cited the collapse of budget talks last month as the only reason he would not run for President.
The battlefield in Albany has taken the form of a broad menu of proposed budget cuts, with the Republican-led Senate trying to pare the welfare rolls and restrict services, the Democratic-led Assembly preferring to cut compensation for health-care providers, and Mr. Cuomo endorsing a more balanced approach.
The Senate Republicans, arguing that deep cuts are needed to bring the state budget into permanent balance, have called for the elimination of emergency assistance programs that provide cash to poor families threatened with eviction to the streets. They also would reduce by 20 percent the welfare grant known as Home Relief, which largely benefits single adults and childless couples, and would terminate Home Relief for employable adults after 60 days.
The Assembly Democrats, meanwhile, would not only extend a temporary tax on hospital and nursing-home revenues that was imposed in 1990 but would also nearly double it for a total added cost of $310 million for health-care providers.
Gary Gambuti, president of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, which has the largest caseload of Medicaid and uninsured patients in the state, said such measures would force him to cut the services that most benefit the poor, like outpatient clinics and emergency rooms. "You can't cut out things that pay you money and keep things that don't pay you money," he said.
 
Long-Term Care
 The area that seems to be receiving the least attention is the part of the Medicaid budget that has grown the fastest -- long-term care. Despite the stereotype of Medicaid as a program primarily for the poor, two-thirds of its recipients in New York are elderly or disabled.
The cost of providing long-term care in nursing homes and at home now accounts for 42 percent of all Medicaid expenditures in the state. Those costs have grown by 82 percent in the last five years, a period in which all Medicaid costs have risen by 65 percent.
"There has been a history with long-term care of not really going after cost containment," said Barry T. Berberich, the long-term care director in the State Social Services Department. "One reason obviously is the constituency, which is largely the frail elderly."
Various proposals have been floated to offer tax incentives for the purchase of long-term care insurance, to prevent New Yorkers from qualifying for Medicaid after shielding assets in trusts, and to lower the amount of jointly held assets -- currently $66,000 -- that a spouse can keep while still qualifying a husband or wife for Medicaid.
But the only change in long-term care getting serious consideration is placing a cap on Medicaid reimbursement for personal-care services. It would restrict the number of hours that homebound patients could receive assistance with cleaning, cooking and other nonmedical services.
The quest in Albany for a semblance of balance is complicated not only by a divided Legislature but by the politics of a volatile election year.
The Senate Republicans sense that they have a winning issue in pushing for deep cuts in welfare and Medicaid programs. Their constituents in upstate New York and the suburbs of New York City see ballooning welfare costs as the leading threat to property tax rates and state aid to schools.
Senator Dean G. Skelos, Republican of Rockville Centre, L.I., played on those fears in a December letter to his constituents. The Governor "and his New York City allies in the Legislature," Mr. Skelos wrote, "want us to leave welfare cheats and Medicaid thieves alone, at your expense, contributing to higher property taxes and a declining educational system."
 
Racial Fears
 In rejecting the most severe Republican cuts, the state's Democrats have suggested that the Republicans are pandering to the racial fears of their mostly white constituents. Mr. Cuomo has suggested that the New York Republican strategy is a direct descendant of President Bush's use of Willie Horton in the 1988 campaign. "I think Republicans are doing it all over the country," he said.
The Republicans, who have traditionally sought to protect business interests, also want to support their constituents in the health-care industry. They are particularly concerned that provider cuts would force heavy layoffs in the midst of the recession.
The power relationship between the Senate Republicans and the health-care industry is vividly reflected in financial contributions. Last year, the Senate Republican Campaign Committee received $164,250 from political action committees representing medical, hospital and insurance interests, according to financial disclosure reports. The Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee received $55,400.
 
Different Concerns
 The Assembly Democrats, meanwhile, have different concerns. Their political power flows from New York City, which is home to 63 percent of the state's 2.5 billion Medicaid recipients and 66 percent of its 1.4 billion welfare recipients.
If the state cuts Medicaid and welfare by tossing people off the rolls, the greatest financial impact will be felt in New York City, where local government may have to care for many of those cut loose.
Yet, without significant progress in containing Medicaid costs this year, there is little chance the Legislature will consider Mr. Cuomo's proposal for the state to assume the local share of Medicaid costs. Even though the Cuomo proposal would require the city to cede personal income tax revenues to the state, Mr. Cuomo calculates that the plan would save the city more than $1 billion a year by the end of the decade.
 
Same Political Pressures
 Pressure for action has built in Albany as other states have enacted cuts once unthinkable in New York, which has one of the most generous entitlement programs in the country.
Last week, the New Jersey Legislature sent a bill to Gov. Jim Florio that would cut off additional benefits to welfare mothers who continue to have children. Michigan last year eliminated its welfare program for single adults and childless couples. California cut welfare benefits to mothers with dependent children by nearly 5 percent last year.
California and Michigan, unlike New York, have Republican Governors, and New Jersey has a newly elected Republican Legislature with veto-proof majorities in both houses. But New York Democrats are feeling the same political pressures that have prompted action in those states.
New York voters sent strong signals in recent elections that they would tolerate neither new taxes nor business as usual from their legislators this year.
Thus, the budget that Mr. Cuomo proposes on Tuesday is not expected to include major tax increases. But it will have to address a gap of at least $4 billion in a budget of about $30 billion for the coming fiscal year.
Much of that gap was created by unexpected growth in the state's Medicaid program, which will spend more than $12 billion this fiscal year in Federal, state and county funds.
Mr. Cuomo's Budget Division expected the state's share of Medicaid spending to grow by 3 percent in the current fiscal year but now believes it could grow by 18 percent. The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, has projected growth of 25 percent.
Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said the state's inability to control Medicaid costs is the factor most to blame for increases in local property taxes of up to 25 percent in some counties last year. Meanwhile, Medicaid now devours 14 percent of the state's revenues, up from 8 percent when Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983.
There is little disagreement in Albany that spending on Medicaid and welfare must be curtailed. In their unsuccessful negotiations to close this year's budget gap, the Governor, Mr. Marino and Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin agreed that the state should produce savings of $1.1 billion from the Medicaid and welfare area.
When the negotiations stalled over the mix of cuts, the three parties had agreed to cuts totaling between $700 million and $800 million, according to participants on all sides.
 
Agreements Reached
 Among the agreements were proposals to continue the hospital tax, to require photo identification cards for Medicaid recipients and to limit Medicaid coverage for podiatry.
There also were agreements in principle to limit Medicaid services available to Home Relief recipients, require Medicaid recipients to make co-payments for treatment, and cap personal-care services. But the talks disintegrated when negotiators could not agree on which Medicaid services would be limited for Home Relief recipients, how large the co-payments would be, and how many hours of personal care would be allowed.
Many of the negotiators believe there is enough room for compromise to craft a quick agreement. But that will occur only when political posturing takes a back seat to real progress, they said.
"This can get done relatively quickly if all the parties would come to the table willing to get it done," said Michael J. Dowling, Mr. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services. "You could get it done in two hours, to be frank with you."

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congress;
With Ingredients for Revolt, Illinois May Lead Way in Anti-Incumbent Vote

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
If the American public's general unhappiness with Congress is going to cost individual lawmakers their jobs, the March 17 primary in once insurgent-proof Illinois will be the first place it shows.
The national anti-incumbent mood has already compelled unaccustomed campaigning by veterans here. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, chafes at hiring "handlers" who remind him to boast of accomplishments like getting money for expressway repairs. But he takes the advice, adding grimly, "When I decided to run, I decided to win." 
 Around the country, scholars, politicians and polls all detect serious risks for Congressional incumbents. Unhappiness with legislative stalemate and unsolved national problems seems to focus on Congress. The House bank scandal and the Senate hearings on Justice Clarence Thomas deepened popular dissatisfaction and spurred talk of term limits.
 
Ingredients for Revolt
 "The ingredients are there for a substantial revolt," said Thomas Mann, an expert on Congress at the Brookings Institution in Washington. He said he would not be surprised to see 30 to 40 House incumbents defeated. In 1990, although average winning margins fell for both Republicans and Democrats, apparently for the first time in history, only 16 incumbents were beaten.
The Illinois primary is the first of the year with significant challenges to incumbents. The economy here encourages such political disrespect, which the no longer formidable Democratic organization once would have squelched or disdained. Illinois has 9.3 percent unemployment, rising local taxes and sharp cuts in state services and aid to localities.
In this atmosphere, challengers blame Congress and political action committees for almost everything. A former alderman, Dick Simpson, told neighbors at a coffee meeting Wednesday that there was no national health insurance because of heavy medical industry contributions to his opponent: Mr. Rostenkowski.
 
Rostenkowski's Recession
 For good measure, he said the powerful Democrat was "significantly responsible for the recession" because of tax legislation and said his foe's voting record was "a little to the left of Attila the Hun."
Al Hofeld, a millionaire product-liability lawyer who never ran for office before deciding last fall to challenge Senator Alan J. Dixon this year, spends heavily on television advertisements. They portray his foe as a "career politician" typical of senators who "sell yourself to the special interests and tap-dance around the issues."
Nationally, polls suggest a host of problems for incumbents. A Gallup Poll conducted Jan. 3 through 9 for USA Today and the Cable News Network found only 43 percent of the public saying most members of Congress deserve re-election. A New York Times/CBS News Poll last October found 57 percent saying that half or more of all members of Congress were "financially corrupt."
Don Foley, the staff chief for the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee, warned that while the move may not necessarily be "anti-incumbent," it is plainly "anti-status quo." He said incumbents must now be able to articulate what they have done and what they would do if re-elected. " 'Experience, seniority' -- those are words that once had some cachet at the polls," he said, but no longer.
 
Seizing the Issues
 Mr. Dixon's response to the opposition of Mr. Hofeld and another foe, Carol Mosely Braun, illustrates the Foley prescription. The Senator's latest television commercial depicts him as a leading advocate of national health insurance, although he has not had a major role on the issue in the Senate.
Campaigning before the state A.F.L.-C.I. on Thursday, he said he had fought the Mexican free trade legislation. He asserted that he had "led the fight in the Senate" for extended unemployment benefits, although there, too, his role has not been a prominent one.
The race plainly has him worried, although he contended in a brief interview that he did not see any evidence of an anti-incumbent mood. "My support is holding firm," he said. Mr. Dixon will rely on a record of getting things done for Illinois and on the political ties he has developed in winning every election he has contested since 1949.
 
Campaigning in the Cold
 Mr. Rostenkowski, running in a reshaped district, 60 percent of whose voters are new to him, may have to break a light sweat in his campaign. But he has more real clout to boast of than does Mr. Dixon. And Mr. Rostenkowski has, in Mr. Simpson, a less formidable, underfinanced opponent, who campaigns at "el" stations in subzero weather to become known.
At a rare high school visit last week -- he explains that neighborhood groups just have not invited him much before -- the chairman enjoyed himself, offering blunt advice like "hit the books." One boy said he wanted a career in politics, so Mr. Rostenkowski advised him to work for a candidate he likes.
At a neighborhood meeting over an unwelcome relocation of a social security office, he smiled broadly and said, "Social Security, that's my jurisdiction," making it clear the move would be stopped.
Known in Washington as an earnest, deal-making chairman more interested in passing bills than scoring political points, and more friendly with President Bush than some Democrats like, Mr. Rostenkowski got his House seat when Mayor Richard J. Daley gave it to him in 1958. If he does not hold it this year, anti-incumbency will be shown to amount to a political earthquake.
 
May Send a Warning
 A defeat for Mr. Dixon would be an only slightly lesser upheaval. But even if the two of them survive their primaries comfortably, Illinois could still send a message to Capitol Hill, for at least three other Representatives face plausible primary challenges.
Representative Philip M. Crane, a Republican, is being pressed hard northwest of here as he seeks a 12th term. Gary J. Skoien, who was a high-ranking aide to former Gov. James R. Thompson, is challenging Mr. Crane as an absentee House member with little real connection to the district.
Two other incumbents, both Democrats, are facing real tests. Alderman Bobby Rush, a former Black Panther, is running against Representative Charles Hayes, who argues that his opponents also include city leaders who oppose him as a labor supporter.
Representative Gus Savage is being opposed for a third time by Mel Reynolds, a Rhodes Scholar and businessman. The changing shape of the district, with its suburban, largely white population increasing from 14 to 35 percent, may hurt Mr. Savage.
Mr. Savage is being questioned by new constituents about past remarks attacking whites. Mr. Reynolds, who is black like Mr. Savage, has a clear shot against him this time. In 1990, the opposition to Mr. Savage was divided and the Representative got most of his 52 percent in the primary from black voters of Chicago's South Side.
In Illinois, more of the incumbents are Democratic. They have the tougher contests. But Republicans might face comparable attacks elsewhere.
Spencer Abraham, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, contends that complete Democratic control of the House makes it hard to blame Republicans for its failings. "I don't think anti-incumbency alone will defeat Republican incumbents unless there is something else added on," he said.
The nation's attitude toward Congress generally is only one piece of the individual elections of 435 Representatives and 35 Senators, of course. By November, the economy or a strong Presidential campaign may preserve vulnerable incumbents of one party or the other and redistricting still has hundreds of House careers to shape.
But on March 17, Illinois will offer the first returns on whether incumbency, usually a tremendous political asset, is becoming a liability.
