HEADLINE: Apathy Is Seen Greeting Agony Of the Homeless

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
A decade after homeless and destitute people began flooding city streets, religious leaders say they fear that Americans are beginning to turn away from the outstretched hands, numbed by the severity of the problem and confused about how to respond.
The compassion that in the 1980's led to shelters, soup kitchens and other private efforts to help the victims of bad economic times has not disappeared, they say, but some fear that it is in danger of being overwhelmed. 
 According to the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, Americans are divided over whether the pervasiveness of homelessness has dulled the country's concern. But younger respondents, those who came of age in the 1980's, were more likely to say that homelessness no longer upsets people.
A large proportion of people taking part in the survey said they considered homelessness a problem that government could address.
 
A Shared Ambivalence
 While warning that resignation to the plight of the desperately poor could have a broad impact on the nation's values in the future, many of the spiritual leaders see the danger as arising not from callousness, but from a sense of powerlessness. And on a personal level they acknowledge that they share some of the same ambivalence.
"The daily encounters harden many of us to some degree," said the Rev. Joan B. Campbell of New York City, executive director of the National Council of Churches. "You do walk past. I've often said, 'What is this doing to me?' "
Similar sentiments were expressed by Sister Mary Rose McGeady of New York, president of Covenant House, the refuge for runaway adolescents. "The terrible agony of it all hits me constantly," she said. "Do you give money or don't you? Are you turning away the Christ who stands in front of you in rags, or are you becoming an accomplice in someone's self-destruction?"
Robert Coles, the author and child psychiatrist who lectures on literature and ethics at Harvard University, said the topic of responding to the destitute had spurred some of the sharpest conflicts in discussions of the subject by students there.
The Times/CBS News Poll showed striking differences in the views of people in various age groups. In the survey, 55 percent of respondents 18 to 29 years old said most people had become so used to seeing the homeless that they were no longer upset by the sight. Of those questioned who were 30 to 44 years old, 45 percent assessed the public's mood in that way, as did 41 percent of those 45 to 64 years old, and 30 percent of respondents over 64.
While the survey cannot be construed as showing that acceptance of homelessness is growing, religious leaders expressed that concern in interviews conducted last week.
The persistence of homelessness and poverty on the streets is having "a very insidious effect," warned Bishop Paul Moore. Before retiring in 1989 as Episcopal bishop of New York, he led an effort to press officials for more aid.
Like other religious leaders, Bishop Moore emphasized the importance of the work that privately organized groups do for the homeless and the hungry, but he insisted that even the best charitable efforts could not substitute for effective government action.
"As for what people should do, I favor an intensive drive to get Presidential candidates to take notice of the issue," he said. "There's been little in any of the speeches I've heard."
In fact, seven out of 10 people who responded to the Times/CBS News Poll say that homelessness is "something the government can do a lot about" rather than a problem "beyond the government's control." That view was given by respondents across the political spectrum: 65 percent of Republicans, 70 percent of independents and 75 percent of Democrats. Fifty-nine percent of people who identified themselves as conservatives said so, as well as 75 percent of moderates and 84 percent of liberals.
The survey also showed that nearly six in 10 Americans now say they are seeing the homeless in their own communities or on their way to work rather than encountering them only through television or reading. This is a significant change since 1986, when the Times/CBS News Poll first asked the question. Then, nearly 6 in 10 respondents said homelessness was something they read about or saw on television.
The new nationwide telephone poll of 1,376 adults was conducted Jan. 6 to Jan. 8 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Indifference May Lie Ahead
 The question of whether what has been a considerable reservoir of sympathy for the homeless will give way to indifference or even anger as Americans steel themselves against constant pleas for help is the opposite of the concern that Michael Harrington raised more than three decades ago in "The Other America."
Mr. Harrington began that book, which is frequently credited as an inspiration for the anti-poverty campaigns of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, by arguing that poverty persisted in America because it had become "invisible." The poor were concentrated in rural areas or inner-city neighborhoods that many people seldom visited and poverty was further disguised by the availability of inexpensive decent clothing, according to that argument.
Now people begging for money often stand several to a block in major cities and in great numbers in bus and train stations. One response has been the measures taken by cities like New York, Atlanta and Santa Barbara, Calif., to restrict begging, prohibit sleeping in public areas or oust homeless people encamped in train or bus stations.
A 1987 survey by the Urban Institute said there were 500,000 to 600,000 people homeless on any given night nationwide. Martha Burt of the institute added that in the course of a year perhaps twice as many people find themselves homeless at some time.
Elfreda Harris, 28 years old, who participated in the Times/CBS News Poll and who agreed to be interviewed, said she recently returned to Prattville, Ala., after four years in Chicago. When she first moved to Chicago, she said, "I'd reach into my pocket, and before long I'd just walk on by -- just got used to the fact."
Another of the religious leaders interviewed, the Rev. Spencer C. Gibbs, the newly appointed General Presbyter for the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) in New York City, said that in walking about a mile and a half in Manhattan recently, "I counted upwards of 33-34 black men on one side of the street begging for loose change. As a black man, it makes me depressed."
He asked: "What effect does this have on the young black children, especially males, who repeatedly see black men on the streets shabbily dressed and apparently unable to provide for themselves?"
One religious leader who doubts that Americans are coming to accept the plight of the homeless is the Rev. Jerry Falwell, who said that he thought "America is too good a nation to let such a problem go unsolved." He said he believed that churches, businesses and non-governmental groups could meet their needs "if everyone were willing to provide a meal or two or a few hours of work." But he also said, "Someone in government has got to start thinking again of government-sponsored work projects."
Others argued that just as Americans were growing discouraged by the ambiguities behind giving money to destitute people, efforts to solve such problems through private voluntarism would end in frustration unless supplemented with political pressure for new government initiatives on housing, poverty and employment.
The Rev. Thomas J. Harvey, executive director of the national coordinating office for Catholic Charities programs, expressed frustration that many religious groups were being forced to assume the role of "safety net."
The number of volunteers working in Catholic Charities programs has gone from 23,000 in 1980 to almost 200,000 a decade later, Father Harvey said, but this should not be viewed as a satisfactory solution.
"I favor encouraging voluntarism, but it's no substitute for social policy," he said. "I don't think people are into burnout, they're into frustration, because we haven't had a domestic agenda utilizing the best bipartisan thinking."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 21, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about the public's attitude toward homeless people described it incorrectly, as did a headline in some copies. While polls show that the public perceives widespread apathy toward the homeless, there are no firm numbers showing an increase in that attitude.

HEADLINE: Aristide Insists on Overhaul of the Haitian Army

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti, whose elected Government was overthrown in a coup on Sept. 30, insisted today that there could be no settlement of the Haitian political crisis without the removal of the army chief and a thorough reorganization of the military.
President Aristide, a populist priest who won Haiti's first genuinely democratic election 13 months ago with more than two-thirds of the vote, was also guarded in accepting the view of the Organization of American States that naming a new Prime Minister would constitute a political solution to the Haitian crisis. 
 Any immediate changes in the status of the army and its chief, Gen. Raoul Cedras, are not part of that political agreement. General Cedras, who said that the President was ousted because he had become a threat to democracy, apparently raised no objections to the O.A.S. political formula that would allow Father Aristide to return.
Today, President Aristide said in an interview that General Cedras had the choice of going to jail or leaving the country before democracy could be restored. But he said ordinary soldiers would be granted amnesty. He accused the military of narcotics trafficking and corruption and called the general and his associates killers responsible for 1,500 to 2,000 deaths and the forced exile of 10,000 political refugees.
"I repeat, political refugees," he said, emphasizing that he rejected the view of United States officials that many Haitians flee for economic reasons.
Diplomats close to the negotiations with President Aristide say that army leaders do not disagree fundamentally that the modernization of the armed forces is important. They would ultimately also accept the creation of a separate unpoliticized police force, which President Aristide is demanding, the diplomats say.
This would take considerable time, they said. Insistence on restructuring the military at the same time that the Aristide Government is restored could prevent a quick settlement.
On Jan. 8, the O.A.S. announced that all parties including President Aristide had accepted Rene Theodore as a new Prime Pinister. Like the President, Mr. Theodore, the leader of the Haitian Communist Party, spent years in exile during the regimes of Francois Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude. American diplomats regard Mr. Theodore as a moderate willing to embrace democracy and a free-market economy. His selection is subject to ratification by the Haitian Parliament.
Today, in an interview in Washington, where he is waiting to meet with Mr. Theodore and a parliamentary delegation, President Aristide said he was not in a position to accept Mr. Theodore as Prime Minister until the two could discuss a future government.
"I have met him only four times in my life, and spoken to him once on the telephone," said President Aristide, speaking in English.
While awaiting Mr. Theodore, who has delayed his trip to Washington for further discussions in Haiti, the exiled President has met with the O.A.S. Secretary General, Joao Clementa Baena Soares, and other officials.
President Aristide, who has been living in Caracas, Venezuela, since the Sept. 30 coup, sidestepped a question about which Americans he hoped to see on his visit here. Many of his supporters are critical of the United States, saying it could be more active in punishing the coup leaders, some of whom are reported to have American bank accounts and visas that allow them to visit this country frequently.
President Aristide would say only that many Haitians would like the United States to tighten its economic embargo on Haiti so that the military would feel the pinch more. But he praised President Bush and his Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, for supporting economic sanctions and his return from exile.
President Aristide said today that despite his misgivings about the military, he remained confident that in "only a few days" there could be a political agreement to clear the way for his return.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 20 about the political crisis in Haiti referred incorrectly in some editions to the size of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's election victory 13 months ago. He won with more than two-thirds of the vote.

HEADLINE: Citicorp's Passage: A Humbling Change - A special report.;
After Losing Luster at Home, Citicorp Seeks Future Abroad

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company and America's flagship in overseas markets, finds itself in an unfamiliar role -- that of banking's stumbling giant.
 After a bitter period of losses, layoffs, cost cutting and slower growth in many American markets, Citicorp is hoping that rapid growth and high profits overseas will enable it to rebuild its financial strength and stature. 
When it emerges from its difficult and humbling passage -- by the end of this year, its executives hope -- Citicorp will still be the banking leader in businesses like credit cards and services for a few hundred global corporate giants. But it will be far behind several other banks that are using their financial strength to build large interstate branch networks with a broad base of American consumers and medium-sized corporate customers.
 
A Different Approach
 The emphasis on foreign business is a reminder that Citicorp still dares to be different. While many American banks have cut back their foreign activities, Citicorp is aggressively exporting credit cards and other consumer banking products to Latin America and Europe and Asia. The bank's position as the leading banker of the world's largest corporations remains important but will be a smaller part of its business in the future.
 Citicorp has corporate offices in more than 90 countries, more than any other banking company, but for all its sweep and stature, it has never been a standout at making money. In five years, only once has Citicorp made enough money to cover dividend payments to its shareholders. And only once in seven years has Citibank, its primary subsidiary, met its profit goal.
 Tomorrow, Citicorp, with $224 billion in assets, will announce the details of its 1991 results, which it said last week would be a loss of $450 million to $475 million. The results reflect continued high loan losses, which totaled more than $5 billion for the year, up from $2.9 billion in 1990 and $1.9 billion in 1989.
 With loan losses high and the American economy mired in recession, Citicorp and its 52-year-old chairman, John S. Reed, find themselves sweating over where to cut expenses. Citicorp executives still dream of pioneering new businesses, but the stark reality is that its problems are so severe that Federal regulators have pressured the bank to shore up its finances by eliminating its dividend, halting further expansion and finding ways to cut costs by $1.7 billion, or nearly 16 percent in a two-year period ending this year.
 "This is a dramatic change at Citicorp, but there really is not much else they could do," said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm specializing in bank stocks. "With consumers in a mood to pay down debts and the corporate banking business in a slump, they cannot count on growing their way out of this problem like they have in the past."
 Even in the highly profitable credit card business, where Citicorp has been the leader since it boldly mailed 20 million cards throughout the country in 1977, the competition is growing stronger. As companies like Sears, Roebuck and American Telephone and Telegraph join the competition with large banks, profit margins are shrinking.
 The last decade at Citicorp, including its final years under the leadership of Walter B. Wriston and Mr. Reed's seven years at the helm, shows a willingness to take risks that produced failure and success -- both on a large scale.
 In the late 1980's, loans to third world countries cost Citibank $4 billion -- a painful wound that might have been a motive for the company to seek a quick recovery by embracing the commercial real estate business with its high profits and high risks. But losses on loans for commercial real estate projects in the last few years have wiped out the $600 million profit of the company's credit card business in 1990, while problems with loans to help finance corporate takeovers have eliminated the fat profits expected in that part of its corporate lending.
 
Bank's Survival Is Questioned
 More than a year ago, Citicorp did not have enough capital, and some experts questioned whether the company or Mr. Reed's job would survive the recession. The financial markets seem to have concluded that Citicorp, at least, will survive, as the company's stock price has increased from $8.50 on Dec. 20, its lowest level in more than a decade, to $14.625 on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Mr. Reed declined to be interviewed for this article, but in talks with stock analysts and investors he has insisted that Citicorp will survive and that he is the best person to lead it. His plan calls for Citicorp to cut costs drastically so that the company earns a profit and rebuilds the capital cushion it needs to absorb unexpected losses.
 Signaling the company's emphasis on foreign consumers, Mr. Reed recently expanded the top management committee of the bank to include an officer for global consumer banking, and he plans to bring in an outsider to oversee commercial lending in Japan, Europe and North America.
 The strategy is to cut costs enough by the end of this year to widen the margin between the bank's revenues, which are projected to reach $16 billion, and expenses, which the bank is trying to cut to $9 billion, from $10.7 billion. That $7 billion margin, which amounts to 40 percent of the bank's projected revenues, will be used mostly to soak up the heavy cost of bad loans.
 "We clearly have gotten into more, or at least our fair share of problems," Mr. Reed said recently. One example: In the breathless takeover frenzy of the late 1980's, Citibank loaned Robert Campeau hundreds of millions of dollars for his ill-fated takeover of several American department store chains, including Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Federated.
 "It was not our best moment when we financed Campeau," Mr. Reed later said in the Harvard Business Review. "I would suggest that if your customer goes bankrupt within one year of a deal, then the deal was not good business for you."
 The lending mistakes have led Mr. Reed -- a banker who never made a loan but rose through the ranks as a strategic planner and developer of Citicorp's consumer business -- to pay more attention to corporate lending. To oversee the restoration of the bank's health and maintain Citicorp's leading position in the highly competitive corporate lending and finance business in Japan, Europe and North America, Mr. Reed is expected to announce the hiring of H. Onno Ruding, a former Dutch Finance Minister and top official in the International Monetary Fund. Citicorp is also looking for a chief credit officer.
 One of Mr. Ruding's jobs will be to improve lending practices to correct Citicorp's horrendous record of the past few years. At the end of September, Citicorp reported that 24.4 percent of its loans for commercial real estate projects were badly troubled, while data compiled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation show a 14.4 percent rate for all the nation's largest banks. About 25.8 percent of Citicorp's loans to highly indebted companies were badly troubled, compared with 11.3 percent for all large banks.
 But trying to change the ingrained lending and spending habits of decades will also mean changing Citicorp's culture. Among the practices to be changed are profligate spending on technology. Salomon Brothers estimated that Citicorp had spent up to $1.5 billion annually in this area, including such brash efforts as making its own automated teller machines. At one point it even considered making its own word processors. That kind of money is about what the Hewlett-Packard Company spent last year on research and development.
 "Citicorp recognized earlier than others that technology could provide them with a competitive advantage," said Laura Jean Stuart, president of a management consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "But they were arrogant enough to think they could do a better job than anyone else and develop their own systems and software for every need." The result, she said, is that the company has a "massive patchwork of old systems that is not particularly coherent or streamlined."
 Citicorp still claims that its investment in Transaction Technology Inc., a California company that designed and built Citicorp's automatic teller machines, was money well spent. Even so, the company says it will now make more use of outside vendors.
 But there are limits on how much to cut. Citicorp must continue to invest in developing products if it expects to sustain the recent annual growth rates of more than 25 percent in overseas consumer profits, which exceeded $300 million last year.
 The promotion last week of Pei-yuan Chia (pronounced PAY-youon JAH), who has Mr. Reed's old job as head of Citicorp's consumer businesses in the United States and 36 other countries, to the six-member management committee underscores the foreign consumer's importance to Citicorp's future.
 In Germany, for example, the local Citibank has used automated teller machines and consolidated account statements (two products that pushed it ahead of the competition in New York City many years ago), to increase growth rapidly. The bank, which specialized in installment loans for lower-middle-income customers when it was acquired by Citicorp in 1974, is now aiming at wealthier customers. By introducing a broader selection of loan and deposit products, including credit cards, and automated teller machines more sophisticated than the machines used by German competitors, the German bank has increased its customer base to more than 2 million households, from 1.5 million in 1988.
 In its foreign consumer business -- serving more than 10 million households through 876 branches -- Citicorp is taking advantage of the fact that local banks in many countries do not pay much attention to consumers. In many instances, like home mortgages in Taiwan and the Philippines, and financing of motor scooters and other durable goods in India, Citicorp has created entirely new markets and profited greatly.
 In such places, "the margins are much better than in the more developed markets, where there are lots of sophisticated players and the pricing is tough," Mr. Chia said.
 
Big Profits In Exotic Locales
 In Brazil, for example, Citicorp is a major force and earns an annual profit estimated at $50 million, even though it has only a few dozen branches compared with more than 1,000 branches for the largest local banks. In India, where Citicorp has 500,000 accounts, up from 100,000 in 1986, profits from consumer banking are growing by 25 percent annually and were estimated at $25 million in 1990.
 Credit cards are a key part of Citicorp's offerings in many foreign countries, and it is looking for faster growth overseas to compensate for slower growth in the United States. While Citicorp does not have the branch networks and large base of consumers needed to offer debit cards, through which purchases are automatically deducted from the customer's checking account, it has learned that credit cards can be sold to consumers who are far removed from a Citicorp branch.
 "The appeal of credit cards overseas is the same as in the United States: It's the best way to pay," said Pete Hart, chairman of Mastercard International. While credit cards are not as popular in some markets, like France and Germany, "there are many other countries where a credit card is a prestige item and is the most convenient way to pay for travel and entertainment expenses," he said.
 In the American market, Citicorp's prospects were recently summed up by a New York rival, who said: "Citi is still the biggest, but they are not necessarily the best any longer. The rest of us have caught up."
 In the domestic credit card business, for example, Citicorp is more than twice the size of the nearest bank competitor, with more than 30 million accounts and at least one card in 19 percent of American households, but Citicorp is reconciled to revenue growth of only 10 percent annually in the 1990's, down sharply from the 30 percent growth rates common in the 1980's.
 In the New York banking market, Citicorp faces a new challenge from the recent merger of Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, which were, respectively, the second- and fourth-largest banks in the New York consumer market. The new bank, known as Chemical, trails Citibank in the number of accounts and deposit levels, but Chemical has more than 500 branches in the New York area -- more than double Citibank's. Chemical also has by far the leading share of small and medium-size business accounts and is likely to find more ways of linking its success in that business to its consumer banking.
 Citicorp is trying to attract new accounts by offering free checking and heavily promoting its family of mutual funds.
 It is also trying to offer its trademark high-technology banking services, but one recent example came to market clumsily -- and behind the competition. When Citicorp rolled out a highly computerized bank-by-phone service last year, it was following the lead of Chemical and others, but it was not until last month that the bank was able to offer customers the convenience of having the same phone number in all six of the metropolitan New York region's area codes. Early this year, when Citibank plans to introduce a service for paying a wide range of bills by telephone, it will be more than a year behind Chase Manhattan Bank's unveiling of a similar service.
 For all its size, moreover, Citicorp has no branches in Connecticut or New Jersey, where many customers of its New York branches live. Last year, Chase moved into Connecticut, and Chemical has expanded in New Jersey.
 Outside New York, Citicorp's purchases of weak savings and loan associations in the mid-1980's were an early attempt to assemble an interstate banking network of offices. But Citicorp's effort, which now encompasses about 350 branches, has been surpassed by regional banks like Banc One of Columbus Ohio; which went into Texas and other parts of the Midwest; Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., a leader in the Southeast and Texas, and the Bank of America of San Francisco, the No. 1 bank in the West.
 Citicorp's savings bank in San Francisco, which has $13.1 billion in assets -- equivalent to a big regional bank -- and branch networks in California, Chicago and Washington, D.C., is the strongest of the group. But it earned only $66.6 million in the first half of last year, for a paltry 6 percent return on Citicorp's investment. In the same period, Citicorp's Florida bank, with $2.7 billion in assets, earned only $2 million. And its Arizona bank had a $27.9 million loss; Mr. Reed says he wants to sell that one.
 To carry the company through its malaise, Citicorp executives scoured the world to find buyers for $1.25 billion of its preferred stock in late 1990. Half the money came from Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, and half from more than three dozen institutional investors. And all of it cost dearly as the hard-pressed Citicorp was required to pay an interest rate much higher than other banks.
 Citicorp has also announced a series of gains from accounting changes and the sale of investments and subsidiaries. And it has signaled that more sales will come. In the first nine months of last year the company had such gains of more than $800 million.
 Robert Albertson, a banking analyst at Goldman, Sachs, estimated that Citicorp probably had at least $1 billion, and perhaps $2 billion, of hidden profits it could tap by selling real estate, investments in various companies and "superfluous businesses."
 
Some Businesses Fell Far Short
 One businesses widely rumored to be for sale is Quotron Inc., a leading supplier of stock quotes and other financial information that has never lived up to Citicorp's expectations when it bought it for $630 million in 1986. Quotron was a centerpiece of Citicorp's information business, which Citicorp officials once touted as a wellspring for future profits.
 But now, talk about the information business has all but ceased. It lost more than $1 billion since 1988, reflecting, in part, write-offs of investments in Quotron and Citicorp's expensive efforts in the point-of-sale business, a network of computers connected to retail cash registers that debit customer accounts and provide Citicorp with information about individual shopping habits. The idea was to generate valuable information that could be sold to food companies and others.
 "Attitudes at Citicorp must change from one of assuming that we can win any game we want to play, to one of we must choose more carefully the games we want to play," said Harrison F. Tempest, chairman of the North American operations of ABN AMRO, the large Dutch bank. "It's emotionally tough to abandon some dreams, but not even the largest bank in the country has the capital to be in every business."

HEADLINE: A Chicken/Egg Debate Over Bolstering Ruble

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In the belief that a free market in Russia requires a convertible currency as quickly as possible, President Boris N. Yeltsin's financial advisers are pushing to achieve this goal in the next few weeks -- over the objections of the Russian central bank and the doubts of the Bush Administration.
 The battle over convertible currency, which would greatly increase the country's attractiveness to foreign investors, is the most visible aspect of a larger struggle between those who want the Yeltsin Government to end numerous subsidies and payments to the people as quickly as possible, and those who favor a slower phasing out of Government supports. 
The latter group is more concerned with maintaining a social safety net than with shoring up the economy.
 Mr. Yeltsin's finance group, headed by Deputy Finance Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, says the President has decreed the free convertibility of the ruble, adding that Russians can now buy dollars at exchange windows in bank and hotel lobbies around the city.
 "You can go to 80 exchange windows and buy hard currency freely," said Pyotr O. Aven, a Gaidar assistant and chairman of the Russian federation's Committee on Foreign Economic Relations. "And if you can't, that is because the banks play their games. They can hoard dollars and we have no control."
 But in visits to three such exchange windows at branches of Menatep, a recently established private bank, clerks would only sell dollars to Russians with passports and visas for travel abroad, and then only up to $200.
 What is more, the decree cited by Mr. Aven, signed by the President in November, says in one paragraph that limitations are lifted on the purchase of foreign currency, and in the next paragraph that the central bank should set up "a limited range of exchange rates for the purchase and sale of hard currency."
 Mikhail B. Brudno, a Menatep director in charge of foreign exchange, said that the paragraphs seem contradictory and that Menatep prefers to wait "until the central bank offers an explanation of what it plans to do."
 His caution might be justified. The central bank chairman has opposed free convertibility, preferring a fixed exchange rate that would overvalue the ruble by offering fewer than 100 to the dollar. (That makes a ruble worth more than a cent.)
 Nevertheless, the ruble appears to be moving toward convertibility. An informal weekly auction has sprung up, conducted by the private banks that have been organized in Russia in the last 18 months. The auction matches exporters who have earned hard currency with importers who need it.
 The current auction rate is 150 rubles to the dollar, which makes a ruble worth two-thirds of a cent.
 Mr. Gaidar and his team argue that the auction is too restrictive. With a freely convertible currency, they say, two things would happen: First, Russian companies would export more goods, confident that the dollars they earned could be exchanged for more rubles than exporters can now acquire legally. And second, people with dollars would demand imports, helping to fill shops and build up commerce.
 The Gaidar team's mentor and chief adviser in this approach is Jeffrey D. Sachs, a Harvard economist who advocated a similar crash program for Poland. "The convertible ruble engages exports right away by producing a realistic, market-based exchange rate," Professor Sachs said in an interview here last week, adding that Russia must revive its nearly nonexistent exports to rebuild dollar reserves and, indeed, to survive.
 
Which Comes First?
 The clash comes over whether the ruble should be made convertible before other steps are taken.
 Some analysts, including officials in the Bush Administration, say currency convertibility should be delayed until the Yeltsin Government reduces the budget deficit and raises oil prices. Higher prices for gasoline and heating oil would reduce consumption, making more oil available for sale abroad.
 Mr. Gaidar also favors these measures, but is not insisting that they be achieved before the ruble is freely convertible. In addition, his group wants the Russian central bank to reduce the number of rubles in circulation -- an anti-inflation measure the bank has so far resisted.
 All three steps -- fewer rubles, a balanced budget and higher oil prices -- would strengthen the ruble.
 "Exporters will bring back dollars and exchange them for rubles only if they have confidence that the ruble will hold its value," said one Bush Administration official.

HEADLINE: A Chicken/Egg Debate Over Bolstering Ruble

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In the belief that a free market in Russia requires a convertible currency as quickly as possible, President Boris N. Yeltsin's financial advisers are pushing to achieve this goal in the next few weeks -- over the objections of the Russian central bank and the doubts of the Bush Administration.
 The battle over convertible currency, which would greatly increase the country's attractiveness to foreign investors, is the most visible aspect of a larger struggle between those who want the Yeltsin Government to end numerous subsidies and payments to the people as quickly as possible, and those who favor a slower phasing out of Government supports. 
The latter group is more concerned with maintaining a social safety net than with shoring up the economy.
 Mr. Yeltsin's finance group, headed by Deputy Finance Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, says the President has decreed the free convertibility of the ruble, adding that Russians can now buy dollars at exchange windows in bank and hotel lobbies around the city.
 "You can go to 80 exchange windows and buy hard currency freely," said Pyotr O. Aven, a Gaidar assistant and chairman of the Russian federation's Committee on Foreign Economic Relations. "And if you can't, that is because the banks play their games. They can hoard dollars and we have no control."
 But in visits to three such exchange windows at branches of Menatep, a recently established private bank, clerks would only sell dollars to Russians with passports and visas for travel abroad, and then only up to $200.
 What is more, the decree cited by Mr. Aven, signed by the President in November, says in one paragraph that limitations are lifted on the purchase of foreign currency, and in the next paragraph that the central bank should set up "a limited range of exchange rates for the purchase and sale of hard currency."
 Mikhail B. Brudno, a Menatep director in charge of foreign exchange, said that the paragraphs seem contradictory and that Menatep prefers to wait "until the central bank offers an explanation of what it plans to do."
 His caution might be justified. The central bank chairman has opposed free convertibility, preferring a fixed exchange rate that would overvalue the ruble by offering fewer than 100 to the dollar. (That makes a ruble worth more than a cent.)
 Nevertheless, the ruble appears to be moving toward convertibility. An informal weekly auction has sprung up, conducted by the private banks that have been organized in Russia in the last 18 months. The auction matches exporters who have earned hard currency with importers who need it.
 The current auction rate is 150 rubles to the dollar, which makes a ruble worth two-thirds of a cent.
 Mr. Gaidar and his team argue that the auction is too restrictive. With a freely convertible currency, they say, two things would happen: First, Russian companies would export more goods, confident that the dollars they earned could be exchanged for more rubles than exporters can now acquire legally. And second, people with dollars would demand imports, helping to fill shops and build up commerce.
 The Gaidar team's mentor and chief adviser in this approach is Jeffrey D. Sachs, a Harvard economist who advocated a similar crash program for Poland. "The convertible ruble engages exports right away by producing a realistic, market-based exchange rate," Professor Sachs said in an interview here last week, adding that Russia must revive its nearly nonexistent exports to rebuild dollar reserves and, indeed, to survive.
 
Which Comes First?
 The clash comes over whether the ruble should be made convertible before other steps are taken.
 Some analysts, including officials in the Bush Administration, say currency convertibility should be delayed until the Yeltsin Government reduces the budget deficit and raises oil prices. Higher prices for gasoline and heating oil would reduce consumption, making more oil available for sale abroad.
 Mr. Gaidar also favors these measures, but is not insisting that they be achieved before the ruble is freely convertible. In addition, his group wants the Russian central bank to reduce the number of rubles in circulation -- an anti-inflation measure the bank has so far resisted.
 All three steps -- fewer rubles, a balanced budget and higher oil prices -- would strengthen the ruble.
 "Exporters will bring back dollars and exchange them for rubles only if they have confidence that the ruble will hold its value," said one Bush Administration official.

HEADLINE: Hope and Anger Mix on King Day

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In pride, anger and sorrow, the nation, and blacks in particular, paid homage to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today on the seventh observance of the national holiday established in his honor.
At the Ebenezer Baptist Church, where Dr. King preached, speakers talked of his unfinished work in often harsh tones that reflected the ravages of the ailing economy and the tide of violence and despair in the nation's inner cities. 
 "Invest in the new order now," the Rev. James Alexander Forbes Jr., of the Riverside Church in New York told the congregation at Ebenezer. He delivered an impassioned sermon that took note of the string of racial incidents that have shocked and divided New York City in recent weeks. "When the power of destruction is stronger than the power of creating, you're dying. It doesn't matter if you're the Soviet Union or the United States," he said.
 
Looking at Social Ills
 The annual service here was the focal point of a range of activities, some of them reflecting the rancorous national debate on race. In Denver, a crowd attacked a bus carrying Ku Klux Klan supporters. In New York City, the rash of racial incidents provided a somber backdrop to services and gatherings throughout the city.
Those who spoke here today, including Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and the South African anti-apartheid leader Winnie Mandela, alternated between looking at the social ills within the black population and the economic and political ills they reflect. Dr. King, who was assassinated in Memphis on April 4, 1968, would have turned 63 last week.
On Sunday, two days after President Bush visited Atlanta to pay homage to Dr. King, Mrs. King challenged the nation to reorder its priorities and work to solve the problems of the poor, particularly the inner-city poor.
"Hope is becoming the most endangered commodity," she said. "Resources such as drug and family counseling programs are scarce; job-training opportunities are nearly non-existent."
She offered statistics that nearly one of four American children under the age of 6 lives in poverty and that babies born in 21 other countries have a better chance of surviving their first year of life than do American babies.
 
'National Disgrace'
 "There are only two words that can adequately describe such conditions for so many children in the wealthiest country on earth, and those two words are "national disgrace,' " she said.
But there was also a strong sense, partly reflecting the conservative strands that have become more a part of the civil rights debate over the past year, that many of the answers to the ills of black America must come from within.
Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan, former president of the Morehouse School of Medicine here, said that blacks did not march for civil rights only to be enslaved by drugs or riddled with black-on-black crime.
"Many of the ills plaguing our society stem from our own decisions," he said.
Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson said that in his first term in office in the early 1980's, about 65 percent of homicides were the result of domestic disputes. Now, he said, almost the same percentage were the result of street violence, with 95 percent of homicides the result of black-on-black violence.
 
Remembering Struggles
 "We've got to stop the guns, we've got to stop the dope, and time has run out," he said. "The boys in the 'hood are killing each other. We've got to stop the guns and stop the violence to remain true to the dream of Martin Luther King."
For speakers like Wilma Mankiller, chief of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, the day was a time to remember the struggles of Dr. King's life and the power of people to change their world.
"If there was any message that Dr. King gave us it was that each of us are responsible for doing what we can in our lives," said Mrs. Mankiller. "When thinking of a tribute to Dr. King, I think all of us recognize that we've lost ground in the last decade or so. All of us collectively have lost ground. The best tribute we could give to Dr. King from now on is to not give up one more inch."
Around the country, observances were held on the King holiday, which is observed nationally and by every state but New Hampshire, which celebrates Civil Rights Day, and Arizona. Most private businesses, however, remained open.
The most dramatic gathering came in Denver where about 150 Ku Klux Klan supporters attended a rally at the state Capitol. When they left, those in a crowd of protesters threw bottles and bricks at their bus.
In New York, speakers such as Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, paid tribute to Dr. King and talked of recent racial incidents that included spray-paint attacks on young students and the rape of a 15-year-old girl.
 
'How Very, Very Sad'
 "I cannot help but think how surprised and how sad, how very, very sad Dr. King would be to see the level of violence in our society, especially in communities of color where violent crimes hit hardest," Mr. Dinkins said. "As African-Americans, we have a special stake in winning this battle against violence in our community. For we did not come this far in gaining respect for the dignity of our lives only to see those lives lost with such indignity. We did not leave the back of the bus only to place our children in the back of an ambulance."
Some 2,000 persons turned out at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to hear recordings of Dr. King's speeches and a tribute to his life.
Yvonne Reaves, 36, of the Bronx came away with a renewed sense of hope.
"It was a small gesture, but it was a beautiful one," she said. "It brings people together. It eases the tension, for a while, anyway."
In Arizona, where the debate over designating a state holiday has been heightened by an angry rap video called "By the Time I Get to Arizona" that depicts state officials being assassinated, several thousand people marched in Phoenix in support of a paid state holiday honoring Dr King. Arizonans voted against the holiday last year, but the measure will again be on the ballot in November.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Wants to Increase Tuition And Cut State Jobs and Medicaid

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
To close the gap of nearly $5 billion in next year's $31 billion budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposes authorizing sharp tuition increases at SUNY campuses, eliminating more than 5,000 state jobs, cutting Medicaid spending by about $1 billion and deferring more than $1 billion in tax cuts.
Most of the biggest elements of the plan, which the Democratic Governor is to present to the Legislature on Tuesday in his annual budget message, have been discussed for some time. The tuition increases, of $200 at some campuses and up to $800 at others, were disclosed today by Cuomo administration aides. If they are enacted, the cost of attending some State University schools will have doubled over the last two years.
 
Major Stumbling Block
 In addition, the new budget would eliminate between 5,000 and 10,000 state jobs on top of the 20,000 cut in the last year. It would also pay for about $500 million in borrowing that the state will likely have to undertake this spring because of the failure of the Governor and the Legislature to agree on any plan for closing the gap in budget for the current fiscal year, which ends on March 31. 
 The major stumbling block in reaching agreement on both the current budget gap and the new plan has been the question of Medicaid cuts. The Governor plans both to cut services and to tighten eligibility requirements -- as favored by the Republicans who control the State Senate -- and to cut state reimbursements to hospitals and other health-care providers -- as the Assembly Democrats favor. But both groups take more extreme positions in their own approaches, and no one here expects any easy compromise.
Since Mr. Cuomo will not officially unveil the plan until Tuesday, there was little reaction to it today from legislative leaders or the Wall Street credit rating agencies that monitor the state finances. But a variety of Cuomo administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, provided portions of the budget plan in interviews today but declined to make it known in its entirety.
The tuition increases, which would raise $60 million, are bound to prompt heated protests from students who have already faced two major increases in the last two years. But another part of the plan may prove even more controversial: to charge more, for the first time in history of the State University of New York, to attend one of the four large "university centers" in the SUNY system -- at Albany, Binghamton, Buffalo and Stony Brook -- than for the other 25 campuses operated by the central SUNY administration.
Discussion of this new policy, known as differentiated tuition, has provoked considerable controversy within the SUNY system. Officials at the university centers, led by H. Patrick Swygert, president of the Albany center, have favored the concept. They say it could help direct more funds to their schools, which in part because of their extensive research operations tend to be more expensive to run than other campuses.
 
'Champagne and Ripple'
 But attitudes about the idea on the smaller campuses have been more mixed. While presidents at some of those campuses say offering a lower tuition than the university centers might attract some students, many others have said it could simply harden a perception that their schools were second-class citizens compared to the prestigious university centers. One president has called this a "Champagne and Ripple effect."
Still, SUNY is the only public university system in the country that does not vary tuition by campuses, according to statistics compiled by The Chronicle of Higher Education.
Technically, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature do not approve tuition increases but only the authorization for them since the final decision is up to the boards of trustees of both the State University and the City University of New York. In proposing the new authorization, Mr. Cuomo may well argue that he is not actually favoring a tuition increase because the board could reject one if it decided to cut costs instead.
But in each case in recent years in which authorization has been granted, tuition increases have followed.
 
Cut in State Assistance
 Because the Governor's budget will include a proposed cut of about $80 million in the state's $1 billion assistance to SUNY, the trustees will probably be unwilling to forgo a tuition increase. Without it, they would have to cut an additional $60 million out of an already strapped budget that has forced SUNY to cut course offerings, library hours and research funds.
Annual tuition at SUNY remained at $1,350 from 1983 to 1990, when it rose to $1,650, and last fall it rose again to $2,150. At CUNY, which is expected to face a somewhat smaller increase than SUNY, tuition has risen in that time to $1,950 from $1,250.
SUNY could raise tuition by an average of $500 a student at the state-operated campuses to reach the $60 million target. But under the differentiated-tuition policy, a more likely scenario would be a range from $200 a year at some two-year colleges to $800 at the university centers, university officials said today.
Because Mr. Cuomo has held intensive negotiations with the Legislature on Medicaid and welfare cuts in the last three months, though without reaching agreement, his proposals in that area are expected to be familiar.
 
'Myths of Medicaid'
 He reviewed several of them today at a news conference he called to dispel what he called the "myths of Medicaid." The news conference, focusing on spending on children and the elderly, was clearly intended as a pre-emptive strike to undercut Senate Republicans' arguments that the state's Medicaid program was rife with fraud and abused by able-bodied and employable welfare recipients.
Among the proposals Mr. Cuomo said he would make is to cut welfare benefits to teen-agers between 16 and 18 who drop out of school.
At least one measure revealed by Cuomo aides today would merely push costs into the next fiscal year.
Because of a calendar fluke, there will be 53 Wednesdays in the 1992-93 fiscal year, which runs from April 1 to March 31. Because the state sends Medicaid checks to reimburse health-care providers on Wednesdays, the extra Wednesday would mean an extra payment for the state. But under the Governor's proposal, the last payment would be made instead on April 1, a Thursday, pushing a $110 million expenditure into the next fiscal year.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (95%);

HEADLINE: Northeast Gas Pipeline Ready But Critics Still Doubt Need

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTH COMMACK, L.I., Jan. 17

 BODY:
After a decade of planning and construction that has provoked fierce opposition from environmentalists, homeowners and oil executives, a major natural gas pipeline from Canada is to begin operation here this month, providing the largest single new source of energy to the New York region since the 1950's.
The pipeline, the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, has been the region's most contentious energy project since the failed Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, which is being dismantled 30 miles east of here. The Iroquois pipeline, along with projects under way to expand pipelines from domestic oil and gas fields, would increase the capacity to pump natural gas to New York, New Jersey and New England by more than 50 percent.
 
Marketing Campaigns
 With the Iroquois pipeline nearing completion, experts in the energy industry say it may lead to a historic shift in a region that is far more dependent on oil from the Middle East to heat its homes and fuel its power plants than other sections of the nation are. 
 More than a dozen utility companies and gas distributors have signed 15- year contracts to buy all its gas and dedicate most of it to home heating and other residential uses. The pipeline will pump enough gas each year to replace 30 million barrels of oil, and its capacity can be doubled by a series of compression stations in upstate New York sites that have yet to be determined.
For customers, the most immediate impact will come in aggressive marketing campaigns that promote natural gas over other fuels. Already, the Long Island Lighting Company has said it plans to convert 10,000 Long Island houses each year from oil to gas furnaces and has done so each of the last two years; it says it currently has about 220,000 customers with gas-heated houses. In contrast, there are about 650,000 one-family oil-heated houses on Long Island, according to oil industry estimates. In Connecticut, the Yankee Gas Services Company, another distributor that will buy gas coming through the Iroquois system, plans to offer natural gas service for the first time in Groton and New London.
Another major market for the Canadian gas could be in new electrical generating plants, which, in the aftermath of the failed project at Shoreham, are planned in New York and New Jersey with gas as their principal fuel.
Anyone hoping for a windfall in immediate cuts in gas prices will be disappointed. As part of their contract to buy the Canadian gas, signed in 1987, the utilities and distributors in the Iroquois project have agreed to tie gas prices to those of other fuels, including heating oil and gas from the United States Oil Patch, the fields from the Gulf Coast to West Texas.
So even if a surplus develops, as some economists are predicting, gas prices will not decline any faster than the costs of alternative fuels.
But proponents of the project say its economic benefits, both to individual users and to the region's economy, will become more apparent over a decade or more, as more plentiful natural gas prevents oil prices fro rising and lets industry expand.
 
Fearing Too Much Of a Good Thing
 "There have been very legitimate questions raised about this project, but any new source that will lessen our dependence on foreign oil is a positive for New York," said Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the state's Consumer Protection Board.
As a project planned a decade ago, when the national trauma of energy shortages was still a fresh memory, the pipeline will begin sending gas into a different economic environment. Although all agree on the New York region's need for more access to natural gas, some experts now say it may get too much of a good thing.
"There is certainly going to be a period, whether it lasts for a decade or more, when we have more pipeline capacity than we need," said Ronald Derhardt, a partner in Jensen Associates, an energy consulting company based in Boston.
Threading its way seven feet below the ground for 370 miles, the Iroquois pipeline runs south from Iroquois, Ontario, through upstate New York, across western Connecticut, and beneath the Long Island Sound to a muddy construction site here, just down a quiet residential side street from an Amoco service station. It will then hook up with smaller existing pipelines.
It has been built for $655 million by a consortium of utilities and gas distributors that will sell its gas in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island. In New York, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and Lilco are members of the consortium and have pledged to buy the largest amount of gas from the Iroquois line.
The consortium says it plans to turn on the Iroquois spigot here on Jan. 28.
 
Environmentalists Say Toll Is Too High
 "This is the culmination of a dream," said Robert B. Catell, the president of Brooklyn Union Gas, adding that projections of excess capacity in a weak economy are wrong.
"The Iroquois pipeline will stimulate economic development," he said, by adding fuel for new electrical power plants, new industry and even new technologies, like cars and air-conditioners run by natural gas.
But critics remain unpersuaded.
Environmentalists say the pipeline has extracted too great a toll in five years of digging and pipe-laying across a rich variety of geography, including streams, front lawns and village greens. Oil executives complain bitterly that by providing a major new source of Canadian gas, it will discourage domestic exploration.
The pipeline has been barraged by protests and lawsuits. Several prominent New York area residents, including Dr. Joyce Brothers, fought vigorously to divert it from their country and suburban properties, and the pipeline's builders agreed in October to a settlement paying New York State $225,000 rather than face charges of illegally digging out a Dutchess County creek bed.
"In most cases, the protests fell under the heading of 'not in my back yard,' " said Anne Marie Mueser of Clinton Corners, a village in Dutchess County. Her protests in 1987 persuaded the pipeline builders to detour the line around her cornfield.
Since then, she has been hired by one of the New York contractors that laid the pipeline to advise its workers on avoiding environmental damage.
"I still object to the project," she said. "Although we certainly do need access to more natural gas, it didn't have to come through a huge new pipeline, and it didn't have to come from Canada."
 
Overruns in Cost And Maybe Supply
 Besides environmental concerns, the project has been marred by large cost overruns, raising its price $70 million above the original estimates. The pipeline consortium says that the additional cost will not require an increase in the price charged natural gas distributors and that it hopes to raise volume within two years to increase revenues.
But even as the Iroquois project has moved from drawing board to trenches, the region's gas pipeline capacity has expanded sharply. Two major pipelines that were built in the 1950's to deliver gas to the Northeast from Texas and Oklahoma, the Tennessee Gas Pipeline and the Algonquin Gas Transmission System, have finished major expansion programs since 1986, adding larger pipelines and powerful new pumps.
The pipeline expansion was undertaken in anticipation of the new Iroquois system, into which both of the other pipeline companies have connected with switching systems in upstate New York and Connecticut. The Iroquois system will allow them broader distribution and will most likely lead them to pump more gas.
That means the region's access to gas is increasing just as its economy struggles through the longest recession since World War II. Mr. Derhardt, the energy consultant, said he expected a surplus of capacity in the pipelines because of reduced projections for industrial expansion and population growth in the 1990's.
But other analysts say the huge new gas resources, by their very presence, will create new markets.
"We are going to see natural gas distributors, who until now just have not had the supply, becoming much more competitive at attracting new customers," said Thomas Kiley, president of the New England Gas Association, a trade group. He said he expected at least a 50 percent increase in demand for gas throughout the Northeast over the next decade.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, homeowners, landlords and the managers of industrial buildings remain much more reliant on heating oil than those in most states.
Across the nation, 88 percent of all homes and apartment buildings are heated by gas, says the American Gas Association. In contrast, it says, gas-fired furnaces heat only 51 percent of the residences in New York, 70 percent in New Jersey and 71 percent in Connecticut; heating oil is used in almost all homes not heated by gas.
 
Reliance on Oil Is Legacy of Barons
 The region's reliance on oil has deep roots early in the century, when American oil barons, led by John D. Rockefeller, discovered huge reservoirs under the deserts of the Middle East. They found that the most efficient route for the oil was across the Atlantic to ports along the northern half of the Eastern Seaboard.
Later, after World War II, vast pipeline systems began linking most of the nation with the oil and gas fields of the Southwest. But by 1960, when pipeline construction had almost halted, the New York region and New England, partly because of their distance from the oil fields, were left with little access to gas.
Now, after decades of oil shocks, political turmoil and heightened concerns over air pollution, "any significant new source of gas is important, particularly in a heavily congested area like New York," said Robert Stobaugh, a professor of business and an energy industry analyst at the Harvard Business School.
One benefit of natural gas is its cleaner burning, he said; it produces less sulfur pollution in the atmosphere than gasoline or heating oil.
Another, he added, is that it will generate more competition between fuel distributors and discourage sellers of heating oil from imposing sudden price increases whenever frigid weather or a political upheaval abroad threatens oil shortages.
Although the consortium that has built the Iroquois pipeline says most of its gas will be used to heat homes and industrial buildings, others say they expect growing demand, which could be partly met by the new pipeline, to fuel electrical power plants.
One candidate is the now-idle shell of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station. The Shoreham plant has been the subject of broad studies on ways to rebuild it for non-nuclear use. This month, the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency created to oversee Shoreham, requested proposals from several corporations to determine if it would make economic sense to convert the plant to gas.
"It would certainly make sense that this major new pipeline will make the natural gas option for Shoreham more attractive," said Mr. Kessel, who serves as chairman of the power authority.

HEADLINE: LIBYA IS EXPECTED TO GET U.N. DEMAND ON BOMB SUSPECTS

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council is expected to serve Libya on Tuesday with a virtual demand that it hand over agents accused of blowing up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988 or face the threat of economic sanctions.
The resolution also calls on Libya to cooperate with an investigation into the destruction of a French airliner over West Africa in 1989. 
 If the Libyans decline to meet the Council's demands, they are likely to be faced with a follow-up resolution in a week to 10 days setting forth the sanctions, diplomats from Council nations said today.
The Security Council is now certain to approve such a resolution, diplomats said tonight, adding that Tuesday's vote could well turn out a unanimous one after the six third-world members said they would recommend the text to their capitals. But some cautioned that Morocco might still abstain out of solidarity with Libya, a fellow North African nation.
 
'Full and Effective Response'
 The carefully worded draft avoids specifically accusing Libya of responsibility for blowing up the two planes but merely "urges" it to provide "a full and effective response" to the demands of the United States, Britain and France "so as to contribute to the elimination of international terrorism."
In practice, this means Libya would have to hand over for trial the two Libyan agents the United States and Britain have accused of helping blow up the Pan Am airliner with the loss of 270 lives, and pay compensation as these two Governments have demanded.
The French Government has not formally asked for extradition of any of those it thinks helped blow up Union de Transports Aeriens Flight 772 over the West African nation of Niger in September 1989 with the loss of 177 lives. But a French investigating magistrate has accused several Libyans of doing so and issued warrants for their arrest.
 
'Remain Seized of This Matter'
 The new draft resolution also avoids threatening Libya openly with sanctions if, as expected, it fails to comply, saying only that the Council decides "to remain seized of this matter."
But spokesmen for the American, British and French Governments have all made clear in recent days that they will ask the Council to impose mandatory economic sanctions on Libya under Article 7 of the United Nations Charter if it refuses to cooperate.
Such sanctions would probably take the form of a worldwide ban on civil aviation links as well as on sales of aircraft and spare parts.
The United States, Britain, France, Russia and China have permanent Security Council membership and can veto any decision. Other members, serving two-year terms, are Hungary, Austria, Belgium, Japan, India, Zimbabwe, Cape Verde, Morocco, Ecuador and Venezuela.
Libya has sent a high-level delegation to attend Tuesday's meeting, headed by a former Foreign Minister, Jadulah Azuz Talhi, who is currently Minister of Strategic Industries.
Mr. Talhi, who is expected to address the Council, made no statement today. But Libya's Arab League representative, Ali Treiki, who is a former United Nations representative, said Libya is ready to cooperate with an investigation into the bombing of the planes but appeared to exclude handing over the accused Libyans. "There is no law which requires us to hand over our citizens," he said. "This is something we can't do."
The resolution hammered out today after weeks of negotiation "strongly deplores" the fact that Libya has not "responded effectively" to the three countries' "request to cooperate fully in establishing responsibility for the terrorist acts referred to above against Pan Am Flight 103 and U.T.A. Flight 772."
It "urges the Libyan Government immediately to provide a full and effective response to those requests so as to contribute to the elimination of international terrorism." And it also "urges all states individually and collectively to encourage the Libyan Government to respond fully and effectively to those requests."
 
First Demand for Extradition
 Today's draft marks the first time the Security Council has effectively demanded the extradition of the citizens of one country to stand trial in another. It is also the first time the Council has implicitly accused another United Nations member of involvement in government-sponsored terrorism.
The resolution's adoption on Tuesday, diplomats say, would thus continue an emerging trend in which the United Nations is becoming increasingly involved in countries' domestic affairs to promote such goals as justice, human rights, democracy, humanitarian assistance and disarmament.
Libya has reacted with growing alarm to the prospect of a new confrontation with the United States and its allies. It says the accused agents are under arrest and is offering to try them itself or send them before some specially convened international tribunal.
The United States and its supporters argue that the Libyan Government cannot try people it sent to destroy the airliners. They also say that no international court is competent to hear such a case.
Libya has also proposed a list of eccentric measures that it wants the United Nations to take to eliminate what it calls the causes of terrorism. These include a ban on hunting, boxing and wrestling, as well as promoting agricultural development by reversing the flow of rivers so their waters can be used for irrigation instead of running to waste in the sea.
Last week the Arab League adopted a resolution praising Libya for offering to release all facts about the loss of the two airliners and calling on the Secretary General "to solve this dispute through negotiations, mediation and judicial settlement."
The final text asks the Secretary General "to seek the cooperation of the Libyan Government" in complying with the new resolution. But the United States, France and Britain prevented the Council from specifically asking the Secretary General to become involved in resolving their dispute, fearing that this could be used as a pretext to delay a decision on sanctions.
Families of victims of the Lockerbie bombing today criticized the draft text of the United Nations resolution as weak and inadequate.
Speaking at a news conference shortly before the scheduled vote of the Security Council, they said that though the United Nations resolution is a first step, it is not enough.
 
'Better Than Nothing'
 "The current resolution contains no deadlines, no provisions for sanctions and the word extradition is not even mentioned," said Susan Cohen, who's 20-year-old daughter, Theodora, died in the crash. "However, it is better than nothing."
Members of the families felt that although there is evidence pointing to Libya's involvement, it should not be the sole accused. "There is ample evidence that both Syria and Iran were involved," Daniel Cohen said. "But, because of political reasons the United States and Great Britain have drawn the Pan Am 103 case very narrowly, accusing only two Libyans."
After the news conference, the families held a brief vigil across from the United Nations headquarters at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza on 47th Street and First Avenue, where they read aloud the names of the 270 people who were killed in the crash of Pan Am Flight 103.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
BUSH AIDES DIVIDED ON HOW TO CORRECT SLIP IN POPULARITY

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The struggle over how to stop President Bush's political slide has fanned staff rivalries in the White House and intensified a broader debate over campaign tactics and economic policy, Administration officials and Republican strategists said today.
Inside the White House, they said, there is a lingering sense of confusion as Samuel K. Skinner, the new chief of staff, struggles to gain control of the policy apparatus and dominate Richard G. Darman, the powerful White House budget director. 
 Their conflict, concealed by a public veneer of cordiality, is linked to a disagreement over whether Mr. Bush has a public relations problem or a fundamental flaw in his domestic policy apparatus.
 
Need for Action Is Seen
 So far, Mr. Bush is said to have accepted the contention, held primarily by Mr. Darman, that his political problems are more a matter of communications than substance. The White House's efforts to come to grips with the political slide have produced a sporadic series of economic initiatives as well as political gestures.
But there is a general agreement among Administration officials, campaign aides and Republican strategists that whatever the diagnosis, Mr. Bush is struggling to catch up at a time when he should be commanding the political field and that he must do something.
Prodded by Mr. Skinner to abandon a position that the economy was basically sound and would heal itself, Mr. Bush last week made several trips intended to demonstrate his concern for the average American, but instead left the impression of a President apologizing for the state of the economy.
In another move intended to show that the President was grappling with the economic issues, the White House today announced proposals to halt the issuing of all new Government regulations for three months. [Page A19.]
On Tuesday, Mr. Bush will unveil a proposal to spend more on preschool children in the Head Start program, a move that officials said would increase financing for the popular program by more than $500 million in the 1993 fiscal year.
But many officials regard this approach as piecemeal and are frustrated that Mr. Bush bowed to Mr. Darman's insistence that the formal announcement of the economic growth package be held for the State of the Union Message next Tuesday.
To help cure the disarray that has struck the White House only five weeks before the New Hamshire primary, the first in the nation, Mr. Bush met with Mr. Skinner to receive his first plan to reorganize the White House staff, an approach that is expected to be unveiled this week. Officials said the plan will focus on communications rather than policymaking.
 
New Slide in Polls
 The sense of political shakiness in the White House was reinforced tonight as CBS News disclosed the results of a new poll in which approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy, his strongest suit, had fallen below 50 percent for the first time. The drop, to 48 percent, was recorded after the President's trip to Japan and represented an 11-point decline from a New York Times/CBS News Poll a week earlier.
The CBS poll of 2,897 adults, conducted on Jan. 14-19, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus two percentage points. It showed that public approval of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy had slipped to 19 percent, from 23 percent in the previous poll. Jimmy Carter, whose lowest score for economic policy was 15 percent in July 1979, was the last President with an economic rating in this range.
The latest poll comes as the White House puts the finishing touches on Mr. Bush's State of the Union Message, which is being presented by the White House as the pivotal moment in both the last year of Mr. Bush's first Administration and in setting the stage for his re-election campaign.
White House and campaign aides are counting on the speech to give a lift to Mr. Bush's struggling campaign for the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18, but his top advisers remain divided over whether Mr. Bush's economic growth plan goes far enough.
Having lost the battle over the details of Mr. Bush's growth proposals, conservatives in the Administration and the Republican Party are already arguing behind the scenes that the plan will not go far enough either toward improving the economy or correcting the politically damaging impression that Mr. Bush is too detached from the concerns of average citizens.
 
Emphasizing Communication
 Other officials contend that there is little Mr. Bush can do to right the economy, a view supported by many economists, and that the main problem is to make voters believe that he is trying.
"Bush seems to have bought the line that it's a communications problem, not a policy problem," one official said. "We're floundering. You have no growth for two years and the White House sits around saying 'Gee, we're falling. We haven't communicated. We've got to show we care.' "
Some officials and Republican strategists say the President has staked a dangerously high amount of his dwindling political capital on the State of the Union Message address, which rarely produces dramatic headlines.
"The way they have this set up, this speech has got to be better than Bush's speech at the Republican National Convention in '88 and in a venue totally unlike a group of 5,000 rabid Republicans," said a senior Republican strategist with close ties to the White House.
Behind the scenes, the relationship between Mr. Skinner and Mr. Darman bears the marks of a classic White House power struggle, with Mr. Skinner insisting that he and Mr. Darman get along fine while at the same time making it clear that he intends to break what White House aides described as Mr. Darman's "chokehold" on domestic policy.
Mr. Darman has been uncharacteristically quiet at staff meetings, officials said. But they said he scored a big victory last month by persuading Mr. Bush to hold his major economic proposals for the State of the Union Message and not promote some of them in advance, as others, including Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, Vice President Dan Quayle, and Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, had been arguing.
Since then, officials said, Mr. Darman has appeared to be preparing the ground to blame Mr. Skinner if Mr. Bush's economic proposals do not go over well. At a meeting in Mr. Skinner's office last week to review the State of the Union plans, Mr. Darman announced that "he had produced an incredibly substantive budget and if that was not clear, it was a communications problem, not a policy matter," one official said.
Another official said, "If I was Sam Skinner, I'd be suspicious."
But officials said Mr. Skinner had not directly challenged Mr. Darman. "Sam either believes Darman's argument that we've just got a communications problem, or he's not willing to challenge Dick," an official said.
Mr. Skinner has let it be known that he is unhappy with the communications staff at the White House, currently headed by David Demarest, and is expected to announce a major shakeup this week, officials said. "Some people are saying internally that this is simply shooting the messenger," one official said.
Another said: "Historically, communications is always blamed when the White House message is weak. The communications system is a good one, but it has to have some grist to run."
