HEADLINE: G.M.'s Gone, but This City's Alive

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORWOOD, Ohio

 BODY:
On Nov. 6, 1986, General Motors delivered a body blow to this city of 24,000. To cut costs, the auto maker said it would close its 64-year-old plant here that assembled Chevrolet Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds.
Residents feared that G.M.'s departure would mean the end to life as Norwood had known it for generations. G.M.'s taxes afforded this small city its independence from neighboring Cincinnati and spawned a wealth of services, including free paramedic services, and generous budgets that had allowed the city to buy a $750,000 incinerator and a $110,000 fire truck, both for cash. 
 With the fate of Norwood and 4,300 jobs so closely linked to General Motors, residents shared worries on the streets and in restaurants. "It's almost as if there was a funeral," recalled Charlotte Shockley, a longtime Norwood newspaper editor and columnist.
Since the last car rolled off the line in August 1987, however, Norwood has discovered that there is life after G.M. Today, where the G.M. plant once stood, a new business park that already provides more than 1,000 jobs is rising. Young professionals who once shunned blue-collar Norwood are moving here and lifting prices of the city's spacious brick homes.
City officials and residents almost unanimously agree that Norwood's prospects are better without the auto maker. "It's been rough, but it's given us the only opportunity in the next 100 years to change the image of Norwood," Mayor Joseph E. Sanker said. "I think we're going to be a much better city in the long run."
Around the country, in towns that stand to be hurt by G.M.'s recently announced plan to close 21 plants and lay off more than 70,000 employees, residents and city leaders are bracing for the worst.
In recent weeks, local government and union officials have marshaled their best arguments to persuade G.M. to stay. Arlington, Tex., for one, has had the site of its G.M. assembly plant deemed an enterprise zone, which would mean tax breaks on future expansions. And Gov. Ann Richards of Texas has pledged to buy from G.M. all the natural-gas-powered vehicles that state agencies will be required to use in coming years.
Throughout the 1980's, from San Jose, Calif., to Framingham, Mass., more than a dozen communities have shared Norwood's struggle to recast their economies after the closing of a Big Three assembly plant. Their stories are as different as the cities themselves, with turmoil intensified or softened by the complexion of their regional economies.
"It can cut both both ways," said Harley Shaiken, a visiting scholar at the Institute for Industrial Relations at the University of California at Berkeley.
Norwood's fate is not the rule, in the view of Mr. Shaiken and others, but neither is the city the exception. The city's successes and struggles offer a broad look at both the possibilities and difficulties of building a new economy without the riches of a high-paying manufacturer like General Motors.
Although Norwood is not out of the woods and has to contend with an ominous $2.7 million budget deficit, it no longer mourns the loss of G.M., and its citizens are upbeat about the future. Their optimism is inspired largely by the city's new office buildings and fountain, which replaced the G.M. plant and brightens what would otherwise be a fading downtown. Some believe the city now has all the ingredients to eventually match the exclusivity of neighboring Hyde Park.
 
Some Get Lower Pay
 There are some former G.M. employees, though, who have settled for lower-paying jobs. Harold Bennie, 44 years old, had planned to retire in 2000, when he would be 52 and have 30 years with G.M. But because he did not want to move to another G.M. plant, he took G.M's severance offer, invested it in mutual funds and works at the municipal court, a job that pays $10,000 a year less. "I don't have the same pocket change," he said.
When G.M. operated in Norwood, it paid a 2 percent payroll tax as well as property taxes on its factory, equipment and inventory of new cars. The money accounted for a quarter of the city's budget and a fifth of the school district's. After G.M. departed, the city cut 40 employees, about 16 percent of its work force. The school district closed one of five elementary schools and laid off 39 employees, including 22, or 11 percent, of its teachers. Because of the loss of G.M.'s revenues, students started paying $20 this year for extracurricular activities that were once free.
 
More Cuts Expected
 The city's auditor, Donnie R. Jones, said the rising cost of all city services would continue to outstrip tax revenues and add $1 million each year to the current $2.7 million budget deficit, even with some rising property values. Although some city leaders believe the new office park will recoup lost tax revenues, Norwood could be forced into bankruptcy unless several cherished services are trimmed, Mr. Jones said. "We grew fat with General Motors," he noted.
But others were not hurt, and some were even helped, by G.M.'s departure. Some of Norwood's 400 businesses suffered temporary setbacks, but every company except a car transporter weathered the closing of the plant, said Charles L. Geraci, executive director of the Norwood Chamber of Commerce.
One reason for the nominal impact: Only about 400 of the G.M. workers lived here. "Those people who lived outside of Norwood took their paychecks and ran," Mr. Geraci said.
 
Home Prices Are Rising
 Housing sales have fallen since the plant closed, but real estate agents and homeowners say values have risen, in some cases as much as 30 percent, in four years. Keith and Jeannine Dostal said they would have never moved to Norwood until G.M. left because of its blue-collar image. But now they own a 4,100-square-foot home they bought for $76,900 in 1990. Mr. Dostal, a 30-year-old pharmacist, said the value of the house had risen $15,000 since he bought it and did some renovation.
G.M.'s plant closing indirectly benefited two other Norwood manufacturers. United States Playing Card and a Siemens electrical engine plant were both negotiating union contracts at the time of G.M.'s announcement. Executives at both companies said G.M.'s closing enabled them to win wage concessions from workers. "They could see that they could lose their jobs," said Ronald C. Rule, president of United States Playing Card.
Siemens and United States Playing Card did not hire many former G.M. workers, but opportunities in the region were plentiful. In the late 1980's, Cincinnati's economy was "really humming," adding about 30,000 jobs a year, said Joseph C. Kramer, vice president of economic development at the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce.
Some former G.M. workers created jobs themselves. Don Combs used G.M.'s buyout to turn a part-time summer job building in-ground pools into a full-time business. Mr. Combs's concern has grown every year since, and he makes more money than he did at G.M. "I would never, ever go back," he said.
Local cultural institutions said they were not hurt by G.M.'s departure because the auto maker rarely supported such local activities, said Mary Lee Beckstedt, the city's treasurer and head of the Norwood Cultural Committee. G.M. workers helped raise $229,000 for the United Way of Greater Cincinnati in 1986, but that represented only a fraction of the total $35 million raised that year.
 
'They Are on Their Way'
 Despite the expectations of many, the social fabric of Norwood has mended almost completely since the shock of G.M.'s announcement. "It's going to take Norwood a long time to fully recover, but they are on their way," said Tom Gustina, a former case worker with the Salvation Army family service bureau. The Rev. Frank H. Niehaus of St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church in Norwood, added, "I see a very positive attitude in the community."
Much of Norwood's optimism is inspired by the fledgling Central Parke business development on the 60-acre G.M. site.
In all, the three buildings in the park house 19 tenants and more than 1,000 workers, including a bank check-processing center, a telemarketing company and a Computerland store. Within six months, the park's developer, the Belvedere Corporation of Cincinnati, fully leased the three buildings. Belvedere plans to invest more than $100 million to develop one million square feet of commercial space.
"In pretty difficult economic times, we've hit a home run," said Steven N. Stein, Belvedere's president.
 
Parking Garage Is Helpful
 Mr. Stein said Central Parke was popular largely because of its central location and its proximity to two main highways. Because of the 1,700-space parking garage left behind by G.M., Belvedere has also been able to offer free parking to its tenants, a costly amenity for tenants of competing projects in downtown Cincinnati. And the rent at Central Parke is roughly half that of downtown Cincinnati, he said.
City officials say the site's redevelopment would have been difficult if G.M. had not torn down the factory. The auto maker was at first hopeful that it could sell the plant although city officials wanted it razed to give them a chance to forge a new economy. Norwood filed a $318 million lawsuit against G.M., contending that it had reneged on its responsibilities to the city. The suit was later dismissed, but G.M. tore down the plant anyway.
 
The Developer's Desires
 Belvedere, the developer, had a particular interest in seeing the site developed as a business park. In 1989, it bought and upgraded a retail center, the Surrey Square Mall, directly across the street. Belvedere executives worried that another developer might build a competing mall. "Norwood's desires and ours were one and the same," Mr. Stein said.
Mayor Sanker is one who predicts that the growth of the business park will help Norwood balance its budget within four years without cutting services. Central Parke has also buoyed the political fortunes of city officials; residents returned all incumbents to office in November.
Indeed, many citizens said morale had improved in Norwood, which was once the butt of jokes in Cincinnati about hillbillies who came from Kentucky to work at the plant. Several residents echoed the words of Theodore A. Hooks, a Norwood native and publisher of The Norwood Times. As a young student, Mr. Hooks bused tables at the Country Kitchen restaurant across the street from the factory; when plant workers went on strike, he worried about his job. "I'm tickled to death that G.M. is gone," he said. "The city depended on G.M. like a crutch."
 
Photos: The city of Norwood, Ohio, has discovered that there is life after General Motors. "I think we're going to be a much better city in the long run," said Norwood's Mayor, Joseph E. Sanker, above, standing outside a new business park that now rises on the old site of the G.M. plant. HEADLINE: Cuban Firing Squad Executes Exile

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HAVANA, JAN. 20

 BODY:
A Cuban exile convicted of sabotage and terrorism was executed by firing squad today in a warning the Government said was aimed at right-wing exile groups operating from the United States.
 Eduardo Diaz Betancourt, 38 years old, was shot after appeals for clemency were turned down by Cuba's Supreme Court and the ruling Council of State headed by President Fidel Castro. 
 The official national news agency AIN, quoted by state television, reported the execution in a brief one-paragraph note titled "Sentence against terrorist carried out."
 Mr. Diaz Betancourt went to the firing squad despite pleas for clemency from leaders around the world.
 
 
Convicted of Sabotage
 The execution was approved as Cuba faced mounting international calls for political change and the worst economic crisis in its history, triggered by the breakup of the country's former ally and supplier, the Soviet Union.
 Mr. Diaz Betancourt and two other men were found guilty by a Cuban court 10 days ago of terrorism, sabotage and enemy propaganda.
 The three, who lived in Miami, were captured with arms and explosives on Dec. 29 shortly after landing on Cuba's northern coast in an inflatable dinghy.
 In a partial response to the international calls for clemency, death sentences against the others, Daniel Santovenia Fernandez, 36, and Pedro de la Caridad Alvarez Pedroso, 26, were commuted to 30 years' imprisonment.
 The Council of State, which made the final decision on the execution, made clear in a statement on Sunday that the death sentence for Mr. Diaz Betancourt was intended as a deterrent to future sabotage missions by right-wing Cuban exiles in the United States.
 The death penalty "fulfills a goal of overall prevention, especially when the idea is to stop such loathsome actions from being repeated, to deter others and so to prevent innocent human lives from being endangered in the future," the Council said.
Mr. Diaz Betancourt, who was said to have been the leader of the group, repeatedly confessed in court and on state television that the group's mission had been to plant firebombs in public places like movie theaters and restaurants and to attack economic targets.
 The United States Government strongly denied Cuba's allegations of involvement. State Department officials were not available for comment on Monday after the execution.
 Cuba's Council of State accused the United States authorities of showing "spectacular incompetence" in failing to prosecute Cuban exile leaders who recruited and trained individuals on American territory for attacks against Cuba.
 Entering the country illegally to commit terrorism, sabotage or other serious acts against state security can carry the death penalty. Lawyers during the trial said that the death penalty could be applied even if the accused had not been able to carry out the actions they had planned.
 The Council of State, in ratifying the death sentence against Mr. Diaz Betancourt, had ruled he was the most directly responsible in the charges against the three exiles.
 It said he was motivated by ambition for political power. The Council said he had hoped his planned terrorist activities would create chaos in Cuba and provoke United States intervention to end Communist rule on the island.
 In the past, armed Cuban exiles from the United States caught attempting to infiltrate were usually given long prison sentences.
 It was the most politically significant execution in Cuba since Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa and three other senior officers went to the firing squad in mid-1989 after being found guilty of corruption and involvement in drug trafficking.
 The three exiles were tried and sentenced amid a wave of nationwide anger in Cuba over the Jan. 9 killing of three policemen, two of whom were shot after being tied up, by a group trying to steal a boat to flee the island.
 The five men and two women of the group have been captured and could also face the firing squad if convicted.

HEADLINE: Bills Fans Overheat Buffalo (in January)

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Cathy Jo Woloszyn spent a lonely 1991 Super Bowl on Manhattan's Upper East Side, desperately looking for a bar populated with Buffalo Bills fans. Instead, the Buffalo native recalled, she found swarms of New York Giants fans, who cheered their team to victory over the Bills.
This year, she will be safely ensconced at the Buffalo Sports Garden, a sprawling warehouse-like bar and restaurant where 1,500 fans watched the American Football Conference championship game on more than two dozen 27-inch televisions (including several in the rest rooms) and three gargantuan screens as large as 23 feet. 
 The hordes will return for the Super Bowl on Jan. 26, and it is a safe bet, as Ms. Woloszyn said, "this place will really be cranking."
As the Bills prepare for their second Super Bowl in two years, Buffalo fans have become fanatics and their city has become one giant cheering section.
 
Bills Mania
 Some people say Bills mania is like the old New York Mets madness: After years of losing, finally, in the last few seasons, the Bills have turned into a genuine National Football League powerhouse.
"The Bills have labored long and hard to get here," said Mike Doyle, a store manager. "People here have suffered through all those 2-and-14 seasons."
Others say it has to do with the city and its people.
Buffalo, in the minds of outsiders, is a dreary place filled with faded factories and cursed with winters that are among the nation's most brutal. But the metropolitan area's 1.2 million people proudly defend their city, and lifelong residents like Ellen Collopy say that theirs is a community of good neighbors and loyal citizens.
That fierce loyalty is evident in the form of "Go Bills" banners draped on workplaces throughout the area, from gritty industrial parks in the northern suburb of Tonawanda to staid law firms like Jaeckle, Fleischmann & Mugel in downtown Buffalo. Shops are doing a booming business in Bills clothing and trinkets, and the classified pages of local newspapers are filled with columns of advertisements selling Super Bowl tickets for as much as $1,250 and even an offer to trade a condo in Cancun for a room in Minneapolis, where the Bills will square off against the Washington Redskins.
 
Cheer or Go Shopping
 "Everybody here's a Bills fan," said Laura Kopra, an office coordinator at Freddy's, one of Buffalo's many giant discount stores. "If you're not, it's best to stay home and stay quiet, or else go out shopping."
Neddy Lojacono, a saleswoman at the department store AM & A's, also disparaged the notion that any true Buffalonian might not be a Bills fan, as she joined other shoppers transfixed by a continuously playing 45-minute video featuring quarterback Jim Kelly and running back Thurman Thomas.
Bills mania is hard to miss at 80,000-seat Rich Stadium, where fans gloat about the fact that the league's highest attendance is in Buffalo -- one of the National Football League's smallest cities.
"Our voices are trained to stand the cheering and yelling," said Ken Wasiewicz, a clerk who happily paid $225 for season tickets this year.
"It doesn't matter if ticket prices go up," which they did this season and are likely to do next season, he said. "We had over 99 percent capacity on Sunday. They said only about 180 seats were empty."
At the Sports Garden, 50 kegs of beer had been consumed by mid-afternoon on the day the Bills won the American Conference title and the right to go to the Super Bowl, said Jeff McKnight, the bar manager. "We're going to have 80 kegs for the Super Bowl, but we'll probably be so full we'll have to turn people away as soon as we open."
He said that the restaurant's owner, Norm Labruzzo, had confided that "the difference for us between the Bills being in the Super Bowl and not being in is about $30,000 at the bar."
Like many at the Sports Garden and throughout the area, Mr. McKnight expects the Redskins to be tough opponents. But even if the team loses, the Chamber of Commerce has planned a rally the day after the Super Bowl. And residents are likely to turn out by the thousands, although some people see Bills players as less than ideal heroes.
"A lot of people are out of work in this area," Mr. McKnight said. "And when you get someone who makes a lot of money like Kelly, who the economic hard times aren't hitting, people resent it."
For many, however, Super Bowl excitement has meant a chance to improve their own incomes. At the airport, James Stokes, a Continental Airlines sales agent, was happily calculating the money to be made from flying three planeloads of players, coaches, team owners and their families to Minneapolis. And on Tuesday, a less savory attempt to cash in on the Bills was uncovered, when the local police arrested two men at the loading dock of Trench Manufacturing, accused of stealing 20 boxes of Bills T-shirts, worth $5,600.
At a time when few retailers' cash registers are ringing, Bills paraphernalia are Buffalo's hottest commodities. In the AM & A's store in Tonawanda, other merchandise has had to make room for a special Bills display.
Among the more exotic clothes are red-white-and-blue zebra-like caps and pants, and the home-furnishings' department is well-stocked with Bills tablecloths, paperweights and blankets. But for true Bills fanatics, the top-of-the-line gift is a $54.95 package that includes a team video and a welcome mat made of AstroTurf from Rich Stadium, complete with an official plaque declaring that it is "Certified Authentic End Zone AstroTurf."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Can a Symbol of Fiscal Aplomb Ever Retire?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In 1975, Felix G. Rohatyn was recruited from the lofty confines of investment banking to help rescue the city from its own excesses. Mr. Rohatyn quickly emerged as a household name.
Today, Mr. Rohatyn is a frustrated gray eminence, an economic statesman whose vision is largely unfettered by a green eye shade and who understands the liabilities of a budget that meets legal definitions of balance but breaches the social contract. His advice as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation is valued by an eclectic following that includes Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, congressmen, chairmen of multinational corporations and, among others, the Government of Kazakhstan. 
 Yet for a man who has been deemed beyond reproach, he has also been greeted by some New Yorkers not as a messiah but as an intrusive messenger preaching fiscal responsibility at the expense of city services and city employees.
 
'Get Its House in Order'
 Today, Mr. Rohatyn (pronounced ROH-ah-tin) is even more concerned about the budget stalemate between the Governor and the Legislature.
"The state is far more culpable than the city," he said. "What's in question is not the ability of the state to get its house in order. The question is whether the state has the political capability to come to any kind of understanding.
"Nobody has recognized that the next time the credit rating is lowered it might not mean a quarter point extra in interest rates but serious market access problems," he said.
Mr. Rohatyn had planned to retire at the end of this month as the first and only chairman of the M.A.C., the state agency created in 1975 to borrow on the city's behalf. But two weeks ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo prevailed upon him to remain indefinitely.
As the embodiment of the M.A.C., Mr. Rohatyn has sometimes been an institutional irritant to Mr. Dinkins and to his predecessors. But as reluctant as the Mayor and Governor may have been to lose Mr. Rohatyn's financial expertise, something even more fundamental was at stake.
 
Message to Wall Street
 Mr. Rohatyn has become such a symbol in public finance that his planned departure, shortly after the Governor unveils his budget today and after the Mayor releases his own financial plan next week, might have conveyed a message to Wall Street that would have further jeopardized the city and state's credit.
"If all of a sudden you were to walk off and leave," Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's spokesman quoted Mr. Dinkins as saying, "people would say the city was falling apart."
Arguably, the role Mr. Rohatyn assumed in the latest crisis is more challenging than the one he played in 1975, when he was recruited by Gov. Hugh L. Carey. In a city inured to crises, there is neither the sense of urgency nor the cooperative spirit that prevailed then. This time, recurring deficits have been compounded by new social problems and by the state's even more pressing budget crisis. And Mr. Rohatyn has been dismissed as a doomsayer so consistently that when his pessimism is justified it may not be heeded.
What distinguished him in 1975 were his negotiating skills, his access to power and to publicity, his proficiency both at crunching numbers and at crafting quotable metaphors, and his ingenuity in forging solutions that seemed to satisfy budgetary and political imperatives.
Today his access is undiminished. But rather than being an outsider from Wall Street, Mr. Rohatyn is one of the players. Moreover, he now personifies the M.A.C. And having outlasted virtually everyone who had a role in the financial struggles of the 70's, he became an inviting target.
 
Faulting Dinkins Plan
 Instead of being viewed as resolving a crisis, he was perceived in some quarters as trying to create one last fall, in order to provoke a solution. He did this, his critics say, by dangling, then threatening to withhold from the city, a billion dollars that could be generated by refinancing bonds issued by the corporation. Without that money, Mayor Dinkins warned that it would have to raise taxes or further shrink municipal government.
The Mayor had planned to use the M.A.C. money instead of raising property taxes. But Mr. Rohatyn, describing the Mayor's preliminary financial plan as too tentative, called substituting M.A.C. money for a tax increase "sacrilege."
That public admonition alone persuaded the administration to draft a revised version in conjunction with the state Financial Control Board, an overseer headed by the Governor.The Dinkins administration now proposes to re-finance some of its own debt to pay off M.A.C. bonds, a maneuver that could cost millions of dollars more but would not require the approval of a recalcitrant Legislature.
Largely without questioning his motives, critics maintain that Mr. Rohatyn usurped prerogatives of elected officials to spend corporation surpluses that they maintain are the city's anyway. For all his well-known glibness, Mr. Rohatyn says he finds it difficult to defend himself without sounding self-serving.
But, he said, "when people ask, 'Who elected Felix?' the answer is that the politicians did, because they needed somebody to do this."
He has been a foil and a prod. But he was so stung by criticism from municipal labor leaders in 1990 that he announced his retirement -- then was persuaded by Mr. Cuomo to return to administer a final transfusion to the anemic city.
After Mr. Rohatyn retires from the M.A.C., he hopes to fulfill a personal commitment to the city by pursuing other civic ventures, including long-range planning for Carnegie Hall and helping to advance the public-education agenda set by his wife, Elizabeth, through her roles, among others, as the vice-chairwoman of Thirteen/ WNET and a trustee of the New York Public Library.
"I'm worn out, I really want to get in from out of the cold," he said last fall. "But everywhere I go, whether social functions or people coming up to me on the street, the message is the same: 'Hang in there.'
"I'm 64," he said. "We're going to stay in the city, but I frankly don't know what I would do if I were 20 years younger. I know it sounds arrogant, but one woman came up to me at a dinner party and said: 'Don't leave. It would be such a symbol. We'd all have to leave.' "
The potency of ideas, the authority to convey them in private and the flair to promote them in public would empower Mr. Rohatyn under any circumstances. He derives institutional power from his chairmanship of the corporation, which he engineered in 1975 to borrow for a city shunned by the private credit markets. The corporation's more than $6.5 billion in bonds are backed by the city's sales-tax receipts, which are diverted each year to pay off the debt.
The dozens of plaques and photographs that line Mr. Rohatyn's modest Rockefeller Center office, along with five Holbein prints, attest to a public presence that could not have been achieved simply by negotiating the sale of M.C.A. to Matsushita or finessing other high-profile deals as the senior partner of Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banking house.
Nonetheless, Mr. Rohatyn said he would never seek elective office. "I don't think I could take the abuse and the pandering that you have to do," he said. "I don't confront people. I negotiate. This is what I do for a living. When you deal in the private sector, you deal in solutions. When you deal with government, the political system insists that there be winners and losers."
Encased with other mementos in a small conference room just outside his office is a certificate of appreciation from Mayor Abraham D. Beame, who presided during the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. Successive administrations resisted proposals to expand the M.A.C.'s mandate. Mayor Edward I. Koch bristled at the strings Mr. Rohatyn attached when he dispensed more than $3 billion in M.A.C. surpluses that had accumulated when bonds were refinanced at more favorable interest rates.
In conjunction with Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Koch, Mr. Rohatyn set the priorities on how the Assistance Corporation's surpluses would be spent -- mostly on education and mass transit. He also helped lobby the State Legislature to relax contract rules that would have driven up the cost of school construction.
Mr. Rohatyn said it was mostly his concern about racial tension in New York that led him to vote for Mr. Dinkins in 1989, when the Mayor became the first black man elected to the post. Today he particularly praises Mr. Dinkins for trying to calm Crown Heights in the aftermath of racial violence there last summer and for his latest aggressive response to racial assaults.
In part to reassure the financial community early on, Mr. Dinkins recruited Mr. Rohatyn as an adviser. Soon after, though, Mr. Rohatyn said that Mr. Dinkins acknowledged, "I'm more comfortable with my friends in labor than with financial geniuses like you."
A former colleague at Lazard Freres, Norman Steisel, Mr. Dinkins's First Deputy Mayor, has periodically been denounced by the Mayor's most liberal supporters as a tool of Wall Street. But, Mr. Rohatyn said, referring to the Assistance Corporation, "if we were tools of Wall Street, we never would have turned our surpluses over to the city."
In 1975, said Barry Feinstein, the head of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, "Felix was an agent of the Governor to bring the parties together."
"Now he has his own self-interest because of his bondholders," he added. "His judgment is clouded by his overwhelming desire to be the consummate financier."
If Mr. Rohatyn says he is frustrated that he has become the embodiment of the Assistance Corporation, it is an image that he has also cultivated as an integral part of his strategy of generally friendly persuasion.
"My role doesn't demonstrate power -- it demonstrates institutional failure," he said, meaning that if political institutions in the city were doing their jobs, his would largely be superfluous. "The only thing I can do is warn people and and try to do it as dispassionately and apolitically as possible.
"I have dreams, but I no longer have illusions," he said. "I don't believe I have a hidden agenda other than the fact that I live here. The Mayor has nothing that I want. The Governor has nothing that I want. There is an ego satisfaction in doing important things well, but if I wanted publicity I could get it in business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The advice of Felix G. Rohatyn, as the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has been valued by an eclectic following. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Auto Import Goal Isn't a Commitment, Japan Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Japan's Prime Minister and one of its leading car manufacturers reiterated today that Japan had made no commitment during President Bush's trade visit to buy United States autos and parts.
A top Bush Administration official responded by saying that if the Japanese back off their auto import goals there will be "a very negative reaction" in the United States. 
 Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and the chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation, Eiji Toyoda, sought to dispel expectations that Japan was bound to meet auto purchasing targets set on Jan. 9, when Japanese negotiators agreed to trade concessions to help relieve the United States recession.
 
Termed a Target
 Mr. Miyazawa told NHK television that an announcement that Japanese auto makers would try to import nearly 20,000 Big Three vehicles and $10 billion more in auto parts was "a target rather than a firm promise." Japan now buys $9 billion in American auto parts a year.
The announcement was "a kind of forecast of how many U.S. automobiles and parts Japan would definitely be able to purchase by 1994," he said in the interview broadcast tonight.
Mr. Toyoda, chief of Japan's largest auto maker, told reporters in a separate interview that Toyota "will study and consider the possibility of selling G.M. cars. It is too much to say we will actually sell them."
At the time the agreements were signed earlier this month, the Japanese auto makers also described their purchase plans as targets, saying that fulfilling them depended largely on an increase in the quality of American-made auto parts. They said, however, that roughly $17 billion of the targets, which were established in November when the Japanese Government urged each auto maker to set a specific buying plan, should be attainable.
They have not been as optimistic about the remaining $2 billion, added during President Bush's visit here. "It is a best-case scenario," a senior Toyota executive said today.
 
U.S. Official Comments
 But in Washington, J. Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said of the statements today by Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Toyoda: "It may be a sign of backing off from the stated goals that they have unilaterally set for themselves. It is not unusual for Japanese Government officials to make what looks like a fairly basic commitment and then qualify it heavily at a later date. This doesn't shock me."
Still, he added, Japanese auto makers realize there will be "a very negative reaction here in the United States if they don't expeditiously move to meet and exceed the goals."
Mr. Farren said the 20,000 import figure was never included in the formal Japanese Government statement -- at the United States request. That was because "frankly any number they might come out with would probably be low and not necessarily realistic," he said.
But the goal of raising auto part imports from $9 billion to $19 billion by 1994 "was in the document the Government put out," said Mr. Farren, who attended the Tokyo meeting.
During the four-day meeting that ended Jan. 10, Toyota announced it was setting a target of selling up to 5,000 General Motors vehicles a year through its dealerships. Japan's other four major auto makers -- Nissan, Honda, Mazda and Mitsubishi -- separately set targets totaling 15,000 more vehicles.
"In terms of a direct agreement with Toyota, we never said we had a direct agreement with Toyota," a G.M. spokesman, John Pekarek, said today in Detroit. "They pledged they would investigate selling 5,000 cars."
In another trade development today, Japan announced a pledge to open bidding to foreign companies on $3.3 billion worth of Government-purchased computer products and services. Japan had signed an accord on Government purchases of American computers during the visit by Mr. Bush.
Computers, like autos, have been a chronic sore point in talks to even out the trade imbalance between Japan and the United States. American negotiators have argued that Government agencies open bidding only to Japanese computer companies; Japan says the same thing about United States Government purchases.
On Wednesday, Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, who arrived in the United States today for meetings with top Government officials, will attend a White House signing ceremony of Japan's agreement to buy American-made computers. He will meet on Tuesday with Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

HEADLINE: A Top Japanese Politician Calls U.S. Work Force Lazy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
One of Japan's most senior politicians said over the weekend that America's economic troubles were rooted in a work force "too lazy" to compete with Japan, and argued that one of the biggest problems of the United States was that nearly a third of its workers "cannot even read."
The harshly worded assessment by Yoshio Sakurauchi, the 79-year-old Speaker of Japan's powerful lower house of Parliament, seemed bound to fuel the trans-Pacific arguments over the causes of America's trade and competitiveness difficulties with Japan. Though Japanese politicians rarely speak publicly in such direct and confrontational terms about the United States, Mr. Sakurauchi's comments seemed to amplify themes that have appeared in the Japanese press and on television since President Bush and his entourage of business executives left Japan 10 days ago. 
 In Washington today, a Department of Education official denied the assertion that a third of American workers could not read, saying that less than 5 percent of the American population is illiterate. [Page D11.]
According to accounts that appeared widely in the Japanese-language press today, Mr. Sakurauchi told a meeting of supporters in Masuda City, a manufacturing and agricultural area in western Japan, that America risked becoming "Japan's subcontractor," and had no one to blame but itself.
"The source of the problem is the inferior quality of U.S. labor," he reportedly said. "U.S. workers are too lazy. They want high pay without working."
About 30 percent of American workers "cannot even read," he was quoted as having said. "So managers cannot convey their orders in written form. Therefore, they get a high ratio of bad parts."
Mr. Sakurauchi's comments clearly caught the Government here off guard. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa is trying to play down differences with the United States and put the best face possible on Mr. Bush's much-criticized visit. Asked about Mr. Sakurauchi's assessment of the talents of American workers, the Government's chief spokesman, Koichi Kato, said that while individual politicians had their own views, "the Government should make no comments about the level, the quality or the education of workers in other nations."
Mr. Sakurauchi is a powerful member of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and no stranger to dealings with the United States. In a long career, he has served as Foreign Minister, Agriculture Minister, Minister of International Trade and Industry and Construction Minister. He has also been the secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party and the head of its chief policy-making body.
 
Gist Is Confirmed
 Reached today at the speaker's office, one of Mr. Sakurauchi's political secretaries, Kyoshi Tsuchida, confirmed the gist of the press reports. But he said that another political secretary who attended the meeting on Sunday said that while Mr. Sakurauchi described illiteracy as a widespread problem among American workers, he did not mention a figure of 30 percent. He is quoted as using that number in two of Japan's leading newspapers, Yomiuri Shimbun and Mainichi Shimbun. Apparently Japanese reporters attended the session.
"The same sorts of thing have been said repeatedly in industry magazines and other publications," Mr. Tsuchida said. "What he wanted to stress is that in the U.S. there is no good communications between managers and workers."
Despite Mr. Sakurauchi's comments, statistics indicate that American factory workers are, on average, still more productive than their Japanese counterparts. A recent survey by the United States Labor Department indicates that the American work force still leads the world in output per worker, and leads Japan by a margin of about 19 percent. But worker productivity in Japan is growing at roughly twice the rate of productivity growth in the United States. If current trends continue, Japan would surpass the United States in productivity around 1995.
Mr. Sakurauchi's comments today recalled several controversial remarks about the United States that have periodically come from Japanese leaders. In 1986, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who runs the faction to which Mr. Sakurauchi belongs, said that blacks and other minorities had lower intelligence levels than other Americans. In 1988, Michio Watanabe, who is now Foreign Minister, said that blacks used credit cards irresponsibly, spending themselves into bankruptcy. And a year and a half ago, during a sweep of a Tokyo red-light district, Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama compared foreign prostitutes to American blacks who, he said, destroyed good neighborhoods.
Mr. Sakurauchi's comments, however, were not overtly racial. Instead, he seemed to reflect a growing sentiment here that America was lashing out against Japan for a litany of domestic problems that are described almost daily in the press here: overpaid executives, a crumbling educational system and too little attention to the quality of products.

HEADLINE: SHAMIR IS VOWING NEW SETTLEMENTS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In a direct challenge to Bush Administration calls for his Government to stop building settlements in occupied lands, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir declared defiantly today that "this construction will continue and no power in the world will prevent this construction."
His Finance Minister went a step further by saying that if the United States insisted on a settlement freeze as the price for $10 billion in American loan guarantees that Israel says it needs to absorb new Jewish immigrants, he would rather forgo the assistance, no matter what the economic consequences. 
 "It is impossible to give up this hold on the land or undermine it for reasons of absorption or the population's welfare," said the Finance Minister, Yitzhak Modai. "We'll have to suffer together."
While the substance of what the Israeli officials said was not new, the timing was significant.
 
Seeking Political Benefits
 Having lost his parliamentary majority on Sunday when two far-right parties walked out of his governing coalition, Mr. Shamir seems headed for national elections in the next few months, and his uncompromising remarks today opened his political campaign. He has apparently decided that talking tough on settlements, especially before a group of cheering settlers in Betar Illit, outside Jerusalem, will do him enough good with Israeli voters to outweigh the harm it is almost certain to cause him in Washington.
"We see the construction in all of Judea, Samaria and the Gaza Strip, and in all the land of Israel," Mr. Shamir said as he planted a tree at the settlement. Judea and Samaria are the biblical names that Israel uses for the West Bank.
"We will build, and I hope very much that we will also obtain guarantees," he said. "In any case, I'm sure we will continue to absorb emigration."
 
One Million New Immigrants
 The Prime Minister chose to take his uncompromising stand on settlements just as Israel is turning to Washington once more to provide the loan guarantees. They are intended to help Israel borrow billions of dollars from commercial banks to resettle an estimated one million immigrants expected from the former Soviet Union by 1995.
When the aid issue first arose in September, President Bush asked Congress to hold off debate for 120 days to avoid ruffling the budding Middle East peace process. Now that period is about to expire. As before, a pivotal issue is the Shamir Government's insistence on putting settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip despite warnings from some Israeli diplomats and American Jewish groups that this construction endangers the assistance package.
Increasingly, these American groups and some Government officials here say they are resigned to getting a lot less than they had originally asked for, in part because of the settlements and in part because of the anti-foreign aid mood in Washington.
 
Polls Suggest Irritation
 Public opinion polls suggest that the irritation with Mr. Shamir's hard-nosed position on settlements is widespread, for many Israelies complain that he is sacrificing the economic well-being and social needs on an altar of unyielding ideology. Some American Jewish leaders, though not all, are also unhappy because they feel that the Prime Minister is pushing them into battle against a White House that has already proved that it has more muscle than they do on this matter.
As though to define these lines even more sharply, the Israeli press today reported that a Government-commissioned study had concluded that unemployment here would rise to more than 16 percent, from 11 percent, in the next four years if the loan guarantees did not arrive.
The study, which warned of "human suffering and social problems," was ordered three months ago by Finance Minister Modai to bolster Israel's case for the assistance. But Mr. Modai said today that "even these kinds of unemployment rates are not the end of society or of the Israeli economy." Retaining the right to build in the territories is more important, he said.

HEADLINE: Thrift Office's Eager Terminator

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In the mire of the savings and loan mess, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., the nation's top savings and loan regulator, has gotten remarkably little mud on his clothes.
The 46-year-old regulator has won so many political points for his swift seizure of faltering institutions and his crackdowns on industry scoundrels that his name has come up as a possibility for the next Comptroller of the Currency. He has successfully calmed a worried Congress, and his personal ties to President Bush and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have brought him into the Administration's inner circle. 
 But many in the industry are less than happy with his reign, which began three years ago when Mr. Ryan became the first head of the newly created Office of Thrift Supervision.
 
Some Say He Has Gone Too Far
 As chief of the agency that decides which institutions will live and which will die, he has been so eager to close them down that his actions have sometimes bordered on the reckless, many industry executives and lawyers say. They contend that he has taken a dragnet approach, closing savings and loans that might have survived. And they say his attacks on savings industry lawyers have gone too far, raising questions about whether his agency has violated due process protections.
"There have been some very heavy-handed actions that have cost taxpayers money," said Douglas Faucette, a Washington lawyer who once worked for bank regulators and now represents industry clients. "Absolutely, many of these institutions might have survived. But in the political situation, they have to round up everyone."
To Mr. Ryan, such criticisms are compliments. "Some think we've been real aggressive," Mr. Ryan said in a telephone interview. "And we plead guilty to that."
Mr. Ryan sees himself as a warrior for the taxpayer. "We are the front-line troops," he said. "We're trying to make it through each battle. Most people here have been in combat positions for three years already."
 
Cleaned Up Teamsters' Fund
 This is not the first time that Mr. Ryan has faced combat. A labor lawyer, he is perhaps best known for having cleaned up the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' pension fund while serving as solicitor in the Reagan Adminstration's Labor Department. After taking on the teamsters, a task made even more delicate by the teamsters' support for Mr. Reagan's Presidential bid, confronting savings-and-loan crooks pales by comparison, some officials say.
But at his thrift agency confirmation hearings, his lack of experience in financial services, along with admissions of marijuana and concaine use in his youth, nearly derailed his nomination. Only after Secretary Brady made a concerted push did Mr. Ryan squeak by.
By his own admission, Mr. Ryan's credentials were weak. "My concern was that I wasn't qualified and it was a big job," he said. Those close to him say that he accepted only after a personal call from the President. Mr. Ryan's only comment is that he took the job "because the right guy asked me."
Since then, he has won high marks as a quick study of an arcane industry whose misdeeds are costing the Government tens of billions of dollars.
"Timothy Ryan is a born and bred Washington operator," said S. William Seidman, former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "And that proves more important than being an expert in financial services. He came to the job well prepared to work the Washington scene, less well prepared to work finance. But he's picked that up rapidly."
 
670 S.& L.'s Sold or Liquidated
 During Mr. Ryan's tenure, his agency has ordered the liquidation or sale of some 670 savings and loans with assets of $350 billion, cut his agency's budget by about 10 percent a year and seen the capital of the surviving industry grow from under 1 percent to about 5 percent of assets.
An institution's capital is its cushion against losses. Those savings and loans determined to be unsound are transferred by the Office of Thrift Supervision to the Resolution Trust Corporation for sale or liquidation.
Currently, there are 2,148 savings and loans with $910 billion in assets under the thrift office's supervision. In the third quarter of 1991, 86 percent of these institutions were profitable, and the industry as a whole showed a net income of $271.8 million -- the third profitable quarter in a row.
But the numbers, rosy of late, mask an industry where the fate of many institutions remains uncertain and where, some say, a regulatory reign of terror pervades. "Everybody who's still alive is scared to death," said one former top Government enforcement lawyer now in private practice.
The argument some executives and lawyers offer is that in his zealousness, Mr. Ryan is closing institutions that if given a little latitude might survive. In doing so, they say, he is costing taxpayers extra money, since the Government has to cover the losses of these institutions -- immediately.
Charles John Koch, chief executive at the First Federal Savings Bank of Cleveland, said that while he was happy to have fewer competitors, Mr. Ryan's course imposed high costs on the public.
 
'Not in a Gambling Mood'
 "Mr. Ryan is not in a gambling mood that any given institution might make it," he said. "So they are teeing up to put anything remotely questionable into the R.T.C. It's good for me as a healthy thrift, but it's not in the best interests of the taxpayers because it costs a lot more."
While Mr. Ryan says that he has closed solvent savings and loans, he adds that his actions have been upheld in court and reflect his goals. "My mission has been to clean up the industry and make sure it is safe and sound," Mr. Ryan said. "We have been admittedly aggressive, but I know we don't have any Charles Keatings running around. We're the regulator of the industry. We aren't the trade association and we're not its promoter. That's how they got into trouble the last time. They had a regulator who was a promoter."
 
September 1993 Deadline
 Mr. Ryan admits, however, to feeling the pressure of a September 1993 deadline, when the cost of the cleanup switches from Treasury borrowings to the savings and loan insurance fund, which is supported by premiums levied on the industry. Mr. Ryan says the "most difficult part of this job" is making sure that the fund starts out with as few obvious liabilities as possible, which means closing institutions that could cause future problems.
"No one wants institutions to crash and then have the thrift insurance fund go down the tubes," he said. "It's like a health-insurance fund. You don't want to take in people with pre-existing conditions."
But that's the source of the problem, some say. "There's no downside to pulling the trigger too early," said Richard K. Kneipper, a Dallas lawyer with Jones Day Reavis & Pogue.
Another sore area is over the new legal tactics Mr. Ryan's agency has used. These include using administrative orders to freeze assets and impose severe penalties, even before a court finding of guilt. And his agency has begun to say that lawyers representing savings and loans also have a duty to report on their clients to regulators.
Congress gave Mr. Ryan's agency broad new prosecutorial powers when it was created in 1989. And he is using them all -- often at the same time. His agency can impose fines of up to $1 million a day, seize assets and set limits on how much defendants can pay for legal representation.
"You can only kill the person once, but there seems to be a lot of bullets going into the body," said Arthur Liebold, a Washington lawyer who represents savings and loans. "I don't think that Congress, by providing authority, necessarily says to an agency that you must excercise every single bit of it and push to the outer limits of statutory and judiciary authority."
Mr. Ryan is well aware of these comments. "Lawyers don't like it because they know they are potential targets," he said, "and accountants and investment bankers don't like it for the same reasons. But that's a major effort of ours right now. So, stay tuned."
Right now, Mr. Ryan's attention is on the "tweeners," savings and loans that are not obviously "brain dead," in regulatory parlance, and that at the same time are not clear winners -- a group with $247 billion in assets. These institutions have poor earnings, low capital and real estate portfolios that could go either way. Many of them, four large ones in particular, are in California.
While Mr. Ryan said he was optimistic about the California economy, he added that dealing with these institutions was much more difficult than his earlier actions.
He is currently floating the concept of "Early Resolution Assisted Mergers," to allow the Government to encourage buyers of these institutions by giving them some protection against the riskiness of the loan portfolios. The most controversial idea would allow existing stock- and bondholders to retain some investment in the institution, instead of being wiped out, a change from current policy.
But this plan is still in the discussion stage, as are proposals to merge the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates banks, with Mr. Ryan's agency. Both agencies come under the Treasury Department, and Mr. Ryan has long advocated their consolidation -- even before his name was raised as a possible Comptroller.
He demurs when asked whether he might like to head the combined agency, listing all the political obstacles to effecting such a union. "My only job," he said, "is to do this job."

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Debate Is Mere Tuneup On Democrats' Journey

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 20

 BODY:
Everybody had an angle in Sunday night's debate among the Democratic Presidential candidates. Stirring political theater it certainly was not, but it gave some clues about what each of the five will be trying to do in the weeks ahead.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas portrayed himself as the tribune of the middle class. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts said his economic program was more highly regarded by experts than those of his rivals. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska talked a lot about health insurance. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California rolled out a whole new tax plan. And Senator Tom Harkin worked hard to justify his claim to be "the only real Democrat" in the lot. 
 No one fell on his face. Each managed to score a point or two at the expense of his rivals. And a few ideas, usually about as common at such shindigs as unfilled jobs in New Hampshire, actually found breathing room.
But all of the five hopefuls have a lot to accomplish before the Democrats' third debate on Jan. 31, which will constitute the next checkpoint on the road to the New Hampshire primary, the nation's first, on Feb. 18.
Governor Clinton, who attracted the most support in a poll published by The Boston Globe the morning before the debate, got a taste of what it is like to be a front-runner. He attracted the gibes of both Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey, with Mr. Harkin particularly hard on his record as Governor.
There will be a lot more detailed examination of that record in the days ahead, including discussions of the success of Arkansas's education overhaul, a sales-tax increase supported by Mr. Clinton and the harsh comments of the Little Rock newspaper on many of his ideas. More than anything else, Mr. Clinton will have to prove that he can take such punches and hit back, because the Democrats are determined, after the passivity of Michael S. Dukakis four years ago, to nominate a counterpuncher this time.
So far, his main rebuttal has been to call attention to the two senators' votes in favor of $23,000-a-year raises for themselves.
The Governor may also have to contend with accusations of extramarital affairs published last week in some newspapers and the potential damage the allegations could cause among women voters in particular. The accusations had relatively little circulation, but they came up during the debate, and despite Mr. Clinton's contention that the American people are tired of negative politics, that is unlikely to be the end of the subject.
His lead is not yet overwhelming, so it is probabaly too early for an ABC alliance (Anyone But Clinton) by his opponents, but Mr. Clinton has not been thoroughly tested, and they cannot afford to let that last.
For Mr. Kerrey, the challenge is to make himself seem the logical alternative to Mr. Clinton for those who find the Arkansan unsatisfactory for one reason or another. There has not seemed to be a tremendous amount of ideological space between them, but Mr. Kerrey is trying to open some and said today that he was "ready for some body contact" with his Democratic rivals.
His new television commercials show him tending goal in a hockey rink, promising to protect American jobs. In the debate, he insisted that the Japanese had blocked the United States from their markets, and he expressed doubts that a middle-class tax cut would "massively stimulate the economy." Both of those views resemble those of Senator Harkin, and may represent an attempt to go after voters who find Mr. Clinton too bland.
Mr. Harkin sought to undermine any such effort by accusing Mr. Kerrey of voting against American workers' interests on the special "fast-track" authorization for President Bush's trade negotiations with Mexico.
Clearly, the Iowa Senator faces the greatest peril here of the three candidates who are given a good shot at eventual nomination. The polls show him with an almost invisible base, and his hard-hitting performance Sunday night was designed to convince people, in his own words, that he alone offered something other than "a tweedledee Democrat attacking a tweedledum Republican." He bluntly termed Mr. Clinton an apostle of Reaganomics.
New Hampshire ought to offer, in this winter of its economic discontent, fertile ground for a candidate who offers a radically different approach on taxes and benefits, and Mr. Harkin is such a candidate. Yet he is faltering. If the problem is the messenger, his television advertisements and a more focused personal style like the one he displayed Sunday night may help; if the problem is the message, and Democrats are convinced that a middle-of-the-road approach is needed to defeat Mr. Bush, there's not much Mr. Harkin can do.
Mr. Brown and Mr. Tsongas face a much more worrisome problem: getting the electorate to take them seriously. Although several influential local commentators praised his performance Sunday night, Mr. Tsongas is still taken as a regional candidate with little real chance, and Mr. Brown, despite a more measured performance than in the last debate, is considered the rank outsider.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa talked yesterday with a prospective voter at Pappy's Pizza in Manchester, N.H. Mr. Harkin says he is "the only real Democrat" in the race. The Democrats' third debate is Jan. 31, and the New Hampshire primary is Feb. 18. (Paul Hosefros for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Move to Spur Economy, Bush Is Urged to Order 90-Day Ban on New Federal Rules

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
President Bush's senior advisers have recommended that he stop all Government agencies from issuing new rules for three months as part of a broad campaign to revive the economy by reducing the burden of Federal regulation, White House officials said today.
The recommendation, most likely to be included in Mr. Bush's State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, comes from Vice President Dan Quayle and other officials, including C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel; Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. 
 Rules required by statute and those considered most likely to have a beneficial effect on the economy would be exempt from the ban, Administration officials said.
 
An Across-the-Board Ban
 "What we envision is a moratorium on proposing new regulations, across the board in every agency, except those rules required by statute or those that stimulate economic growth," a White House official said, confirming a report in today's issue of The Wall Street Journal. "This will send a clear signal to agencies that the President wants them to re-examine all regulations and their impact on the economy."
The moratorium would affect most of the 4,800 regulations now being developed by Federal agencies.
White House officials said Mr. Bush was troubled by studies documenting a resurgence of Federal regulations since he became President in January 1989. The number of pages in the Federal Register, a crude but useful indicator of regulatory activity, increased last year by 26 percent, to 67,715 pages, the highest number since 1980, the final year of the Carter Administration.
As Vice President, Mr. Bush was in charge of President Ronald Reagan's Task Force on Regulatory Relief, which blocked hundreds of rules deemed burdensome to business, consumers, universities or local governments. But as President, Mr. Bush has allowed such rules to proliferate.
White House officials listed seven broad areas in which they now hope to reduce Federal regulation on entrepreneurs and businesses: environmental protection (including fuel economy standards for automobiles); energy (natural gas, electricity); transportation (trucking, ocean shipping, airlines); exports; communications (cellular telephones, cable television); biotechnology, and "access to capital."
Gary D. Bass, director of O.M.B. Watch, a consumer group that monitors the Office of Management and Budget, said the moratorium was "an outrageous attempt by the Administration to appeal to business interests in an election year."
Mr. Bass also said the effects of the moratoriium would run beyond three months because "agencies will be afraid to initiate regulations to protect workers, consumers and the public in general."
Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the House Government Operations Committee, which supervises Federal regulatory policy, said, "Particularly in light of what appears to be the total lack of any economic analysis to support this proposal, it is likely only to increase the perception that President Bush is desperate, rudderless and lacking in any original program to get the economy back on track."
 
Improper Interference Charged
 Mr. Conyers and Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the Committee on Governmental Affairs, have charged that the White House improperly interferred in the rule-making of Federal agencies.
White House officials said the 90-day ban on new regulations could be imposed by the President alone without action by Congress.
"For tax policy we have to go to Congress, and for monetary policy we have to depend on the Federal Reserve, but regulatory policy is one area where the President can act unilaterally," said a White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Administration officials said they did not have a reliable estimate of benefits from the moratorium. One White House official said it could save businesses $10 billion to $100 billion a year. But Gail E. Shearer, manager of policy analysis for Consumers Union, said the Administration "undervalues the benefits of regulations that protect health and safety."
It is not clear who would decide which regulations are exempt from the 90-day ban.
Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, and Edward M. Emmett, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, welcomed the prospect of a moratorium. Mr. Clarke said his agency was drafting "an absolute mountain of regulations, guidelines and restrictions" to be imposed on banks.
Mr. Emmett estimated that the nation could save $40 billion a year by curtailing trucking regulations. "We still have vestiges of a regulatory scheme from the 1930's," he said.
Murray L. Weidenbaum, who was chairman of Mr. Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers in 1981 and 1982, and James C. Miller 3d, who was Mr. Reagan's budget director from 1985 to 1988, applauded the idea of a ban on new rules.
"It will signal employers and producers that the Bush Administration is seriously concerned about the costs of regulation," said Mr. Weidenbaum, now a professor at Washington University in St. Louis. "It will also give regulatory agencies a more adequate opportunity to carefully develop the regulations that are coming out at prodigious rates."
The action recommended to Mr. Bush is reminiscent of a 1980 campaign pledge by Mr. Reagan, who said he would declare a moratorium on new regulations. As President, he killed many pending rules and ordered rigorous comparison of the costs and benefits of all proposed rules.

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: Diplomats Are Edgy as India Stubbornly Builds Its Nuclear Arsenal

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In sharp contrast to the rest of the world, South Asia is on the brink of a nuclear arms race, say senior Western diplomats and foreign political figures who have visited New Delhi in recent weeks.
This arms race is viewed with particular alarm because of the continuing tension between India and Pakistan over Kashmir, a region over which two wars have already been fought. 
 And although both India and Pakistan are regarded as nuclear powers by Western intelligence agencies, these diplomats generally contend that it is India, rather than Pakistan, that has blocked any meaningful progress toward defusing nuclear proliferation.
"South Asia seems to be bucking the trend on reducing international tensions," said a senior diplomat here. "We see South Asia at the precipice of a nuclear weapons race. Within the next five years, both sides will have medium-range missiles. Each side will have to assume the worst of each other. And this is destabilizing because of the hair-trigger nature of these missiles in times of tension."
 
First Nuclear, Now Chemical
 India detonated a nuclear device in 1974 for what it said were peaceful purposes, and Pakistan is generally recognized as having developed its own nuclear abilities. Indeed, in testimony this month to the Senate subcommittee on nonproliferation, Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, expressed Washington's anxiety over the direction both nations were taking.
"In South Asia, the arms race between India and Pakistan is a major concern," Mr. Gates told the subcommittee. "Not only do both countries have nuclear weapon and ballistic missile programs; they have recently pursued chemical weapons as well. These programs are particularly worrisome because of constant tension and conflict in Kashmir." All American assistance to Pakistan was cut off in 1990 because of its nuclear-weapons program.
In the last year, and especially in recent months, concerted international pressure -- a medley of wooing, cajoling, encouragement, suggestions, hectoring and plain blunt talk -- has been applied to India, pressure intended to get the Government to address the question of nuclear proliferation in South Asia. So far none of it has worked.
 
Pakistan Proposes Talks
 Since June, Pakistan has been making proposals for talks with India over nuclear issues, has volunteered to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty if India does and has suggested a gathering of the United States, Russia, China, India and Pakistan to discuss the elimination of nuclear weapons in South Asia.
In November, during a visit here by the Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, Science and Technology, Reginald Bartholomew, the United States proposed more sweeping five-power talks to explore a greater range of options.
Among his ideas were a test-ban treaty and pledges not to attack urban centers, along with a proposal that both India and Pakistan sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and submit to international inspection.
 
No Response From India
 India has remained silent on all these proposals, instead offering arguments as to why it cannot contemplate a limit on its nuclear options. These arguments are made publicly in the press, privately in conversations with foreign journalists and even, with hardly any differences, in discussions with foreign governments.
Foremost, India insists that Pakistan retains aggressive intentions toward India and that it has its own nuclear weapons. With its smaller army, the Indians argue, Pakistan will inevitably rely more on its nuclear arsenal, however tiny, if there is a serious conflict along the border.
The Indians also argue that as long as China, a nation with whom it fought a border war in 1962, possesses nuclear weapons, New Delhi cannot consider any proposal that would lead to a nuclear-free zone in South Asia, since China shows no signs of giving up its nuclear weapons. India also contends that there is an inherent unfairness in the pressure from the large powers on New Delhi when they continue to possess large arsenals of their own.
But these arguments have not been met with sympathy, neither in Washington nor in Moscow, nor in London nor even in Tokyo. "Nonproliferation is not an American issue," said a diplomat here. "The French and the Germans have found religion on this issue. Even the Japanese have expressed their concerns to the India about this."
The United States and Britain in particular, are pressing India to put forth some ideas of its own. Last week, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain was here and the issue of nonproliferation headed his agenda. And next month Ronald F. Lehman 2d, the director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmanent Agency, is to visit New Delhi to re-emphasize Washington's position.
"I have left them in no doubt of the growing anxiety of nuclear proliferation," Mr. Hurd told the BBC. "They left me in no doubt that so far as they are concerned they see the problems here in this part of the world as resulting from the differences between of India and Pakistan."
After emerging from his meetings with Government leaders, the Foreign Secretary was pessimistic about prospects for India joining any five-power talks on nuclear proliferation. "I didn't have the impression that this was likely in the near future," he said.
Diplomats here and in Western capitals are becoming increasingly frustrated by India's refusal either to discuss proliferation with them or to put forth ideas of their own.
At the British Embassy here, David S. Keeling, first secretary for information, said: "What we have suggested to the Indians is that there is no point in turning their backs on these ideas, that they should frame proposals of their own. Why not come out with some positive proposals of their own and come and sit down and talk about it?"
"India is becoming more and more conspicuous in its stance," said a senior Western diplomat here. "The Indians know that the countries they are depending on to make their economic reforms a success are pushing them on nonproliferation. They have a hard choice to make."
Particularly worrisome, this diplomat said, is the rush toward the development of medium-range missiles by both sides. "They say they have a legitimate need for missiles," the diplomat said. "China has them. Pakistan is getting them. It's a matter of parity and all that. This is extremely dangerous."
 
The Political Factor
 Many diplomats here say the difficulty facing India's leaders in grappling with nuclear issues is as much political as substantive. The main opposition party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu chauvinist party bitterly hostile to Pakistan, opposes signing the nonproliferation treaty. Indeed, in a visit to the United States this month, the party's president, Lal Kishen Advani, said India should retain its nuclear ability.
Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, who heads a minority Government in Parliament and who is delicately pushing forward with the most radical restructuring of India's economy since independence, is not seen by most diplomats as willing to provoke a showdown with the opposition over the nuclear issue. Pakistan's continued aid to separatist rebels in Kashmir has made it virtually impossible for him even to engage his counterpart in Islamabad in discussing the matter.
But a diplomat here said the Indians had been told repeatedly: "Pakistan has said it will match any Indian move on nukes. Maybe it's a bluff, but it should be called."

HEADLINE: Net Up 9.9% At Raytheon

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Mass. Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Raytheon Company today reported a 9.9 percent increase in quarterly earnings, saying its diversity helped shield the company from a weak economy and military cuts.
Raytheon, a leading Government contractor, reported earnings of $157.8 million, or $2.37 a share, for the last three months of 1991. That compared with profits of $143.6 million, or $2.20 a share, in the 1990 quarter. 
 Sales dipped slightly to $2.43 billion, compared with $2.46 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier. But Raytheon also tried to cut costs during the year, shrinking its payroll by about 5,000 jobs.
For 1991, Raytheon reported its seventh straight year of record earnings. Annual profits rose 6.2 percent, to $591.8 million, or $8.95 a share. Sales were virtually flat at $9.27 billion. That compared with earnings of $557.3 million, or $8.53 a share.
Annual profits were down in Raytheon's electronics segment, which does much of the company's military work. But profits rose 43 percent in the energy services division.
Raytheon shares lost $1.50 each today, closing at $87.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
