HEADLINE: Congress Returns Today To Fight Over Economy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Congressional leaders are predicting that they will kick out of the starting block when they return to work Tuesday, trying to overcome election-year partisanship and act quickly on a number of measures intended to stimulate the economy, like a tax cut for the middle class and an extension of unemployment benefits for the jobless.
The political discord of Presidential election years usually shackles Congressional action, but leaders say this year could be different, at least on tax policy, because the recession demands efforts to stimulate the economy. 
 While most economists warn that a tax cut might worsen the budget deficit and harm the bond market, Democratic leaders say it is politically imperative for them to work with President Bush to take action.
"Both the President and Congress will try to act expeditiously to get things done because the economy is in trouble," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said in an interview. "We'll try to move a tax bill quickly."
The first test will come early this week when Democrats in the House introduce legislation to extend unemployment insurance another 13 weeks. Mr. Bush vetoed two earlier versions last year before signing a 20-week extension in November. Democratic leaders say they have the votes to override a veto, but they believe the President has to be more cooperative this year.
The White House and Democratic leaders in Congress appear ready to tinker with the spending restrictions of the 1990 budget agreement, allowing them to use money from reduced Pentagon spending for non-military purposes. They also appear to be moving toward penalty-free withdrawals of individual retirement accounts for first-time home buyers and tax incentives for businesses willing to make capital investments.
The White House is expected to propose a smaller tax cut than the Democrats support, but differences appear to be lessening.
Republican leaders in Congress say they are willing to work with Democrats to cut taxes, but they will fight Democratic efforts to increase social spending by directing that cuts in military spending be targeted at reducing the deficit or paying for tax cuts.
"The big debate will be over what should be done with defense savings," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "The Democrats desperately want to spend it. We will fight any effort to destroy spending restraints."
Republicans will also promote a cut in taxes on capital gains, a proposal that George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, said he would oppose unless the rate for the wealthiest taxpayers is increased. That is a concession the White House is not expected to accept.
 
Education Debate Looms
 Economic matters are likely to dominate Congressional action until the Easter break, particularly in the House, where tax legislation originates. But as the session progresses, the Democratic Congress and the Republican White House are likely to shoot arrows at each other over a number of other issues, including banking regulations, energy conservation, changes in health insurance and family and medical leave.
The first arrows are expected to fly this week, when the Senate debates a $850 million education bill sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that would give parents a choice in deciding on what public schools they want their children to attend. Senate Democrats will sharply criticize an alternative proposal by the Bush Administration to use Federal money to subsidize parents who choose to send their children to private schools.
Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate Republican whip, said that if the Democrats did not accept the President's education proposal it would mean "just the usual business, a highly partisan wrangle" that could spill over on the debates on crime and health care. But he predicted that both parties would try to cooperate to a greater extent than in most election years because of "this tremendous specter hanging over all the incumbents."
 "The public is restive." the Senator added. "We have to do something."
 
Family Leave and Health Care
 Family and medical leave promises to be a defining issue this political season because it is popular among many middle-class voters but is opposed by the President as an intrusion on business. Both the House and Senate last year passed bills that would require all but small businesses to give their employees unpaid leave in the event of birth, adoption or the illness of a relative.
Noting that a conference committee will soon reconcile the two versions, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House majority whip, said, "We'll send Mr. Bush a bill and let him veto it."
Many leaders expect that the hottest Congressional debate of the year to be over health care, with most Democrats demanding comprehensive changes in the nation's health insurance system to cover unemployed and part-time workers, as well as all women and children.
Although proposals like universal national health insurance are gaining momentum, particularly in the House, a veto by Mr. Bush has been promised for all but the most modest changes, like tax incentives to expand private insurance coverage.
In foreign affairs, Congressional Democrats are most likely to challenge the President on China and trade. The Administration appears to have shelved its free-trade pact with Mexico until after the Presidential election, but protectionist impulses may grow on Capitol Hill, especially if the recession deepens.
The Senate is scheduled to vote on a House-Senate conference report that would insist that China release all Tiananmen Square protesters and halt importation of goods produced by Chinese prison labor.
 
Democratic Consensus Needed
 But first, Senate and House Democratic leaders must meet this week to decide how much to cut military spending below the 1990 budget agreement and how to divide the savings. Senator Mitchell has proposed a cut of $100 billion in military spending over the next five years.
Then the Democrats must reach a consensus on what kind of tax cut they support and whether any revenue that would be lost would be balanced by a tax increase on the wealthy. Mr. Gephardt said that the Democratic leadership had still not decided on what kind of tax cut package it would endorse, but he added that most Democratic members supported plans proposed by Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, or Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
The Bentsen approach would offer families a tax credit of $300 for each child 18 years old or younger and, regardless of income, full deductability of up to $2,000 in contributions to individual retirement accounts. Lost revenue would be made up by a 5 percent cut in military spending.
The Rostenkowski plan calls for an income tax credit equivalent to one-fifth of the Medicare and Social Security taxes a taxpayer pays, with a minimum of $200 for a single filer and $400 for a working couple. The credits would last two years, and would be financed by higher taxes on the rich.

Taxes: An assortment of middle-class tax cuts are being considered.
 * One approach, proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, would grant income tax credits equal to 20 percent of the Medicare and Social Security taxes paid by individual filers and families. The credits would be financed by higher taxes for those with the highest incomes.
 * Another approach, proposed by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, would give families tax credits for each child and full deductability of up to $2,000 for contributions to individual retirement accounts.
Health care: More than 30 bills intended to improve the health insurance system have been offered. They include plans which would require companies to expand coverage, as well as to grant tax incentives to individuals and companies to buy or provide coverage, extend many Medicare and Medicaid benefits to all citizens, or create a national health insurance program.
Energy: Congress will consider redrafted legislation aimed at promoting renewable fuels and conservation.
Crime: Efforts will be renewed in favor of legislation to expand the death penalty and handgun control.
Family and medical leave: A Senate-House conference is due to reconcile bills that would guarantee workers unpaid leave for sickness, adoption or birth.
Foreign Policy: Congress must decide what kind and how much aid to give to the Soviet Union, and whether or not to restrict imports from Japan and China.

HEADLINE: Home Health-Care Employees Reach Pact on Wage Increases

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
In a labor agreement likely to set the pace for publicly financed home health-care services in New York City, the union representing about 20,000 nurses' aides announced a tentative agreement yesterday with 28 private agencies on a 5 percent wage increase, from $5.90 to $6.20 an hour.
The agreement affects about a third of the 60,000 workers in New York City who are paid under the Medicaid program to care for elderly and disabled patients who are stable enough to be discharged from a hospital. The number of home health-care workers has swelled in recent years as government agencies have tried to cut costs by moving people out of the hospitals and nursing homes.
 
Lump-Sum Payments
 Union officials say the workers, many of them middle-aged women with much less clinical training than registered nurses or therapists, are among the lowest-paid employees in the health-care industry. 
 "These are poor people serving poor patients," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, which reached the agreement. "They are the most under-represented workers in America."
The agreement comes 18 months after the last union contract on home-care services expired. A ratification vote by union members is set for today. The agreement, which expires July 1, would make the wage increases retroactive to last July and give workers a lump-sum payment of between $1,000 and $1,200.
Union officials said the main impetus for the agreement was obtaining support for the wage increases from the city, which reimburses the home-care agencies.
Under the agreement, the private health care agencies granted a wage increase that exactly matches the state's estimate of inflation.
The agreement includes several new benefits. The agencies agreed to contribute to a new pension fund, at the rate of 6.5 cents an hour. Union officials estimated the contributions to the pension fund would total $4 million a year. In addition, the agencies would begin contributing to a new training fund. Union officials conceded that workers would ultimately need more money to finance their pensions adequately, but described the agreement as a first step in providing retirement benefits.
Tom O'Brien, executive director of Family Home Care Services of Brooklyn and Queens, who represented the agencies in the negotiations, said the agreement would likely be the model for two other unions that represent home health-care workers. "This will set the pace. You can be sure of it," he said.

HEADLINE: Nationsbank Posts Loss After Merger

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Nationsbank, the new name for the country's fourth-largest banking company, created by the year-end merger of the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and the C&S/Sovran Corporation of Atlanta, said it had a $243.8 million loss in the fourth quarter and a profit of $201.8 million, or 76 cents a share, for all of 1991. The loss, the bank said, was a result of its previously announced plans to lump various merger expenses into the final quarter of last year.
Nationsbank also said it expected to cut costs by $450 million annually as a result of a closer study of the merger plans, rather than $350 million as it had previously forecast. The bank first, however, had to charge off $314 million of expenses in the fourth quarter for costs that included closing offices, combining computer systems and making severance payments to employees. 
 Earnings were further reduced as the company added $525 million to its reserve for loan losses, up from $430 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30. Most of the reserves were needed for loans at C&S/Sovran, which was badly hurt by real estate projects in the Washington area.
The fourth-quarter loss compared with a profit a year earlier of $38.3 million, or 13 cents a share. For the full year profits were down 66 percent from $594.7 million, or $2.61 a share, in 1990.
Despite the increase in reserves for loan losses, John Mason, a banking analyst at the Interstate/Johnson Lane Corporation, in Charlotte, said that problems with bad loans were declining.
 
Cleaning Up Problems
 "It looks," he added, "as if they are cleaning up the old mess, and not strugglihg with newly emerging problems."
He noted that the total of loans 90 days delinquent, plus other loans not expected to be repaid in full and holdings of real estate acquired through foreclosure, was slightly less than $3.03 billion at the end of the year. That was up only about $61.4 million from Sept. 30 and was by far the smallest quarterly increase of the year.
Nationsbank's loss for the fourth quarter would have been even greater but for a profit of $222.2 million from its investment portfolio, where declining interest rates caused bond prices to rise. Because loan demand from Texas has not been enough to absorb all the deposits generated in that state, Nationsbank has accumulated $24.9 billion in its investment portfolio in the last few years that is the largest of any bank in the country. Profits on those investments, which the company reports in its income only when it sells securities, totaled $453.5 million last year.
Analysts expect additional profits from the investment portfolio this year, since the portfolio's market value at Dec. 31 was $915 million greater than the value shown on the company's books.
As Nationsbank reduces its investment portfolio and increases its consumer lending to its goal of 50 percent of all loans, from 39 percent at the end of last year, analysts expect profits to increase because the consumer loans pay interest rates of well over 10 percent, or several percentage points higher than yields on its note and bond investments.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Yen In Light Trading on Holiday

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen and was narrowly lower against other currencies in light holiday trading.
Gold prices closed higher. Gold rose $3.80 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $357.80 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357.50, up $3.50. 
 Analysts said the dollar remained vulnerable against the yen after Friday's intervention by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan. The two central banks sold dollars to push the dollar lower against the yen.
Traders are "not in any big hurry to test the central banks' resolve after the big selloff Friday," said Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst with MMS International.
The dollar fell to 123.25 Japanese yen in New York yesterday from 124.55 late Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 4 yen, to 123.95 yen, and in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 123.70 yen.
Trading was very light as big banks were closed and other traders took the day off for the holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Mr. Faust said the market was expected to remain quiet for the rest of the week in the absence of any new economic statistics and in advance of a meeting next weekend of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
The British pound gained against the dollar yesterday, rising to $1.7980 in New York from $1.7955 on Friday. In earlier London trading, the pound rose to $1.7905 from $1.7780.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.59155 German marks, down from 1.5920; 1.4095 Swiss francs, down from 1.4085; 5.4275 French francs, unchanged; 1,198.50 Italian lire, down from 1,199.25, and 1.14955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15025.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $358.85, from $356.30 late Friday. In Zurich, it rose to $358.30 an ounce from $355.55.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.62 an ounce to close at $355.78
Silver lost 1.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange and closed at $4.257 a troy ounce. Silver also fell in London to a late bid of $4.28, from $4.30 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Efforts to Reduce Retiree Costs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
PUSHED by a new accounting rule, most large employers are examining ways to reduce the enormous future costs of medical benefits they have promised to retirees. Benefits consultants say some executives view the benefits as a "gratuity" rather than a permanent obligation, when they are not detailed in an employment contract. But most employers say they are committed to continuing the programs, albeit often with reduced benefits, despite rapid growth in both medical costs and the numbers of retirees.
Under an accounting rule that takes effect in 1993, corporations with at least 500 employees must calculate future retiree medical obligations and charge off the costs against income -- either all at once, or spread over 20 years. The rule does not require setting aside cash for the future costs. 
 Michael J. Gulotta, president of Actuarial Sciences, a consulting unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that employees' concerns about their economic security would push some companies to set up tax-deductible funds dedicated to future retiree costs. Trust funds negotiated with unions qualify for special tax breaks.
After discussions last year with its unions, A.T.& T. invested $361 million for retiree medical benefits in two voluntary employee benefit accounts. One is for union members, the other for nonunion people. The telephone company said it expected its accumulated liabilities for future retiree health benefits to be $5.5 billion to $7.5 billion, after payment of taxes.
The retiree accounts are much less attractive for businesses with fewer union employees. A recent survey of 1,200 employers that offer retiree health benefits, by the A. Foster Higgins consulting firm, found that only 8 percent were "prefunding" the benefits and 3 percent were setting aside some funds. The vast majority, 89 percent, were spending only for current medical expenses of retirees.
The Central Telephone Company, a unit of the Centel Corporation in Chicago, has not established a retiree medical account, said Steve Bailor, Central's vice president and controller. It reports the future expenses in its annual reports, he said, but it uses the money "for general business purposes."
Some utilities are asking state regulators for rate increases based on the expenses, whether or not money is being set aside. Florida granted such a request by Centel's Florida unit. But officials in California and a number of other states said that such increases would have to be based on money set aside by utilities in their states.
In view of the meager tax advantages in retiree benefit trust accounts for management and other nonunion employees, Mr. Gulotta at Actuarial Sciences said that a number of employers were considering setting up trusts that would buy life insurance for employees. The up-front expense would be considerable but the insurance could grow with tax-free interest, reducing a company's liability under the new accounting rule.
Companies that have invested in employee benefit funds "today will have less of a burden in the future than those who have not," Mr. Gulotta said.
But Judith F. Mazo, a senior vice president in Washington with the Segal Company consulting firm, said that many employers were reluctant to invest in the funds because of uncertainty about future changes in the nation's health system that could make the issue moot.
Some unions have similar qualms, said Meredith Miller, assistant director of employee benefits with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "They have been resisting the idea of prefunding," she said, "because they did not want to break apart the retirees from the major plan" -- risking dividing their members over benefits. "They are pushing for national health care," Ms. Mazo said.
Patricia Wilson, a principal with A. Foster Higgins, said: "Many employers still maintain that benefits are gratuities rather than contractual obligations. I think they're right." Even so, she added, employers were not canceling promises.
"They need to satisfy the needs of retirees, whether they fund through pensions or a medical plan," she said. "If they cut back on retiree benefits, they may be forced to increase wages or contributions to a 401(k)" employee savings plan.
FHP Inc., a health maintenance organization based in Fountain Valley, Calif., is taking a different approach with the help of Federal money for the elderly. H.M.O.'s can get 95 percent of the usual Medicare costs per patient.
"We can relieve the companies of all or a preponderance of liability under the accounting rule," said Wescott W. Price 3d, FHP's president. Medicare members got basic coverage and free prescription drugs, he added.
FHP said companies like Chevron, B. F. Goodrich, Northrop, Rockwell International and TRW were offering the plan to retirees. Dan Heslin, director of employee benefit programs at Rockwell, said his company encouraged retirees to join H.M.O.'s by adding dental and vision services that Medicare would not cover. But he said the program appealed mainly to longstanding H.M.O. members who lived near an H.M.O.'s doctors.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Up a Bit Abroad

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved a bit higher in overseas trading yesterday.
There was no activity in cash fixed-income markets in the United States in observance of the holiday for the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Futures markets in Chicago were open, but they closed early because of the holiday. 
 Analysts said the modest price improvement abroad was probably a delayed reaction to the results of the University of Michigan's midmonth reading on consumer confidence, released on Friday.
 
Surprise in Confidence Report
 Traders had been speculating that confidence surged in mid-January in response to the Federal Reserve Board's aggressive cuts in interest rates on Dec. 20.
In fact, the survey showed that confidence fell a bit further during the first two weeks of the month. The results prompted traders in the United States to bid up securities prices on Friday.
Remarks by a Fed governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., had no impact on trading yesterday but may be an influence today.
In a speech before a Florida business group, Mr. Kelley said the United States must accept undesirably slow economic growth while the excesses of the 1980's are worked off.
In recent weeks, concerns have mounted among credit market participants that the recent declines in interest rates engineered by the Fed will generate a recovery that is more than mild.
 
30-Year Bond at 104 29/32
 At the close of trading in Europe, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds were offered at a price of 10429/32 , up 11/32 , to yield 7.58 percent, compared with 7.60 percent late Friday.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, the nearby March Treasury bond contract rose by 3/8 point, to 103.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 1037/32 , up10/32 , to yield 7.03 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, up 2/32 , to yield 4.93 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.76 percent, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at 3.87 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.94 percent.
Because of the holiday, the Treasury did not hold its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday. The auctions will be held today.

HEADLINE: Paris Showcase of Ukrainian Performing Arts

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In his film "Meeting Venus," the Hungarian director Istvan Szabo used a Paris production of Wagner's "Tannhauser" as a metaphor for the quarreling cacophony of the new Europe. "Ukraine in Paris," a five-month showcase of the performing arts from that newly independent country, which began here on Friday night, seems a kind of real-life echo of Mr. Szabo's film, exposing the mixture of privation and pride, confusion and purpose that defines the Ukrainian intelligentsia in these unsure times.
The showcase, planned before independence but given a new weight by it, will consist of two opera productions this month by the Kiev Opera, several ballet programs by the Opera Ballet in February, performances by the National Ballet of Ukraine in March and April and by the Kiev branch of the Red Army Chorus (billed on some posters as the Ex-Red Army Chorus) in May. 
 Friday's opening performance of Mussorgsky's "Khovanshchina" in the cavernous Palais des Congres -- at 3,800 seats it is nearly three times the size of the company's home theater -- was remarkably assured. It was old-fashioned, but it was also more stylistically secure and vocally consistent than what was heard from the Bolshoi Opera of Moscow in New York last summer. This success was all the more remarkable given the comic-opera chaos that attended the arrival of the Kiev ensemble.
Their charter flight was delayed a day. Their buses arrived an hour late at the airport. They had to wait two hours in their hotel lobby for their room keys. Most of them straggled into the theater only a couple of hours before their first performance, exhausted and bereft of proper stage rehearsal.
"We are artists," complained Anatoly Mokrenko, a former singer and Ukrainian nationalist writer who was named company director in November. "For me, it is difficult to grasp the situation. We need our rest."
Irina Molostova, a longtime Kiev stage director born and trained in Moscow, was more adamant. "Can you imagine the courage of our artists?" she asked just before the opening-night performance. "You might ask, 'How do these people, who have nothing to eat, who have so many difficulties, sing so beautifully?' "
It was a good question. The operas -- the other is Tchaikovsky's "Mazeppa," which receives its first performance on Tuesday night -- are being given with alternating casts. The singers heard on Friday would have done honor to any operatic ensemble in the world, although their vocal amplitude was difficult to gauge in the quirky acoustics and subtle yet distinct amplification of the Palais des Congres.
Like so many Slavic troupes, the Kiev Opera seems particularly strong in male voices, with solidly sonorous performances by Valentin Pivovarov as Ivan Khovansky, Nikolai Chopcha as Dosifei and Aleksandr Vostriakov as Golitsin. Equally impressive was the choral singing, with more than 100 colorfully attired soldiers of various allegiances, Old Believers, peasants and townsfolk filling the stage with sight and sound.
 
Realistic Conventions
 Miss Molostova's production, unlike the Bolshoi's timid and erratic attempts at modernization, stuck securely within realistic conventions. The company used Shostakovich's orchestration, as does the Metropolitan Opera, although some 45 minutes of music were shorn (at least for Paris). No doubt the production was considered snappily up-to-date when it was new in 1963, but now it looks comfortably ensconced in tradition.
"Unlike Western theaters," Miss Molostova said with a distinct touch of disapproval, "we don't change productions every one or two seasons. Our style depends on the composer. With Mussorgsky, we are traditionalist, because what is important is the period of the opera, the 17th century. To my mind, though, 'Khovanshchina' is a modern opera, from the point of view of its ideas. It's like Gorbachev and Yeltsin: everybody's grabbing for power, and the people lose their heads."
It might seem odd that a showcase of Ukrainian culture would open with two operas by Russian composers, even if "Mazeppa" is being sung in Ukrainian and concerns, at least ostensibly, a 17th-century Ukrainian hero (Tchaikovsky chose to emphasize a fictional love story over politics). According to Miss Molostova and Mr. Mokrenko, however, the reason for this repertory is simple: musical superiority.
"Tchaikovsky and Mussorgsky are classics; they belong to the whole world," said Miss Molostova, who like Mr. Mokrenko spoke in Russian through an interpreter. "There are Ukrainian operas, but our national opera had a later and more difficult development than Russian opera. When our theater was founded in 1867, we could not sing or compose in Ukrainian. The Urkrainian language was not permitted until 1926. Now, the company sings most Russian operas in Russian and all the rest in Ukrainian."
 
The New and the Classic
 Mr. Mokrenko, who wears a lapel pin of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag, said that a systematic policy of Russianization persisted in all aspects of Ukrainian culture well after 1926. He said that the company now included about 4 Ukrainian operas in its annual repertory of 30 works, and that he hoped to gradually increase that number without abandoning the classics, Russian and otherwise.
"We have to test the Ukrainian operas that have been written to know what we already have, and encourage new ones," he said. "Until now, Ukrainian composers have had no motivation, because what they wrote wasn't produced. We have to develop the creativity of our composers."
Mr. Mokrenko's optimism comes at a time in which major artistic institutions of the former Soviet Union face a cloudy future. The Kiev Opera and Ballet employ a total of 1,200 people, nearly half of them vocal soloists, chorus singers, ballet dancers, orchestra members and artistic stage personnel of one sort or another. So far, relatively few of the star singers have defected to the West -- Miss Molostova says that's because they are more patriotic than their Bolshoi peers -- which contributes to the sense of ensemble closeness heard and seen on Friday.
 
Inflation a Problem
 Although the new Ukrainian Parliament has pledged to increase the theater's subsidy in real economic terms, inflation has confounded long-range planning. "Already, before this trip to Paris, we had to raise salaries twice," Miss Molostova said. The annual budget has increased 10-fold in 10 years, from 1.2 million rubles to 12 million, nearly all of which reflects inflation. "The situation is so unstable, we can't even speak of figures and percentages," she went on.
Dmitri Gnatuk, a former star baritone with the company and now stage director of its new "Mazeppa" (the production was first seen last year), said: "Three months ago the top ticket price was three rubles. Now it's seven rubles. Fortunately, the audiences have held pretty steady."
"Still, I am sure that with independence we will live much, much better," added Mr. Gnatuk, who is a native Ukrainian and worldwide exponent of Ukrainian folk songs. "Not only the Ukrainians but all the nationalities that live in Ukraine." He smiled at the Russian-born Miss Molostova. "Even the Russians will live better than the Russians in Russia."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Perils Of Life in Minneapolis

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
THEY have signs on some of the larger streets here that inform drivers that these are "Snow Emergency Routes." The signs draw a glance from the Super Bowl crowd beginning to stream in for next Sunday's game. The signs in fact are not taken down even in summer. I remember asking someone about this when I moved here in 1965. "Remove them?" she said. "For three days?"
This was kind of a joke, but you never know when it's going to snow in Minneapolis. Last Halloween, just a couple of days after the World Series here, 28 inches fell. So the people are prepared: like the hotel doorman who greets you in a raccoon hat and a raccoon coat; like those residents who sought to make the snowplow the offical pace car for the Super Bowl. 
 While the weather can be brutal, the locals still laugh. Ha. Ha. This is not new, either; the Sioux, the original tenants of the land here, named one of their landmarks Minnehaha Falls, "Minnehaha" meaning Laughing Waters.
I lived here for two years, working at The Minneapolis Tribune, and I liked this town very much. It is as clean as a declarative sentence, as easy to move around in as one of those great old houses on Lake of the Isles, or on Summit Avenue in St. Paul, and the landscape around the Twin Cities is often beautiful. I've never again seen the changing of the leaves in fall as gorgeous as it was along the banks of the Mississippi here. Not even in Hancock, N.H.
They have their problems here, though, like any big city, from a fall in the economy to a rise in crime. "You heard of the Rolex girls?" I was asked. "They were women in bars who met visiting businessmen who wore Rolex watches and other jewelry. They went up to the men's rooms, drugged and robbed them. Now, everyone knows these things can happen. But people here were amazed because it happened in Minneapolis."
And the town has had its growth -- skyscrapers and skyways and malls exist where none did before -- but nearly 25 years after I left here for Gotham, much of it seems unchanged.
I have even been invited to go ice fishing.
I remember the first such invitation many years ago. I was told about this quaint local custom, in which people either sit outside, mufflered like mummies, and peer down a hole, or they erect wood and tin shacks as soon as the lakes freeze over. People in those houses bring in furniture and heaters and televisions and schnapps, carve holes in the ice of the living-room floor and fish.
I thought I'd try it. "We'll go to White Bear Lake," my host said. "It's pretty safe there."
"Safe?" I said. "You mean some aren't safe?" "Well," he said, "some guys rush the season, or there's a weak spot in the ice. And sometimes people driving their trucks or cars on the lake go down in it. Houses float away sometimes, too."
"In other words," I said, "people drown while ice fishing."
"Happens all the time," he said.
I didn't make it ice fishing that weekend and attended something else. I don't remember what, probably a snowball fight.
The Super Bowl is going to be played in the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, home of football's Vikings and baseball's Twins. But I covered those teams in the old Metropolitan Stadium, an outdooor ball yard that had the feel of a cozy, minor league park, and was terrific. I saw Fran Tarkenton running for his life on numerous occasions on frozen fields, and I saw a rookie with an eye-catching swing stroke one of his first hits in the major leagues, a pinch-hit single to win a game in the ninth inning. Rod Carew went on to get some 3,000 more hits, and a bronze plaque in the Hall of Fame.
Carew enjoyed Minneapolis, and fell in love in Minneapolis, marrying Marilyn Levy. But I also remember another side of life here for him. He was infuriated when police officers would stop him while he was jogging, figuring, he said, that if a black man was running, he must be running from something.
I once saw the namesake of the Metrodome at a University of Minnesota football game -- the school is in Minneapolis, and he was class of '39. In the closing minutes of the game at Memorial Stadium, with the Gophers losing by an insurmountable margin to Kansas, Vice President Humphrey saw that his companion, Gov. Karl Rolvaag, was rising to go. Humphrey gently put his hand on the Governor's arm to keep him in his seat. "If the old ship goes down," Humphrey said, "we go with her."
Minnesotans can be that hardy, that loyal, that dreamy. Meanwhile, I still haven't gone ice fishing. Maybe one day. First, though, I've got to work on my breaststroke.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Six Mind Benders

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Now that we have been told everything we always wanted to know about sex but were afraid to ask, could somebody please tell us the answers to some other questions we've been afraid to ask because the answers are probably so obvious that asking the questions would make us look stupid?
Question 1: Why does the United States have to import paper clips from Taiwan? Cars from Japan are one thing. Making a car may take a lot of good old Japanese know-how, which may be beyond Americans at the moment. But paper clips? 
 You mean to say Americans are too dumb to bend a flimsy little piece of metal three times, then put it in a flimsy cardboard box with a lot of other flimsy little bent pieces of metal, and send the boxes to the local stationery store?
You mean to say it's cheaper to bend this metal in Taiwan, then ship it all the way across the Pacific, then all over the continental U.S., than it is to make them down by the gas works and have them delivered around town by kids on bicycles?
Obviously that's exactly what you mean to say, or every paper clip in this house would not be made on the other side of the world. Is it dumb to ask what's wrong here anyhow?
Question 2: Speaking of Japanese car know-how, why do President Bush and the Detroit auto big shots go to such pains to make Americans look like whiners by trying to make the Japanese buy more American cars?
Are we wrong in thinking the problem is not that the Japanese aren't buying enough American cars, but that the Americans aren't buying enough American cars? Wouldn't it make more sense, and help us keep our dignity, for the President and Detroit big shots to persuade Americans to buy more American cars?
Question 3: Speaking of Detroit, doesn't the political campaign to put tougher trade restrictions on Japanese car imports amount to the same thing as trying to give Detroit a government handout?
Why is it that when government takes care of large industries its tenderness is called "tougher trade policy" instead of "welfare"? If New Jersey has a good idea in cutting off added welfare payments to mothers who don't stop having babies, isn't it an equally good idea, if the government starts subsidizing the auto industry, to cut the subsidy every time car tycoons conclude a losing year by giving themselves a pay raise?
Question 4: Speaking of New Jersey, why did the Republicans there scream when the outgoing Democratic Legislature proposed repealing Governor Florio's tax package?
Didn't the new Republican Legislature get itself elected by sympathizing loudly with the public's hatred for the cruel, brutal, unfair, beastly, not to say monstrous taxes enacted by the Florio Democrats? Shouldn't the Republicans, then, have supported the outgoing Legislature's attempt to rid New Jersey of this burden?
Can it be that New Jersey Republicans secretly believe tax revenue, especially when provided by brutal Democratic governance, is actually wonderful stuff for politicians to have at their disposal, especially when the rascals who provided it have been tossed over the side?
But why are there no outraged-taxpayer demonstrations against the Republicans for refusing to support repeal of the punitive Florio taxes? Is it because American voters are more hardened to being conned by Republican than Democratic governments, hence more stoical about it when betrayed by the G.O.P.?
Question 5: Why does the stock market reach record heights at the very moment the President of the United States declares the national economy is in a "free fall"? Does this mean that what's bad for the average American is terrific for Wall Street? And does it work the other way around? Would the economy snap out of the present slump if only the stock market would collapse?
Honestly, now, is there any difference between playing the stock market and taking your bankroll down to the big casino on the Jersey shore?
Question 6: Why do serious people keep saying Dan Quayle is "not as bad as he's made out to be"? The question isn't what degree of badness Quayle measures out at. Most of us probably aren't as bad as a lot of people think we are, but does that put us among the top 500 people most qualified to be President?
Why doesn't anybody ever say, "Dan Quayle would make a great President"?

HEADLINE: Prague Has to Drive Fast in Economic Mud;
Lustration Is Necessary

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Perils of 'Lustration' " (editorial, Jan. 7), criticizing the lustration process in Czechoslovakia where former Communist Party officials are banned from employment in high posts for five years, misreads the situation in my country. You have assumed a stable country with a normal market economy, but neither of these conditions hold.
At all levels and in all sectors of society, former members of the Communist Party are employed, many of whom acted as agents of the notorious secret police. In the current situation in Czechoslovakia, where the economy is dominated by state enterprises, they have enormous power. 
 During the transformation from Communism to a democratic system, when former social structures are being replaced by new institutions, these people have used their positions and the information they have been privy to for so many years for two purposes: to enrich themselves and to maintain their dominance as long as possible. They know that in a democratic, market system, they will have fewer occasions for their extralegal activities and that positions of responsibility will be filled on the basis of competency, not membership in the Communist Party. Clearly they have no interest in assisting the transformation process.
Germany after World War II experienced a salutary denazification process, and so it is necessary for Czechoslovakia to undergo a process of decommunization. Lustration is merely an instrument to accelerate this process. By no means is the law ideal. But it should be noted that the "five-year ban on employment" applies only to high-level functions in government and top management of state-owned enterprises and it applies only to officials of the former Communist Party above a particular level.
If America had experienced the ravages of a Communism that for 40 years ruined our economy, demoralized us and consigned an entire generation to emptiness, perhaps you would be more understanding of our need for lustration.
 
PAVEL SOLC
Swarthmore, Pa., Jan. 8, 1992

HEADLINE: AID TO EX-SOVIETS IS BEING HINDERED

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Two months after Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan announced a $165 million program to send free American food to what was then the Soviet Union, no food has been delivered and only one contract, worth $15 million, has been awarded.
And that contract, providing for deliveries of mostly butter to Armenia, will not be carried out until Feb. 20 because shipping companies refused to lease refrigerated air-freight containers for fear they would be stolen, said the Rev. Yeznig Balian, who is supervising the delivery for the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America, which is based in New York. 
 As diplomats from four dozen nations and seven multilateral institutions prepare for meetings in Washington on Wednesday and Thursday to coordinate assistance to the former Soviet republics, aid programs remain bogged down by Western red tape and Soviet corruption.
 
Theft There, Ultracaution Here
 The disappearance of German food parcels from St. Petersburg docks, the availability of Dutch ground meat on the Russian black market and the rejection of free British beef by Moscow authorities with possible links to hoarders have made headlines in the West.
The invisible twin of the problem there is caution verging on paralysis among Western aid officials, who lack the staff to supervise large-scale deliveries and find private voluntary organizations overwhelmed by the task.
The result is that while many Western and Russian experts warn that shortages could provoke the overthrow of the democratic governments in the former Soviet republics, any major Western assistance organized at the conference is unlikely to arrive soon.
Frustration is also causing American and German officials to speak seriously of sending humanitarian supplies with forces from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which will be represented at the conference.
 
Pace Is Slowing, Not Quickening
 The European Community has delivered barely half of the $300 million in food grants it pledged 13 months ago, said a senior community official who insisted on anonymity. None of the $600 million in food credits announced then has been disbursed and almost none of a recent $250 million package of grants, he added.
Japan has pledged $600 million in aid and credits but has only just begun deliveries after several months of worrying about who would repay the loans.
When Mr. Madigan announced the $165 million in food grants along with $1.25 billion in food credits on Nov. 18, the Agriculture Department had already been negotiating for a month or more with nonprofit groups.
But the need to insure that these groups have realistic distribution plans, guarding against spoilage and corruption, has kept a half-dozen contracts from receiving final approval, said Roger D. Runningen, a spokesman for the department.
 
A Warning from the Embassy
 The delays have produced irritation at the highest levels of the American Embassy in Moscow, Administration officials said.
The embassy has repeatedly warned the State Department that food must be shipped more quickly, and is considering a plan to begin selling some food to Russian officials to reduce the embarrassment of giving food away and then having it show up in markets anyway, the officials said.
The food delivery issues will be taken up by a special committee at the conference this week, led by Canada, Britain and Germany.
And for those who want to flee the uncertainties of the new economics in the new republics, Foreign Minister Guido di Tella of Argentina said in an interview published today that his country would be willing to accept up to 100,000 immigrants from the Russian minorities in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, Reuters reported.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 23, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about food aid to the former Soviet republics omitted an American contract, because of incorrect information provided by the Agriculture Department. The department awarded a $1.2 million contract last week to the Brother's Brother Foundation in Pittsburgh.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1349 words

HEADLINE: Economy Likely To Revive Soon, Congress Is Told

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
At the start of a Presidential election year in which the economy is a central issue, the Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the economy would begin a weak recovery by the middle of 1992 and warned lawmakers not to endanger the recovery by resorting to radical changes in economic policy before the November election.
In a report to Congress, the budget office said the recession was likely to end within six months. But it offered no guidance as to whether Mr. Bush and Congress would be able to withstand the mounting political pressure for steps to stimulate the economy. 
 The pressure from that side of the budget debate was raised a notch today when a group of conservative Republican members ofCongress said at a luncheon at the White House that that they favored a strong economic growth program, including deeper cuts in capital gains taxes than the Administration has been planning.
 
Bad News on Joblessness
 The legislators implied that they might introduce their own tax cut proposals if the President's plan failed to satisfy them but stopped short of threatening to do so, said Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack F. Kemp, who attended the meeting.
The Congressional report also included some bad news for Mr. Bush with its prediction that unemployment would average about 7 percent this year, despite the modest economic growth foreseen for the last two quarters of 1992.
Unemployment is the most politically sensitive economic issue in a Presidential election year. White House advisers have been debating how vigorously to attack unemployment and the low growth rate as a means of reversing the decline in Mr. Bush's popularity and combating the assertion from his rivals that he lacks concern for people of average income.
In the report, the nonpartisan budget office said that the recession had made "further deficit reduction inadvisable this year" but that "the deficit should return to the top of the political agenda in 1993," because huge deficits cripple economic growth.
In an interview tonight, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the budget office, said that if recovery was jeopardized with significant further deficit reduction, "it would only add to the national debt and leave us in a deeper hole from which to climb out."
 
High Unemployment
 Mr. Reischauer is scheduled to present his conclusions on Wednesday at a hearing of the Senate Budget Committee.
The report said Federal spending would account for nearly 25 percent of the gross national product this year, the highest share since World War II, as the Federal budget deficit soared to a record of $352 billion. It also predicted a growing gap between Federal spending and revenue, which it expected to account for slightly less than 19 percent of the gross national product.
The budget office predicted that the nation would begin to pull out of the recession in the second half of this year but that the economy would grow only 2.8 percent between the final quarters of 1991 and 1992.
"This lukewarm performance will only gradually reduce the hardships that the recession has brought to many parts of the country," it said. "The unemployment rate will remain high for some time, averaging close to 7 percent in 1992."
The nation's unemployment rate climbed to 7.1 percent in December 1991, the highest in five and one-half years. Nearly eight million people were out of work.
In the interview, Mr. Reischauer said: "The economy is basically dead in the water at this point. We expect it to strengthen over the course of the spring, in large measure because of the easing of monetary policy that occurred in the last half of 1991."
 
Difference in Forecasts
 The budget office's forecast of economic growth is slightly above that of private economists. The White House forecast will be in the President's budget proposal later this month.
Last year at this time, the budget office was estimating that the 1992 deficit would be $298 billion. And Mr. Bush was projecting a 1992 deficit of $281 billion.
In its new report, the budget office said, "The deficit outlook is far bleaker than was expected when Congress and the President reached their budget summit agreement in the fall of 1990." But it asserted that "the budget would be in a much deeper hole" without that agreement.
The budget deficit was $269 billion, or 4.8 percent of the gross national product, in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, 1991. The $352 billion deficit projected for the current fiscal year would amount to 6 percent of the G.N.P., just shy of the post-World War II high of 6.3 percent in 1983.
For politicians, public officials and lobbyists, the report means that the battle over the Federal budget will probably be more difficult than usual this year, as the desire to stimulate economic growth comes into conflict with the need to control the deficit.
At the White House luncheon today, the Republican lawmakers criticized Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady for not pursuing a bolder economic policy, according to The Washington Post, which first reported the meeting in its early edition of Wednesday's issue.
The lawmakers, including Senator Connie Mack of Florida and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Minority Whip, were invited to the luncheon by Samuel K. Skinner, the chief of staff, and Robert M. Teeter, the chairman of Mr. Bush's re-election campaign. Mr. Skinner, who has been portrayed as seeking to wrest policy-making power at the White House from Mr. Darman, has has been talking to Republican members of Congress for the last 10 days about the President's plans, and today's lunch gave them a chance to respond, one participant said.
 
High Debt Growth Expected
 In his report, Mr. Reischauer reviewed many proposals to stimulate the economy through various combinations of tax and spending programs known as fiscal policy. But the report concluded that "no changes in fiscal policy can provide major stimulus to the economy unless they increase the budget deficit."
The budget office foresaw explosive growth in the Federal debt -- the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing -- and rapid growth in the interest that must be paid on it. Interest payments will continue rising despite the recent decline in short-term interest rates, the report said.
The ratio of the Federal debt to gross national product will reach 52 percent this year, it said, a level not seen since the mid-1950's, when the Government still owed huge amounts from World War II. The budget office said this ratio, which measures the Federal debt in relation to the size of the nation's economy, would reach nearly 55 percent in 1994 and 1995.
Interest payments on the Federal debt will be "the third-largest category of spending in the budget" this year, after Social Security and military spending, the report said.
"Debt held by the public is projected to grow from $2.7 trillion at the end of 1991 to $4.2 trillion in 1997 as the Government runs $1.5 trillion in deficits over the six-year period," it said.
The budget office, created in 1974, strives to be nonpartisan, works for both Democrats and Republicans and does not endorse specific legislative proposals.
The report laid out criteria for evaluating proposals to combat the recession. "The most effective fiscal policy actions are those that can be applied quickly, stimulate the economy rapidly rather than gradually and encourage spending rather than saving," it said.
The budget office said several measures might satisfy these criteria and stimulate the economy "with perhaps only minimal adverse long-term effects." They include personal tax rebates on 1991 tax liabilities, temporary tax credits for additional business investment in plants and equipment, and a temporary increase in Federal aid to state and local governments.
The President is known to be considering the investment tax credit and some type of tax cut for families, but he has not signaled any interest in additional grants to local governments.

HEADLINE: SPENDING CUTBACKS OUTLINED BY CUOMO TO BALANCE BUDGET

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, rebuffed in bids to forge a long-term solution to New York State's chronic fiscal ills, presented the Legislature today with a more traditional approach that would pare spending on nearly all local-aid and state programs in his 1992-93 state budget.
He pleaded with lawmakers to pass the budget by April 1, the statutory deadline that he and they have failed to meet in each of the last seven years. 
 The Governor's $30.2 billion spending plan, unveiled in a somber presentation in the State Capitol, would in general provide New York City and other local governments and school districts with slightly less in state aid than they received this year, further squeezing their budgets even as their costs and the demands for services during the recession continue to rise.
 
Impact on Dinkins Budget
 In New York City, officials said the Cuomo plan would add $300 million to $350 million to the $1.6 billion potential gap in the $29 billion budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins is to present next week. Aides to the Governor vigorously disputed the number, saying relief from some state mandates and Medicaid programs would make the overall impact roughly a wash.
Although Mr. Cuomo said his budget officials had come up with a balanced plan, he acknowledged that they had done so based on a variety of Federal and state projections that the economy would rebound slightly by the fall. This, if true, would raise some tax revenues and lower spending on social-service programs for the poor. Similarly optimistic projections built into last year's plan proved incorrect, causing a major shortfall to develop.
 
Tax Cuts Deferred
 The spending plan outlined today does not include any tax increases, but it does for the third year in a row defer hundreds of millions of dollars in tax cuts -- an average of a little more than $100 per taxpayer -- passed in the flush fiscal times of the mid-1980's. A planned reduction in the 15 percent surcharge on corporate tax liability would also be put off.
By offering across-the-board cuts but withholding Draconian action against any segment of the budget typically protected by either the Republican-led State Senate or the Democratic-controlled Assembly, Mr. Cuomo was clearly trying to present a conciliatory document that could garner relatively quick agreement here. [News analysis, page B6.]
The Cuomo plan also imposes $127 million in new and higher fees, including an increase from $16 to $20 in the cost of a four-year driver's license and a roughly $1-a-year surcharge on all telephone bills to help finance emergency medical services.
The across-the-board approach, of course, is no guarantee of success. The Governor and lawmakers have been feuding for months over the contours of the budget, and Mr. Cuomo today repeated accusations that the Senate had deliberately walked away from an all-but-agreed-to deal earlier this month.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, L.I., seemed to leave himself maximum flexibility in his response to Mr. Cuomo's plan.
He said the Governor "falls short in his approach to trim welfare and Medicaid costs," but added that he was encouraged that Mr. Cuomo had adopted what he said were several Republican proposals in these areas. Among them were fingerprinting welfare recipients to deter fraud, requiring the poor to make co-payments (50 cents to $3) for some Medicaid services and requiring some younger recipients of benefits from social programs to live with their parents.
 
'A Disgrace'
 Mr. Cuomo warned today that another delay in adopting the budget -- last year's final accord came a record 65 days after the deadline -- could prove "catastrophic" for the state, whose credit rating was lowered earlier this month to the worst of any state except Massachusetts. He said further action by Wall Street, which could be prompted by a late budget, could force some public authorities and school districts to pay exorbitant rates to borrow or could shut them out of the markets.
"The perennial failure to adopt a budget on time is a disgrace," Mr. Cuomo said today. "This year, 'timeliness, timeliness, timeliness' should be the mantra repeated everywhere in the Capitol."
Under the Cuomo plan, the state's "general fund" budget, which accounts for spending derived from nearly all state taxes and fees, would rise by 1.4 percent to $30.25 billion. But factoring in Federal funds for Medicaid, welfare, housing and other areas channeled through the state government, as well as some bonding for capital programs, the state's "all funds" budget would grow by just under 6 percent, to $56.5 billion.
The plan provoked expressions of dismay from dozens of advocacy groups, ranging from hospital organizations and schoolteachers to patrons of the arts. The unhappiness could bode poorly for its chances of approval in the Legislature. But on the other hand, it seemed to lend some credence to Mr. Cuomo's assertion that there were no "sacred cows or sacrificial lambs" in his budget plan.
The Governor's proposal would, in tandem with cuts made in the last year, reduce the state work force to about 160,000 employees from the fall 1990 level of 185,000.
About 6,500 jobs would be eliminated in the coming fiscal year, an action budget officials said would save $233 million and affect nearly every agency, from about 1,500 layoffs at the State Office of Mental Health to a dozen or so each at the much smaller Council on the Arts and the Department of Agriculture and Markets.
Mr. Cuomo said his plan would bridge a potential gap of nearly $5 billion -- $500 million of which comes from borrowing the state will need to undertake because he and legislative leaders failed to agree on filling a hole in the current budget.
 
Medicaid Cutbacks
 Other actions would be savings of about $1 billion in the roughly $5 billion the state had projected to spend on Medicaid in the coming year, derived from a mix in cuts in services and eligibility levels for recipients and higher state assessments on hospitals and nursing homes.
About 2.5 million people are enrolled in the Medicaid program, serving the poor, elderly and disabled.
While today's budget plan can hardly be characterized as an upbeat document, it did include an assumption that there would be somewhat of an upturn in the economy later this year that would increase sales-tax and income-tax collections by 2 to 3 percent over this year.
But Mr. Cuomo, who in the past has ridiculed White House projections of an economic rebound, said he would accept the forecasts for this budget.
Asked at a news conference by a Newsday columnist why he did not use more conservative estimates, given the midyear deficits that have materialized in recent years, the Governor retorted: "Because I'd have to kill your schools on Long Island and you'd crucify me."

HEADLINE: Libya Unyielding Despite U.N. Demand

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Security Council voted unanimously today to demand that Libya turn over for trial the agents accused of blowing up two civilian passenger aircraft and killing 440 people, but Libya indicated no willingness to comply.
The Council's resolution in effect tells Libya to cooperate with the investigation that Britain, France and the United States are conducting into the two bombings by surrendering two Libyans indicted for these acts. Pan Am flight 103 was blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 and U.T.A. flight 772 over Niger, in Africa, a year later.
 
'Satisfaction' Among Families
 
 This is the first time the Security Council has ever demanded the extradition of citizens of one country to stand trial in another or implicitly accused a member government of involvement in terrorism.
Representatives of the families of passengers killed on the Pan Am flight reacted with satisfaction to the vote.
Aphrodite Thevos Tsairis, chairwoman of the Victims of Pan Am Flight 103, who lost her daughter in the crash, spoke of "a tremendous feeling of satisfaction," saying this was the first time a state had been "indicted for state-sponsored terrorism."
But she also described today's resolution as only "the first stepping stone" toward a much stronger resolution imposing economic sanctions on Libya.
If Libya does not comply with the resolution, the United States, Britain and France have said, they will ask the Council to impose mandatory economic sanctions, most probably by cutting off civilian air links and banning the sale of aircraft and spare parts.
 
'False Premises,' Libyan Says
 Addressing the Council before it voted, Libya's Minister for Strategic Industries, Jadallah Azouz el-Talhy, a former Foreign Minister, said the indicted Libyan officials were guiltless because the accusations against them were based on "false premises and assumptions."
Since Britain, France and the United States have asked Libya for information about the bomb attacks but have refused to share the results of their investigations with Libya, Mr. Talhy argued, they lack evidence to support their charges.
Nevertheless, Libya has said that it will investigate and try the officials itself. But Mr. Talhy said Libya's investigation "has not made any progress" because the three countries refuse to share their evidence with Libya.
"How can you condemn Libya for its failure to cooperate after Libya has taken all these actions to cooperate," he asked the Council.
 
A Call for Arbitration
 The Libyan Minister said the Security Council had no right to tell it to extradite its own nationals, adding that the dispute was essentially over interpretation of the 1971 Montreal Convention on terrorism against civilian aircraft and should be resolved by international arbitration. In the past Libya has also offered to send indicted officials for trial by the World Court or some other international tribunal.
The United States, Britain and France all rejected the Libyan Minister's contentions. Speaking for Britain, Sir David Hannay, this month's Council President, said the two officials indicted in the Pan Am 103 disaster should be tried "in Scotland or the United States" since the plane was American but crashed in Scotland.
He reassured countries that ban the extradition of their nationals that the new resolution did not "establish any precedent that would cast doubt on the legitimacy" of such rules. But there could be no confidence in the impartiality of Libyan courts, he said, and no international tribunal has jurisdiction over criminal acts.
 
'Evade Its Responsibilities'
 The United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said Libya had "sought to evade its responsibilities." If further action is needed, "we are convinced the Council is ready on a continuing basis to face up to its responsibilities," he said.
France's deputy representative, Jean-Marc de la Sabliere, said Libya still had not replied satisfactorily to the three countries' demands, but he hoped it would now do so after hearing this "unanimous reaction of the international community."
At the insistence of the Council's six developing world members, the resolution also asks the new United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali of Egypt, to try to persuade the Libyan Government to comply with the new resolution.
What the Secretary General will do remains unclear. But Western diplomats say the Council will now have to give him a reasonable amount of time to intervene with the Libyan authorities before considering sanctions.
 
What Might Happen Next
 At present the United States, Britain and France say that cutting aviation links with Libya appears the most acceptable sanction.
While Libya's principal export is oil, an buyers' embargo is considered unlikely because -- on top of the embargo against Iraq -- it would further disrupt supplies to Western Europe. Germany, Italy and Spain, for example, rely on Libya for between 8 per cent and 15 percent of their supplies.
The unanimous vote on today's resolution was widely seen as a diplomatic triumph for the United States and its allies as well as a further sign of the Council's increasing willingness to intervene in the domestic affairs of countries in the name of promoting democracy, human rights and disarmament.
Several countries, including China and India, usually staunch upholders of the belief the United Nations should not intervene in members' internal affairs, voted for the resolution.
China's representative, Li Daoyu, said his Government condemned all acts of terrorism but still hoped for a negotiated settlement to the dispute.
India's representative, Chinmaya Gharekhan, recalled that India had been the victim of terrorism, including the blowing up of an Air India passenger airliner on its way back from Canada with the loss of some 400 lives.
But he also stressed the importance of respecting national sovereignty, which he said "is widely perceived to have come under some strain recently."

Mr. Talhy said the council had no right to tell it to extradite its own nationals. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Mayor Seeks New Image: From Grandmother to Tough Leader

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Mayor Sophie Masloff was in her elegantly appointed office talking to a reporter when her chief of staff stepped up to her desk and interrupted. "Sophie," he said, "I popped a button off my jacket and I was looking for you to sew it on for me."
The aide, Joseph Sabino Mistick, was poking fun at the image of Pittsburgh's first female Mayor as a soft and nurturing grandmother. It is an image she encouraged at first, often calling herself "an old Jewish grandmother" and saying she wanted to be known as Sophie to everyone in this city of 370,000 people, which has a large elderly population and about 80 ethnic neighborhoods. 
 "My friends all say, 'That's enough of this old Jewish grandmother bit,' " she told reporters in 1988, after being appointed interim Mayor to serve out the term of Mayor Richard S. Caliguiri, who died of a rare blood disease. "But it's a fact: I am a grandmother and a housewife. I can't say I'm a 35-year-old hotshot."
Mrs. Masloff, a Democrat, was elected to a full four-year term the next year. Now the immensely popular 74-year-old Mayor, who faces a projected $35 million deficit in this year's $340 million budget, is trying to shed the grandmotherly image for something closer to that of a hotshot politician.
 
A Tougher Image
 In a recent interview, she talked of having "almost blackmailed" local banks to invest in a housing project by threatening to close city bank accounts. She boasted about lowering the city's wage tax just before her last election, and vowed not to raise taxes this year no matter what happens.
"I am making some very tough decisions," she said, referring to having laid off 120 workers over the past 12 months. She talks of laying off as many as 180 more of the city's 5,000 workers.
But apart from her desire to project herself as a professional politician responding to the recession, Mrs. Masloff acknowledges that the grandmother image has become her Achilles' heel, as it plays into criticism of her management skills from political opponents.
Mrs. Masloff is unquestionably shrewd, but she has had only a high school education and she delegates so much authority to her aides that they automatically reply to many of the substantive questions asked of her in public meetings and in news interviews. She almost always reads prepared statements in public and has been known to write words on her hand to jog her memory.
 
Springsteen or Bedspring?
 Her verbal gaffes and malapropisms are relatively few but often colorful, and they rattle behind her like a string of tin cans. She has, for example, never been able to live down her 1988 reference to Bruce Springsteen as Bruce Bedspring.
Her critics are blunt. "I don't think she knows what's going on," said Tom Flaherty, the city controller, who was a candidate for mayor in the last primary election.
Jim Ferlo, the most vocal of several critics on the nine-member City Council and a likely opponent in next year's primary for mayor, said, "She's absolutely ineffective, a laughingstock." No one has formally announced a candidacy. These critics, like most, are fellow Democrats. Democrats hold every major office in this city, where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by six to one.
Political opponents dwell on what they call her lack of vision for Pittsburgh, which has been extremely successful in diversifying its economy since the death of the steel industry in the early 1980's, but less successful in keeping the new biotechnology and computer companies within the city limits and on the tax rolls. Last year alone four companies, with more than 3,000 jobs, moved just outside the city to industrial parks with more space and lower taxes.
But apart from economic difficulties, Pittsburgh is remarkably free of many big-city problems. Along with many corporate headquarters, it has relatively affordable housing, generally good public schools and its streets are among the safest of any big city in America. And in more than a half-dozen interviews, Mayor Masloff's critics could not point to any major mistake she had made. Her biggest error, it seems, was an ill-conceived, and hastily withdrawn, proposal last year to use city dollars to build a $100 million baseball stadium right next to the 20-year-old Three Rivers Stadium.
Mayor Masloff often dismisses criticism as sex or age discrimination. Conceding that she makes speaking mistakes like anyone else, she also complains that some people misunderstand her sense of humor. "In some situations, where you have to listen to a lot of boring speeches, I can't resist the opportunity to say something silly," said the Mayor, who has a high-pitched, raspy voice. "But some people are not too humorous, and lately, I've come to the place where I limit joking around because it might look like I don't know any better."
Mrs. Masloff is like a popular movie that the critics pan. "Nobody likes Sophie but the people," said Jacques L. Kahn, a local advertising executive.
Mrs. Masloff has not sampled her approval rating lately, but it may well be high, based on the jovial greetings she received on the street the other day. It was "Hi, Sophie!," or "How're you doing, Sophie!" just about everywhere she went.
Wearing a plum dress and a red coat, Mrs. Masloff gave a reporter a whirlwind tour of her favorite places in Pittsburgh. The stops included a stand-up lunch in a fish store, shopping for spice in an Italian market and a visit to the Hill District, just outside the downtown area, where she grew up. Her childhood home, along with several blocks of blighted houses, has been razed to make way for several hundred units of subsidized housing that are now under construction.
Sophie Friedman Masloff was born on Dec. 23, 1917, to Romanian immigrants. Her father, Louis Friedman, an insurance salesman, died in 1920, and her mother, Jennie, worked in a factory rolling cigars and never spoke a word of English. Mrs. Masloff, who lived with two half-sisters and a half-brother from her mother's previous marriage, went to a local high school, now an abandoned building waiting to be recycled.
 
Death of Husband
 She married Jack Masloff, a security guard in a downtown office building, when she was 21. The Masloffs had one child, Linda Busia, who lives in Pittsburgh with her husband, Nicholas, a Conrail track inspector, and their two children, Michael and Jennifer. Mr. Masloff died last June.
Mrs. Masloff says she has always been interested in politics and became a volunteer in the Democratic Party in the late-1930's. She obtained a succession of low-level jobs working for Allegheny County, which includes Pittsburgh, and in the State Court of Common Pleas downtown, where she ultimately became an assistant chief clerk. In 1976, after 40 years of service to the Democratic Party, Mrs. Masloff was nominated and elected to a seat on the City Council. She served there for 12 years, ultimately becoming Council president, and says her major accomplishment was helping bring cable television to Pittsburgh.
In 1988, when Mayor Caliguiri died, Mrs. Masloff automatically became the interim Mayor for one year. The next year, the party did not endorse her candidacy for mayor and she received no endorsements from news organizations, but she won a stunning upset victory over five men in the primary and ran unopposed in the general election.
And Mrs. Masloff, who always did her family's cooking, laundry and cleaning, interrupted her primary campaign every night so that she could go home and fix her husband dinner. "We had an old-fashioned marriage," she said.
