HEADLINE: In Letter, Khrushchev Tells Of Mockery Over Cuba Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Among the most embarrassing aspects of the conclusion of the 1962 missile crisis for Nikita S. Khrushchev was the mockery it exposed him to from China and other Communist countries, according to a document made public today.
In a rambling letter dated Jan. 31, 1963, to Fidel Castro explaining why he had backed down in the face of United States pressure and withdrawn nuclear missiles from Cuba, the Soviet leader complained of "representatives of some Socialist states" who were "distorting," and "criticizing" his actions. 
 The letter was written at a time when relations between Beijing and Moscow were already quite strained, and Khrushchev, who then headed the Soviet Communist Party and Government, foreshadowed the Soviet Union's decisive rupture with China. More than half of it -- 30 pages in Russian and 22 in English translation --is devoted to Chinese criticisms of Soviet policy on Cuba.
 
Critics of Soviet Policy
 The Khrushchev letter is among documents freshly declassified by Cuba and distributed at a news conference here after a meeting about the missile crisis that included American, Soviet and Cuban officials in Havana this month.
Addressed to "Dear Comrade Fidel Castro," the letter noted that "viewpoints did not always coincide" between Khrushchev and the Cuban leader, then Prime Minister.
He then said he wanted to explain his decision "to deploy our ballistic rockets" in Cuba "because even the representatives of some Socialist states are thinking in a rather strange way, distorting not only our initial steps but also those we took later."
Khrushchev went on to assert that those critics of Soviet policy "really didn't do anything to help Cuba when it was faced with mortal danger," later making clear he was talking about China by referring to Chinese Communist attacks on the United States as "a paper tiger, dung."
 
Invitations to Castro
 "Some are now daring to slander us," he continued, "stating that when resolving the conflict in the Caribbean we guided ourselves exclusively by our own egotistical interests. That is the greatest offense against the Soviet people." He said "our men would have fought to the end along with our Cuban brothers," had there been an American invasion.
Evidently Khrushchev was concerned lest Mr. Castro consider abandoning his alliance with the Soviet Union and switching to China. To that end he not only assured Mr. Castro of wishing to "help strengthen the economy" of Cuba, but urged him repeatedly to come to his country for an extended trip in the spring and to hunt and fish.
The Castro Government did flirt with the Chinese Communists then and later, but ultimately committed itself to the Soviet Union.
 
Three Documents Released
 The letter is one of three documents released after a meeting Jan. 8-13 in Havana of officials from the three countries directly involved in the missile crisis 30 years ago, sponsored by the Center for Foreign Policy Development at Brown University.
Another document is the text of a draft treaty on Soviet-Cuban military cooperation that was supposed to have been signed in November 1962, but made obsolete by the withdrawal of Soviet missiles weeks earlier.
The third was the text of a letter from Khruschev to "Comrade Castro" dated Oct. 22, 1962, noting President Kennedy's speech demanding to control the shipment of weapons to Cuba and inspect those already in place.
In it, Khrushchev said, "Because of the situation that has arisen we have instructed the Soviet military representatives stationed in Cuba on the need to take necessary measures and to be at full readiness."
At the Havana conference, Mr. Castro said he interpreted that, wrongly as it turned out, as Soviet willingness to fight for Cuba.

HEADLINE: New Worry for Bush;
Possibility of Supreme Court Decision On Abortion Poses Campaign Risk

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Supreme Court's action today on abortion activates an extraordinarily divisive issue in the 1992 Presidential election and becomes one more worrisome variable for President Bush's re-election campaign.
Since the Supreme Court began restricting abortion rights, most notably in 1989, Democrats have grown increasingly convinced that their support for the constitutional right to choose abortion is a major political plus. 
 Many Republican strategists had hoped to cast their party in 1992 as a "big tent" where all sides could feel at home. But today's action suggests that the conservative Court created by Presidents Reagan and Bush will send a very different message this year.
Most of the major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination were already beginning to attack Mr. Bush for his staunch opposition to legal abortion. Today's Court decision, accepting a Pennsylvania abortion case for review and raising the possibility of overturning or further weakening Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision legalizing abortion, before the election, suggests that the issue could haunt Mr. Bush throughout the general election campaign.
 
Partisan Lines
 The partisan lines could hardly be clearer: All five of the major Democratic candidates will help mark the 19th anniversary of Roe v. Wade Wednesday night at a Washington gathering of the National Abortion Rights Action League. Mr. Bush, who once held a more flexible stand on abortion earlier in his political career, has remained fiercely anti-abortion as President and Vice President.
The political impact of abortion, like every other aspect of the issue, is a matter of dispute. Both sides come armed with voting data that show they have the greater political power and can produce more votes at the polls. What is clear is that Mr. Bush is headed for a squeeze from both sides.
Patrick J. Buchanan, who is challenging Mr. Bush from the right in the Republican primary here, declared today: "I'm pro-life and I think my party should be pro-life. If that loses my party votes, so be it."
At the same time, Frank Greer, an adviser to Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas, gave a taste of the Democratic attack to come. "It's going to be a voting issue," Mr. Greer said. "I believe George Bush has packed the Court and he's going to pay a political price for it. This will push the issue front and center."
Torie Clark, press secretary to the Bush campaign, declined to comment on the potential political fallout. "No comment on hypotheticals," she said.
Both Mr. Bush and his party leaders seemed to recognize that public attitudes were changing on the issue as the Court moved closer to overturning Roe v. Wade. As a result, Mr. Bush has tried to signal that those who disagree with his stance on abortion were nevertheless welcome in the party. But even before today's Court action, Mr. Bush was having trouble managing the issue in his own party and seemed headed for a battle over the Republican platform, which now calls for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion.
The worst case scenario for Mr. Bush, in the view of many Democrats and some of his Republican friends, would involve the High Court overturning Roe at the height of the campaign. That, coupled with the weak economy, could have a significant impact on the younger, suburban voters who are a critical swing vote in many Presidential elections.
The abortion rights issue had seemed to cool since the handful of elections held in 1989, right after the Court handed down Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, which gave states sweeping new powers to restrict abortion. The Virginia and the New Jersey elections for governor that year seemed to turn on the abortion issue, giving major advantages to the Democrats that year. But in 1990, when the economy started to lag and war was looming in the Persian Gulf, the issue no longer seemed as dominant.
There are constant arguments over which side has the greater political clout. Abortion opponents assert that their forces vote, consistently and single-mindedly, on the issue -- in far greater numbers than those who support abortion rights.
Both sides are dug in. And the Supreme Court today may have guaranteed that a new and bruising round of the struggle will be fought in 1992.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles on Verge Of Ending Japanese Pact

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Smoldering American resentment against Japanese economic competition has flared into a political firestorm in California, and Los Angeles County officials appeared today to be on the verge of canceling a $122 million contract they awarded just a month ago to a Japanese company to build rail cars for a new mass transit line here.
Instead, they proposed today to build a new factory to build the cars in Los Angeles County, providing jobs for a region deeply mired in recession and putting the county in direct competition with the Japanese. 
 The action represented a stunning political reversal in the face of bitter public protests that have mounted steadily since Dec. 18, when the 11-member Los Angeles County Transportation Commission awarded the contract for 41 automated rail cars to theSumitomo Corporation of America over a competing bid from the Morrison-Knudson Corporation of Boise, Idaho. Sumitomo had hired as one of its lobbyists the former Republican Governor of California, George Deukmejian.
 
Pressures Building
 The pressures were building as President Bush took a trade mission to Japan earlier this month in an effort to open Japanese markets more to American companies.
The protests culminated on Jan. 13 with a 70-0 vote by the state Assembly urging cancellation of the contract. Bending under crushing political pressure, the executive director of the commission, Neil Peterson, ordered Sumitomo on Friday to halt work on the project immediately. The full commission has scheduled a meeting Wednesday afternoon, at which it is widely expected to officially cancel the Sumitomo contract and reopen bidding.
"We have listened carefully to the concerns expressed by the public and our elected officials," said Ray Grabinski, a Long Beach City Council member who is chairman of the commission and who had originally approved the staff recommendation in favor of Sumitomo as the better qualified bidder. "And we believe this action plan addresses the strong desire to keep the jobs generated by our transportation investment, and specifically rail vehicle procurements."
A spokesman for Sumitomo, Chuck White, said that the company was unable to comment until the commission acted Wendesday. But he said the company was found to be the best bidder and had met or exceeded all requirements with regard to American and local content and in use of subcontractors operated by minorities and women. He added that Sumitomo would employ 370 workers in Los Angeles County for the final assembly of the cars, though the car bodies, systems integration, propulsion and air-conditioning equipment would be made in Japan.
 
30-Year Plan
 The contract was for the Green Line, a 23-mile, 14-station rail line connecting the suburbs of El Segundo, near Los Angeles International Airport, and Norwalk. Scheduled to begin service in 1995, it is part of a $150 billion 30-year plan to build a modern mass transit system, including a subway downtown, to relieve massive congestion on Los Angeles area roadways. Sumitomo built cars for the Blue Line, from Long Beach to Los Angeles, which began operation two years ago.
But the Green Line's approval came in a vastly different economic and political climate. The commission appears to have underestimated the depth of resentment and worry about the faltering economy in Southern California.
"It's amazing; it touched a hot button like nothing has here for a long time," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation, a private group attempting to retain and create jobs in Los Angeles County, which has more than eight million people.
"In the 21 years I've been in office, I've never seen people more angry than about this," said Joel Wachs, a Los Angeles City Council member who has been a outspoken foe of the contract.
 
'Spending Dollars at Home'
 "We're in a recession," he said. "I see a feeling of spend our dollars at home where they do the most good. People are hurting."
In another indication of the growing "buy America" sentiment, Mr. Grabinski called on the legislature in Sacramento today to pass legislation permitting the commission to establish rules requiring 60 percent domestic or local content in future contracts and to grant preference to local businesses.
In preparation of the cancellation, Mr. Grabinski and Mike Antonovich, a county supervisor who will succeed Mr. Grabinski as chairman of the transportation commission this month, called a news conference to present a six-point plan to build what they called an "L.A. Car." If approved by the commission, it would scrap for now the driverless cars preferred by Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles in favor of a manned car similar to those in use on the Blue Line.
Assemblyman Richard Katz, a Democrat from Los Angeles who sponsored the Assembly resolution, has urged that the contract be put out for bids again with a requirement that 75 percent of the work be done in Los Angeles County. That would not be possible now, because there is no factory equipped to produce rail cars in the area. But talk has been growing of converting an automobile plant that General Motors plans to shut this summer in the Van Nuys area of Los Angeles.
 
200 New Jobs
 The rail plant that is envisioned would produce two rail cars a week and create 200 direct jobs at the beginning. The commission estimated that once environmental and other permits are issued, the plant could be in operation within 26 months. The plant would be owned by the county but operated by private companies producing the rail cars, which presumably could also be sold to other cities installing high-speed commuter systems.
If successful, the plant could foreshadow the revival of what was once a thriving American industry in mass transit, long since ceded to the Japanese, Italians and Canadians.

HEADLINE: Grand Forks Journal;
History's About-Face Felt on Plains

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND FORKS, N.D., Jan. 19

 BODY:
For the last quarter of a century, this quiet farming and university town high in the Dakota plains stood sentry at the front gates of the cold war.
Just outside of town, spread over an area the size of New Jersey, underground silos storing 150 long-range nuclear missiles puncture the wheat, potato and sugar beet fields, their deadly tips pointed north toward the former Soviet Union. No one needs reminding that in a nuclear war, Grand Forks would be a bull's-eye at the top of Moscow's hit list. 
 So last summer when President Bush took all nuclear bombers and older long-range nuclear missiles off alert, and the Soviet Union collapsed, people here breathed more easily.
"Most people had a feeling we were living at ground zero," said Mike Jacobs, editor of The Grand Forks Herald. "Now there's a sense there won't be a nuclear war, and we won't be incinerated."
But the President's order did not cover the more modern MX or Minuteman-3 missiles around Grand Forks Air Force Base and three other bases in North Dakota, Montana and Wyoming. Some 2,000 nuclear warheads remain on alert, ready to fire at a moment's notice.
But at whom? For the 50,000 people in this riverfront town 80 miles south of the Canadian border, the question sums up the uncertainty of straddling old world and new.
"We feel less like targets now," said Lorraine Whitty, a 44-year-old native North Dakotan. "But we shouldn't be too hasty. The world is still a very unstable place."
Grand Forks has grudgingly accepted the missile fields since the military installed them 26 years ago. But there have been scary moments. In 1980, a B-52 caught fire at the air base 15 miles from downtown. The Air Force neither confirmed nor denied that the plane was carrying atomic weapons, but people here feared the worst.
In the movie "War Games," the fictional generals realized that a computer hacker had set off a simulated Soviet attack on the United States only after calling Grand Forks to see if the base had been vaporized.
The underground silos and command posts are inconspicuous, especially on a day like today, when light snow and temperatures hovering around 20-below give the site the look of a frozen tundra. Only a chain-link fence enclosing a 110-ton concrete pad hints at the destructive power below. It has been a year or so since protesters picketed a site.
"They don't bother no one," Earl Gunderson, a 70-year-old retired Merchant Marine engineer, said of the missiles. "If war ever did break out, they'd hit cities, too, and everyone would be a target."
The scenes from the underground, though, are Strangelovian. At launch-command center, known as "Charlie Zero," Capt. Mark Turcotte invites a visitor into the vault-like bunker 45 feet beneath the surface and wrapped in a reinforced-concrete egg eight feet thick. Chairs and computer consoles are bolted to a floor that is mounted on shock absorbers to withstand a nuclear "near-miss."
"I'd be crazy not to think what would happen if I were ordered to launch these," said the 28-year-old captain, motioning to a console panel of "alert" lights glowing red. At the bottom of the console is a row of lights marked "missile away."
Elsewhere on the sprawling air base there are signs of change. The "hot strip," a walled-off part of the runway where three or four nuclear-armed B-1B bombers always stood on 24-hour alert, is now deserted.
Peace may exact a price. Residents worry that the thaw in relations with what was the Soviet Union will render the base obsolete. The base, with its 12,000 personnel and dependents, pumps about $212 million into the local economy every year.
"We'd definitely feel the impact," said Debbie Steding, manager of the local Holiday Inn, which relies on the base for at least 10 percent of its customers.
So far, no one is talking about closing the base. But with Minot Air Force Base 210 miles away fielding its own set of Minuteman-3 missiles, many North Dakotans fear that the Pentagon will say that the military does not need both installations.
Some here would applaud. Ron Smith, a 34-year-old firefighter, said, "To me, there's a lot better things the Government can spend our money on than missiles."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON AID TO RUSSIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The 47-nation conference on coordinating aid to the former Soviet Union opens at the State Department on Wednesday, with a host of tensions between the United States and its allies bubbling just beneath the surface over how best to help Russia and the other republics, officials and experts involved say.
At issue are both clashing egos and clashing policies. Many European officials, who were not consulted about the conference before it was announced, say they resent the leadership role being taken by the United States, which some of them argue is an effort to disguise how little Washington is actually doing. No longer feeling the need for Washington's security umbrella after the demise of the Soviet Union, the Europeans are increasingly speaking their mind. 
 They say that if the United States wants to lead the coordination effort, it must lead in giving. After all, they say, the United States did not simply "coordinate" the Marshall Plan for European recovery in 1947, it fully financed it. From that fact its leadership flowed automatically.
"France regrets the United States of America, which has only contributed 20 percent of urgent food aid, is in charge of coordination," the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, has said.
 
'Still Worth Doing'
 Other European participants are being more charitable. An Italian official said the conference "is probably more of a political gesture than anything else, but it is important to mobilize people."
A British diplomat said, "It is not going to change things overnight, but we feel it is still worth doing."
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who came up with the idea for a coordinating conference, has been guarded about exactly what he wants to come out of the two-day meeting.
Playing down expectations that the conference will somehow come up with new sums of money for Russia and other republics, he told reporters today that it was important that donor nations "get together and at least compare notes about preparations to confront what may very well be some major difficulties there, as reformers and democrats in the former Soviet Union try to continue their fight to embrace democracy."
But some leading American specialists say that the focus on coordination is inadequate, given the needs of Russia and the price reforms already introduced by its President, Boris N. Yelstin. What is needed is not simply a humanitarian aid package, they say, but a whole, multibillion dollar economic aid program to support Mr. Yeltsin's move to free markets.
 
Calculated Risks
 "The West has got to be ready to take some calculated risks right now in supporting Yeltsin's imperfect, but nevertheless bold, initiatives," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a former Assistant Secretary of State for International Economics. "If Yeltsin does not succeed, he is not going to be followed by a combination of Thomas Jefferson and Milton Friedman. He is going to be suceeded by some Rasputin-like xenophobic nationalist."
Nevertheless, Mr. Baker, aware that asking for money to aid the Russians would probably not be politically popular in the United States in this election year, has emphasized that this is not intended to be a conference to pledge new aid. Rather, it is intended to better coordinate the distribution of food, energy, medical, housing and technical aid already committed by the various countries to members of the new Commonwealth of Independent States.
Conference subcommittees will be assigned to devise "action plans" to spell out how to improve the amount and flow of humanitarian aid to different areas of the commonwealth and prevent redundancies. Progress will be reviewed at a meeting to be held in three months.
The United States has already pledged about $4 billion in food credits and technical aid and delivered about two-thirds of it. The European Community has contributed about $4 billion, as well as donations from individual members, and Japan about $2.6 billion.
The State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, seeking to defuse simmering tensions over who gives how much, said today: "We're not here to come and take score or find out who's ahead in the sixth inning. We're here to coordinate our assistance and try to make it more effective."
 
'The Biggest Dodge Going'
 The Germans and French, who will be the first to be affected by any turmoil in the former Soviet Union, tend to favor more fundamental economic aid now, not simply humanitarian aid. The Bush Administration has preferred to wait for the Russians and others to introduce sound economic reform programs. But that patient approach is now under fire from many American experts.
The coordinating conference "is the biggest dodge going," said Jeffery Sachs, a Harvard University economist who advised Poland and is now advising Mr. Yeltsin. In Eastern Europe, the West gave financial aid from the very beginning, he said.
Mr. Hormats said: "This meeting, which is being held at the foreign ministers level, has to go beyond mere coordination. Coordination can be done by technocrats. These ministers need to make some fundamental decisions, not just about coordination but about whether at this moment in history it is more important to support the Yeltsin reforms with a broad package of economic assistance."

HEADLINE: 47th St. Photo Files for Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Embroiled in legal squabbles and unable to pay its creditors, 47th Street Photo Inc., whose stores epitomize the feisty, combative world of consumer electronics retailing, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.
The company, known for being the first with the latest gadgets at the lowest prices for those shoppers willing to brave curt clerks and congested floors, said that all four of its stores in New York City and on Long Island would remain open as usual. Indeed, it was business as usual yesterday at its stores on West 45th Street and West 47th Street, which were swirling with bargain hunters searching for VCR's, stereo equipment, cameras and computers. 
 The company was pushed over the edge into Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after it defaulted on about $500,000 in payments last week to the Transamerica Commercial Finance Corporation.
Sales fell about 21 percent last year, to $225 million, according to the company, and it laid off about 20 percent of its work force -- now down to about 300 -- which largely consists of Hasidic Jews from the Williamsburg and Borough Park sections of Brooklyn.
In court papers filed in Manhattan, Irving Goldstein, the immigrant from Hungary who founded 47th Street Photo in 1965, said he was filing for bankruptcy because of a lien on the company's collateral.
The company has more than 200 creditors, whom it owes $57 million, against $30 million in assets, according to the court documents.
Abraham Weiss, a financial consultant to 47th Street Photo, said Transamerica, a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco, froze the company's bank accounts on Friday, making it impossible to do business.
In June, Transamerica won a $10 million judgment against the retailer and agreed on a schedule that required 47th Street Photo to pay it about $62,000 a week. Mr. Weiss said the retailer had paid back about $2.8 million to date.
But in a statement yesterday, Transamerica said 47th Street Photo had defaulted on an extraordinary $450,000 payment due Jan. 15, and a day later, failed to make its weekly payment. That was the day Mr. Goldstein signed the court papers that were filed yesterday.
On Jan. 17, Transamerica said, 47th Street Photo agreed to a new payment schedule and then promptly failed to make the first payment.
Mr. Weiss said that 47th Street Photo had tried to negotiate with Trans america over the weekend but that the talks had broken down.
"Our feeling is that Transamerica forced us into the filing," Mr. Weiss said. "We couldn't conduct commerce. All the money that was coming in was going right back out to them, so we couldn't do business with our vendors."
He said 47th Street Photo would contest the June judgment and try to get back the money it had already paid Transamerica.
Mr. Weiss said he was "99 percent sure" 47th Street Photo would not go the way of Newmark & Lewis, another local consumer electronics chain. Newmark & Lewis, which filed for Chapter 11 protection last September, announced last week that it was closing its remaining stores.
"We're really on top of things at the moment and feel good about things," Mr. Weiss said.
For years, competitors marveled at 47th Street Photo's sales volume and the lightning speed with which it brought goods in and sold them out. Though 47th Street Photo never added new stores by the handful like Newmark & Lewis, Nobody Beats the Wiz and other competitors, its reputation spread across the country through a lucrative mail-order business.
One of the many legends about the quintessentially New York retailer had it that even the International Business Machines Corporation bought personal computers for its offices from 47th Street Photo, finding it quicker and cheaper than getting the terminals from its own factories.
"It's always been this mystique-laden operation," said Martin Brochstein, senior editor of Television Digest, a weekly newsletter on the consumer electronics industry. "It looked like a hole in the wall, but it did an incredible volume."
Attempts to obtain Mr. Goldstein's home telephone number to ask for his comments were unavailing.
The secret of 47th Street Photo's business was simple: cash. Mr. Goldstein was always able to procure the best merchandise at low wholesale prices because he paid distributors up front in cash, people familiar with his business operations said. And he freely bought in the "gray market," picking up manufacturers' overruns and other retailers' excess inventory for a fraction of the list price.
People familiar with the operation, but who refused to be identified, said the retailer's profit margins were relatively slim. So, Mr. Goldstein took the cash generated by the stores and invested in real estate, as property values skyrocketed during the early 80's.
But the bottom fell out of the real estate market at the same time the consumer electronics business hit the skids. Once the sole source for bargain-basement-priced cameras, tape recorders, batteries and sunglasses, 47th Street Photo lost its edge as competition in the consumer electronics industry became a local and national war in which price was the only potent weapon.
It did not help that in the last few years the consumer electronics industry failed to come up with any product to drive the business the way videocassette recorders and microwaves once did.
And then recession not only compounded the industry's ailments, but also dried up the cash flow 47th Street Photo depended on. Recently, it closed its Nassau Street store after enlarging the ground floor of its flagship on 47th Street.
The company remains tangled in a vitriolic legal spat between Mr. Goldstein and Joseph Fischer, who served as an adviser to the 47th Street Photo founder.
Mr. Goldstein hired Mr. Fischer to handle his business affairs in 1987, after Mr. Goldstein was severely injured in an automobile accident. Mr. Goldstein had previously invested in real estate managed by Mr. Fischer.
The relationship soured as the stores, hit by the recession and the bust in the consumer electronic business, struggled to pay down debt on the real estate transactions.
Each man is now suing the other, charging broken promises and defamation and seeking money.

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Washington Memo;
Senate Jousting Is a Lesson in 'Bipartisan' Debate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The 1992 election campaign arrived on Capitol Hill today, as senators called for bipartisan efforts to solve national problems and then split on party lines over education legislation.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said, "The needs of the nation are not partisan." Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said Americans would reject "the same old partisan posturing, political games and Congressional gridlock." 
 Then they started sparring over the education bill, which Republicans say Democrats have shaped in a way that ignores, for partisan reasons, President Bush's main proposals.
The continual drumroll of appeals to interest above party means one of two things. At its most optimistic, it reflects the hope that the other side will see that its hand is so weak that it will throw in its cards. An example of this is another extension of unemployment benefits. Democrats believe the recession has such political impact that Republicans cannot delay the measure in 1992, as they did in 1991.
 
Dole Out of Character?
 The more frequent and realistic purpose is reflected in Mr. Dole's assertion that the public is impatient with partisanship -- even if it was offered by one of the Senate's most skilled and avid partisans.
Norman Ornstein, a Congressional expert at the American Enterprise Institute, said Congressmen are fearful that "the public, which is already unhappy with them, will turn on them with a vengeance.
"The signal they're getting from the public is, 'Do something, stop that bickering,' " Mr. Ornstein said.
The issue where fear of seeming to be partisan will probably do the most to produce compromise legislation is on an economic growth package.
 
Deadlock May Be Avoided
 Neither party is likely to be happy with the emphasis in the other's economic proposals, which will only be fully on the table once President Bush gets around to offering his plan next week. Democrats will argue that the Republican plan does too much for the rich; Republicans will say the Democrats care too little about real investment. But as Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, said today: "I don't think we will have deadlock. I don't think either party can afford it."
But on other questions, the Democrats have come so far since their immediate post-Persian Gulf war disarray that battles are almost certain.
For example, when a bipartisan poll conducted by Tarrance and Associates and Greenberg-Lake asked last June who was better at handling the economy -- President Bush or the Democrats in Congress -- 41 percent preferred Mr. Bush and 30 percent picked the Democrats. When the question was asked in December, only 28 percent picked Mr. Bush and 45 percent the Democrats.
On education, a 34-34 percent deadlock in June has shifted so that 43 percent think Congressional Democrats can do better, and only 28 percent prefer Mr. Bush. Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander came up to the Senate today to tell reporters that the public would not tolerate Democrats if they blocked Mr. Bush's plans.
 
Big Stakes for Both Sides
 The Democrats have another reason to push an agenda. After 11 years, they hunger for an ally in the White House and sense that they have a chance of defeating Mr. Bush. But, of course, the Republicans have a reason to fight back. They want to shore up Mr. Bush in his area of greatest weakness by combating the argument that the President has no domestic policies.
So the $850 million education bill is just the first of several efforts by the Democrats to flex their muscles.
On unemployment benefits, the Democrats were so awed by Mr. Bush last year that they waited until late July to push a bill on this bedrock Democratic issue. This year, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, will introduce a bill on Wednesday for another 13 weeks of benefits, and a hearing will be held on it on Thursday. The measure will probably come to the House floor in February.
The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee is expected to vote on Wednesday to send a major health care measure to the floor, and on Thursday the same committee will begin hearings on broader anti-recession measures. Regardless of whether these measures go anywhere soon, they offer competition for headlines, television time and political attention.
Legislation to require employers to offer leaves for workers whose families need personal attention, and an effort to split the differences between House and Senate Democrats on campaign finance legislation, are other efforts sure to go ahead in the face of promised Presidential vetoes, which will almost surely be sustained. But family leave offers Democrats a popular-sounding issue, and any bill which can be described as improving the campaign spending situation offers a defense against public discontent.
Beyond the economic growth measure, expectations of bipartisanship today usually focused on talk of the other side's giving in. Mr. Dole said it would be nice if Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who is managing the education bill, gave some ground. But Mr. Dole grinned and said that a bipartisan approach would be "refreshing and new."
An even franker suggestion came from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who told reporters, "Beware the politician who claims to be nonpartisan."
Mr. Mitchell spoke of bipartisan approaches in his speech opening the session. But earlier, referring to Mr. Alexander's suggestions on the education bill, he said, "We expect the best result from a political process in which competing views are debated."
But there are also reservations. Mr. Rostenkowski, who is reluctantly agreeing to the political demands for tax-cut legislation even though he expressed doubt that it would help the economy, said last week he longed for the days when "you took your shots just before the election, and then after Jan. 1 of the odd-numbered year you'd start governing."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Analysts Back Burlington Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Analysts today supported a plan by Burlington Industries to become a public company again, saying the move was timely considering the recent strength of the stock market and falling interest rates.
Burlington Industries Equity Inc., the parent of the textile company, said on Monday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 57 million shares at an initial price of $14 to $16 a share. 
 At those prices, the sale would generate between $798 million and $912 million and put 83 percent of the company's stock in public hands.
"I'm not sure what factors there may or may not be behind it, but it's a healthy sign," said James Thayer, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
Burlington Industries went private in 1987 in a leveraged buyout engineered by Morgan Stanley & Company to thwart a takeover attempt by the New York financier Asher Edelman.
The buyout left Burlington with $3 billion in debt, though that was reduced to $1.9 billion in 1988 through asset sales. Its debt as of Dec. 28 was $1.76 billion.

HEADLINE: New York Announces Plans For Executive Life Bailout

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Insurance regulators in New York announced a rescue plan yesterday for the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York that should pay 100 cents on the dollar to the insurer's 118,000 customers. But insurance professionals said the plan would make it impossible for customers to cash in their policies without incurring substantial penalties, known as surrender charges.
The professionals said that under the plan, which requires the approval of a New York State court, some customers would earn significantly lower interest on their policies and annuities than they had before Executive Life of New York and its sister company in California were seized by the respective state regulators last spring. Both were units of the bankrupt First Executive Corporation of Los Angeles. 
 The plan calls for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York to only provide bookkeeping services for Executive Life annuities that are currently making payments and to take over the rest of Executive Life's businesses.
 
Cancels Old Contracts
 The businesses to be taken over are deferred annuities, whole-life policies, term-life policies and so-called interest-sensitive policies -- known as universal-life policies. Executive Life's contracts for deferred annuities and these three types of policies would be canceled, and the holders would be issued new contracts by Metropolitan Life.
Under the plan, however, any customer picked up by Metropolitan Life would be considered a new customer and would be subject to the cancellation fees charged to other new Metropolitan Life customers. That would apply even if a policyholder was an Executive Life customer for years and was eligible to cash out without penalty.
Under Metropolitan Life's current rules, customers who cash in their policies the first year pay a surrender charge of 7 percent of the account's value. The penalty declines by a percentage point for each year the policy is in effect.
Executive Life customers who turned down a Metropolitan Life contract would face even stiffer penalties for cashing out. They would be paid in four annual installments, and no interest would be paid on balances that remained with the company.
Most customers who converted to Metropolitan Life would get the same interest rate they had with Executive Life -- anywhere from 4.5 percent to 5.5 percent depending on the type of contract. But some Executive Life customers who had policies that guaranteed minimum rates as high as 8 percent would earn less with Metropolitan Life.
"It seems very unfair to the policyholders" and a great deal for Metropolitan Life, said Michael Berman, a leading Executive Life agent in New York.
Kevin E. Foley, the New York Insurance Department official overseeing the bailout said no company would rescue Executive Life if it had to pay 8 percent interest and could not impose the surrender charges.
At Metropolitan Life, Ted Athanassiades, a senior executive vice president, said most Executive Life customers had expected to hold their policies for many years, so the schedule of surrender charge was not that important.

HEADLINE: Wisconsin District to Assign Pupils On Basis of Income to Disperse Poor

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Amid much debate, the La Crosse school district next fall will become the first in the nation to use family income as the criterion for assigning elementary students to schools.
The plan is designed to break up a large concentration of poor students in just two of the district's nine elementary schools. By dispersing both poor and affluent students more evenly, administrators said they hoped to address several issues, including reducing the stress of teachers who work primarily with the poor, enhancing the education of poor children and exposing all students to a greater cross section of classmates. 
 But many parents, rich and poor alike, are inflamed. They oppose the district's decision to bus about a third of the 3,500 elementary students to execute the plan and say they want their children to attend the nearest school.
School officials said widespread busing was necessary next fall anyway, because two schools built to ease crowding will open and are on the outskirts of town, away from most residential neighborhoods. They also point out that a group of elementary school principals and administrators examining the needs of all the district's children had come up with the new family-income approach.
 
Using a Federal Standard
 The school board, an elected body, approved the plan, 8 to 1, two weeks ago. It will use the standards of the Federal free-lunch program to determine who is poor; by the standards, the children of a family of four with an annual income of less than $17,420 qualify for free lunches.
"We certainly have set up a plan that is not easy," said Superintendent Richard A. Swantz. "But we think this is a good thing to do, even though it is very controversial."
Thousands of parents disagree.
"People don't live in a small community to have their kids bused," said Jay Hoeschler, a real estate developer and real estate broker who opposes the plan because his two children will be bused. "There's no one who's going to say there's no value to socioeconomic mixing, but putting them on buses and moving them all over the place, there are far more negatives to that."
The district has ordered that no more than 45 percent and no less than 15 percent of an elementary school's enrollment be children who qualify for free lunches. The busing plan will affect only elementary schools because they tend to be more homogeneous by neighborhood; the district has only two high schools and three middle schools, so they attract a wider mix of students.
The La Crosse district has 7,722 students this year, including middle and high schools. Eighty-five percent of the students are white, and of the 1,163 minority students, 904 are Asian, most of them Hmong.
The district is working to insure that both low-income and affluent students are among those bused, Mr. Swantz said.
The development of the plan has been watched with growing interest by education specialists, who think the district is taking a risky path by busing students without first giving parents an incentive to support busing, regardless of its legitimacy or necessity.
"The benefit of obtaining a socioeconomic mix is outweighed in many parents' minds by the cost of being bused, or mandatorily being reassigned to a school they did not choose," said David Armour, a school-busing expert at George Mason University in Virginia who is monitoring the La Crosse plan.
A more palatable approach for parents, for example, would have been the use of magnet schools to disperse students and ease crowding, which could also encourage a better socioeconomic mix, said Joe Nathan, director of the Center for School Change at the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota.
Mr. Nathan said that La Crosse's approach was similar to busing for racial purposes, and that given the largely unsuccessful experiences of many school systems in busing for desegregation, the district might be better served by other approaches. "We've spent 20 years trying to push people together," he said, "and it's ultimately unwise and doomed."
 
Problems in Some Schools
 But La Crosse officials have stuck to their plan. By blending students based on family income, they said they had a rare chance to break disturbing trends in schools where a majority of the students are poor. In other communities, schools with heavy concentrations of the poor have deteriorated over time because of the variety of ills, like absenteeism, associated with poverty.
"Why wait until our schools have problems?" asked David L. Johnston, the district's assistant superintendent. "We have an opportunity now to keep them from becoming bad."
It is difficult to see immediately many differences between the schools attended by La Crosse's poor and those attended by its middle class. Hamilton Elementary School, one of two schools where 70 percent of the nearly 400 students are eligible for free lunches, has a computer laboratory; so does State Road Elementary School, in an affluent neighborhood where only 4 percent of the 500 students receive free lunches. Both schools are well maintained and have well-stocked libraries and enough counselors.
But differences lie below the surface.
At Hamilton, Donnie Lee, a first-grade teacher, spends a great deal of time addressing problems among her 25 students, usually family problems that have little to do with education. Some students are withdrawn, she said, and need to be coaxed to communicate. In addition, she said, students are sometimes late to school because no one wakes them and sends them off.
"You have all these things going on at home that affect what's going on in the school," said Ms. Lee, who supports the district's plan because, she said, a better student mix would allow "for more teaching time than is now possible."
"I think what the schools are trying to do is good," said Grace Dahl, whose two sons are attending preschool and first grade at Hamilton this year but will attend another school next year under the district's plan. "It's important for kids to see both sides of life. We're not rich by any means, but we aren't dirt-poor either."
 
Objections From Parents
 For all the benefits touted by school officials and some parents for mixing enrollment based on income, many parents remain furious. About 4,000 people signed petitions last October protesting the district's decison to abolish the longstanding practice of letting children attend schools nearest their homes. A few families are considering moving to a different neighborhood so their children will not be bused.
While many parents object to busing, others question the premise of the district's effort to blend students by income. "Why should we be the subject of a social experiment?" asked Kevin O'Keefe, a lawyer who has three children, though none of school age. "If you want to do something for poor kids, study what other schools have done rather than do a social experiment. To me, it's the height of craziness."
Early on in the district's deliberation, some parents threatened to file a lawsuit to block the plan. But experts in busing said district officials had done nothing illegal in redrawing boundary lines, and the threat of a lawsuit has faded.
Dr. Charles Miller, president of the board, said that busing per se, not the idea behind it, was behind much of the criticism.
"Anytime you change school boundaries, you have people coming out of the wall," Dr. Miller said. "Socio-economic blending is no red herring. We knew this would be controversial, but we did the best we could."

HEADLINE: Citicorp and 2 Other Banks Post Losses as Loans Sour

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The decline in the California real estate market has caught up with some of the state's largest banks, and yesterday Wells Fargo & Company and the Security Pacific Corporation announced large fourth-quarter losses as a result. And Citicorp, as expected, posted losses for the fourth quarter and the year.
Wells and Security Pacific had also said earlier that they expected losses in the quarter that were close to the shortfalls announced yesterday of $231 million at Wells and $409.2 million at Security Pacific. They also warned that severe problems could continue as long as the state's economy remained weak. 
 Following are the details of the banking companies' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp announced losses of $133 million in the quarter and $457 million for 1991. It had lost $382 million in the fourth quarter of 1990, but earned $458 million that year. Citicorp also said it was nearing the halfway point of its goal of cutting its expenses by $1.5 billion by the end of this year. The company's stock fell 62.5 cents a share yesterday, to $13.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Excluding the extra $285 million in expenses for managing the real estate it has acquired through foreclosure and other costs for nonrecurring costs, like severance payments to employees, Citicorp reduced its expenses last year by $700 million, to $10.1 billion, from $10.8 billion in 1990. As part of its expense cuts, Citicorp has reduced its staff to 86,000, from 89,000 three months ago and 95,000 a year ago.
Revenues at Citicorp grew slightly, to $14.8 billion, from $14.6 billion last year, a much slower rate than normal, which the banking company attributed to the effects of the weak American economy.
Among Citicorp's large business groups, the global consumer business earned $196 million in the quarter and $549 million for the year. A sharp rise in delinquencies in the bank's credit card business kept profits well below the $905 million earned by the global consumer group last year.
The corporate-finance business in Japan, Europe and North America succeeded in reducing expenses and in improving trading profits, but still reported a loss of $466 million in the quarter and $1.02 billion for the year. The loss reflected the growing burden of bad loans.
Problems with commercial real estate loans accounted for most of the $647 million in loan write-offs and write-downs on the real estate Citicorp owns because of foreclosure. About 21 percent of Citicorp's $12.45 billion in commercial real estate loans were in California as of Sept. 30, but John S. Reed, the banking company's chairman, said yesterday that the loan losses were spread widely throughout the United States, Australia and Britain.
Mr. Reed also noted that problems with other kinds of business loans, which typically become more severe after the bottoming out of an economic recession, were increasing, but not to a serious level.
To help strengthen the management of its corporate lending business, Citicorp yesterday confirmed the appointment of H. Onno Ruding, a former Dutch Finance Minister and senior official at the International Monetary Fund, as vice chairman.
Mr. Ruding, who earlier in his career was an executive at ABN AMRO, the largest bank in the Netherlands, said yesterday that he aimed to strengthen Citicorp's systems of checks and balances to keep a rein on bankers who were inclined to push for growth and new business.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo, where loan troubles emerged as a serious problem in the second half of last year and where the company is known for keeping expenses low, managed a $21 million profit for the year, down from $712 million in 1990.
"The downturn in the California real estate market really accelerated last year, as the state's economy began a free fall," said David Shulman, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc. and an expert in real estate markets.
Wells Fargo said the primary reason for its large fourth-quarter loss was the need to add $700 million to its loan-loss reserves, after a review of its books by Federal examiners. Other parts of its business continued to perform well, as the company increased slightly the difference between the rates it pays to depositors and the rates it charges borrowers.
Non-interest income grew to $251 million, from $204 million a year ago, mostly because of higher charges on consumer accounts and other fees. Wells's stock fell $2.375 a share yesterday, to $64.75.
 
Security Pacific
 Security Pacific lost $774.5 million for all of 1991, compared with a profit of $161.3 million a year earlier.
Mr. Shulman, of Salomon, said the real estate market, particularly for commercial developments like office buildings, "will get worse before it gets better and will be aggravated by the merger of Bank of America and Security Pacific" later this year.
The elimination of 20,000 jobs, out of a combined 96,500 at the end of 1990, that he expects to result from the merger will reduce demand for office space in California by about five million square feet, or more than the total commercial space under construction in downtown Los Angeles in the middle of last year, Mr. Shulman noted.
The BankAmerica Corporation expects savings from the merger to be well in excess of $1 billion a year and said yesterday that the earnings report by Security Pacific did not change its plans to proceed with the merger.
Security Pacific's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $32.625.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Move Up in Price Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell again yesterday, as the recovery from the sharp selloff of the last two weeks continued.
"Underwriting all the corporate paper issued during the early part of January made Treasuries cheap," one government securities trader said, since dealers had to sell Treasury issues to cover positions in unsold corporate issues. 
 "But the distribution of that corporate paper is taking place, and the market is correcting as it happens. Rates backed up by 50 basis points" in the recent selloff, the trader added, "but only half of it was justified."
Much of the price improvement in longer-dated securities occurred during trading in Asia and Europe. And American dealers said there was good demand in the United States for short-term bills and notes.
"The selloff over the last couple of weeks was overdone, and as a result we were presented with some real value late last week, particularly in issues with maturities from two years to seven years," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
 
3-Month Bills at 3.78%
 Demand for short-term securities was also manifested at the weekly sale of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.78 percent, down from an average rate of 3.83 percent at last week's sale. Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 3.84 percent, compared with an average rate of 3.87 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 1051/32 , up by 13/32 , to yield 7.57 percent, compared with 7.58 percent on Monday.
All of the gains in the bond came overseas. At its highs of the day, the bond was offered in London at a price of 1056/32 , Mr. Sullivan said.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10313/32 , up by half a point, or $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 7.01 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 987/32 , also up by half a point, to yield 6.69 percent.
 
5-Year Notes at 6.25%
 Before the auctions today and tomorrow of new two-year and five-year notes, the two-year securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 4.94 percent.
The new five-year notes, to be sold tomorrow, were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.25 percent.
New issues continued to flow into the investment-grade corporate bond market. Among the issuers were ARCO, the Los Angeles-based oil company, and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, the principal subsidiary of J. P. Morgan & Company.
ARCO offered $250 million in 30-year securities through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The 8.25 percent bonds were priced at $98.80, to yield 8.36 percent, 78 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager on the sale of $200 million worth of 10-year subordinated notes for Morgan Guaranty.
The 7 3/8 percent notes were priced at $99.75 to yield 7.411 percent, 40 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-1 by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.
 
$600 Million Bond Sale
 The biggest offering of the day was the sale of $600 million in noncallable 20-year bonds for Tele-Communications Inc., the Denver-based cable company. The 9.80 percent bonds were priced at $99.608, to yield 9.845 percent, 2.28 percentage points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead underwriter for the offering. The securities carry a split rating. Moody's rates the bonds Baa-3, an investment-grade rating. But Standard & Poor's gave the issue a speculative, BB rating.
Investors in the municipal bond market were apparently unmoved by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget proposals yesterday. Traders said prices of most New York State debt securities were virtually unchanged.

HEADLINE: Fed to Relax a Bank Rule

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said yesterday that it would phase out by June 30 the requirement that banks disclose in their financial statements the total amount of loans to highly indebted leveraged companies.
The 7-to-0 decision eliminates the definition of certain loans now called highly leveraged transactions, which banks issued in the 1980's. 
 The Fed noted that the special category had caused some analysts to view the loans as extra risky, and might have had the unintended effect of discouraging bank lending to some highly leveraged borrowers or setting higher prices for the loans.
Although bankers supported the Fed's move, they were not sure yesterday if it would mean the end of disclosures about loans to highly indebted companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission has required such disclosure, though it has never issued its own definition of what loans should be included.
John D. Heine, a deputy director at the S.E.C. said future disclosure by banks "will depend on the situation" and noted that banking companies are still required to disclose facts which are material to investors.
The other bank regulatory agencies, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, are also phasing out use of the "highly leveraged transaction" designation.
The change by bank regulators is part of their efforts to prevent their examinations from impeding the availability of credit to worthy borrowers. Regulators and examiners were criticized last year for unduly tough oversight which, some economists said, created a credit shortage that weakened the economy.
But bank examiners will continue to scrutinize leveraged-transaction loans in their annual bank reviews.

HEADLINE: Chase Investigating Loss

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation said the drop in its fourth-quarter profits reported last week reflected the effect of possible fraud by a borrower, Arochem Inc., a Connecticut-based oil refiner and trader.
"We are aware of a problem with Arochem and took appropriate action in the fourth-quarter financial statement," a Chase spokesman said on Monday, declining to elaborate. 
 A banking official said yesterday that the F.B.I. tion was investigating fraud at Arochem. Chase had $80 million of a syndicated loan to the company, said the official, who asked not to be identified.
Last week, Chase, citing higher loan-loss provisions and a weak economy, said its profits had slipped about 30 percent in the quarter, although it ended with a profit for the year.
The New York-based banking company said its fourth-quarter profits slipped to $135 million, or 80 cents a share, from $193 million, or $1.32 a share, a year earlier.
In the quarter, Chase charged off $77 million in commercial loans, $37 million of which were attributed to two unidentified loans, Chase officials said last week.

HEADLINE: Gesture of Fiscal Conciliation

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
In promoting his budget as a vehicle for a quick deal with State Senate Republicans, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo armed himself today with political ammunition to assail the Legislature if it fails again to pass a timely budget.
Mr. Cuomo could have used his budget to present a stridently Democratic response to the recession, which has helped generate a $4.8 billion gap in the state's $30 billion budget. 
 Instead he crafted a proposal that would not increase broad-based taxes, would impose heavy cuts in Medicaid and welfare programs and would make relatively small reductions in state aid to schools. All are positions embraced in principle by the Republican majority in the State Senate.
 
An Entreaty for Action
 Even before Mr. Cuomo formally presented his budget today, he began selling it as a gesture of conciliation to the Senate Republicans.
"It will accommodate them sufficiently so they can feel, 'O.K., this isn't a declaration of war -- this is an entreaty for us to sit down and negotiate something and to do it in a hurry,' " Mr. Cuomo said in a news conference on Monday.
But if Mr. Cuomo's budget represents something of a peace offering, it also carries an implicit threat. Given his concessions, Mr. Cuomo seemed to be suggesting today, the only thing that could frustrate a budget agreement by the start of the fiscal year on April 1 would be a strategy of deliberate obstructionism by the Senate Republicans.
If that happens, Mr. Cuomo can be expected to wage a fierce election-year campaign to make the damage stick to the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, and his Republican colleagues.
"If the Senate's made up its mind that they want to make it late, there's no way to stop them," Mr. Cuomo said in offering a preview on Monday. "If that's what they want to do, the state is gone."
 
Doomsday Warnings
 With the help of Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York City investment banker whom Mr. Cuomo has supported as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the Governor has tried to raise the stakes in recent days by issuing a series of doomsday warnings.
Another late budget, the two men have warned, could lead Wall Street rating agencies not only to downgrade the state's credit rating again but also to lower it to junk-bond grade. That would essentially close the credit markets to the state and threaten New York with bankruptcy.
After Standard & Poor's dropped the state's general-obligation bond rating last week to the second lowest level of any state, New York's rating stands three notches above investment grade. But Mr. Cuomo has said that if the state fails to meet its budget deadline for the eighth year in a row, the credit agencies might lose patience and destroy the state's rating in a single fatal blow rather than downgrading one step at a time.
Both the Senate Republicans and the Democrats who control the Assembly recognized today that Mr. Cuomo's strategy was to offer a deal that the Senate could not easily refuse.
"The fact that he recommended school-aid cuts of $168 million when he had been talking late last year about cuts of $600 million was some sort of olive branch," said Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "I would say his attitude was conciliatory."
 
'Some Progress'
 Mr. Marino, a Nassau County Republican, conceded that Mr. Cuomo's budget represented "some progress." But he said the Governor had not gone far enough in cutting the Medicaid and welfare budgets and he challenged Mr. Cuomo to push the Assembly Democrats toward the Governor's position.
"While the Governor has made some progress in moving to adopt some of the structure reforms proposed by the Senate Republicans, it remains unclear if he will be able to deliver the support of his fellow Democrats in the Assembly," Mr. Marino said.
Mr. Cuomo made it clear in his news conferences today and on Monday that he was a reluctant convert to some of the policies he endorsed in the budget. Some of them, he said, reflect misdirected blame for the state's dire financial condition.
The Governor did not seem enthused, for instance, about his proposal to terminate benefits after six months for employable recipients of Home Relief, a welfare program largely for single adults and childless couples, and he mocked the Republican emphasis on proposals -- many of which he has not accepted -- to combat fraud and abuse by appointing a welfare inspector general and by requiring Medicaid recepients to carry identification cards.
"We're not going to get ripped off even by old people who are sick," he said. "We'll see to it they don't steal the sheets, I guarantee you. We're going to fingerprint them. We're going to have inspectors general. But let's not make the mistake of thinking that they are the cause of our problems."
Mr. Cuomo devoted much of his news conference today to stressing his commitment to cutting the social-services budget. By proposing $1.158 billion in savings from Medicaid and welfare programs in the 1991-93 fiscal year, Mr. Cuomo said he was going beyond the $1.1 billion in savings that the Senate and the Assembly had agreed to seek in their unsuccessful negotiations over a 15-month budget.
 
Negotiations Scheduled
 But the Senate Republicans complained that too much of the savings came from proposals to increase taxes on hospital and nursing-home revenues, and not from cuts in spending.
That is likely to be a dominant topic in the negotiations scheduled to start in Mr. Cuomo's conference room on Wednesday afternoon, when the Governor has invited Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino to begin their discusssions.
For the time being, all parties are cautiously optimistic, including the Governor.
"What it takes to make the talks successful is very easy -- will," Mr. Cuomo said. "Not intellect, that's all been used up. Will -- that's the part of the psyche we haven't used."

HEADLINE: Recession Prompts First-Time Gifts as Neediest Cases Lead '91 Pace

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
"I have not donated money to the Neediest Cases fund before," Deborah Dorfman of Princeton, N.J., wrote, "but the need seems so great this year."
That simple note goes a long way toward explaining the remarkable success of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this year. The appeal, which continues through Feb. 29, has managed to surge $476,000 ahead of last year's pace in part because of a large increase in the number of first-time contributors like Ms. Dorfman, who gave $50. So far, almost 13,000 donors have contributed almost $4.4 million. 
 In the short notes and letters attached to their checks, donors have described many reasons for making their first contribution. But the declining economy has been the most common theme.
"This donation comes from thankfulness for coming through another year," wrote Lynn Ann Harris of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., who gave $50. "All in my family who are old enough to work have work. We are all able to meet our rent/mortgage obligations, other bills and put food on our tables. We have enough and in this economy, that's quite a lot."
Carol R. Kolton of Westfield, N.J., said the rising needs of the city's poor, sick and disabled were impossible to ignore. "In the past it has been easy for me to turn the page and say someone else will respond," she wrote in a note attached with $100. "This year everyone who has the ability should respond because the need is so enormous."
 
Times Covers Overhead
 Freida Malament of Massapequa, L.I., had often intended to make a donation but "usually forgot because of the pressures of my own life." In a letter attached to her $25 check, she explained: "This year I feel especially grateful for my health and my very good and caring daughter. I feel lucky to have her and my relatively tranquil life."
Several first-time contributors are newcomers to the city. "As a recent emigre to N.Y.C. I have noticed that people are particularly hard pressed this year," wrote Clarinda Bisceglia, who recently moved to Brooklyn from California and contributed $50. "I myself have not been able to find work on a steady basis, but I am fortunate to have had some savings."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor, and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases," has expanded to meet needs of thousands of individuals.
The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar is passed on to seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief including food, homes and clothing for those without. The seven charities also use the money to provide job training for the disabled, counseling for substance abusers and to support a wide array of AIDS-related programs.
Many first-time donors made contributions despite their own problems. "Although my earnings this year are only a tenth of what they were five years ago, I could not find it in my heart to avoid contributing this year," an anonymous donor who gave $50 wrote. "While many earnings may be down this year, the opinion I have of myself cannot possibly be higher. I hope this note will encourage others to follow suit by making positive contributions toward your fund. As for myself, I plan on making this a tradition."

HEADLINE: United Technologies To Cut 13,900 Jobs; Blow to Connecticut

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The United Technologies Corporation, the largest private employer in Connecticut, announced a series of plant closings and cutbacks yesterday that would eliminate 13,900 jobs, including 6,412 in the state, by 1995. The cuts represent 7 percent of the 193,000 workers employed worldwide by the sprawling company, whose businesses include Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Otis elevators.
The largest job losses will be at the Pratt & Whitney division, based in East Hartford, Conn., and are a result of declining military spending, company officials said. But virtually all parts of the company will be affected. 
 The military-related cuts are just the latest to hit Pentagon contractors in the region. The Electric Boat division of General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn., has said it will eliminate 10,000 jobs because fewer submarines are being ordered. On Long Island, the Grumman Corporation and other military suppliers lost an estimated 20,000 jobs since the procurement boom of the mid-1980's.
Connecticut's Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., was vacationing in St. Croix, in the Virgin Islands, but his office said state officials had feared that United Technologies was planning to move many operations out of state, which would have been a much harder blow to the state's economy. The Governor's office said it hoped that the company's restructuring would make it stronger and ultimately help to preserve Connecticut jobs.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, agreed with the Governor's office that the news could have been worse. But he said he feared the ripple effect from the company's decision to cut in half its list of parts suppliers, to 250 from 500. "That's a real blow to us, in terms of our manufacturing base," he said. "That can have as significant an impact as what we're talking about here."
 
Executive Ranks Hit Harder
 The company's executive ranks will be hit harder than the overall work force, as 12 percent of management jobs will be eliminated. Some of the cuts, at its corporate headquarters and research laboratories, have already taken place, officials said. In all, the company said it would close or consolidate more than 100 operations worldwide, cutting its total factory space by 16 percent.
United Technologies officials said the purpose is to reduce costs by $1.1 billion a year by 1994 to improve the company's financial performance. But for 1991, the cost of program was $1.28 billion. In addition, the company took a charge of $256 million for the anticipated costs of meeting environmental standards.
The special charges produced a loss of $1.22 billion in the fourth quarter and a loss of $1.02 billion for the year. The loss did not come as a surprise since the company announced last fall that it would take a charge of over $1 billion that would produce losses in both the quarter and year.
The loss for the quarter compares with a profit of $168.8 million, or $1.32 a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter totaled $5.81 billion, down 2.3 percent from $5.95 billion a year earlier. The loss for the year compares with a profit of $750.6 million, or $5.91 a share, in 1990. Total sales were $21.26 billion for the year, a decline of 2.4 percent from $21.79 billion in 1990. The company's stock closed yesterday at $54, down $1.25 for the day.
The environmental charge had not been forecast, but in cases where accounting rules allow companies to choose when to recognize particular losses, companies typically choose years that are going to be bad anyway to pave the way for better earnings in future years.
Robert F. Daniell, the chairman of United Technologies, said some of the plant closings and layoffs "recognize the realities of a shrinking U.S. defense budget." In 1990, 22 percent of the company's sales were to the Federal Government. But he said the need to improve efficiency and the prolonged recession were factors as well.
 
Drop in Engine Orders
 In a letter to Pratt & Whitney employees, James G. O'Connor, the head of the division, said production of jet fighter engines was expected to drop from a high of 700 in 1982 to about 50 next year. Sales of civilian engines and spare parts are being held down by the financial turmoil in the airline industry, he said.
"Over all, our total engine and spare parts forecast shows production volume declining through 1995 then leveling off through the rest of the decade," Mr. O'Connor said. About 4,100 jobs are expected to be lost at Pratt & Whitney in Connecticut, and a total of 5,096 in the division. United Technologies employed 47,650 in the state before the cutbacks began last year.
Beyond the problems in the military business, Mr. Daniell said the plant closings and job cutbacks were intended to make the company more efficient. "We have begun a transformation more profound and more potent than any single event in the corporation's recent history," he said.
 
Blow to the Economy
 Meeting with securities analysts in New York, Mr. Daniell conceded that announcements of plant closing and job reductions would not help pull the nation's economy out of recession. He defended the reductions as necessary for the company. "This is correct for us at this time," he said. But he added, "It is a dichotomy, I'll admit."
The analysts seemed generally to be favorably impressed by the presentation by Mr. Daniell and other top company executives. "The size of the charge was eye-popping, but the returns could be wonderful," said Howard Rubel of C. J. Lawrence. The company said the object of the changes was to increase profits to 18 percent of shareholders' equity by 1994 from the low to mid-teens recently.
"The actual announcement was anticlimactic; they had telegraphed it well in advance," said Michael Lauer of Kidder, Peabody. "This is a company that is not likely to benefit from a pickup in the economy except for its automotive parts business."
 
Most Cuts This Year
 United Technologies officials said the bulk of the job cuts, more than 7,000, would take place this year. But job reductions will continue at Pratt & Whitney through 1995. More than 1,700 jobs were cut at the company's corporate offices and the Otis elevator division in 1991, officials said.
The company said the layoffs would save $440 million a year. Closing plants will add another $260 million a year and improvements in design, engineering and manufacturing will add the remaining $380 million in projected savings.
Mr. Daniell said the company would seek to reduce the cost of developing products by seeking alliances with overseas companies. He cited a recent agreement between Pratt & Whitney and a division of Germany's Daimler-Benz to develop jet engines jointly as an example.
He also said the company agreed with the forecast of some analysts that the company would earn from $4 to $5 a share this year. "Whether we are at the high or low end of that range depends on the economy," he said.
 
A Bad Year Anywhere
 The special charges masked what would have been a disappointing fourth quarter and year for the company. Sagging sales of military engines and spare parts depressed fourth-quarter operating earnings at Pratt & Whitney to $138 million from $252 million. Since the division typically produced more than 50 percent of United Technologies' total profit, the corporation's fourth-quarter operating profit was down 14 percent, to $302 million from $351 million.
For the year, Pratt & Whitney's problems were given as the main source of a 41 percent decline in operating earnings, to $968 million from $1.653 billion.
The company said it would close its Pratt & Whitney overhaul and repair plant in Southington, Conn., but keep a separate manufacturing operation in the same town. The Carrier air-conditioning and heating equipment subsidiary said it would close plants in City of Industry, Calif.; Knoxville, Tenn., and Ellijay, Ga.
