HEADLINE: Bank Fund, C.D. Yields Down Again

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit dropped for the week that ended yesterday, but the pace of the decline slowed, according to figures released yesterday by The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that follows bank rates. The explanation, however, does not give much solace to savers hoping for an end to the rate declines.
Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher, explained: "The modest decline in savings yield for the most recent week was caused partly by the Monday bank holiday" observing the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Some institutions that normally change rates effective on Wednesday, he said, will cut them on Thursday of this week instead. 
 "That will further depress the week's average yields, because the down cycle still has a lot of force behind it," Mr. Heady said.
 
Steeper Drop Is Seen
 By the end of the week, Mr. Heady expects the average fall-off in yields on short-term certificates of deposit to be down 6 or 7 basis points rather than the average of 3 basis points reported this week. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Among commercial banks in the New York area, the average money market account yield was 3.70 percent, down 2 basis points.
Among the savings institutions in this area, money market account yields fell 9 points, to 4.29 percent.
For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area banks was made by the Carteret Savings Bank in New Jersey, which lowered its rate by 53 basis points. The Dollar-Dry Dock Bank of New York led the way with a drop of 11 basis points for its three-month certificate of deposit, and Green Point Savings Bank in Brooklyn made the largest cut in its yield on its six-month certificate of deposit, dropping it 15 basis points.
The Monitor said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area also showed significant declines in savings yields, with the average yield on a money market account down 7 basis points, to 3.71 percent, and six-month certificates of deposit down 3 basis points, to 3.88 percent.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday, the average rate on the maturities at auction was 3.78 percent and 3.84 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.E. Net Up by 2% In Quarter

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Helped by continued strength in financial services, the General Electric Company said yesterday that profits in the last three months of 1991 edged up 2 percent, to more than $1.26 billion. It also cited growth in businesses where products are ordered many months or even years in advance, like medical equipment, power systems and aircraft engines.
The double-digit profits in these businesses compensated for sharp declines at the company's NBC broadcasting subsidiary and in the economically sensitive materials group, which supplies products like plastics to a wide range of industries. 
 Earnings per share were $1.46, up 3 percent from $1.42 a year ago. Revenues for the quarter rose 2 percent, to $17.5 billion, from $17.2 billion a year ago.
G.E., as is its custom, did not supply details of the quarter's performance by any of its business units. But John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s chairman and chief executive, said that the broadcasting and materials groups were the only segments of the company not reporting operating gains.
The earnings fell right in the middle of the narrow band of estimates by Wall Street analysts who follow the company. G.E. shares fell along with the rest of the market in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, ending yesterday down $2.50, to $78.
 
Annual Net Off 38.7%
 G.E., which is based in Fairfield, Conn., ended 1991 with earnings of almost $2.64 billion, or $3.03 a share, down 38.7 percent from more than $4.30 billion, or $4.85 a share, in 1990. But that decline included a $1.8 billion charge in the first quarter of 1991 to cover a change in how the company accounts for its future obligations to retirees.
The accounting change did not affect cash flow. Without it, net income for the year rose 3 percent, to almost $4.44 billion. Per-share earnings rose 5 percent for the year to $5.10, increasing at a faster clip than income because the company repurchased about 15 million shares last year for about $1 billion.
Mr. Welch said that G.E. had met many of its long-term objectives for the year. The operating margins of 11.3 percent were down slightly from 11.6 percent in 1990, but the decline was entirely due to NBC, the company said. Margins improved to 11.9 percent from 11.5 percent at the other businesses.
 
Big Gain in Financial Services
 G.E. said it earned almost $1.3 billion from financial services, spurred by $6.2 billion worth of acquisitions in the leasing and credit card business. The company said that it was also helped by a "significant" turnaround at Kidder, Peabody, the company's investment banking and stockbrokerage subsidiary.
G.E. said that its aircraft engine group won more than 55 percent of all new orders for large commercial aircraft engines last year, although its backlog declined to $11.9 billion from $13.2 billion at the end of 1990. The power systems group won 60 percent of the worldwide business in its segment and increased its backlog 23 percent, to $9.6 billion, the company said.
G.E. also reported double-digit profit growth and increased worldwide market share for its medical business, which makes CAT scanners and other expensive diagnostic systems. The appliance business managed a slight profit gain despite falling demand for appliances in general.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Shuffle of Economists: Dean Witter Lands One

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
At a time when the stock market is bubbly and the economy is flat, chief economists at some of the nation's biggest banks and brokerages have been involved in a giant job shuffle.
The latest job hopper is Joseph G. Carson, 39, who will be chief economist at the Dean Witter Financial Services Group, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company. Until recently Chemical Bank's top forecaster, Mr. Carson lost that post to Irwin Kellner, his counterpart at Manufacturers Hanover, after the two banks merged. 
 By switching from a bank to a brokerage, Mr. Carson will be focusing on the needs of small and large equity investors. "It's more balanced, it's a great opportunity," he said. "It gives me a very, very big platform to speak from."
In a roundabout way, Mr. Carson owes that platform to Edward J. Hyman, the top-rated Wall Street economist who had been chief economist at C. J. Lawrence for nearly two decades. Mr. Hyman set off a chain reaction when he left to set up his own firm, the ISI Group, last year. Edward E. Yardeni, then Prudential Securities' chief economist, moved into Mr. Hyman's old job at C. J. Lawrence and Richard D. Rippe of Dean Witter jumped into Mr. Yardeni's slot at Prudential, creating a well-timed opening for Mr. Carson at Dean Witter.
"Joe is very talented " said Nancy Lazar, ISI's executive vice president. But in her view, "There's definitely no cosmic significance" in all the job-swapping among forecasters.
One sign of Mr. Carson's acumen is that he's been a bear on the economy since late 1989. He correctly anticipated the sharp slowdown in growth that made the economy acutely vulnerable to shocks like Saddam Hussein's August 1991 invasion of Kuwait. And, despite the postwar pickup in Americans' mood and spending, Mr. Carson refused to forecast the arrival of a real recovery before 1992.
When will the recovery start? Sometime in the spring or summer, Mr. Carson said. But he also thinks that the next few months will be rougher than the consensus of economists expects.
That could sprinkle a raindrop or two on the stock market parade and perhaps scare away some of Dean Witter's customers. But Mr. Carson is cautiously optimistic that interest rates are headed even lower and that corporate profits will start to recover before the end of the year.
A native of Girard, Ohio, a small town near Youngstown, Mr. Carson and his family had close ties to General Motors. Both his parents worked there and so for a time did he -- as a senior economist after he earned his master's degree at Youngstown State University.
Mr. Carson arrived on Wall Street just as the 1980's bull market was taking off. He was senior economist at Merrill Lynch, responsible for divining the direction of the United States economy, from 1981 until 1986, when he joined Chemical.
A serious golfer who snared a golf scholarship as an undergraduate, Mr. Carson says he wishes he could play every weekend. Not likely. In addition to his demanding new job at Dean Witter, Mr. Carson has recently acquired another major responsibility: Jordan, a 3-month-old son born to his wife, Debra.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Economy Is In/Out of Woods

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FORECASTING, the economic wits say, is difficult especially about the future. But these days you can't even put much faith in descriptions of the present.
Depending on which professional is doing the appraisal, the American economy is now: A) Grinding slowly ahead for the third straight quarter but carrying such heavy regulatory and other burdens that the recovery is glacial; B) Turning down again after an aborted, post-Iraq recovery; C) Still gripped by a recession that is now the longest since World War II. 
 Don't know quite what to make of this? Want somebody in authority to help get your bearings? Well, George Bush told voters in New Hampshire last week that the economy was in "free fall," a statement far more pessimistic than any made by his advisers -- some of whom wouldn't acknowledge the onset of recession until it was six months old.
Candidates are expected to apply political spin, but what is one to make of a Presidential statement, later asserted to be merely "rhetorical," that accentuates the negative? It's quite possible, some economists say, that gross domestic product will be positive for the fourth quarter when the Commerce Department publishes the results next week.
Economists, of course, have long disagreed about economic prospects, much of this having to do with their judgment about the starting point as well as the relative strength and importance of the forces at work on the economy.
The latest survey of 48 respondents by Blue Chip Economic Indicators shows the consensus predicting growth in G.D.P. this year of 1.6 percent but with one predicting 4 percent growth and one predicting modest contraction.
But economists at least tend to look at the same group of variables, such things as personal incomes, inventory levels, interest rates and plans by industry to invest in modernization.
Ask corporate executives about how things are shaping up, however, and the stress will be elsewhere. They focus on orders, backlogs, taxes, regulations, profits and factors peculiar to their industry. Also of importance, however, is the fact that corporate people generally don't consider a recession over until all lost ground has been regained. To the economist, however, recovery begins much earlier, when things start to improve even if business is still 20 percent below pre-recession levels.
Another source of confusion is the statistics themselves. Some, such as housing starts and first-time claims for unemployment insurance, gyrate wildly despite efforts to adjust them for recurring seasonal factors. There is also the question of adjusting for inflation, which for 1991 retail sales was the difference between the smallest gain in 30 years or the biggest decline in 11 years.
Then there are such things as demographics, droughts and oil shocks. The current unemployment rate, for example, would be considerably higher than 7.1 percent if the labor force were growing at the rapid pace of the early 1980's, when joblessness during the steepest postwar recession surpassed 10.5 percent.
One also needs to keep in mind that some statistical series, such as building permits, tend to move in advance of the economy as a whole, while others, such as the prime interest rate and the unemployment rate, lag behind it. Industrial production is one of the main coincident measures but it, too, can be misleading such as in December when the index fell again but only because exceptionally warm weather curbed output at utilities.
While G.D.P. is generally used to summarize economic performance, attempts are occasionally made to combine indicators to provide a more revealing bottom line. One was the "misery index" devised by the economist Arthur M. Okun that simply added the inflation and unemployment rates. At around 10 the misery index is scarcely half the level it reached in the late Carter and early Reagan years. Another, a 10-item composite dubbed the Economic Performance Index, has been proposed by Republican members of the Joint Economic Commmittee.
The vast array of data on the economy, much of it conflicting or at odds with one's own anecdotal evidence, often seems to defy attempts to make the pieces part of a coherent whole -- at least one tied to reality rather than ideological predilection.
Yet one thing that does seem fairly clear to many analysts these days is that the economy is not as bad as is widely perceived. One of the many possible explanations for this is the fact that unlike previous downturns the present one has caused heavy and probably permanent loss of jobs among white-collar workers. Another is that the pain is concentrated on the East and West Coasts, which largely escaped the forced restructuring of the Rust Belt a decade ago.
Since the news media -- purveyors of the mostly bad news -- are housed mainly where things are worst, David Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill offers one obvious solution: "Relocate all the reporters," he suggests, "from Washington and New York to Minneapolis."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
New on the Laser Menu: Potato Skins, Well Done

 BODY:
A research lab in Ohio is using sophisticated laser technology in the service of one of the most mundane culinary tasks: peeling potatoes.
Battelle Memorial Institute, a research laboratory in Columbus, has devised a way to use lasers to burn the skin off potatoes instantly. "You just see a little puff of vapor, and there is a naked potato," said Dr. William McComis, Battelle's projects manager for food science and engineering. "It's a fascinating thing to watch." 
 The project was done on behalf of H. J. Heinz's Ore-Ida division. Ore-Ida's peeling currently involves putting 900 pounds of potatoes into a pressure cooker the size of cement mixer. When the steam is released, the skins are literally blown off by the rapid drop in pressure. But along with the skin goes almost 10 percent of the potato.
The process also creates a troublesome byproduct, a grayish-brown gruel with the viscosity of hot peanut butter. "Right now, they pay pig farmers to haul it away," Dr. McComis said.
To solve these problems, Dr. McComis's team turned to lasers, inspired by a fellow researcher who had success using a laser to strip paint from metal.
Bouncing its beam off the mirrored facets of a revolving wheel, the laser creates an arc of light that quickly scans the surface of the potato, burning off the skin without cooking the potato. The beam heats the skin to about 1,000 degrees, leaving only a trace of carbon residue.
The process is only an experiment now, peeling one potato at a time. To make the technique commercially feasible would require three $1 million industrial-strength lasers, the type most often used to weld or slice neatly through slabs of metal. Directing beams at each potato from three sides, the lasers would be able to peel 30 potatoes a second as they raced by on a conveyor.
Because the price of lasers is slowly dropping, Mr. McComis hopes the process will eventually be economical. To show off the additional utility of the process, the Battelle scientists turned the laser on other foods and vegetables of special interest to Heinz. As it turned out, the skin of large tunas destined for Heinz's Starkist cans proved too uneven -- thick scales on the dorsal section, thin skin over the belly -- for the lasers to work effectively.
But Mr. McComis found an application that should have great appeal to the giant ketchup company. "It works beautifully on tomatoes," he said.

HEADLINE: It's Time to Come Home, Now: Those Little Local Spots Are Back

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
ROLL out the red-checked tablecloths. The little place around the corner is back. The neighborhood restaurant that isn't too fancy, isn't too expensive and isn't too far away.
There has never been a shortage of these places in New York City. In 1925, George S. Chappell noted in "The Restaurants of New York" that every side street "bristles with small restaurants, neighborhood places which care for their particular section." Their mellow, side-street glow is eclipsed by the dazzle along the avenues whenever cash flows freely in the city and big restaurants boom. But when the glitz dims, the local joints remain. Or, they are reinvented. 
 For every luxury restaurant extinguished by the current economy, it seems that a small, inexpensive place has taken root. Some are family-owned and mirror their locale. Others are ersatz, shamelessly courting leaner pocketbooks with price-slashing, and countering a sense of economic and social ennui with nostalgic decor and throwback cooking. The red-checked tablecloth is to New Yorkers what his ragged blanket is to Linus.
Willies, a pub at 1426 Third Avenue (81st Street) that was converted to the upscale Malabar's in the 1980's, recently reverted to its previous incarnation, with the old tablecloths: Business has doubled.
"People walk by and see those cloths and, I'm telling you, girls, it's amazing," Cathy Messina, a waitress at Willies, said to two customers recently. "They reel around and come running in."
Caring is the unifying principle among the city's busiest restaurants today. "In the 80's we were building huge spaces that awed people," said Sam Lopata, the restaurant designer. "Restaurateurs can't afford to awe customers now, so we build cheaper, more intimate dining rooms and beef up the personal involvement instead. Soothing and caring has replaced aweing and performing."
Austere faux marbre is out, he said. Wood walls are in. The price of padded armchairs or architect-designed seating can't be amortized on dinner checks any more; mismatched kitchen chairs give a different sort of comfort.
"You want to create the illusion of something that has endured long enough to have nicotine stains on the ceiling," Mr. Lopata said. "You want to create a sepia photograph that people can place themselves in. It is reassuring."
The yen for reassurance may be what's turned stretches of some neighborhoods into yesteryear. In Sunnyside, Queens, new-old Irish pubs, like Sidetracks and Bliss Street Station, are popping up and packing them in. Along Washington Street in Hoboken, N.J., new Italian restaurants like Amanda's and Cella Luna recall the old spaghetti joints. It is tough to walk more than two blocks in Greenwich Village without confronting a new-old cafe.
Today's old haunts seem to fall into three basic categories. The Bar and Grill is a "Hey, guy," slap-on-the-back kind of place. The Cafe tends toward understatement and empathy. The My Place, usually denoted by homey names like Vince & Eddie's or Mi Cocina, is mom-like, which often means the best cooking.
The Bar and Grills, like Joe's Bar and Grill in the Village, Luke's Bar and Grill on the Upper East Side and Willies, are packed with a "pub meets the frat house" crowd. Customers trade Armanis for Gap wear. In Bar and Grill vernacular, "good food" means "lots and cheap." Martell's, a pub that originally opened 30 years ago at 200 East 83d Street, serves a barely passable chicken pot pie and a bowl of chili that wouldn't make it to the semifinals of any chili contest, but the place, which was recently rebuilt after a fire, is jammed.
"It's not as cool as it used to be," said Laura Jenson, 39, an accountant who grew up in the neighborhood. Since the restaurant has been renovated, she said, "It's as if somebody opened a Martell's in a mall."
But she keeps coming back. "I love the people," she said. "My husband and I come at least twice a week."
When he renovated, Joseph Smith, the restaurant's owner, tried to keep the feel of the old place. "I had a new tin ceiling made so the place would look old," he said. And when it comes to customers' names, his recall, as any Bar and Grill aficionado would say, is "awesome." His beef and barley soup might be too salty, but on New Year's Eve Mr. Smith got five standing ovations.
At Joe's Bar and Grill, at 142 West 10th Street, the meatloaf is only O.K. and the salmon so-so, but every few weeks the place seems to spontanteously combust into neighborhood gatherings. Sunday nights' "soup and sandwich" dinner at Joe's is a flashback to Bohemia and bluejeans.
Bar and Grills have sprouted all over but the Upper East Side remains the heart of Bar and Grill country. "We have a whole slew of young professionals who party in this neighborhood," said Joe Salvato, manager of Willies.
That slew's best mirror is Luke's Bar and Grill, a wood-paneled pub that opened last year at 1394 Third Avenue (80th Street) and has kept a full house nightly with a bigger and better burger, big salads, a decent bowl of spaghetti and an average check of $15. Luigi Militello, the restaurant's manager, said, "They come back because I know their names and I don't make a big deal out of dinner."
This no-big-deal subversiveness in kitchens on the city's side streets sends a shiver through the citadels of chic. Discussing the scaling down of local restaurants in an interview last year, Gilbert LeCoze, the chef and owner of Le Bernardin, said: "It will be the death of cuisine. A chef cannot afford to imagine and create on a $20 check average."
But while they may not have invented a new culinary genre, the cooks in Cafe and My Place restaurants often turn out fine versions of familiar dishes.
"It's reassuring to eat quiche Lorraine again," said Jon Riley, a 47-year-old investment banker who was eating at Tartine's, a tiny cafe at 253 West 11th Street. The cramped storefront, which opened in December, is small, and has lots of single diners reading over dinner. Let the Bar and Grills foster an esprit de corps through Super Bowl parties. At Cafes, group participation is more like group therapy, heavy on the support factor.
"I'm afraid he's overwhelmed," worried a guest who had been waiting for a croque-monsieur (made on brioche here, and very good) for nearly an hour on a recent week night at Tartine's.
"He only has six burners back there," nodded the woman at the next table, empathetically glancing from her book to the kitchen door.
"Would it be easier if we just had the onion soup and spinach salad?" asked one of two gentlemen sharing a table in the opposite corner of the cafe.
The chef, Thierry Rorchard, opened Tartine's with his partner, Jean-Francois Bernard, a pastry chef, after several decades of working in large French restaurants in New York. He said he hadn't gotten used to "doing everything myself." But the soups, sandwiches, omelets and beef mignonette are almost always good. The check is always about $10 for dinner. And the neighborhood has embraced Mr. Rorchard and Tartine's in a strong, protective hug. Some call ahead to see if he needs them to stop for milk, lemons or parsley on the way over to dinner.
The Cafe is widely imitated throughout the city. But the Village remains its epicenter. Anglers and Writers, a charming jumble of mismatched antiques that opened last year at 420 Hudson Street (St. Luke's Place), is a place where neighbors linger for hours.
"We look lived-in, not fabricated," said the owner, Craig Bero. One couple who had been regulars before moving to the Upper West Side now write him postcards. "They miss me; I miss them," said Mr. Bero, who also owns the Village Atelier on Hudson Street. "That's what a neighborhood cafe is about."
The Atelier, which opened three years ago at No. 436, was an advance guard in the recent wave of My Place restaurants. It looks like an idealized farmhouse in Wisconsin, which is where Mr. Bero grew up. The pan-fried brook trout and pike, game and the pies that his mother, Charlotte Bero, bakes are, too, the best of the Midwest. My Places always bear the imprimatur of the owner and are usually efforts to bring "back where I came from" into "where I live now."
In a city of strangers, My Places are therefore tough to resist. Today, they are the most crowded -- and most frequently imitated -- restaurants in town. If a neighborhood restaurant feels more like a business than home, it is a My Place pretender. If, on the other hand, every detail is intimate and idiosyncratic, you've entered an authentic My Place.
Don't be put off my by noise. "I can't believe all these people," said Marzena Hurgado, who with her husband, Jose, the former executive chef of Cinco Di Mayo, opened Mi Cocina at 57 Jane Street (Hudson Street) in August. The cooking is highly personalized Mexican fare. There are tender tamales and Oaxacan chicken soup, fresh shrimp in a mellow, roasted tomato sauce, and fresh flour tortillas wrapping grilled vegetables. The menu says "service by Marzena."
"We just wanted to do a place our way, very personal," Mrs. Hurgado said. "We aren't flashy. They have to look for us. And they find us."
Uptown at a My Place gone berserk, Eddie Schoenfeld, proprietor of Vince & Eddie's at 70 West 69th Street, was facing a line of 10 people who were waiting for tables, waiting to order the onion tart or white bean soup, the lamb shank with dried cherry sauce or roast chicken. Dinner can top the $25 mark. The crowds keep growing.
"We knew if we cooked just a little up the scale from meatloaf, and made people feel cozy, we'd be fine," said Mr. Schoenfeld, who has run restaurants for several decades. "But what we are looking at here is a neighbhorhood joint that's turned into a destination dining spot."
Mr. Schoenfeld, in an entrepreneurial flurry, has recently opened Fishin' Eddie at 73 West 71st Street, and plans in three months to open Chop Suey Looey's Litchi Lounge in midtown and a string of Chinese take-out kitchens. He'd like to take personal credit for his business success, but he can't.
"What people want most right now is to be taken care of and that's what I've always done the best," he said. "But in another era, you'd never find this many people wanting to be taken care of this much."

HEADLINE: Some Neighborhood Haunts Go Back 120 Years, Some Only 40

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
THEY are harbors of serenity in the feverish metropolis. You won't find them in the trend-tracking urban magazines, nor will their chefs be lionized in lists of up-and-coming stars. And the chances of spotting Warren Beatty or Michelle Pfeiffer chewing the fat at the bar are about equal to encountering Saddam Hussein on the IRT.
These are the original neighborhood haunts. They are steady, family- owned, economical pub-style restaurants. The clientele is so loyal that if someone does not show up at the appointed hour, the owner calls to see if anything is wrong. 
 "I've been coming here since 1943 and not a day goes by that I don't stop in," said Alice Mulligan, a Greenwich Village resident, who was having an early evening cocktail with a friend at Gene's, a vintage Italian restaurant on West 11th Street in the Village.
Such steadfast patrons can be found at all of New York City's neighborhood haunts. One of the oldest and most enduring is Billy's. Dating to 1870, originally on First Avenue near 56th Street, Billy's was forced to move twice: in 1880 to the southeast corner of 56th Street and First Avenue, then in 1966, to the present location, three blocks south.
The Billy's of today retains its Old New York charm, with an ornately carved mahogany bar illuminated by an original gas lantern, red-checked tablecloths and menus posted on the wall. Almost all customers get a hug from the hostess upon entering, and the genial, wisecracking waiters are studies in quiet efficiency.
"We have the children and grandchildren of Billy's longtime customers now coming in with their own children," said Joan Condron Borkowski, the owner and great-granddaughter of the founder. "That's so nice to see."
A major appeal of restaurants like Billy's is their consistency. You can go there one day and return 10 years later and find the exact same decor, same menu, same crowd and same staff. "It's a second home," Mrs. Borkowski said. On a recent weeknight, Joseph Donadic, a waiter there for 30 years, estimated that 95 percent of the dinner crowd were regulars.
The traditional American steakhouse menu at Billy's is the same as it was in the Eisenhower Administration, with just a few contemporary concessions. "I fought my father for four years to add vegetables to the menu, and he finally gave in," Mrs. Borkowski said. Pasta was the great innovation of 1991, the result of lobbying by some regulars. Among the other selections are roast prime rib ($19.25), sauteed calf's liver ($15.50), salisbury steak ($15) and broiled fillet of sole ($15). The fare is simple, fresh and copious.
Fanelli's Cafe opened at the corner of Prince and Mercer Streets in lower Manhattan in 1872, just two years after Billy's. "It was originally called Prince Cafe and owned by a guy named Nicholas Volpe," said the current owner, Hans Noe. "I learned that from a signature etched on the glass doors."
Mr. Noe, who has owned the bar and restaurant since 1983, said the second owners, Harry Green and Joseph Israel, kept it until 1915, when a former boxer named Michael Fanelli took over.
If Nicholas Volpe were to walk into Fanelli's Cafe today he would feel right at home. He would pass through the original etched glass doors, shuffle over the same tile floor, take a seat at the same magnificent carved mahogany bar, order a locally brewed beer and maybe dine on shepherd's pie. The only difference might be the wall covered with photos of famous pugilists, an addition of Mr. Fanelli in the World War I era.
Fanelli's appears to be a hangout for struggling young SoHo artists and musicians, as well as families who crowd around the formica-topped tables in the back dining room. It's hard to stickle over a mountain of food covering every inch of the plate that costs $9.75. Burgers, meatloaf, chili, pizza, grilled chicken breast, pasta and shellfish platters are the specialties of the maison.
While many upscale restaurants have been struggling through the recession, Fanelli's Cafe has continued to grow every year, Mr. Noe said.
Donahue's, a steakhouse and bar on the Upper East Side, is a period piece in its own right, though the period is not 19th century but rather 1950's. The long, rectangular bar is a time warp with its wood paneling, tile floor, television overhead and eerie blue lights emanating from behind the liquor shelf. The back dining room has 10 black vinyl booths, overhead fans, and nautical art on the wall.
Martin Donahue opened the restaurant in 1950, and today it is run by his son, Michael, and his granddaughter Maureen. "We get a lot of writers and antiques people who live in the neighborhood," Maureen Donahue said. "Teddy White was in here four times a week. He was like my stepfather."
Camaraderie is one draw of a place like Donahue's, and so, too, is economy. On the menu are items like Hungarian goulash ($9.50), eggplant Parmesan ($10.50), sirloin steak ($15.95) and pork chops ($12.25).
"A lot of these people go to Le Cirque and other fancy places on weekends," Miss Donahue surmised. "During the week they come here to be easy and relaxed."
Gene's, on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village, resembles the type of Italian restaurant that existed in every suburban town in the 1950's and 1960's: smoke-stained murals, big mirrors, sundry oil paintings, blue-green floor tile, discolored soundproof tile in the ceiling, symmetrical rows of tables, and friendly waiters in short jackets. Opened in 1919, it has been a social and gastronomic anchor for the neighborhood ever since.
"We never change anything on the menu," declared Albino Ramirez, who with Concepcion Domingez, has owned Gene's for 12 years. "But of course, if a customer wants something special, we will make it."
On the extensive menu are linguine with clam sauce ($12.95), baked ziti Sicilian style ($8.75), shrimp marinara ($13.95), broiled lamb chops ($16.95) and veal piccata ($13.95) and more. Mr. Ramirez said that he could offer inexpensive food because his overhead is low and his business is holding steady.
On a weekday afternoon, three regulars were getting a head start on cocktail hour while chatting with Mr. Ramirez. "These trendy places that open uptown, you go once and that's it," said Alice Mulligan, who lives nearby. Her friend, Sheila Thorpe of Ridgewood, N.J., who says she has been coming to Gene's for years, adds: "Whenever I come into the city, I make a point of coming here. That's unusual."
Mr. Ramirez, a small, stout man with a slender mustache, beamed.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Making a Movie Take the Rap For the Violence That It Attracts

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
The type of individual who would brandish a semi-automatic weapon at a movie theater where Ernest Dickerson's "Juice" is playing (as someone did in Commack, L.I., the other evening) is the best argument for the reasonableness of what Mr. Dickerson has to say. His film addresses the peer pressures at work on a group of Harlem high school students, one of whom eventually develops a taste for murderous mayhem and viciously attacks his friends.
The irrational bravado and macho posturing displayed by Bishop (Tupac Shakur), the film's bad-boy character, are undoubtedly shared by those gun-toting, knife-wielding moviegoers who have put "Juice" in the news. In the wake of similar violent outbreaks surrounding the openings of Mario Van Peebles's "New Jack City" and John Singleton's "Boyz N the Hood," it's not surprising to find this happening again. All these films address the frustration faced by young urban black men, and all have become lightning rods for that frustration. So bad news is being delivered, both in the lobby and on the screen. 
 When that happens, the messenger tends to take the blame. But can "Juice" be held accountable for the behavior it has provoked? The film observes Bishop's actions from the viewpoint of Q (Omar Epps), who is worried and frightened by what he sees and eventually renounces the recklessness of Bishop's actions. Mr. Dickerson, who both wrote and directed the film, depicts Bishop as a loose cannon and condemns him by the time the story is over. Fundamentally, "Juice" leaves no question as to where its values lie.
On its surface, which involves a rap soundtrack and a fairly lighthearted attitude toward petty crime, this film says something slightly different. (So does its advertising art, which underscores Bishop's toughness, not Q's fears. Obviously, frightened young heroes don't sell tickets the way tough ones do.) Although no more exploitative than "Boyz N the Hood," which decried gang violence in South Central Los Angeles but still felt the need to depict some, "Juice" sends a mixed message just by illustrating the dangers it deplores. Like the English rock star played by Eric Bogosian in "Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll," the one who speaks so invitingly of all the debauchery he has given up, "Juice" conveys a vivid sense of the temptations its characters try to resist.
For the portion of the audience that has created disruptions in theaters where "Juice" is playing, those things must loom disproportionately large. Viewers who grew up heavily influenced by violent films and television shows, by rap records and MTV, are bound to have short attention spans and a taste for easy excitement. They may well miss the subtlety of the antidrug attitudes of a "New Jack City" if they pay more attention to the exploitative touches -- the shootouts, flashy jewelry, fast women, stacks of money and close-ups of crack vials -- that help frame the message.
At a time when black American film makers have achieved new prominence, and when an important creative boom is under way among them, they can't be faulted for matching white Hollywood's standards of violence. None of these films makes crime any more alluring than it has long been in movies about the Mafia, and none is any more violent than a vehicle for Bruce Willis or Arnold Schwarzenegger. Even by comparison with rap music video, which is currently under fire for Public Enemy's depiction of an assassination plot against state officials in Arizona (because that state has not yet endorsed Martin Luther King Day as a holiday), "Juice" seems comparatively responsible and tame.
But a film like this does not simply speak for itself, any more than a "J. F. K." or a "Thelma and Louise" does. Whenever a movie arrives amid a blizzard of attendant news stories, its message tends to be distorted and oversimplified, a process that in the case of "Juice" has proved more dangerous than usual. "Juice" now joins other black-oriented films that have indirectly incited their audiences to deadly violence, and the coincidence must be taken seriously. Those who distribute and advertise such films are now forced to anticipate the possibility that the film's meanings will be misunderstood.
The regrettable but necessary step of hiring extra security guards for theaters playing "Juice," an expense that will be absorbed by Paramount Pictures, introduces an air of economic reality into the problems raised by this film's release. The more responsible a distributor feels for the climate in which a film is shown, the calmer that climate is likely to be. And film makers addressing themselves to volatile viewers may wind up thinking harder about the unintended messages their work conveys. Films have every right to mirror society's troubles. They also have an obligation to avoid making those troubles any worse.

HEADLINE: America-Bashing, Not All False

 BODY:
First came President Bush's clumsy, embarrassing effort to bully the Japanese into buying unwanted autos and parts. Now Yoshio Sakurauchi, Speaker of Japan's lower house, gratuitously and falsely berates U.S. workers as lazy and illiterate. As apologetic Japanese officials realize, these views could not have spewed out at a worse time, with overtones of trade war already audible in the Presidential campaign. 'Sneak Attack!' yesterday's New York Post shouted, voicing the offense many Americans are apt to feel.
Both countries have an urgent interest in halting such bilateral blame-mongering quickly. And it is in Americans' particular interest to recognize why Speaker Sakurauchi's comments sting. However coarse, they come close to some truth. 
 Mr. Bush's performance in Tokyo was rightly condemned by U.S. commentators as soon as the shock of his flu attack receded. Now it's Mr. Saku rauchi's turn for reproach. Speaking to constituents Sunday, he reportedly said that the source of America's competitive problems "is the inferior quality of U.S. labor. . . . U.S. workers are too lazy. They want high pay without working." About 30 percent "cannot even read. . . . So managers cannot convey their orders in written form. Therefore, they get a high ratio of bad parts."
As a former Foreign Minister, Mr. Sakurauchi ought to know that illiteracy in the U.S. is closer to 5 than to 30 percent and that American labor productivity remains higher than in Japan. How diligently, Americans might ask, did this experienced politician work on his research?
America's work force is not the problem. Auto workers who want to work hard but instead face widespread layoffs are entitled to feel offended. Meanwhile other Americans, less threatened, also bridle at Mr. Sakurauchi's outburst. They see Japan's economy growing while America sputters in recession.
Mistakenly, they blame bilateral trade deficits. They are not mistaken to wonder why this country, with its faith in success and upward mobility, now seems to be steadily losing ground. They recognize that some things are wrong: Americans need to consume less and save more. They need to revitalize management and morale. They need to adapt production to world market needs.
All that is harder than exchanging epithets, but promises far happier results. President Bush and his crew of auto executives did Americans no favor by trying to press import quotas on a resentful Japan. Japanese politicians have every right to complain about U.S. blame-mongering, but not by blame-mongering themselves. Americans have every right to resent crude criticisms from Japan, but not to forget that the main problems are made in the U.S.A.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Who Should Liberate Iraq?

 BODY:
Should America encourage Iraqis to overthrow Saddam Hussein? Yes. Should it advertise that any new Iraqi government could expect an early easing of the international economic embargo and generous reconstruction aid? Yes again. But should the U.S. commit itself in advance to give armed support to any group that challenges the Iraqi dictator, as Saudi Arabia now urges? Under present circumstances, the best answer is no.
The world has every right to hold Saddam Hussein accountable to international law. But replacing even the most obnoxious regimes, provided their cruelties are confined to their own territories, is best left to the people directly concerned. 
 Besides, a military blank check might have disastrous consequences. The offer could be taken up by an Iraqi cabal no less brutal than the present Government. A rebel coalition with weak domestic support could get bogged down in protracted fighting. Kurdish or Shiite rebels could provoke wider regional war.
A year ago, the issues were different. Saddam Hussein had occupied Kuwait, in defiance of U.N. resolutions. His deployments threatened Saudi Arabia; his statements showed he was trying to use force to control oil prices and supply. And, as postwar inspections revealed, he was assembling a nuclear capability in violation of Iraq's Nonproliferation Treaty commitments.
Compare that with the situation today. Iraq's forces have been thrown out of Kuwait and badly mauled. They pose no immediate threat to anyone outside Iraq. An effective international embargo prevents Baghdad from rebuilding its military might. And the Security Council's cease-fire resolution, with the implicit threat of military action, has shut down nuclear, biological and chemical weapons development.
At the same time, Saddam Hussein's survival in power is a political embarrassment to President Bush, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the U.N. coalition -- and a nightmare for the Iraqi people.
Kurdish families are exposed to the ravages of winter in the open. Suspected dissidents face mass executions and other forms of state terror. Millions of Iraqis have been condemned to malnutrition and illness by their Government's callous rejection of U.N. terms for humanitarian relief.
If those conditions result in a rebellion with good prospects for success, and with a reasonable likelihood of setting Iraq on a more constructive course, there may be a case for the U.S. to provide limited logistical support.
But any decision to return to Iraq in force needs to be preceded, as before, by U.N. and Congressional deliberation. Iraqis deserve better than a quick fix; Americans deserve better than a campaign season surprise.

HEADLINE: Here's a Way To Fight Japan

BYLINE: By Joseph I. Lieberman; Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, is Senator from Connecticut.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Congress will soon be asked to cut taxes to combat the recession. Cuts for the middle class would be fair and might encourage more consumer spending. But the economy needs more than a quick fix -- an extra $300 in every middle class family's bank account. It needs a large-scale, aggressive, long-term Government-business partnership for growth.
People worry that the recession is not just another cyclical slide from which we will bounce back. They fear, correctly, that unless America takes fundamental action, we will never improve our living standard. We will keep slipping because of our social and economic weaknesses and the strengths of our European and Asian competitors. 
 The Speaker of the lower house of the Japanese Parliament has characterized our workforce as "too lazy" to compete with Japan. We must reply the way we replied to Nikita Khrushchev's threat, "We will bury you," and again prove to the world and ourselves that we are still capable of the hard work that has always been the path to success in America.
This means we must urgently deal with our weaknesses: the deterioration of our manufacturing sector, our low rate of investment, slowness in bringing new products to market, limited nondefense research and development, the lack of coordinated public and private planning and investment, our inadequate education system and a declining work ethic.
Incentives such as capital gains tax cuts, investment tax credits and credits for research and development and for worker education and training are necessary to unleash private capital and creativity. They should be part of an overhauled tax system that promotes long-term low-cost capital for sectors needing growth, particularly manufacturing.
Developing joint planning and action with business means breaking through ideological barriers. The U.S. has never had a pure laissez-faire economy; since our founding, we have had a mixed economy that relies on market forces as much as possible but also uses Government for economic growth and creating jobs -- as in aerospace and agriculture, for example.
The Federal Government should reorganize such agencies as the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and the office of the U.S. Trade Representative, and charge them with stimulating economic expansion. They might be coordinated by an economic growth adviser to the President or all be brought under the Commerce Department, which could be renamed the Department of Economic Growth.
We can focus on the 22 technologies the White House has designated as critical to growth and then did nothing about. They include advanced materials, computer-integrated manufacturing and biotechnology. While investment tax credits and capital gains tax cuts would help some businesses and entrepreneurs in these sectors, other industries will need low-interest loans or Federal investment to insure that foreign companies, whose governments support them, do not have an unfair advantage.
In alliance with business, the Government should take as much as possible of the $22.5 billion spent yearly at Federal laboratories and refocus it on commercial and industrial products and technological development. Such cooperation can keep America at the leading edge of breakthroughs in energy, medicine and other high-tech fields.
We must give our exporting businesses the support Asian and European governments give their companies. This means more and better financing authority for the Export-Import Bank, tougher trade negotiations that emphasize the opening of markets and, if needed, agreements that result in an increase in specified U.S. exports when a trade imbalance persists.
And we should dramatically improve support for scientific, technical and engineering education and training by expanding tax credits for employers providing such programs and creating apprenticeships with business in public schools.
If the Administration continues to dismiss such pragmatic steps, on the ground that the Government has no business picking winners and losers, the losers will be the millions of Americans whose jobs will go to foreign workers in countries where governments understand their responsibility to expand domestic businesses in a competitive global economy.

HEADLINE: No Time to Be Stingy With Russia

 BODY:
Western Foreign Ministers gathering today in Washington need to concentrate on one urgent task: arranging a substantial transfusion of aid to Russia and a beleaguered Boris Yeltsin.
Europeans, especially Germany, have been quick to act. The U.S. by contrast has been slow and stingy, in part because foreign aid is politically unpopular. But without more aid, Russia could slip back into autocracy. 
 The Bush Administration annoyed many Europeans by convening the conference. Washington seemed to be seeking maximum credit for a modest effort. The Administration could put things right, and enhance its influence in Europe, by shouldering its fair share of the burden.
All the former Soviet republics face a treacherous transition from Communism. Russia, by its size and strength, is critical to its neighbors' success. But its prospects are uncertain. Mr. Yeltsin is surrounded by rivals and advisers ready to counter economic crisis and popular discontent with authoritarianism. Furthermore, most of the preconditions were not in place when Mr. Yeltsin freed prices, like banking and tax systems and tight money. And no economist knows whether hoarders and producers will move enough goods to market to halt spiraling inflation.
No sooner did Mr. Yeltsin take the leap than his rivals began backtracking. Their distaste for the disorder of markets and democracy is exceeded only by a dangerous nostalgia for the strong hand.
Aid, carefully targeted and delivered, can calm public anxiety and give reforms time to work. It can allow Russia to downsize a restive Red Army by supplementing severance pay. It can help convert military to civilian production.
Germany was quick to provide aid and credits. It sent much-needed food and medicine. And it is spending substantial sums to build housing back home for Soviet troops, the price for their withdrawal from eastern Germany.
Washington demeaned these efforts as self-interested -- as if helping the former Soviet Union transform itself and demobilize the Red Army does not serve America's interests as much as Germany's. Washington also contends it has helped as much as Bonn. Yet by any reasonable standard -- aid per capita or aid as a proportion of G.N.P. -- the American effort doesn't measure up.
The idea of increasing foreign aid may seem to challenge America's mounting preoccupation with troubles at home. But the U.S. needs to assure tranquillity in Europe. And it can easily afford more aid once it cuts its bloated defense budget.
"Let Germany do it" is no answer to Russia's need. America will pay the price if it skimps now.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The $64 Question

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
It's hard to imagine, looking over New Jersey's new welfare legislation, that the people who designed it sought information or help from those who will be most affected by it.
Have they talked to the people who have pumped themselves up with job training programs and then been blindsided by the reality of the job market? Have they talked to the women on welfare who fear that if they go to work they will lose their children's health care coverage? Have they talked to those who have stayed on public assistance rather than take minimum wage jobs because they had no place to put their kids while they worked? 
 No one hears those voices. The poor are a losing franchise; even the Democratic candidates for President, some sounding suspiciously like Rockefeller Republicans, seem to have thrown them over to concentrate on the forgotten middle class. The voices of compassion are reedy and thin, replaced by those reflecting, sometimes overtly, sometimes subtly, the stereotypes: that the welfare rolls are filled with lazy people who maximize their drag on the public weal by spitting out a child a year.
In New Jersey the result is legislation, called the Family Development Initiative Act, that may be well meaning but is about as reality-based as "Star Trek."
The most controversial part of the package refuses additional benefits to women who have a child while enrolled in the welfare program. This plays to the notion that welfare mothers are having one baby after another, which is simply untrue; a family on welfare in New Jersey is slightly smaller than the state average.
And it suggests that poor women have kids for the money. Right now, a woman on welfare in New Jersey receives an additional $64 a month if she has another child, or around $2 a day. I'd like to propose a month during which all members of the legislature attempt to meet their daily nutritional needs on $2.
The list of groups objecting to that provision includes the New Jersey Catholic Conference and the National Organization for Women, the American Civil Liberties Union and the state Right to Life group. Bad legislation makes strange bedfellows. Supporters of the bill say that middle-class people don't get government subsidies for additional kids, conveniently ignoring tax credits and deductions. They argue that it will teach women on welfare responsibility, a kind of legislative "tough love" program.
What it will really do is teach a 3-year-old what it feels like to have an empty stomach.
The Family Development Initiative Act, signed yesterday by Gov. Jim Florio, allegedly a Democrat, requires that all welfare recipients attend school or job training or risk losing benefits. In theory this sounds fine, until you remember the state of the economy, even for the middle class. "The myth of a meritocracy has overshadowed the reality of available jobs," the New Jersey Council of Churches said in a statement opposing the legislation. Job training? Great. For what jobs?
The welfare system is a mess, and everyone knows it. When you meet a 16-year-old with a newborn who is the third generation of her matriarchal line to settle back into the quicksand of public assistance, you know that a system meant to get people back on their feet has instead cut many of them off at the knees.
And the solutions to welfare dependency are daunting: more emphasis on reducing teen-age pregnancy and the dropout rate, more education and training that targets the real needs of a changing job market, more innovative thinking about new ways to get people working, more initiatives for child care and health care.
Real welfare reform is going to require radical action, massive root changes, another war on poverty. And radical action requires big ideas, not $64 questions. One good way to begin is to talk to the strong, smart women who have as much contempt for the welfare system as any middle-class person could, but who find, simply put, that it is the only way they can manage to put peanut butter in the cupboard for their kids. Putting a lid on the peanut butter is an insulting and punitive way to show them that you want to improve their lives. They've probably got some better ideas if anyone's willing to listen.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
An Ad in Defense Of the Ad Deduction

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Proposals to cut the Federal deficit by lowering the deductions on advertising as a business expense have not made much progress over the last five years. But as President Bush's State of the Union address nears, the American Advertising Federation is not taking any chances.
In a pre-emptive strike against such a measure's inclusion in this year's budget package, the group has created an ad in the form of a letter to the President. It describes advertising as an "engine of economic growth" and goes on to say: "Like you, Mr. President, we want to help get America's economy started again. Incentives to advertise are incentives for growth." 
 Wally Snyder, the federation's president, said that The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal had agreed to run the ad and that other publications were still considering it. It is expected to appear tomorrow, five days before the address.
The advertising industry's tax status will "be threatened for the next several years as budgets are challenged and Government explores for new sources of revenue," Mr. Snyder added. "We feel like we really need to be pro-active on this issue."

HEADLINE: Japanese Trade Surplus Surged Last Year

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus has reversed course after a three-year decline, surging by 50 percent in 1991, the Government said today. The announcement is likely to fan increasing resentment in the United States and other nations upset because the surplus, they say, stems from Japan's adherence to unfair trade policies.
The Finance Ministry said that for the year, Japan sold $78.23 billion more goods overseas than it imported, compared with a $52.15 billion surplus in 1990. These preliminary figures were for what is called the customs-cleared trade surplus. The Government will later announce broader figures that include a variety of other costs of conducting trade, like transportation and insurance. Those inclusive figures are generally cited by economists when they discuss trade imbalances. 
 Because of the American recession, Japan's custom-cleared trade surplus with the United States rose only slightly, to $38.45 billion, from $37.95 billion in 1990. Economists said that inclusive of all trade costs Japan's surplus with the United States exceeded $43 billion, which is expected to be roughly three-quarters of the total United States trade deficit. Many expect that to rise much more quickly this year if the economy begins to recover and Americans buy more Japanese cars, television sets and the like.
 
Asian and European Expansion
 The surplus with the European Community jumped 48.1 percent and with other Asian countries it rose 43.2 percent, demonstrating a new resilience in Japan's trade policies. For one, it showed that exporters were able to make up for the slower growth in the United States and expand sharply their shipments to Asia and Europe.
Such a big jump in the politically sensitive figure also suggests that just days before an important meeting of the finance ministers of the leading industrial countries in Garden City, L.I., policy makers here and abroad may have to start over to find ways to shrink Japan's remarkably persistent trade imbalances. Already there is speculation that for the second time since 1985, the dollar will be engineered lower in what is effectively a devaluation against the yen.
The dollar has already declined slightly against the yen for the last year to the current level of about 123 yen to the dollar. However, that has shown no apparent benefit for America's trade deficit yet. "This is the 28th year in a row Japan has had a trade surplus," said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here with the securities brokerage arm of Deutsche Bank. "I think we have to conclude it is structural, and that the measures taken have not been effective."
Today's news also comes at the start of a Presidential campaign in which America's battered industrial competitiveness and trade deficit are becoming major issues, particularly after President Bush's troubled trade mission to Japan earlier this month.
 
Imports Rise Slightly
 In its report today, the Finance Ministry also said Japan's exports surged 9.6 percent, to $314.6 billion, while imports rose by a modest seven-tenths of a percent, to $236.4 billion, because of a slowdown in the Japanese economy.

HEADLINE: Japan Seeks Ways to Tame Stock Market

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Financial industry executives and officials, alarmed about the Japanese stock markets entering its its third year of a deep slump, are contemplating emergency measures that could reverse several years of liberalization and make it harder for foreign brokers to do business in Japan.
The measures under discussion range from introducing new restrictions on trading in stock index futures -- the principal source of profits for many foreign brokers in Japan -- to forming a huge fund with contributions from banks and securities houses to inflate share prices with concerted buying, a method last attempted tried here in the 1960's. 
 In a host of speeches, press conferences and leaks to the news media, officials of securities houses, industry associations and the authorities of the stock exchanges have made it clear in recent weeks that they do not intend simply to let market forces take their course.
Behind their discussions lies a fundamental question about whether Japan can turn back the clock and intervene to manage its financial markets in an era when capital flows around the globe with increasing freedom.
There is also a much quieter concern over the growing profitability of foreign brokerage houses here. They are gaining ground against their much larger but scandal-battered Japanese rivals, the so-called Big Four -- Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi.
In the first half of the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 6 of the 10 most- profitable firms here were foreign. Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley, which reap a substantial portion of their profits through program trading that involves stock index futures, occupied the third and fourth places.
The Nikkei index future, representing the value of 225 leading Japanese stocks, permits investors to bet on the market's general direction. In trading, American firms have used their technical advantages to earn tens of millions of dollars in Japan through computer-assisted trading strategies, including program trading.
Most traders and brokerage executives say that creation of a stock-buying fund to bolster prices would certainly fail because the market is simply too big to be propped up in this way. Nonetheless, a report on Wednesday by the Mainichi newspaper that such a plan had been discussed contributed to a sharp rebound in share prices. The Nikkei stock index rose 675.82 points on Wednesday, to 21,534.12. Today, the Nikkei was up 46.60 points, a little more than two-tenths of 1 percent, to 21,580.72.
Adding urgency is a decline that has brought the Nikkei from a peak of 38,915.87, on the last trading day of 1989, down almost to 20,000. Prices haved slid steadily this year. Many here believe that if the market falls through the 20,000 barrier, it will begin to damage the Japanese economy and perhaps cause panic selling.
Most industry executives are betting that the authorities will rein in trading in stock index futures, which some blame for the market's troubles.
Thus far, the American firms have been trying to work behind the scenes to block restrictions on their key business here. The possibility of new restrictions in the financial markets comes after President Bush tried to open other Japanese markets to American businesses.
 
Protection for Investors
The foreign firms say that futures trading merely reflects and helps investors protect against volatility and that restrictions are unwarranted.
"It's shooting the messenger," said Richard Greer, head of the Tokyo office of Baring Securities. "I don't think it would have much effect to restrict the futures market, and in fact, some of the recent measures to restrict it seem to have increased volatility."
Mr. Greer added that some trading had simply been driven to Singapore, where another version of the Nikkei stock index futures contract is traded.
Tomoko Aikawa, a spokeswoman for Nomura, confirmed reports that representatives of the Big Four held an emergency meeting on Tuesday to discuss market-bolstering measures.
Index futures trading, Ms. Aikawa said, "was a very important topic." Creating a fund to mop up stocks was discussed, but was not a serious possibility, she added.
"The end result was that they decided to form a working group to take up proposals for regulations and administrative things that could be changed to make it more convenient for the market and for investors," Ms. Aikawa said.
The Osaka Stock Exchange, where the key Nikkei futures are traded, has already made it more difficult and expensive to trade stock index futures. The margin, or downpayment, that an investor must make has risen from 9 percent in September 1988, to 30 percent as of last month. The margin rate was increased three times last year.
In addition, the exchanges have slowed down the pace at which prices can change, a practice that effectively suspends the stock index futures market when the underlying stock market is volatile. In the rally on Wednesday, traders said, the stock index futures market was suspended more than it was open.
 
Japanese Rush to Sell
Many experts insist that some of the measures could do more harm than good by making it more difficult for investors to move in and out of the market. They also say that what ails the Japanese stock market is not some technical problem with stock index futures but the Japanese themselves dumping shares with abandon.
According to the Tokyo Stock Exchange, institutional investors here were net sellers of 1.78 trillion yen, about $14.35 billion at current exchange rates, worth of stocks in 1991. Investment trusts, the Japanese equivalents of mutual funds, sold a net 1.52 trillion yen of stocks, while nonfinancial corporations sold 1.86 trillion yen worth and individuals sold a net 2.53 trillion yen in stocks.
The only big buyers are foreigner investors, who were net purchasers buyers of 5.62 trillion yen of Japanese shares last year.

HEADLINE: Bush to Press Congress to Approve $645 Million for Ex-Soviet Lands

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
At the start of a conference to discuss aid to the former Soviet Union, President Bush said today that he would ask Congress for $645 million in new aid for Russia and the other independent republics.
It is not clear whether Congress, under pressure in an election year to deal with domestic problems, will approve the assistance. 
 The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said he would be inclined to back the additional aid, but only if the President "will finally take the lead in selling it to the American people, explaining to them why it is in their self-interest and helping them to understand that this is not the end but the beginning if we are to seize this great moment."
The President made the announcement as he opened the 47-nation conference at the State Department, which was convened by the Bush Administration to better coordinate assistance of food and shelter for the new Commonwealth of Independent States. The new aid proposal seemed in reaction to criticism that his Administration had not done enough to assist the former Soviet republics.
By all accounts the atmosphere of the meeting was cordial and announcements on concrete steps for improving aid to the Commonwealth are expected Thursday.
 
Poor Distribution
 Among the more novel proposals made today was a suggestion by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany that the Western allies create an institution that would hire unemployed Soviet nuclear scientists to work on peaceful research and keep them from selling their services to hostile nations. Nevertheless, some of the tensions between the allies over how to help were also apparent.
The French representative, Elisabeth Guigou, Minister for European Affairs, said in her opening speech that the problem now is not the threat of famine in Russia and other republics, but "poorly organized distribution" systems on the ground, as well as corruption.
Implicitly criticizing Washington, she said that what is needed now is not another international conference or structure overseeing aid, but rather practical, on-site mechanisms to make sure that what is already available gets to those who need it.
Ms. Guigou said France regretted that Russia and other former republics were barred by Washington from attending the conference -- on the ground that they would compete with one another for more aid -- "since they are the practical actors, and it is through joint efforts with them that our emergency aid will be most effective."
Although Mr. Bush said the conference would not be a pledging session, complaints from European countries like Germany and France that Washington had to lead with its pocketbook if it wanted to be treated as the leader in the coordination effort, intensified pressure on the President to step up the Administration's assistance.
Addressing the European, Asian, Japanese and Arab foreign ministers gathered around a single conference table in the State Department's Benjamin Franklin Room for the two-day meeting, Mr. Bush said: "Let us bring equal commitment to the challenge of helping to build and sustain democracy and economic freedom in the former U.S.S.R. just as we did to winning the cold war. Let us help the people throughout the independent states to make the leap from Communism to democracy, from command economies to free markets, from authoritarianism, to liberty."
Saying that the "U.S. cannot and will not falter at the moment that these new states are struggling to embrace the very ideals that America was founded to foster and preserve," Mr. Bush said he was proposing that Congress approve $645 million in new humanitarian and technical assistance. He did not specify where this money would come from.
The new aid would include $585 million for humanitarian and technical aid, $25 million for medical aid, $20 million for training in private farming and farm businesses and $15 million for development.
 
Will Congress Approve?
 The new assistance, which would not have to be repaid, would put the total American contribution to the Soviet aid effort at $5 billion. Most of that $5 billion, though, are farm credits for the republics to purchase American grain and other foodstuffs. Such credits benefit American farmers and must, by law, be repaid.
Whether Congress will approve the new aid in an election year is unclear, and could depend on whether the money comes out of the defense budget or the existing foreign aid budget or involves a new outlay of cash.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat from Connecticut and chairman of the House Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, reacted negatively to Mr. Bush's request, saying: "I think that the President needs to focus on the United States. The Germans and the countries that are in better economic shapes should be putting together the packages. They'll be hard pressed to pass any additional aid without first dealing with the domestic issues."
But other key Democrats who have long been pressing the Administration to take advantage of the historical opportunity to transform the Soviet Union, were more positive about the proposal.
 
'Absent at the Creation'
 "A new world is being born and the United States is perilously close to being absent at the creation," said Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Deleware Democrat who chairs the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Europe. "It will be tragic indeed if a year from now, we find ourselves mired in a debate over 'Who lost Russian democracy?' "
There still seemed to be, though, a large gap between the historical task that President Bush outlined and Washington's contribution, which many experts say must quickly go beyond humanitarian aid into the more far-reaching economic assistance, like a multibillion-dollar currency stabilization fund of the sort used to underpin Poland's move to free markets.
 
Producing Work Plans
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who suggested the conference in a last-minute addition to a foreign-policy speech, said in his opening remarks that the ministers should confine themselves to trying to reach two immediate goals, neither of which have been fully explained yet to reporters or the public.
First, five working groups have been established to coordinate assistance in the areas of medicine, food, energy, housing and technical advice. Those groups, which are each chaired by two different countries, "should produce work plans -- documents that the working group co-chairs and the other participants can use as guides for action," said Mr. Baker.
As an example of the sort of working coordination, he pointed out that last month German milk powder was shipped via Canadian planes to Russia.
Second, he said, "We must identify appropriate follow-up mechanisms to insure that coordination will continue into the immediate future."
In that regard, the ministers agreed today to meet in Lisbon in the first half of 1992 to follow up on what has been organized at this meeting, and to invite Russia and the other republics to attend as well.
He was more restrained in discussing Japan's "important contributions," while adding "now other nations in the Far East, the Middle East and Latin America should commit their expertise, their resources to assure the success of reform."
But Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, told his colleagues that European requests for a huge increase in Japanese aid to the former Soviet Union were not possible right now, according to Japanese officials.
Mr. Watanabe told the Germans, for instance, that while they have signed a peace treaty with the Soviet republics, Japan is still seeking the return of Pacific islands occupied by the Soviets during the war.
