HEADLINE: Budgetary Brinkmanship;
Dire Threats to Cut Essential Services Are Often Just a Ploy

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
As tax receipts slip and budgets come under the knife in statehouses, city halls and private institutions, the region is witnessing the flowering of a kind of brinkmanship in which officials seek to protect their budgets by threatening to cut where the pain will be worst.
The object of this exercise is not usually to perform the dire amputations that are threatened, budget experts say, but to arouse support for an agency's strongest suit, usually the area in which it comes in contact with the public, and to deflect budget-cutting attention from more vulnerable, back-office operations with no public constituency. 
 In the last six months or so, the region's taxpayers have seen the City University threaten to lock out 10,000 incoming freshmen this spring and New York State's chief judge warn that thousands of criminals might be loosed upon the streets unless the courts' budgets are restored to desired levels. Nassau County Health Department officials decided that the wisest money-saver would be to eliminate the crews that check public beaches for such hazards as discarded needles, and New York State park officials once determined that closing a major beach just in time for the start of the summer season was their best source of savings.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is no stranger to budgetary brinkmanship, avoided the tactic in the state budget released Tuesday. But history shows that the gambit is most likely to be deployed in the final stages of negotiations with the Legislature, as it was last summer, when the Governor threatened to close Long Island beaches to force the lawmakers to raise fees instead.
"One of the most frequent bureaucratic responses to budget cuts is to come forward with programs that will so outrage the public that the cut will be rejected and the money restored," said Dall W. Forsythe, who was Governor Cuomo's budget director until September, when he left to teach government at Harvard's Kennedy School.
"It is the job of a good budget office to sort out the cuts that are proposed with that in mind," he went on. "If a budget office does its job well, most of these proposals never come to light."
Mr. Forsythe's favorite example of the art crosses his desk annually, he said, sent along by the Department of Social Services. Responding to requests to trim budgets, he remembered, the department would unfailingly propose eliminating the emergency telephone line for abused children.
 
Protecting the Operation
 "It's a matter of people in an agency trying to protect their operation by making it as painful as possible to cut their budget," said Ernest Reock, director of Rutgers University's Bureau of Government Research. "They try to protect an area that is vulnerable by picking out something that has a great deal of attractiveness and government support. It's fairly common. I do it myself."
Mr. Reock declined to give an example of his own use of a technique that has come to be known as the Washington Monument Defense, named in the early 1980's for a National Park Service official who, asked by Congress where some budget savings could be found, suggested closing the Washington Monument, one of the capital's most popular attractions.
Clearly, one department head's bureaucratic gambit is another's responsible defense of the public good. Mr. Reock aside, few department chairmen admit to doing anything so tacky as grandstanding.
So when Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds of City University of New York recently threatened to lock out 10,000 freshmen in the spring unless City Hall restored $5.6 million of its budget -- and when the plan somehow found its way into the news media -- the move was widely viewed as another page in the old budget game. The proposed cut, after all, amounted to less than 2 percent of the CUNY's $281.5 million annual budget.
 
CUNY Lock-out Plan
 But CUNY officials bridle at any suggestion of game-playing. "It got a great deal of attention, no doubt about it," said Jay Hershenson, a spokesman for the university. "There were a number of officials who wondered if the Chancellor really intended to follow through if the cuts were made. The answer is yes, absolutely."
Because the threatened cut could have come midway through the current budget year, the impact would have been doubled since the loss would have to be spread out over six months instead of 12, Mr. Hershenson said. The city's contribution to the CUNY budget had been cut by 29 percent since 1989, he added, and the recession is driving more and more applicants into the CUNY system, including 10,000 more for this spring term than for last year's. That was the group targeted for delayed admission under the lockout plan.
The gambit paid off. All but $900,000 of the cuts were restored.
Budget brinkmanship was evidently in play at other institutions in the region, whatever the merit of the officials' warnings. On Long Island, John H. Marburger, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, warned last month that he might double the tuition or dismiss 500 employees, 18 percent of the total, if Governor Cuomo asked for further cuts in his campus budget. "In normal times, you might consider this political game-playing, but these are not normal times," Dr. Marburger said at the time.
Not surprisingly, a common defense against budget cuts is to argue that reduced spending will eventually end up wasting money and costing the taxpayers more. When Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey cut the state education department's budget from $47 million to $37 million last year, the Commissioner of Education, Dr. John Ellis, warned that the reduction would make it difficult for him to see that state education funds were properly spent.
Nor are private institutions exempt from the dire threat. In November, 26 department heads at Columbia University threatened to resign if the administration went through with proposed cuts beyond those agreed to in the Department of Arts and Sciences budget. The department heads' threat remains because the issue has not been resolved.
The Columbia department heads originally made their threat in a letter to a ranking university official, just as Chancellor Reynolds's threat to delay freshman admissions was originally made in a private message to Mayor Divid N. Dinkins and the City Council. But such threats must be public to be effective, and both soon found their way to the public.
Since budget money is drawn from a single pot, budget threats are often aimed at competing bureaucrats as well as at legislatures and taxpayers who might be persuaded to support tax or fee increases to avert a well-orchestrated threat. Richard Nathan, now provost of the State University of New York at Albany and an assistant director of the White House Office of Management and Budget during the Nixon Administration, said this competition produces precisely the wrong results.
"The good commissioners, who are really trying to make hard choices and do the kinds of needed structural change that you can make during a period of fiscal adversity, get hurt," he said in an interview. "Nobody squawks about the more carefully designed, thoughtful strategic choices that really look to get at low-priority programs or those that outlive their usefulness. So the people who use high-profile, 'Look what you are doing to me!' strategies get their cuts restored, and the good guys, the men and women who do the hard work, get their cuts accepted."
As a result, Mr. Nathan said, a new dynamic is introduced: budget brinkmanship as a counter-feint, in anticipation of similar ploys from competing agencies.
One of the most dire public threats of budgetary Armageddon during the current budget season came in November from Chief Judge Sol Wachtler of the New York Court of Appeals, who said he would have to close all of the state civil courts and half of the criminal courts, freeing "thousands of criminal defendants," if Governor Cuomo went through with a proposed $26 million cut in the court system budget.
Judge Wachtler backed up his threat with a lawsuit against the Governor, which he dropped last Thursday when he and Mr. Cuomo agreed on a formula that would restore 471 employees to the court system. But Governor Cuomo denied having given in to a Judge Wachtler threat.
But the administration is not immune from the gesture, either. Last June, at the beginning of the beach season, Governor Cuomo threatened to close Robert Moses State Park after the Legislature trimmed the state budget by more than he had requested.
The park, part of the Fire Island seashore, attracts 3.5 million visitors a year, and the threat produced 1,000 angry calls from Long Island officials and beach-goers. That was -- arguably, at least -- just the response the Governor had hoped for.

HEADLINE: Senators Hearten Dinkins

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins concluded two days of meetings here today saying he had found new support for efforts to make the plight of America's cities a focus of national economic policy.
"Washington can no longer turn its back on cities," said the Mayor, who also attended a meeting here of the United States Conference of Mayors. "We need help now." 
 The meetings were part of an effort by Democrats on Capitol Hill to seize the initiative on domestic policy, which is considered President Bush's Achilles' heel, and make it the focus of the presidential campaign.
 
Sees Change in Congress
 By the time Mr. Dinkins left this afternoon he was declaring victory. He said he had detected a sea change in the Congressional attitude towards cities and new understanding that improving the faltering economy depends on Federal help in rejuvenating urban areas and their suburbs.
"Clearly the attitude of senators is to recognize some urgency," he said. "That just hasn't been the case heretofore. There's recognition we have to do something and do something quickly."
The Mayor said the clearest sign of the new awareness was the formation of the Senate Task Force and Advisory Committee on Community and Urban Revitalization. A pet project of Mr. Dinkins and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, it is touted as the country's first urban caucus and a way of increasing cities' political clout, which has declined sharply amid the suburbanization of the country.
"This is really a historic group; it's a pretty impressive group," Mr. Dinkins said.
The formation of the group was announced by the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine. It is to meet several times a year and its chairman will be Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the powerful Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. The group also includes two Governors, William D. Schaefer of Maryland and Ann Richards of Texas, as well as mayors, business, labor and community leaders from around the country.

HEADLINE: 2.6% Gain In Starts Of Housing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
In a report pointing to economic recovery, Commerce Department figures showed today that builders broke ground for new homes in December at the fastest pace in more than a year and that permits for future construction did even better.
Housing starts ran at an annual rate of 1,103,000 last month, or 2.6 percent above the November rate, with all regions but the West posting gains. Permits rose 5.8 percent, to 1,051,000. 
 New-home construction tends to be one of the first sectors to revive when the economy emerges from recession and its activity ripples widely because each new dwelling means fresh demand for such consumer durables as appliances, furniture and carpeting. Permits are one of the components of the Government index that is meant to foretell economic trends.
 
Stimulation Is Seen
 "Last month's rise in housing starts shows that low interest rates clearly are stimulating demand," said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors.
Separately, a national survey by the Federal Reserve found that while overall economic activity was "lackluster" in late 1991 and the first two weeks of 1992, construction of single-family homes "expanded modestly." Sales of homes picked up, the Fed added in its "beige book" report, noting that "realtors, mortgage lenders and home builders are generally optimistic for the spring."
Housing could scarcely get any worse than it was in 1991, which saw starts dive to 1,014,700, the lowest level since 1946 and 14.9 percent below the depressed level of 1990. This was just half as many houses as were built in the industry's best years.
From their recent peak of 1.81 million units in 1986, starts fell for five straight years. Since March, they have climbed in seven of nine months, falling only in September and November.
 
'Coming Back Modestly'
 "Housing is coming back -- not storming back but coming back modestly," said David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. He said the main reason to expect further improvement was still lower interest rates, with the latest starts and permits figures not yet reflecting the latest, aggressive easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve just before Christmas.
Still, according to Thomas Holloway, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, a relatively sluggish overall recovery will keep starts in check this year. His forecast calls for a total of 1,210,000, 19 percent above the 1991 figure.
The December improvement in starts was entirely in single-family homes and small buildings with two to four units. House starts rose to a 948,000 annual pace, from 910,000 in November, while small multi-dwellings rose to 56,000 from 33,000. Starts in apartment houses and other buildings with five or more units, however, slumped to a pace of 99,000 from 132,000, the lowest since the end of World War II.
Mr. Berson observed that family formations typically fall during recessions and that builders seemed to have withdrawn from this sector until recovery had clearly taken hold. But he said he was encouraged by December's rise in permits for buildings of five or more units, to 168,000 from 148,000, that he said appeared to reflect optimism that recovery was on the way.
Activity varied by region. Starts rose to a rate of 139,000 from 122,000 in the Northeast, to 243,000 from 226,000 in the Midwest and to 469,000 from 457.000 in the South. They fell, however, in the West to 252,000 from 270,000.
The number of actual groundbreakings nationally, with no seasonal adjustment or annualization, was 66,800, with 29,500 in the South and just 8,000 in the Northeast, the report showed.
For permits, single-family homes rose to an 840,000 pace in December from 787,000 in November, while two-to-four unit structures fell to 43,000 from 58,000.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "A Bad Year for Housing Starts" showing annual housing starts 1946-1990; "Housing Construction" showing new private housing started and permits authorized during the month, in millions, at seasonally adjusted annual rates, 1990-1991. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Wants Former Chicago Bank Chief in Top Economic Post

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Barry F. Sullivan, a longtime banker and the retired head of the First Chicago Corporation, is the Dinkins administration's top choice to be New York City's new Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and is to tell Mayor David N. Dinkins as soon as today whether he wants the job, mayoral aides said yesterday.
Mr. Sullivan, who was born in the Bronx and spent 23 years at the Chase Manhattan Bank before leaving to head First Chicago in 1980, made a strong impression in an interview with Mr. Dinkins at City Hall last week, the aides said. He would replace Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, who has said she wants to spend more time with her children by shifting to a less demanding post. 
 Under pressure from business organizations to hold down taxes, retain companies and resolve the city's fiscal problems without devastating service cuts, the administration has sought a senior business figure to become chief economic steward and cheerleader to help bolster its credibility. One of the Mayor's financial advisers, David Rockefeller, the former head of Chase, helped recruit Mr. Sullivan for the post.
"The business community is enthusiastically behind him," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership and New York Chamber of Commerce.
Mr. Sullivan, 61 years old, retired from First Chicago last fall after presiding over the bank through a decade. In Chicago, he was regarded as having helped that city's first black Mayor, Harold Washington, build links to the white business establishment. He increased the bank's lending to poorer communities.
He is currently heading an effort to involve Chicago business people in reviewing the finances of the city's public schools, an effort that Dinkins aides said might force him to delay taking the new post in New York for some time, or require him to start part time.
 
Accused by Former Aide
 Throughout his time in Chicago, Mr. Sullivan kept a family home in Bronxville, just over the Westchester County line. Top city officials are required to live in the city, and Mr. Sullivan has told those involved in the search that if his residency became an issue, he would take an apartment in the city.
One of Mr. Sullivan's former top aides in Chicago, Jeffrey Tassani, pleaded guilty last year to bank fraud and was sentenced to five years in prison for accepting kickbacks from businesses for arranging bank contracts. Mr. Sullivan was not implicated in the wrongdoing, but Mr. Tassani later charged that the bank under Mr. Sullivan had sponsored a gambling party for bank officials. Bank executives later reimbursed the bank for expenses of the party.
Lizabeth Weiner, a spokeswoman for the bank who is also fielding calls for Mr. Sullivan, said he had been refraining from commenting on his possible appointment, and he did not return a message left at the Bronxville house.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Free and Taxable Funds See Sharp Decline in Yields

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report dropped sharply for the week ended yesterday, and yields of taxable funds also dropped significantly.
Walter Frank, economist for the organization, attributed the sharp decline in yields on the tax-exempt funds to a "lack of supply of municipal bonds early in the year, as well as the easing by the Federal Reserve late in December." Another factor, Mr. Frank added, was an inflow that took assets of the tax-exempts to a record level. 
 These factors came together last week, he said, adding that "we expect to see an outflow from the tax-exempt funds for the next few weeks until yields show some increases from the current low levels."
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempt funds dropped 28 basis points, to 2.76 percent from 3.04 percent, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 2.72 percent, also down 28 points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
During the same period, the 30-day compound yield dropped 27 points, to 3.57 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped 26 points, to 3.51 percent.
 
Three-State Leaders
 Among the yield leaders in the three-state area, the top Connecticut fund continued to be Fidelity Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 3.28 percent, down from 3.54 percent.
In New Jersey, the top fund was Fidelity Spartan N.J. Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield of 3.25 percent compared with the previous leader, which reported a 3.58 percent yield a week ago.
In New York, the top fund again was Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compound yield of 3.60 percent, compared with 3.83 percent a week ago.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds rose by $663 million, to a record of $98.1 billion this week.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios dropped by one day, to 52, this week.
 
Strong Still the Leader
 Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee continued to lead the way with a seven-day compound yield of 3.84, down 45 basis points. "That is almost half of 1 percent," Mr. Frank commented.
Meanwhile, assets of the taxable funds rose by $7.6 billion, to $502.5 billion, topping last week's record. The average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds remained unchanged, at 57. Mr. Frank said about $3 billion of the increase came from institutions, which meant that most of the inflow could be attributed to public investors.
 
Taxable Yield: 4.14%
 As for the taxables, Mr. Frank said: "Taxable money fund yields are in the process of bottoming, and the decline in their yields should end in the next two or three weeks. I would expect that we would see the institutional money flows into the taxables dry up as other market yields become more attractive."
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield dropped to 4.14 percent, from 4.28 the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield also fell by 14 basis points, to 4.05 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compound yield declined to 4.39 percent, off 12 basis points, and the simple yield dropped 11 basis points, to 4.30 percent.
The taxable fund with the best seven-day compound return for the week was Parkstone Prime Obligation Fund, distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus, Ohio, with a yield of 7.02 percent, partly because of capital gains.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.94 percent, compared with 3.99 percent a week ago, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Interest rates rose and prices of Treasury securities fell in light trading yesterday, as market participants continued to grapple with conflicting signals about the economy and to cope with additional new corporate debt securities.
Those developments overshadowed a strong auction of $13.7 billion worth of two-year notes, which were sold at the lowest yield since the Treasury initiated the regular sale in 1974. 
 A report showing that housing starts rose 2.6 percent in December, to their highest monthly level since November 1990, was a bit more robust than expected and provided a reason to sell securities early in the day.
 
Fed Reports Weakness
 But economists noted that despite the improvement, housing activity remains at low levels. Moreover, a report issued later in the day by the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks, known as the "beige book," showed the economy was very weak at the turn of the year.
The housing news is "modestly encouraging," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "But it is such a gradual recovery that it by no means indicates anything more meaningful for the economy over all. And the beige book was surprisingly gloomy."
Aside from the housing data, traders also cited heavy issuance of new 10-year and 30-year investment-grade corporate debt securities as another reason why prices of longer-term notes and bonds fell yesterday.
The contents of a Government report outlining sweeping changes in the way Treasury securities will be sold in the future, and who will sell them, had no impact on prices in the credit markets, according to market participants.
The Province of Manitoba led the way in the corporate debt market, offering $500 million of new 10-year notes.
At the two-year note auction, the securities were sold at an average yield of 4.99 percent, down from the average 5.12 percent yield at the last two-year note sale on December 18.
The securities traded well after the auction results were announced, and by late in the day were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 4.96 percent.
Today the Treasury is expected to sell $9.25 billion worth of five-year notes.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the securities were offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent.
At current yield levels, demand for the new notes should be strong, traders said.
"If the five-year auction can go reasonably well, this market might do pretty well for awhile," Mr. Johnson, the economist, said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 104 3/8 late yesterday, down 21/32 , to yield 7.62 percent, compared with 7.57 percent late Tuesday.
Among reasury note issues outstanding, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 7/8, down 17/32 , to yield 7.08 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 98, down1/4 point, to yield 6.73 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.73 percent late yesterday, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 3.81 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late rate of 3.90 percent.
In the corporate debt market, the Province of Manitoba's 7.75 percent 10-year securities were priced at $99.929 to yield 7.76 percent, 67 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The First Boston Corporation acted as lead underwriter.
First Boston was also the lead underwriter on a two-part, $325 million offering of 32-year and 5-year first mortgage bonds for Arizona Public Service.
The $175 million worth of 8.75 percent 32-year bonds were priced at $99.144 to yield 8.83 percent, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The remaining $150 million of the offering consists of 7 1/8 percent five year securities that were priced at $99.892 to yield 7.15 percent, 85 basis points over the prevailing yield on the new five-year Treasury securities to be auctioned today.
All of the securities sold are noncallable for life. Both parts of the issue are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by a competitive sale of $200 million worth of securities for Dade County, Fla.
A bid from an investment group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won the bonds.
The securities were reoffered to investors with yields ranging from 3.40 percent on serial bonds maturing in 1993 to a maximum yield of 6.35 percent on serial bonds maturing in 2008.
A term bond maturing in 2011 was priced to yield 6.385 percent.
The issue is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, and is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: Company Earnings;
$318 Million Loss Is Posted at Caterpillar

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Weighed down by the recession and labor battles, Caterpillar Inc. today reported a $318 million loss in the fourth quarter and predicted that it would lose more money in the first quarter of this year.
Also today, Moody's Investors Service Inc., the ratings agency, lowered the long-term debt and commercial paper ratings of Caterpillar and its units, affecting $3 billion in debt. 
 The world's largest maker of construction equipment said it had lost $318 million in the last three months of 1991, after a profit of $11 million, or 11 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
 
$324 Million Charge
 The quarterly loss included a charge of $324 million for the likely closing of its plant in York, Pa., and the further consolidation of its Brazilian operations. Caterpillar has said its decision to close the York plant depends on contract concessions it wins from the United Automobile Workers union.
For the quarter, the company's sales fell 10.5 percent, to $2.46 billion from $2.75 billion.
For all of 1991, Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., said it had lost $404 million, compared with a profit of $210 million, or $2.07 a share, in 1990. Its sales shrank nearly 11 percent, to $10.18 billion from $11.43 billion.
The most significant factor in the 1991 loss, Caterpillar said, was a 12 percent drop in sales, caused by a slump in demand related to the recession.
The company forecast a first-quarter loss because of labor problems at its plants and uncertainty about the economy.
 
Union Dispute a Factor
 Caterpillar said its contract dispute with the U.A.W., which has idled 9,300 employees by strikes, lockouts or related layoffs, has disrupted operations but did not have a significant effect on the bottom line. The standoff began 11 weeks ago, and no settlement is in sight.
Analysts said the results disappointed Wall Street investors.
"The numbers were worse than the Street assumed, but then the charge was bigger than expected," said Tobias Levkovich, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Nevertheless, Caterpillar's shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $46.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In its downgrading announcement today, Moody's also said Caterpillar's long-term debt remained under review for possible further downgrade. The agency cited the negative effect from its dispute with the U.A.W.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
High-Flier May Be Airworthy Again

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A LITTLE over a year ago, Sequent Computer Systems Inc. hit the invisible wall that seems to lie in wait for high-flying high-technology companies. Sequent, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., and makes superminicomputers, missed its earnings forecast for the fourth quarter of 1990 and spent the first three quarters of 1991 mired in red ink.
Sequent's troubles began with a significant decline its original equipment manufacturing business, in which Sequent computers are resold by the Unisys Corporation. That arrangement, coupled with the recession and some internal difficulties, left the company in a position where it "couldn't peel expenses fast enough," said Casey Powell, Sequent's chairman and chief executive. 
 So, in the third quarter of 1991, Sequent carried out a huge overhaul, paring its work force by 25 percent and canceling a major development project. The company now says it will report a return to profitability in the fourth quarter when it releases its results next week. And on Monday, Sequent announced a series of products and a strategic relationship that should help it return to its former fast-growing ways.
Sequent, founded in 1983, went public in 1987 when sales were $20 million, and posted annual profits for four consecutive years. In 1990, its last profitable year, Sequent earned $18.8 million on revenue of $248.8 million.
Analysts say Sequent could show earnings growth again in 1992 with just modest sales growth because the company has reduced its expenses so much. Sequent has put its house in order, these analysts say, and some are ready to be investors again in the nine-year-old company.
"I was really a skeptic," said Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Research."But they have done a remarkably good job of fixing things. I recommended the stock this morning, and I feel good about Sequent now."
After trading for as little as $7.50 last year, Sequent shares have rebounded to the midteens; they closed yesterday at $16.50, up 25 cents, in over-the-counter trading.
Ms. Conigliaro said Sequent impressed her with "a backlog that is bigger by far than anyone could have expected in their wildest dreams." The backlog, estimated to be above $30 million, insures that Sequent will weather the seasonally slow first quarter.
In addition, Sequent "is on the right side of a lot of things" that are becoming trends in computing, she said. Among these are the use of industry-standard microprocessors; multiprocessing, in which computing is divided among a number of processors at once, and the Unix operating system software originally developed by A.T.& T. but now an emerging industry standard.
Indeed, Sequent, which was founded by 17 former Intel Corporation employees, was a pioneer in merging these industry trends into one computer. Its machines, which range in price from $53,500 to $467,500, use from two to six Intel 486 microprocessors, the chip commonly found in the most powerful personal computers. By running these chips in parallel, Sequent computers can outperform more costly minicomputers and mainframes.
Sequent computers are most often used to run relational data base management programs, like the Oracle Systems Corporation's products, which companies use to keep track of everything from payroll to product sales. While Sequent machines sometimes replace conventional minicomputers, they are increasingly used as information servers -- devices that both coordinate multiple networks of personal computers and reduce the load on a company's central mainframe. Having developed a "parallelized" version of Netware, Novell Inc.'s network operating system, Sequent can use its machines to orchestrate networks of thousands of personal computers.
The company "is well positioned as a leading supplier of very cost-effective superminicomputers for relational data base management," said Neil Weintraut, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. Other strong points for Sequent, Mr. Weintraut said, are its replenished product line, the link with Novell and its strengthened direct sales force. He rates the company a long-term buy.
On Monday, Sequent announced three computers in its Symmetry 2000 line, all using the latest higher-speed version of the 486 chip. Perhaps more significantly, Sequent announced that the Open Software Foundation, an industry group that includes I.B.M., had chosen its machines as the primary computers for development of multiprocessor versions of OSF/1, the foundation's version of Unix. Sequent machines were already the test platforms for Unix System Laboratories, the foundation's direct competitor, which is led by A.T.& T.
"The company had already established itself as the Intel-based multiprocessor platform of choice on the U.S.L. side; now they've garnered the same honor from O.S.F.," said Shao Wang, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Mr. Wang upgraded Sequent from a sell to a hold last month and retains that rating, based as much on the uncertain state of the economy as on Sequent's prospects. But, he added, for a company that lost money in 1991 and might earn only 50 cents a share in 1992, "the valuation is not exactly cheap."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Decline Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday in quiet trading.
Gold prices were slightly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $357.90 an ounce, off 10 cents. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 5 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $357.50. 
 Analysts said most of the day's activity centered on the Japanese yen and the German mark as traders anticipate the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers on Long Island.
Many expect them to take some action to support a higher yen, which in turn would help address Japan's trade imbalance with the United States and Europe.
"It would also give the Bank of Japan more room to cut interest rates," which would have a favorable effect on the dollar, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
Others say the finance ministers from the United States, Germany, Japan, Italy, France, Britain and Canada may go as far as agreeing to coordinate interest rate moves and monetary policy, said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.
The market had little reaction to new data showing housing starts fell 14.9 percent last year to their lowest level in 46 years. And the release of the Federal Reserve's so-called beige book, which said the economy ended last year in the doldrums, also failed to influence the dollar.
"The consensus is that by midyear we will recover, but the attitude is not by much," Mr. Malpede said.
In Tokyo, the dollar was unchanged at 123.34 Japanese yen. Later in London, it fell to 123.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 123.38 yen, down from 123.68 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8050, from $1.8080 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.8055 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.8045.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5905 German marks, up from 1.5865; 1.4090 Swiss francs, up from 1.4060; 5.4210 French francs, up from 5.4085; 1,195.50 Italian lire, up from 1,194.00, and 1.1556 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1551.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
$6.8 Million Loss for Wang

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 22

 BODY:
Wang Laboratories Inc. reported a quarterly loss of $6.8 million on Tuesday, but the troubled computer company said it was encouraged that its revenues had stopped declining.
Results for the three-month period that ended Dec. 31 compared with a loss of $24.7 million in the comparable period a year earlier.
But for the second consecutive quarter, Wang reported an operating profit of $3.9 million. The loss came after deducting interest and taxes.
The results, moreover, were the first in more than a year in which the quarter's revenues exceeded those from the preceding quarter.
Revenue totaled $495.9 million in the quarter, the second of Wang's fiscal year. That was down from $544.2 million in the comparable period a year earlier, but up from $460.7 million in the first quarter of the fiscal year.
Richard W. Miller, chairman of Wang, said the company faced economic and market pressures similar to those confronting other computer makers.
"We are encouraged, however, by our second-quarter results," Mr. Miller said, "which indicate that Wang's revenues and financial performance remain stable despite these external adversities."
Wang has been trying to recover for more than two years. A key to Wang's future will be a new alliance with the International Business Machines Corporation. Under the alliance, Wang will sell a variety of I.B.M. computers, some under the Wang label.
Mr. Miller said those products would begin moving in the current quarter. As expected, he said, the second quarter did not include any significant revenues from I.B.M.

HEADLINE: English Bathrooms: Out of the Closet

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The term water closet may sound like a quaint euphemism, but over the years it has also come to be a pretty fair description of the typical British bathroom. As often as not, it is a cramped, airless cubicle, a kind of architectural afterthought crouched at the end of a creaky hallway or hidden beneath the stairs of a 19th-century terrace house.
But in the last few years, the British bathroom has begun to come into its own. Not only are new houses equipped with larger and more luxurious bathrooms, but there is a growing trend to remodel and update old bathrooms, often using florid antique or reproduction fixtures that evoke the look and feel of Victorian manor houses. 
 And there has been a sudden explosion in the consumer market for showers and shower stalls, to either replace or supplement that most essential British fixture, the bathtub. The most elaborate are advertised as "power showers" because they employ hydraulic pumps, often noisy, to augment the chronically weak household water pressure. Built directly into bathroom walls, they cost $200 to $1,000, depending on spray options and flow rate.
"For years, Britons wouldn't hear of showers, partly because they liked their baths, and partly because we just don't have the proper water pressure like you do in America," said Stephen Quigley, the managing director of Richmond's, a large plumbing supply store in southwest London. In most English houses, water pressure is dependent on a gravity-fed tank in a loft or an attic.
"But I think the bath is going the way of the full breakfast," Mr. Quigley added. "It's a life style thing. People don't have time in the morning for a leisurely bath or breakfast."
In pushing out their bathroom walls and abandoning bathtubs for shower stalls, Britons may be doing something much more substantial than flirting with the latest trend in interior design. They are, in a way, tinkering with their own cultural plumbing, a trend that some consider vaguely unsettling.
"Perhaps there is a bit of snobbery about it, but I think the idea that a bathroom ought to be carpeted and wallpapered and painted in peach colors is absurd, even vulgar," said Gavin Stamp, an architect, writer and member of the Victorian Society, which works to preserve and celebrate 19th-century architecture. "Bathrooms do matter. But they ought to be well plumbed and solid: substantial, like the engine room of a ship."
Indeed, some essential breakthroughs in sanitary engineering and indoor plumbing took place in 19th-century Britain as a result of the work of Thomas Crapper, who invented the siphonless flushing mechanism, and the Rev. Edward Johns, who introduced his popular "dolphin" toilet to the United States at the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876.
Moreover, some 19th-century English fixtures were extraordinarily ornate, a reflection of the Victorian love of machinery: enameled hand basins and fluted toilet bowls and gold and brass taps and fixtures. Some public restrooms were adventures in sanitary wonderland. For example, in one tank in central London in the late 19th century, the flushing water was held in a suspended glass globe in which an attendant kept goldfish. (The mechanics of the device assured that the goldfish would not be lost in the flush.)
Indoor toilets were not uncommon in British houses by the late 19th century, but the emphasis on bathing as a matter of general hygiene was much slower to catch on. Min Hogg, editor in chief of The World of Interiors, the magazine that perhaps best captures the eccentricity of British decorating, said the English seemed to develop a sense of the bathroom that differed from what was evolving on the Continent and across the Atlantic. "That's why the French have the bidet, and we do not, and the Americans have showers, and we do not," Ms. Hogg said.
Bathrooms were not common in working-class housing projects until after World War I, said John Pennell, the director of the British Bathroom Council, an organization that represents big manufacturers of bathroom products. Even then, they tended to be very cramped; they were quite deliberately made the absolute minimum size. Their design, he said, probably reflected some degree of class bias.
"I think most architects, who were middle class, had a difficult time being persuaded that bathrooms were really necessary for working-class people," Mr. Pennell said.
Over the years, the relatively spare, compact British bathroom has attracted the curiosity of foreigners. They have marveled at the absence of a bidet or shower, at the fact that the toilet is often sequestered in a tiny room all its own, and at the plumbing of sinks, which invariably have separate taps for dispensing hot and cold water. Beppe Severgnini, an Italian journalist who wrote "Inglisi," a social history of the English published last year by Hodder & Stoughton, said this meant that washing one's hands in England required choosing "between getting your hands scorched under the hot tap or frozen under the cold one."
Mr. Severgnini concluded that the British have what he called a "troubled relationship" with their bathrooms, underscoring the point by noting that the English commonly use more than a dozen euphemisms to describe a bathroom. Among them are loo, gents', ladies', lavatory, toilet, convenience, lav, water closet, W.C., bog, john, can, head, latrine, privy and powder room.
But Mr. Pennell and others argue that the British are changing. Although the recession has slowed conversions and remodeling, the British Bathroom Council estimates that nearly half of all British houses now have showers, as against only about 30 percent a decade ago.
One house with a "power shower" is that of David Deane, a London businessman, and his wife, Karen.
"The old bathtub, with its hand-held shower, was fine if you had an hour to spare," said Mr. Deane, adding that he fell in love with brisk morning showers on trips to the United States and had a shower installed in his house in 1987. "The problem was, the dribble of water you got was never enough to get the soap off. I used to keep a pitcher beside the tub, to fill up and bang over my head, to rinse off properly."
 As Mr. Pennell sees it, "The idea now is that the bathroom is part of the living space and ought to reflect the way people see themselves."
To that end, for example, Armitage Shanks, the largest British maker of bathroom equipment, now markets complete bathroom suites in a variety of styles and colors with names like oyster, chablis, peach and champagne. One suite, the Clivenden, is designed along Edwardian lines; it has fluted basins and a mahogany toilet seat.
There is also a big market for antique bathroom fixtures salvaged from junkyards and demolition projects. In the last two years, at least half a dozen shops offering reconditioned basins, taps and heavy fixtures, like re-enameled cast-iron tubs with claw-and-ball feet and rolled edges, have opened in London.
Because the fittings are not the same size as modern pipes, they are often difficult to install, and much heavier than modern appliances, a hazard in itself. A man who put a reconditioned antique marble tub into his Belgravia row house not long ago returned home to discover it in the basement, where it had halted after crashing through three floors on its way down from a loft bathroom.

(Photographs by Jonathan Player for The New York Times) (pg. C6)

HEADLINE: A Natural Hoarder Opens a Shop, and the Style is 'Neo-Flea'

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
THE shop sort of announces its personality as soon as you walk in the door:
"Wonderful old paint," reads the tag on a country pie safe, "$995." "Home-style delicious, $4.50," says a sign by some jars of applesauce. "Authentic country frame and photo, dated 1924, $225" catches one's eye. A Boston-terrier-shaped iron doorstop -- "$255 (rare)" -- stands on a table; another stands in the window. 
 Then there's the lineup of vintage soda bottles with names like Skipper, Crass, Whistle, Patio and Variety Club. They're $20 each.
"Aren't they just great and graphic?" said Jenny Eiger, the owner of Home Town, a new shop at 131 Wooster Street (Prince Street) in SoHo.
That's everything you need to know, and maybe a little more.
Selling an irrestible mix of what some people deem treasures and others junk, Ms. Eiger, who is 30 years old, embodies the acquiring ethos of her generation. She seizes on items that avid flea-market enthusiasts have gotten in the habit of hunting for: well-worn painted furniture, old toys, birdhouses, cast-iron doorstops, license plates, ($35 each at the shop) and felt banners, ($45 each).
And it doesn't come particularly cheap. It does, however, require a certain eye, and Ms. Eiger seems to have it. She hopes others will share in what she calls her "vision."
"You have to have one when you decide to open a store in a recession," she said.
Here's the vision: "New York City is nobody's hometown," she said. "Everyone is trying to create a little piece of home in their own urban apartment."
A self-described "hoarder by nature," Ms. Eiger's home happens to be a loft on lower Broadway. A part of the loft now serves as a holding area for items on their way to the store. Or back again.
"The store is really a facsimile of my house," she explained.
Tin boxes, green kitchen bowls, whirligigs, tiny Adirondack chairs and dog-shaped cast-iron doorstops that may be in transit to the store contribute to the informal homey look. Most are minus the price tags, of course.
It helps create an esthetic in which overscale snowshoes, a weathered wheelbarrow and an American flag as a room divider do not seem particularly outrageous. Not exactly "country" in style, the look is more just down-home and lived-in. One might call it "neo-flea" or "well-styled-flea."
A few things in Ms. Eiger's loft -- the wooden wheel that once steered her grandfather's boat, for example -- are there to stay. Other items, captured on trips upstate and points south and west of Manhattan, are already neatly stickered, bound for the store.
But nothing leaves without causing Ms. Eiger some angst. "Sometimes it's heart-wrenching for me to give something up," she said. "I feel responsible. I want to feel it's going to a good house. Sometimes I feel sad when someone buys something. I think, 'no one will love it as much as I do.' "
She's getting better at letting go.
Ms. Eiger opened the shop a few weeks before Christmas, after working for 10 years as a studio manager in a fashion photography studio and in advertising at Barneys New York.
"I did this on my own after working for lots of people my whole life," she said.
Ms. Eiger, who grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y., recalled that people thought she was weird because she only liked "things that were old."
"My Dad was a C.P.A. and a lawyer, my Mom an English teacher, and my grandmother was an interior decorator," she said. Tin boxes were what she collected as a child. Now she has expanded her collecting to include, among other things, cast-iron bookends and vintage cameras.
Opening the store was like a personal mission, years in the making. "I did everything myself," she said. "I looked for six months for the right location. I choose everything myself. Do you know about Mom and Pop shops? Well, this is a Mom shop."
Ms. Eiger tends to keep one of everything for herself. In the store, a half dozen roulette wheels, at rest, span one of the freshly painted white walls. At home, a solitary one hangs on the wall. "That's the best one," Ms. Eiger said. "I couldn't part with it."
The value or age of a particular object is not what particularly appeals to Ms. Eiger. She goes for what she described as "visual appeal."
"I also like things to be functional," she added, "like tables people have put their feet up on for years," or chairs that look a little the worse -- or, to her eye, the better -- for wear.
"The 90's are all about staying home and being comfortable," she said. "I like furniture that is not going to get damaged no matter what. It's kidproof and familyproof."
Although Ms. Eiger does not do restoration, she does do some cleaning of objects. But not repainting. "Everything is as is," she said.
There are certainly others who share her taste. On a recent visit to the store, people were politely jostling each other. The fact that there are customers at all amazed her parents, who, in spite of their skepticism, have been ardent supporters of her venture. Her mother, Juliette, for example, is Ms. Eiger's traveling companion on buying forays.
Her father, Leonard, calls it Jenny's World, Ms. Eiger said.
But on the day she opened the store, Mr. Eiger stopped in early in the morning.
"Who would ever buy this?" his daughter recalled him saying about a glass jug filled with clay marbles.
Later in the day, Ms. Eiger telephoned her father and said, "Guess what the first thing I sold was?"
Now that really made her smile.
Home Town is open Tuesday through Sunday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Telephone: (212) 674-5770.

HEADLINE: Requiring Classes In Divorce

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga.

 BODY:
BEFORE a very still and somber-looking audience of 80 parents, a social worker portrayed a slice of contemporary American life.
"I am a 6-year-old boy, and I live with Dad," said Aubrey Lee, the social worker, in his Southern drawl. "One hour before I am supposed to visit Mom, Dad says, 'You can't see Mom. The check didn't come.' " 
Mr. Lee looked hard at his audience, all mothers and fathers with pending divorce cases in this Atlanta suburb, and asked, "How do I feel?"
How a child feels in the turmoil of divorce -- before, during and after the breakup of the family -- was the subject of a four-hour seminar that brought these parents one morning last week to the Cobb County Juvenile Court. They were not there voluntarily: They were ordered by the court to attend.
"If you don't go, you don't get a divorce," said Judge Watson L. White, chief judge of the Cobb County Superior Court.
Here and in some other parts of the country, judges in divorce proceedings are sending warring parents to court-required seminars to open their eyes to the trauma of divorce for children. Their aim, they say, is to force parents to cease battle long enough to consider the repercussions for the innocent victims caught in their crossfire.
"The purpose," Judge White said, "is to make parents listen to experts who say, 'This is what is happening to your children, this is what they are feeling, and here are some things you can do to lessen the trauma.'
"Parents are so involved in hating each other. They tell a child the other is no good. Children don't want to take sides, but they are pushed and pulled and torn. We want to lessen the bitterness and help parents communicate with each other for the benefit of the children."
Judge White said he believed the program was having an effect. "Some couples are compromising and are settling their cases without a bitter court fight because they realize it would hurt their child and isn't worth it," he said. "We don't have statistics to back this up, but we know it's happening."
Cobb County's program, which is called "Children Cope With Divorce: Seminar for Divorcing Parents," began in October 1988 and has served as the model for similar programs that began recently in Atlanta, Savannah and Decatur, Ga. It has also been duplicated in Marion, Ohio, St. Petersburg, Fla., and Indianapolis.
"This is the wave of the future," said Judge Cynthia J. Ayers of the Family Law Division of the Marion County Superior Court in Indianapolis, where the program began last July. "Fifty percent of all marriages end in divorce, and 70 percent of those families have children. Many people never consider the impact of divorce on their children."
The fast-paced curriculum touches on emotional, psychological, social and economic implications for children in a divorce. It also deals with how and what parents should tell children about a divorce, and how they can help them deal with separation and visitation.
The program addresses the needs of children according to their age and developmental level. It is a mixture of lectures, films and role-playing by a pair of seminar leaders, who dramatize common conflicts that arise in families as a result of divorce. The audience is encouraged to comment on the behavior of parents and children in those scenarios, and how they affect and often manipulate each other.
"Parents see themselves in our role-playing, and they begin to recognize things they typically do out of anger toward each other," said Bev Bradburn-Stern, the social worker who designed the seminar for Families First, an Atlanta social service and counseling agency that runs the program.
Supporters of the program concede that in four hours it can barely skim the surface of a difficult and complex subject. "Instead of four hours, it ought to be 40 hours," Judge White said. "I hope it will be expanded."
Nancy J. Parkhouse, a deputy court administrator for the Cobb Superior Court who is coordinator of the seminar, said: "It is an overview, but the main thing is awareness. It makes some very strong points, and hopefully they will stick in people's minds."
It was Ms. Parkhouse who brought the program to the attention of judges here. She said the concept for the seminar began several years ago in Wichita, Kan., where it is also court-mandated, but that a new curriculum was developed here.
The growing interest in this type of program is buttressed by research suggesting that divorce can have deep and long-lasting consequences for children. Some researchers have found that emotional scars can remain well beyond childhood, into adult life, resulting in anger, depression and fears of betrayal and abandonment.
Dr. Judith S. Wallerstein, a psychologist who has studied long-term effects of divorce, said that while the four-hour seminar was useful, she would prefer a more ambitious series of required seminars that wove together the needs of parents with those of children.
"You have to recognize how much parents are hurting," Dr. Wallerstein said. "You have to help them to feel less bewildered and to make informed decisions about custody and visitation. Still, the four-hour course sends a morally important message to parents: your children are of concern to society, and divorce has consequences for them. Not everybody knows that."
Judges say there have been complaints from lawyers about the program, especially at the beginning. "Lawyers thought we were intervening with their clients and were creating another bureaucratic step in the divorce process," said Judge Ayers of Indianapolis.
Judge White of Marietta added: "There was a lot of grumbling from lawyers at first -- they do not like new procedures -- but there was no organized resistance."
About 7,000 parents have attended the seminar here since it began. The program is largely supported by a $30 fee, which parents pay. The fee is waived for the 6 percent of parents who the court determines cannot afford it.
At the session last week, which was led by Ms. Bradburn-Stern and Mr. Aubrey, parents heard some basic facts about divorce in America, including these:
* More than one million children are affected by divorce every year.
* Half of those children will grow up in families where parents stay angry.
* Sixty percent of them will feel rejected by at least one parents.
"For children in a divorce, the family as they know it is no longer," Ms. Bradburn-Stern said. "That stability is now gone. Divorce is a process of loss. Children are scared.
"The family goes on after divorce, but it is restructured. How can you make it work, and make children feel loved and secure? Children need both parents. It is not easy to work that out. It takes time."
A few people in the audience dabbed at their eyes. Ms. Bradburn-Stern suggested that divorced parents create a business-style relationship with each other for matters concerning the children.
"Has anyone had the experience of doing business with someone you didn't like?" she asked. There was immediate laughter. "That is what this is like. You have to deal with the widget seller because you need a widget."
After the seminar, many parents said they had not wanted to attend, and in some cases were angry about being forced to do so. But they also said that in the end, they had found the morning useful.
"I thought, 'I don't need it, they won't tell me anything,' " said Patrick Brownlee, a restaurant manager who has two sons, 4 years and 19 months old. "But I learned I need to listen more to my kids, and not be so strict when they first come back after visiting their mother."
Jim Brown, a drafting engineer who has a 3-year-old son, said: "I don't advocate mandated programs, but this has a lot of value. I was aware that my son needs to be comforted by both his parents, but now I will make an extra effort."
Carla Kirby, a Juvenile Court clerical worker who has two sons, 1 and 2, said she had not looked forward to the program.
"I was apprehensive and didn't know what to expect," she recalled. "I did get something out of it. There is so much uncertainty when you get a divorce. This helps you know what to expect."

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXVI;
Minnesota Basking In Found Money

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The downtown streets of the host city of Super Bowl XXVI are quiet, the climate-controlled skyway mall shopping areas less than bursting with activity.
Yet, the city awaits a mini-explosion of business beginning Thursday as tens of thousands of out-of-towners make their way to this city for a long weekend of marketing and glitz that happens to conclude with a football game on Sunday. 
 "Sixty thousand guests coming for three days," said Steve Davidson, a restaurateur, who will cater several major Super Bowl events. "All the hotels are booked up and everybody's got to eat."
 
Hotels and Restaurants Benefit
 Hotels and restaurants will be the prime economic beneficiaries of the boomlet coming to the seven-county Twin Cities area despite the recession. A University of Minnesota study predicts about $47 million in spending by the 58,000 out-of-town fans coming to the game (along with 6,400 other visitors believed to be coming sans tickets), including $9.4 million on hotels and $6.8 million on restaurants.
Spending on the six games played by the Minnesota Twins in the American League playoffs and the World Series was informally estimated at $18 million in October, the city's busiest convention month, when most guests coming to the area were forced to lodge outside Minneapolis and St. Paul.
But the Super Bowl, where 90 percent of the visitors come from elsewhere, is a different kind of economic event.
"For the middle of January, our slowest month, $50 million is gangbusters," said Greg Ortale, president of the Greater Minneapolis Convention and Visitor Association.
 
Booked Solid
 The area's 15,500 hotel rooms are booked solid from Friday through Sunday nights. Restaurant reservations are nearly as hard to get, unless you are Jim Kelly or Joe Gibbs.
But Ortale said the hotels were asked to require three-night minimum stays, not four, the norm for Super Bowl lodging, a strategy geared to speed booking for the hundreds of small and large groups that might have wondered how to spend an extra day in only the second cold-weather site to be host to a Super Bowl.
The average stay expected for visitors here is 2.5 days, down from 3.9 in Tampa, Fla., the warm-weather spot where last year's Super Bowl was played.
"For this month, we'd usually have an occupancy rate of 50 percent, but with the Super Bowl, we'll go up to 70 percent," said John Kelly, general manager of the Radisson Plaza, a downtown hotel. "We've been sold out of all 360 rooms since 1989."
 
No Warmth, No Beaches
 Local organizers have tried mightily to convince doubters that the area deserves the Super Bowl despite its freezing temperatures and foot-high snowfalls. No, they say, they cannot offer warm sun and beaches.
On one level, the Twin Cities are portrayed as a clean and friendly mecca of arts, sports and commerce, with networks of enclosed skyway shopping areas as warm as the Metrodome. But it also encourages its image as a winter playland, an identity enhanced by the opening Tuesday night of the St. Paul Winter Carnival ice palace, its 10 million pounds of ice rising 166 feet high.
"Some people around here wanted us to have 6 or 8 inches of snow so we can show we can live with it, and at 30 degrees and no snow, we can't celebrate winter," said Paula Gottschalk, executive director of the Minnesota Super Bowl XXVI, the task force that organized the Minneapolis bid for the Super Bowl and has organized local events (including handing out portable hand warmers).
But she was not upset that as of today, there was no snow falling and temperatures were in the relatively balmy 30's.
 
Showing Off the City
 Beyond what visitors spend during a Super Bowl -- and an estimated $60 million was spent by those attending Super Bowl XXV in Tampa -- the motive for being host to a Super Bowl is to show off the city for the regular business of tourism and conventions.
"It's quality of life and a city's image, factors that escape quantification," said the economist Robert Baade of Lake Forest College in Illinois, an expert in assessing the economic impact of stadiums and sports events.
The cumulative effect of, in the course of a year, being host to the Super Bowl, the World Series, the Stanley Cup finals, and, in March, the college basketball Final Four cannot hurt the area's viability, even in the midst of a nationwide recession, or the prospects for its new 200,000-square-foot convention center.
"We're not a cow town anymore, which we probably were as recently as 1970," said Wilbur Maki, the Univesity of Minnesota economist who performed the Super Bowl economic study. "We're also more than just a trade center for the Upper Midwest. We're a world city."

HEADLINE: MCI, Grown Big, Looks Abroad

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, they figure that this year is 8 A.D., or eight years after the formal divestiture of A.T.& T. The dark time before that is known as B.C. -- before competition.
But figured another way, this year is actually 10 A.D., 10 years after the initial agreement to dismantle the biggest company on earth. 
 Since then, industry competition is still expanding, more rapidly than ever, and MCI figures to benefit. New competition this year will arise overseas, where barriers are bound to fall in Europe and Asia, lowering prices for international long-distance calls and creating opportunities for former upstarts like MCI.
 
All Seek Foreign Accords
 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, MCI and United Telecommunications' U S Sprint are all looking to reach agreements with giant foreign companies like Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, France Telecom, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom and BT, the former British Telecommunications.
Such large foreign carriers will naturally want a foothold and an ally in the United States, if only to court lucrative corporate customers. "We think they'll come to us," said Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's president and chief executive. "A.T.& T.'s too big and their competitor in too many places, and Sprint's too small. So that leaves us and we'll be smiling."
Analysts agree, up to a point. "MCI is the premier competitor to A.T.& T.," said Robert B. Morris, a telecommunications analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But MCI itself may be getting too big, so they will have to watch out for smaller competitors, just like A.T.& T."
Now that A.T.& T., with its own aggressive discounts and marketing, has slowed MCI's gains in the domestic market, MCI has all the more need to expand its foreign business. Foreign alliances will aim first at providing services for large corporations to transmit huge amounts of data. But they may eventually help improve services for residential customers. The installation of more modern networks around the world over the next three years should make new voice, video and data services, like video conferencing and remote medical consultation, available in businesses and eventually the home.
The world's telephone companies, known in the business as PTT's, or post telephone and telegraphs, are mainly state-owned monopolies. But because of the unification of European markets that begins in earnest in 1993, the telephone monopolies will find European versions of MCI trying to offer cheaper services, especially to big business customers.
"The PTT's are just the Bell System with a foreign accent," said Daniel F. Akerson, an MCI executive vice president and a former executive of A.T.& T.'s long-distance service. "Anything you see happening here, you'll see overseas."
New competition will also come at home, as the very concept of a long-distance call is redefined. Today, a long-distance call is a call across the old Bell System borders -- more than 160 artificial divisions known as local access and transport areas. They have little relation to the cost of calls but were an administrative convenience for the old Bell System.
These artificial divisions mean that a 51-mile call in one jurisdiction may be local, while a 50-mile call elsewhere may be long distance. Sometimes, a local call costs more than a longer, long-distance call whose price is kept low by competition.
Iowa already allows some competition within these local access and transport areas, and Minnesota plans to. But the real money would be in crowded metropolitan areas, like the San Francisco Bay area. A call from San Francisco to San Jose, an hour's drive away, is still a local call, with charges by the minute. The price is determined only by Pacific Telephone with oversight by California regulators. MCI, U S Sprint and others are now banned from competing in such a lucrative market.
The last decade has seen how competition has already transfigured what was once called Plain Old Telephone Service. A.T.& T. enjoyed a near-monopoly in long-distance service, a total monopoly in local calls and high prices. Now it is out of short-haul calls altogether and has lost a third of its long-distance market to competitors, a market that last year was worth $61 billion, more than the annual revenue of Mobil.
MCI, which had about 1 percent of the long-distance market in 1982, had about 19 percent last year, or about 62 billion minutes of telephone use, according to Robert B. Morris, a telecommunications analyst at Goldman, Sachs. In 1991, it earned some $528 million on revenue of more than $8.5 billion.
MCI has been helped especially by its Friends and Family Progam, which offers 20 percent discounts to customers for, in effect, recruiting their friends to MCI.
Competition has also changed how consumers think about long-distance calls. Where once they put egg timers near the phones to remind chatty teen-agers to cut short their annual Thanksgiving talks with grandmother, long-distance calls, at least in the United States, now lack the glamour of extravagance.
Spurred by competition from MCI and U S Sprint, A.T.& T. has cut the cost of a 10-minute call from New York to Los Angeles by about 40 percent, or more than 60 percent adjusted for inflation. And new technology like digital switching and fiber-optic cables has made possible not only lower prices but also everything from the operation of office fax machines to the quick transfer of complex medical images between hospitals.
 
Origins of MCI
 All this hubbub in what was one of the most humdrum of utility services began in 1968 when William G. McGowan, an entrepreneur and the son of an Appalachian union organizer, helped found MCI, a microwave radio service that saved 80 percent on long-distance phone bills for truck drivers. Although aimed at a limited market, microwave transmission from tower to tower made possible a cheaper form of long-distance communication that was a clear threat to the 100-year-old A.T.& T.
The Justice Department suit against A.T.& T. followed shortly after a 1974 civil suit by MCI challenging the Bell monopoly. In 1982, A.T.& T., in order to end the lawsuit, agreed to spin off the local telephone companies and become a long-distance carrier. Two years later, Federal Judge Harold H. Greene carried out the company's breakup.
Hobbled but still active after a heart attack in 1986 and a heart transplant the following year, Mr. McGowan, 64 years old, has transferred day-to-day responsibilities to Mr. Roberts, 49, who added the chief executive's title last month.
"People forget what the Bell System was like," said Mr. Roberts, a former project director at Westinghouse Electric who joined MCI in 1972. "It was like a company that owned all the airlines, owned all the airports, plus the cabs, buses and subways from the airports."
With the phone company's dominance of both long-distance and local service, newcomers like MCI found it difficult to get customers. MCI and others could provide only limited long-distance service because they did not have access to the Bell System's local phone lines. "Our customers would get off our plane, but they couldn't get downtown because A.T.& T. owned the cabs, the buses and the subways and wouldn't let us on them," Mr. Roberts said
Now, with many so-called equal-access issues resolved by the Federal Communications Commission in favor of competition, MCI, Sprint and other carriers can compete on a more equal footing. Instead of having to dial cumbersome access codes with personal identification numbers, Sprint and MCI customers can now dial "1" plus their number -- the same as for customers of A.T.& T.
But A.T.& T. enjoys what MCI regards as unequal access in other areas. Credit-card calls, which are popular with business executives, favor A.T.& T. because its customers need only dial "0" and their number to begin the transactions.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Success, Then Anxiety, in Korea

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

 BODY:
South Korea's rush toward first world economic status has dazzled admiring outsiders. But it leaves many Koreans anxious that material advances may have come at a spiritual cost.
Three decades of thundering growth have revolutionized material life. In barely one generation, a nation of destitute peasants has become a nation of city dwellers addicted to cars and appliances. This new middle class threw off authoritarianism; democratic institutions are now taking root. 
 Seoul's diplomacy, long steeped in crude anti-Communism, has grown more sophisticated, yielding prizes like full relations with Moscow, economic ties with China, a United Nations seat and, most recently, reduced tensions with Communist North Korea.
As became evident on a recent visit, for many South Koreans these gains have not brought contentment.
Officials who served past dictators still hold office under President Roh Tae Woo, a former general. They seem uncomfortable with the tumult of free debate.
Executives of conglomerates like Hyundai and Daewoo complain of a weakened work ethic and pine for the paternalism of the past. They lament that recent wage gains, a product of more democratic labor relations, have dented the competitiveness of Korean exports. But productivity is again outstripping wage hikes. And South Korea's product mix keeps shifting upscale from clothing to ships to computers, suggesting more efficient use of an educated work force.
It's not just the powerful who fret. The former dissident leaders Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam worry that history may cheat them of their turn in the presidential Blue House. Both see this year's elections as a last chance. Kim Young Sam, now a Government stalwart, hopes Mr. Roh will anoint him as heir. Kim Dae Jung protests, as ever, the Government's failure to live up to democratic norms. But his criticism is undermined by a widespread belief that his own style is just as authoritarian.
Less-famous dissidents fear the formidable repressive apparatus that survives. A harsh National Security Law still restricts most forms of contact with North Korea. More than 1,000 political prisoners remain behind bars. And students continue to die at the hands of the police under suspicious circumstances.
Farm families are alarmed at U.S. pressure to permit rice imports. Without the income from rice prices protected at several times world market level, they fear they would be forced to give up the only way of life they know.
Almost all Koreans hope for an early end to the partition imposed on their nation in 1945. But some, noting Germany's recent experiences, fear the consequences of a too-sudden collapse in the North, perhaps following the death of Kim Il Sung, who is nearly 80.
Americans often carelessly lump Korea with Japan, or assume its history began with the Korean War. But Koreans are acutely conscious of their long cultural and political traditions. It was through Korean craftsmen and scholars that an isolated Japan first learned of Chinese civilization. Korea established a unified state earlier than any present European country and maintained its unity and independence for a millennium, until 1910.
The 20th century brought brutal Japanese colonialism, two devastating wars, partition of the Korean Peninsula and decades of dictatorship. Today wounded nationalism and intense pride play a prominent role in Korean life. Decent and educated Koreans suspect the U.S. of trying to prevent reunification and using exports to destroy the Korean way of life.
The Bush Administration has been adept in working out policies for a changing Korea, especially on the delicate issue of North Korea's nuclear plans. As South Korea develops its economic might, extends democracy and multiplies links with the North, Washington will need to broaden contacts north and south, showing due sensitivity to national pride. Korea, which has achieved so much, is worth the effort.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
