SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 544 words

HEADLINE: Consumers Need Rules, Not Stunts

 BODY:
President Bush is about to declare a three-month halt to new Federal regulations, according to White House sources who choose to remain anonymous. And well they might. This idea is the purest campaign prattle.
The moratorium is said to be part of the President's economic revival plan, which he will outline in his State of the Union address next week. The underlying idea is that excessive regulation hampers growth. 
 For example, strict standards for waste disposal drive up the cost of the original product; likewise the new requirements for fuller disclosure in food labeling. Strict rules for issuing low-priced "penny stocks" make it harder for small ventures to get started.
A three-month breather, to take stock and revamp, would supposedly foster growth by freeing the private sector from unwanted surveillance. Also, regulatory measures that themselves stimulate economic activity, such as the approval of new drugs, would still be allowed, as would regulations with deadlines set by law.
There's certainly nothing wrong with regularly reviewing regulations to see if they are working as intended or need to be modified or even canceled. But a sudden halt can only confuse regulators and regulated alike, all the more so at a time of public alarm about the safety of personal products like breast implants and sleeping pills.
Mr. Bush is no doubt dismayed by the evidence that, during his three years in office, the volume of new regulation has soared back toward its level in the last year of the Carter Administration. He can blame his own effectiveness.
There has been a necessary growth of regulation to institute two new laws that Mr. Bush championed -- the Clean Air Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Also he picked good people, by and large, to run the regulatory agencies. Rather than undermine laws they are supposed to administer, as some Reagan appointees did, they enforce them.
Is the President now telling them they've done their jobs too well? Or pointing out that this is an election year, and he's feeling the heat from his backers in business?
A moratorium also raises questions about Vice President Quayle's vaunted Council on Competitiveness. It's supposed to keep an eye on overeager regulators. But it has only a small staff, and got bogged down in controversy when it tried to gut some widely supported environmental controls. So, faced with a storm of protest, the man who said he wanted to be the environment President now throws up his hands and says, O.K., we just won't have any regulations for a while.
The range of the moratorium's estimated benefits is a measure of the Administration's wishful thinking. One of those anonymous White House sources says it could save businesses $10 billion to $100 billion a year -- that is, no one really has the slightest idea. What's more, those supposed savings don't count their cost, in terms of diminished protection for public health and safety, as well as for consumers and investors.
After three years of Presidential inattention, three months of review seems an afterthought. Careful regulation is an honorable objective. But a freewheeling shutdown ignores modern reality. Increased regulation reflects the increased complexity of life.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Baker's Big Bash

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
America's $33-billion-a-year intelligence industry doesn't know what to tell President Bush about the central question facing three score foreign affairs bigwigs gathered in our capital this week: whether or not to pump serious money into embryonic Slavic capitalism.
The C.I.A. has just renamed its Soviet division to catch up with the times. (The first name suggested was Commonwealth of Independent States Office, but that led to the acronym "Kissoff," so it is called the Slavic and Eurasian office.) The spooks at Slav-Eu, headed by George Kolt, have long been high on Boris Yeltsin and his free-market reformers, and think that money to bolster the new states would be well invested. 
 However, the rest of the intelligence community, led by the State Department's Douglas Mulholand, is still grumpy about the rise in Moscow of the man it used to dump on as a "buffoon." The Yeltsin-bashers were mainly Gorbaphiles and Shevardnadzniks, enamored of the orderliness of central power, and now support only "humanitarian aid" -- mainly credits to buy Kansas grain -- secretly hoping Gorby's tidiness will make a comeback.
Where's Robert Gates, the new D.C.I., who once defied James Baker and took a hard line against the salvation of Communism?
He's torn. At the moment he is canvassing the entire Federal Government, looking for odd jobs and new bureaucratic missions to occupy his bloated agency, and needs the support of the Supreme Bureaucrat, James Baker, who can deliver O.M.B.'s Richard Darman. Secretary Baker arranged this week's diplomatic extravaganza to dramatize our interest in acting like a superpower -- while, in an election year, passing the tab to Japan and the Saudis.
The C.I.A. Director must rely on his former rival and State's attendant Yeltsin-demeaners to preserve his vast spookery. But at the same time, O. Ye Gates knows the risk to the U.S. of not helping the Yeltsinites in their hour of need: if the reformers fail, back comes sclerotic perestroika with a big army and we face a new time of global troubles.
It's a dilemma. If the C.I.A. advice is to provide only technical and emergency aid, that would suit the Bush-Baker inclination to badmouth foreign aid while piously deploring isolationism; but if the C.I.A. virtuously damns the politics and endorses the pro-Yeltsin opinion of its Slav-Eu experts, there may be no more clandestine cakes and ale.
I can sympathize with Mr. Gates because my own favorite Slav-euologists disagree.
Judy Shelton of the Hoover Institution was right in predicting "The Coming Soviet Crash" when all Western intelligence was wrong. She now holds that the reformers' flotation of the ruble is mistaken, and private investment will come only when spending is curbed, oil and food production are privatized, borders are opened and taxes reduced. With classic logic, this superb economist argues against government aid because only pain triggers basic change.
Anders Aslund accurately estimated the Soviet arms budget at an unsustainable 25 percent of G.N.P. at a time when the C.I.A. was blindly buying K.G.B. disinformation. Like Ms. Shelton, he resisted the siren song of Harvard's "grand bargaineers" to bail out Gorbachev with massive aid before Communism died and the Soviet empire broke up.
This free-market Swedish economist, who has the run of the Kremlin these days, tells me that supply-and-demand is working: fresh fish is on sale on Gorky Street for the first time in memory, at less than sky-high prices. And he says that armaments spending has been cut by 85 percent.
However, the Russian Central Bank is still pumping out inflationary credit to local banks locked into the old nomenklatura; as that is curbed, he thinks the time would be ripe to provide a $6 billion ruble-stabilization fund to spur capital investment.
Who's right, Judy or Anders? I don't know, and nobody can be certain; but the downside risk on helping now is little, and on not helping is great. So the prudent hard line is to help, and the President's $645 million pledge yesterday is not much help.
In making this painful choice, I am sending a message to our econo-spooks at the cookie-pushers' orgy: Make the aid call on its merits and let the pols take care of the politics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
'It Is Our Only Hope'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Dov Frohman is one of Israel's high-technology business stars, a vice president of the California microcomputer company Intel and general manager of Intel Israel. Last year he won the Israel Prize for engineering and technology. A jolly man with a large beard, he has had an international career.
Twenty years ago in California Mr. Frohman invented the Eprom chip, a breakthrough that helped start Intel's phenomenal growth. He took a year off in Africa, teaching in Ghana and going up the Congo River in Zaire. Then he persuaded Intel, with much difficulty, to start operations in Israel. They have been a great success. 
 In a conversation the other day I asked him how Israel could provide employment for the Soviet Jews who want to come here. Some 325,000 have already arrived. Others are holding back because Israel's economy is weak and there are no jobs for them.
His answer was: Attract investment from abroad, especially in high-tech ventures. He said Israel had the asset of "qualified manpower, people of creativity, imagination. With globalization, everything in business is mobile except manpower. So companies are going to look for centers of excellence.
"So why don't we have more high-tech investment? The problem is political and economic stability. Why would a business want to go to an unstable place?"
The current peace negotiations with the Palestinians and neighboring Arab states are a major reason for hope, he said; even the fact that the parties are talking has changed the atmosphere.
"Peace is the great thing," Mr. Frohman said. "I don't think we can get accelerated growth unless we solve the problem."
Mr. Frohman is not alone in his belief that peace is a key to economic growth. Other business leaders have the same view. One is Aharon Dovrat, the founder of Israel's largest private conglomerate, Clal.
"Peace is a precondition to attract investment on any significant scale," Mr. Dovrat said. "It is our only hope.
"Give us peace, and it is a marvelous country -- with many reasons to attract investment. If Israel had had peace for the last 10 years, it would be approaching Switzerland.
"People won't send their money to a country that is full of unrest. The idea of attracting investment and at the same time building settlements on occupied land is completely crazy."
Ephraim Arazi, the founder of Scitex, Israel's biggest high-tech company, made a similar point on Israeli television recently. He said the country needs "a stable political atmosphere" and cannot have that if it goes on "playing a double game" in the West Bank -- not annexing it but not letting it be Palestinian territory.
"Menachem Begin understood that to make peace we had to give up territory," Mr. Arazi said. "He gave us a precedent. So let's do something."
An important American supporter of Israel, Laurence Tisch, the chairman of CBS, was interviewed by the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot. He said his companies would not invest in Israel now. The interviewer asked what would change that position.
"The peace process and privatization in Israel," Mr. Tisch replied. "An end to the Arab boycott and relations between Israel and the Arab states would create incredible investment possibilities in Israel.
"I hope the Israeli Government will understand the opportunity it has and will speed up the peace process."
It hardly needs to be said that the Government of Israel does not accept the industrialists' premise. Its policy is precisely to continue what Mr. Arazi called the "double game," not formally annexing the occupied territories but accelerating settlements in them.
The public is deeply divided. Polls suggest that a narrow majority would freeze the settlement process if that opened the way to agreement with the Palestinians.
But few people have probably framed the issue in the stark economic terms that are in the business people's minds: as a choice between continued occupation of the territories and economic growth. And Prime Minister Shamir, facing an election, is highly skilled at obscuring the choice -- at assuring Israelis that they can have it both ways.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 357 words

HEADLINE: How to Make a Quick Economic Turnaround

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Let there be no mistake as to the causes of the current economic recession; understanding these causes will show us how to bring about a recovery. They are the past and current inappropriate monetary and fiscal policies, in order of importance. 
 From 1987 to 1990, the Federal Reserve had been tightening credit to fight a nonexistent inflation threat. The 1987 stock market crash and the mini-crash of 1989 were not enough to convince the Fed that its policy was wrong. It took the resulting recession and the dramatic fall of President Bush in the opinion polls to get it to lower interest rates.
In 1986 the discount and prime rates were 5.5 and 7.5 percent, respectively. Today they are 3.5 percent and 6.5 percent. The Fed has probably overreacted on the discount rate in this regard.
It is strange that during the Fed's tightening period, the voices of criticism were practically nonexistent; today many are calling for a further lowering of the discount rate. The Federal Reserve is now on the right track and should leave well enough alone.
As for fiscal policy, Congress and the Administration can correct the mistakes of the 1986 tax reform law by reinstating the tax deductibility of interest paid by consumers. The double taxation of interest income, as well as dividends, should be eliminated once and for all.
Congress and the Administration should follow this basic principle of taxing income only once and removing the tax on capital gains entirely. Dividends paid to stockholders should be a tax-deductible expense for corporations just as interest payments to bondholders are. Both interest and dividends are legitimate payments to long-term capital and should be treated the same.
By doing this immediately, Congress can help bring about a quick and dramatic turnaround in our economy. Bickering about taxing the rich and tax breaks for the middle class may score some political points, but they will delay needed policy changes and do very little for economic recovery and growth.
 
LOUIS MANZELL
Adjunct Professor of Economics
Monmouth College
West Long Branch, N.J., Jan. 10, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 165 words

HEADLINE: How to Make a Quick Economic Turnaround;
Tax-Cut Illusions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Don't Look for Jobs in Japan" (editorial, Jan. 6), you advocate stimulating the economy through further cuts in the interest rate and/or tax cuts and increases in government spending. Such policies have traditionally been used to pull the economy out of recession by stimulating demand. 
 But at a time when, as you say, Americans are already overconsuming, and when a disproportionate share of that consumption is of products made by other countries, such demand-based policies may do more to stimulate further the economies of those other countries than our own.
How many Americans, if they have extra cash in their pockets or can get a lower-rate loan, will use it to buy an American car? And of course at the same time lower interest rates make it even less attractive to put any of that extra cash into savings, which, as you rightly point out, is the real key to reinvigorating the American economy.
 
PAUL JELLINEK
Mercerville, N.J., Jan. 10, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 196 words

HEADLINE: How to Make a Quick Economic Turnaround;
Reform Tax Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is a solution to correcting our depressed economy, but first we must identify its primary cause. It is the tax reform act of 1986, which put the crimp in the consumer real estate and automobile markets by the following changes:
(1) Raising rental residential real estate depreciation from 19 years to 29 1/2 years. 
 (2) Limiting investors in rental real estate to $25,000 of operating rental losses a year from unlimited losses prior to Jan. 1, 1987.
(3) Establishing limits on the deduction of consumer interest on loans on home real estate.
(4) Phasing out the deduction for consumer interest for loans on personal purchases such as automobiles.
These items were made too liberal in the early 1980's and needed to be corrected, but the adjustment was far too radical and had the effect of pulling the rug out from under the economy. We need to give relief by partially restoring these deductions on a temporary basis, if not permanently, to enable us to help pull the economy out of recession.
 
GERARD L. CARON
Lynn, Mass., Jan. 13, 1992
 
The writer is a certified public accountant.
